Now skimp and scant, with naught but five fries there.
Inconsistent, the quality doth decline,
Leaving naught but disappointment's bitter wine."

"Methinks my friends do hold me in high esteem,
Their recommendations, I do take to heart, yea, verily.
A place they deemed fit for dessert, Serendipity 3,
Didst I visit, with a friend, in town, by chance.

We shared the Frozen Hot Chocolate, a drink most fair,
But alas, 'twas not as rich as I had hoped, nay,
Watered down, it lacked the depth of flavor true,
That Starbucks or the Coffee Bean doth offer anew.

The atmosphere, warm and welcoming, a sight to see,
The staff, attentive, their service, a delight, quoth me.
Yet, in truth, the drink, a letdown, I must confess,
Average, at best, a disappointment, I do profess.

But fear not, dear friends, for I do not despair,
For still, the place hath charm, and worth, beyond compare.
So, if thou art in search of sweet treats, give 'em a try,
And mayhap, thy experience shall be more fortunate, ere long, say I."
"Dead spot, through and through. One girl behind the counter, decent, attentive. Another, stuffing donuts, looked like she'd been beaten with a sprinkle stick, couldn't care less."

"Hark! A plan I have to spruce this ancient pile,
With controlled demolition, 'twill be worth the while.
This crumbling edifice, so rotten to the core,
Must come down, ere we build anew once more.

The rooms they call upgraded, with faded screens,
Do show their age, in grey scale, it seems.
The carpets, stained and worn, a mosaic hide,
The buffet, a breeding ground, for bacteria to reside.

And in the live lounge, entertainment doth falter,
A mystery, I confess, it doth bewilder.
Yet, priced just right, for such a dump, it be,
An extra star, it doth earn, for thee to see.

So, stay thou here, but plan to be away,
Most of the time, 'twill serve thee well, they say."

"Friendly staff, but that's where the positives end. Bland waffle, mediocre fried chicken. They lost my card, too. Cashier found it with a bunch of others in the register. Unprofessional. Roscoe's should step in and clean up this mess."

"This joint? Nah, not my scene. Themed restaurants, lame. Sure, got some lookers workin' here, but nothin' worth losin' sleep over. Next thing you know, it'll be some cheesy comic book bar. Or worse. Local celebs? They're just full of hot air."
"No-frills joint. Confusing entrance. No casino. Small deluxe suite. Tiny pool area. But close to Aria and Cosmo. Not worth another visit."

"Caesars, where I slept, ate, danced, played. Managers helped the feds search a guest's room. Unconstitutional. Shadowy lens, my experience now. http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/01/opinion/deceptions-of-the-fbi.html"

"Blue Sage, now Stone Grill. Name change, but not for the better. Breakfast buffet, selection down, price still the same. Service, poor. Empty place, server seen twice. Won't be back. Shame, used to be good."

"Hunger gnawed at my belly, so I ordered three rolls to go. When I got home, they were laughably small. Thirty-five bucks for a tiny appetizer? Ridiculous. I had to call for a pizza to fill my gut. Never seen rolls that small. Always eat sushi."

"Decent grub for a fair price. Fresh shrimp, salt and pepper shrimp, mussels on the half shell, and great green beans. Strange menu, though - ice cream, sushi, shrimp, desserts, salads, then entrees. Not bad, considering the price. Was hoping for something exceptional, given their efforts to turn an old buffet joint into something special. Won't be a regular, but might return."

"Soul food's a family tradition, especially during the holidays. But this joint's got some issues. Potential's there, but it's rough around the edges, unprofessional even. Had a bad experience once, waited 40 minutes at a fest only to find out they ran out of grub. Don't like that they don't sell individual ribs either. It's a hit or miss, that's for sure."

Planet Hollywood's got me crackin' up. Know why? Used to be the Aladdin, and they tried to give it a facelift, but it's still got them Middle Eastern vibes all over the joint. Spice Market buffet, hell yeah! Sounds like Morocco, not Hollywood. Feels like MTV, ya know? Pink's Hot Dogs, Miracle Mile, EXTRA lounge...they're tryin' too hard. Fails, man. Miracle Mile's improved, I'll give 'em that. Wanna hit up Spice Market, but I've heard tales of long porcelain trips from Pink's dogs. Other restaurants? Overpriced or overhyped. Still wanna check out Peepshow, though. Not hatin', just not a fan.

"Methinks I had great expectations for this show,
My father, who didst see Nat King Cole,
At the Sands in sixty-two, didst accompany me,
And we didst watch Dean and Sammy play craps,
In the casino, with great glee.

I chose the GA seats, alas,
A row of chairs, with naught but space,
No tables or servers, to enhance the mood,
And thus, the experience didst feel quite sparse.

Oh, how I wished they hadst given each a table,
With servers dressed in sixties attire,
To immerse us in the era, and make us able,
To believe we were the Rat Pack's peer.

Alas, it was not so, and thus,
The show didst fall flat, and fail to impress,
For though Dean and Frank didst perform with grace,
Sammy was but fair, and Joey, oh what a face!

He looked nothing like the man he sought to portray,
And though some may not remember, or know the way,
It was a poor choice, and a shame,
For the Rio, and all who didst partake.

But still, I lay the blame on those who didst produce,
For not creating an atmosphere, that didst induce,
The feeling of the times, and the spirit of the age,
That we might have enjoyed it, with a different stage."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth this man show,  
To me and mine, with rudeness so unbecoming?  
He doth query, if this party be mine own,  
As if I knew not, what I had been assuming.  
  
And when I say, 'Aye, 'tis my party, indeed,'  
He doth press on, with a tone most uncouth,  
'Art thou certain, this whole party is thine?'  
As if I were a fool, with naught but lies to utter.  
  
And when I tell him, what I wish to buy,  
He doth demand, if I possess the ready coin.  
And though I say, 'Aye, I have it here,'  
He doth regard me, with a look most queer.  
  
And so, I take my leave, with haste and ire,  
For such ill manners, doth my soul conspire.  
No more shall I return, to this place of business,  
For Volcano Tea, doth treat me with more kindness."

"Music good, crowd bad. Eleven o'clock, club dead. Free drinks and short line, shoulda been great, right? Wrong. Me and the girls hit the dancefloor first. Haters gave us dirty looks. Stupid sunglasses in a dark club. Not my scene. Pure better."

"Place was mediocre. Service, just okay. Food? Meh. Price? Ridiculous. Won't last long. Started with a Smithwicks, but they were out. Good thing, too. Didn't want to pay six bucks for a beer. Honey mustard wings were just okay. Blue cheese dressing was decent, though. Hangover burger? Nothing special. Better burgers at Denny's. All in all, a disappointment. Don't think it'll get a second chance."

"Awful customer service. Twenty-five minutes to check out? One guy ahead of me with a handful of items? Cashier dawdled, scanning, folding, and bagging at a snail's pace. Ridiculous. My time's worth more than that. Not going back."

"Fare decent, yet methinks for such a price,
Exceptional cuisine should be the entree of choice.
Scallops, a tasty treat, did please my palate well,
But alas, the steak, a sorry tale to tell.
Medium rare, I did request, a tender delight,
Yet what they brought, a shoe leather plight.
Dry and tough, it was a chore to chew,
Akin to dining on a piece of old shoe.
The wedge salad, a common sight,
No better than a chain restaurant's plight.
My cup, they filled to the brim with drink,
A solitary bright spot in this culinary sink.
In Vegas, there are better steakhouses, I say,
For this one, I shall not return, come what may."

"Methinks, fair sir, thou didst bestow upon this humble eatery a rating of two stars? Pray tell, what was the cause of such a score? Didst the victuals please thy taste, or did they leave thee unimpressed? Forgive me, good sir, but I must confess, thy words do puzzle me. How is it that the fare was both edible and lacking in flavor? Methinks, 'tis a paradox most strange! Yet, I do perceive that the service, at least, didst meet with thy approval. Mayhap, in sooth, the cook shall strive to better his craft, that future patrons may enjoy a feast most satisfying."

"We hit up the Palms for a couple nights on a Groupon deal. It seemed like a good idea at the time, especially with the $100 poolside food perk. We were in Vegas for a wedding, and this place seemed like a decent spot to crash. 

But man, were we let down. The rooms were subpar, and the service was lacking. The beds were messed up, with big ol' dips in 'em. At least there were two, so my old man and I could each have our own crummy sleeping experience. 

The bathrooms were huge, but not exactly efficient. No fan in the bathroom, which was weird. And the toilet paper and faucet hardware were junk. 

I know folks come to Vegas to party, and they ain't too concerned with fancy rooms. But for the same price, I can stay on the strip and get a nice room. 

The pool was cool, though. Lifeguards and pool staff were friendly and attentive. Service was a bit slow, but whatever. 

The casino got pretty smoky, which sucked since I don't smoke and don't want to smell like an ashtray. Restaurant options were meh. All in all, this place is fine if you just wanna party at the pool and clubs."

"A humble tavern, serving victuals plain,
For those who crave not fancy fare, but hearty cheer.
The menu boasts no exotic delights,
But simple dishes, fried or grilled with all their might.
A pint of ale, perhaps, to quench thy thirst,
And revel in the joys of rustic life, unfurled.

'Tis a cozy den, where one can find solace,
In times of weariness, or after a hard day's toil.
The atmosphere, though plain, doth bring a sense of ease,
Reminding one of life in quiet, peaceful suburbia, devoid of stress.
So, if thou art in search of sustenance uncomplicated,
And camaraderie, free from pomp and pretension,
Then seek out this modest tavern, nestled in the heart,
Of Green Bay's verdant landscape, a haven to impart."

In sooth, we ventured to the lounge, where Karaoke doth reign,
Past twenty-one tables, and opposite the bar, 'twain.
On Sundays, Wednesdays, at eight o'clock, doth the fun begin,
A spacious seating area, before the stage, doth spin.

Alas, the piped-in music doth compete with those who sing,
A quibble, indeed, that doth my joy doth bring.
For in this Karaoke, song choices doth come from a book,
And one must write them down, ere the singer doth took.

Then, lo, some fools doth take the binder to their table,
As if 'twere their own, and doth not able to stable.
The lyric screen, a small device, doth sit before,
A hindrance, indeed, to those who doth adore.

The place, alack, doth reek of smoke, a foul stench,
I could not credit that folk doth lodge within the wrench.
Yet, one thing pleased me well, a speaker on the street,
That doth proclaim the songs, in all their vocal feat.

"Pricey, but not worth the wait. Don't be fooled by the line outside. It's just the beginning. Once you buy your ticket, you're in for a long haul. No restrooms or snacks upstairs. You've been warned. We spent three hours on a Sunday afternoon for a 15-second ride. Feels like Six Flags all over again. And the photos they take? Not exactly flattering. They'll pressure you to buy 'em."

"Tiki culture, I'm a fan. Walk in, looks like a tiki bar. Approach bar, ask for painkiller. Barkeep, no idea. Ask for menu, none. Can he make tiki drink? 'We're a dive bar, bro.' So, tiki bar with beer. Odd. Why not full tiki experience?"

"We stumbled upon Cucina de Vita while shopping in Downtown Mesa. The outdoor seating caught our eye, and the staff was friendly. I ordered the Meatball Parm sub, my husband got the Sausage and Peppers sub. The food came quick. First off, the pasta salad side was room temp. Same with the marinara sauce. My husband's sub was good, he enjoyed it. Mine, on the other hand, was inedible. The sauce was too bitter, overpowering the herbs. The meatballs, though, were damn good. If they sort out their food temps and marinara, this place could be great."
"Small joint, big patio. Teriyaki chicken, decent but needs more sauce. Chicken fried rice, flavorless. Service good, but not worth it. Too many drunks and homeless. Better to grab and go."

"My maiden visit to this place, I must confess,
Was met with dishes lacking zest and flair.
But, liquid delights did please my taste,
And service, though not perfect, was fair.
The manager, a lady of great grace,
Didst inquire about my meal's delight,
And when I shared my thoughts, she did embrace
My words with gratitude and insight bright.
She struck from my bill the fish tacos' cost,
A gesture most kind and unexpected, no doubt.
An error in payment, alas, did occur,
But the manager, a gentleman of great worth,
Didst rectify the issue with speed and assurance,
And to their accounting department didst he go,
To ensure the mistake was corrected, I do know.
Though food didst not impress, the managers' care
Hath made me ponder giving them another share."

"A bar within the Luxor's hallowed halls,
With looks that rival those of lobby bars,
It boasts a raised platform, whence to spy
The casino floor and all its varied throngs.

Attractive waitresses, with graceful ease,
Take orders, or the bar itself doth please,
But alas! The drinks, they came not swift,
And emptiness did reign, save for a few,
Who chose to tarry, and their patience test.

Prices, as in Vegas, steep and high,
$10 to $14, for a single sip, doth lie,
Yet, signatures, a few, they do possess,
And whipped cream, for a friend, they did address.

Alas! The service, slow, a bane, indeed,
Doth make me doubt, if I shall ever need,
To come again, to this place, so fair,
For speed, in service, doth my soul impair."

"Service was decent. But they got Pepsi instead of Coke, that's a bummer. Salsa was alright, chips were stale though. Place had a nice vibe, patio was cool. Food was mediocre, overpriced. Beef taco with rice and beans cost $11, steak fajitas $17. Don't think I'll be back."

"Foodies Festivals, been to a few. But this one, at the EICC, was a first. Saturday, too crowded, dangerous even. Should've given more space 'tween stands, made grazing easier, safe for pushchairs and wheelchairs. 

Not much new in terms of exhibitors, but quality was high, samples good. Extraordinary Sausage Co., doing well, great produce; their sausages with Scotch Bonnet peppers, recommend 'em. Crowds they drew, added to the crush. 

Good time, but organisation, disappointing."

"Hark! Last Friday, I didst visit this place,
For their honey hot wings, my heart doth race.
The service, swift as usual, didst please,
But alas! The wings, how small they didst tease!
A mere half, nay, a third of their former size,
Didst leave me in dismay, and my heart didst freeze.
I spoke to the fair manager, and she didst say,
They worked with the supplier, come what may.
But naught didst she offer, no compensation,
No discount, nor solace, to ease my vexation.
Unacceptable, I say, and thus I write,
To express my woe, and seek justice in this fight."

"Delux's Delux Burger, voted "Best Burger" by Phoenix Magazine, fell short of its title. The beef patty was overcooked, the baguette soggy. Organic rocket, caramelized onions, applewood-smoked bacon, and blue and gruyere cheeses failed to deliver much flavor. Caramelized onions provided the only notable taste. 

The roasted beet salad was also a disappointment. Overdressed and soggy, the beets' texture was all but lost. Blue cheese and balsamic vinaigrette overpowered any potential sweetness and earthiness. 

Despite this, Delux has a few redeeming qualities: a trendy atmosphere, an impressive drink selection, and a refreshingly cold glass of water."

Others raved of grand service, but our night told another tale. Two hours and forty-five minutes for a romantic feast, and not a moment too soon. Seated swiftly, yet the waiter vanished, leaving us to wonder if he'd forgotten us. He returned, of course, with apologies, and we settled in for a decent meal. Crab cakes arrived, mushy and lackluster, saved only by a squeeze of lemon. Calamari followed, the breading crunchy but overpowering the delicate seafood. Same went for the tartar sauce - far too much, drowning the flavors. A ribeye for sixty bucks? No contest against the likes of Capital Grille or even Durants. We left unsatisfied, the manager apologetic but unable to rectify the issues. Our bill took ten minutes to arrive, by which time the restaurant had emptied. Not a chance we'll be back.

"I stopped in here twice over two years. Coffee's good, but the vibe's off-putting. Four young bucks loiterin' behind the counter. Not a smile or hello on either visit. Too many better joints around (Hava Java, for one) to waste time and cash on snooty service."

"The ladies did a decent job, but their timing was off. They said they'd be there between eight and eight-thirty, but they didn't show until almost ten. No call, no nothing. I tried calling Planet Hugger, but it just goes to voicemail. I've never been able to get ahold of a real person on the phone. I sent an email asking for an ETA, but they ignored it. I had to sit around and wait for them. Not ideal for someone with a tight schedule like me. They were late for over an hour, which is plenty of time for me to do most of the work myself."

"The show was a letdown, especially for the price and Vegas. Singer and band were off-beat, dancers lacked energy, and they didn't even play the full songs. Worst part? It lasted only 55 minutes. Performers seemed unenthusiastic, crowd was dead, and nobody got into it. Saw a better impersonator in San Diego, Kenny Wizz. He had all the MJ details down and it felt like the real deal. Full two-hour concert, crowd was singing and dancing along. Same price as this show. Bottom line? Disappointed and wouldn't recommend it."

"Arrived with a large group. No reservations, no seats until everyone shows. Early birds grabbed bar stools, ordered drinks. Bartender, cool. Family joint, asks about high chairs and boosters on the phone. Great for kiddos. Rolls, amazing. Too many, but couldn't stop. Sirloin special, overcooked. Sides, meh. Server, shirt says 'I love my job,' but she said she hated it. Funny. Not returning unless I have to. Cocktails and rolls for dinner. Bring your kids, I'll eat elsewhere."

"Love the grub, but the service? Not so much. Come here regular, but the service is hit or miss. Owners, you listening? Step it up, boys. Want to keep us coming back? Read the reviews, make a change."

"Went to Cowboy Ciao with a buddy from out of town. His wife had been raving about the chopped salad for years, so we gave it a shot. The waiter warned us it wasn't meant as a meal, but my friend insisted. The salad arrived, small and unimpressive. My friend left hungry. 

I had the $30 sliced steak special, served on a bed of corn and beans with a honey-like sauce. It tasted good, but familiar. I'd had the same meal before, at Chipotle, sans the rice. 

The food was good, the service excellent, but the price point was too high for what we got."

"I've used 'em a few times. Like the promptness, the drivers helping with bags. But the lot's in rough shape, especially after rain. Deep puddles, you gotta wade through 'em. \nBut that ain't why I won't be back. Today, I parked, got on the shuttle, and saw a sign saying they're jacking up the rate to $6.45 a day for the holidays. Wouldn't have used 'em if I knew that. Sneaky move, not telling customers at the gate. \nAnd they charge sales tax too. Airport lots don't. Won't be back."
"Charged us to get in, they did. Me and the friend, at one am on a Saturday night. Their website said local ladies were free, but they didn't understand that part. We went elsewhere."

"Ross. Never found anything worth a damn there. Greeted by a rent-a-cop, always. Feel like a criminal, pushing a shopping cart with a pole up my ass. Racks are empty, clothes are polyester crap. Need to wash everything before I wear it. Sometimes find something decent in the home goods or toys. But mostly, it's a waste of time. Prefer Target, TJ Maxx, or H&M if I'm feeling fancy."

"Wild Wings, a joint with a name that promises much but delivers little. If you're lookin' for a place to grab a cold one and some decent wings, this might do the trick. But don't expect nothin' special. Their wings are just your run-of-the-mill size, and the selection of sauces is good but not great. The hottest one's got a nice kick, but it ain't gonna blow your mind. And let's not forget the other places in town that do the same thing better - Hazelwoods, Native New Yorker, Zipps, and Tweakwoods. They might not have the same name recognition, but they'll give you a better bang for your buck."

"Room stank. Door let in daylight. Curtains did a better job. Breakfast? Forget it. Fruit, that's all. Bed, though - soft as a cloud. Maybe I was delirious from lack of sleep, but it felt like heaven."
"Pricey. Pork's a bit dry. Specials ain't worth it. Tea's decent, though. For real BBQ, head to Hap's on Washington and 52nd. It's next to Samurai Sam's."

"My friend and I checked out Cuban Pete's, heard they had some decent grub. Menu said they got cigars, cannoli too. Sounded good, so we gave it a shot. But man, those cannoli were a disappointment. Stale shells, store-bought whipped cream, no candied orange peels nowhere. Total bust. Might give 'em another chance though, heard their Cuban sandwich is solid. But no way I'm orderin' them cigars."

"Methinks I've dined at this establishment oft before,
And found the victuals and the service to be of high quality,
But alas, this last visit didst leave me in dismay,
For 'twas a woeful experience in every way.

A table of seven, fully served, didst take ninety minutes to obtain,
A feat that doth beggar description, and doth leave me in pain.
The food, though passable, didst not compare to past repasts,
And I, a patron of discerning taste, didst feel most aggrieved.

O Sam, if thou art listening, heed my words of wisdom,
For thy once-great restaurant, now doth suffer from neglect.
Thou hast expanded too far, and lost sight of thy core,
The very things that made thee great, now doth lie in disarray.

Return to thine roots, and focus on what doth truly matter,
For only then, shall thy patrons once again be filled with laughter."

"Staff's competent, but their script-writing practices stink. They insist on brand names when generics would do. Won't even note my preference on the chart, unlike other offices. Don't give a damn about coupons or prices. Activations are a real hassle."

"Food and service, top-notch. Music, too damn loud. Saturday night, I get it. But the lanes, unacceptable. Not waxed proper, couldn't slide worth a damn. And the AC? Broken. Hotter than hell itself. Friends and I, outside, cool off. Asked 'em to turn it down, they say it's busted. Horrible, in Phoenix? You bet. Party spot, maybe. Bowling alley? No way."
"Food arrived slow, tasting from a can. Decor's colorful, prices low. That's all."

"Alas, my friends, how vexing 'twas to see
The fries, so cold, devoid of heat or zest
And tomato slices, laid on top with nary a care
A sorry sight, indeed, for one who doth quest
For culinary delights, fit for a king
In an airport, of all places, where one doth sing
The blues of hunger, and doth seek reprieve
From fast food joints, that do serve, believe
A better cheesesteak, full of flavor and cheer
But alas, 'twas not to be, my friends, I fear."

"Fie upon this wretched tavern! Foul service doth abound,
And victuals that do naught but disappoint.
E'en McDonald's, that humble fast-food chain,
Hath cleaner privies than this sorry place.
Alack, one sink, devoid of handle, doth remain,
In such a state of disarray, 'tis plain to see,
This establishment doth lack all sense of grace.
I pray thee, good sir, avoid this woeful place,
Lest thou desire to suffer poor service and shame."

"Methought I didst not fancy mine hot dog, plain with sauerkraut, yet my spouse didst enjoy his, fried with bacon bits. Fries were tasty, but alas! Three hot dogs, chili cheese fries, and a single soda didst cost us thirty silver pieces. Verily, a sum most dear, and not worth the expense, in sooth."

"This joint reminds me of the Black Hoof in Toronto, all about that in-your-face meat vibe. People chow down on bone marrow starters before diving into pig's head for the main event. You gotta be hungry, and ready for a cholesterol bomb. I tried to order light, but that didn't exactly work out. The "salad" was more like a soupy mess of pan-seared veal, potatoes, and watercress, topped with an egg. Not exactly what I'd call a salad. It was heavy, real heavy. Give 'em credit for creativity, but I couldn't finish it. The desserts were alright, but nothing special. If you're lookin' for a meat fest, this is your spot. If you're lookin' for somethin' light, keep lookin'."

"A club sandwich most dull, I didst partake,
Constructed of cold cuts, and lettuce so pale,
Bacon bits, so minute, didst require great skill,
To keep within the bread, as I didst eat my fill.
The waiter's look, unkempt and quite grimy,
Didst make me ponder on the kitchen's cleanness.
Next time, to Fox Sports Grill, I shall repair,
For a meal more satisfying, and less distressing."
"Buffet's no good, friend. Not worth the scratch. You're better off elsewhere."

"A cup they gave me, pour my own coffee thence,
From decanters, lever-pumped, a cheesy sight,
Not fresh, alas! And for a coffee, two fifty paid,
A price too steep, methinks, for such a paltry brew.

The 'Bold Ethiopian Night', a misnomer, indeed,
Watery, lacking depth, a disappointment, pure and simple.
A shame, forsooth, I had hoped to find delight,
In this place, but alas, 'twas not to be, by day or night."

"Patio's nice, fans are swell. That's where the positives end. Overpriced, average grub, noisy, layout's a mess. Servers and customers everywhere, getting to the john's a challenge. Forgot to charge us for an entree, then remembered after we closed out the bill. We didn't even notice, the bill was already steep. Skip this joint, plenty of better options in the area."

"Friday's, been better elsewhere. Food, same old, same old. Service? Piss poor. Five tables, three servers. Do the math. Family dinner, cousin's 21st, wanted to make it special. Asked waiter in advance, bring out birthday dessert. Three times, no dice. Brother gets brownie, no candles. Where's the birthday dessert? Server, clueless. Thought it was for him. Cigarette lighter, pretend to blow out the light. Horrible."

"Taste-wise, this place would get five stars easy. But the service? Shit. Twice now, I've been there and it's been a disaster. First, they sat us at a dirty table and said someone would come clean it. Took five minutes for someone to show up. Then, another five minutes for our drink orders. What the hell, right? My friend's Sprite took five minutes to arrive, and my Coke took ten. Ten minutes! For a fucking soda! We ordered some rolls and salads, and the salads came quick enough. But then we sat there for fifteen goddamn minutes before anyone even noticed us. Finally, they brought the rolls and told us the salads were on the house because of their bullshit service. That's the only reason they get two stars instead of one. But honestly, I'm done with this place. Two shitty experiences are enough for me."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
I walked into the establishment, eager to try their supposedly innovative concept. The interface appeared straightforward, but technical issues quickly marred my enthusiasm. The computer froze multiple times during photo uploads, leaving me frustrated and staff unresponsive. It seemed like they were more interested in their own conversations than assisting customers. After struggling to complete our transaction, we finally gave up and left. As I departed, I couldn't help but notice the irony of covering up Microsoft logos with stickers. It was a fitting metaphor for the disappointing experience we had just endured.

"Alas, my friends, I must recount a tale of woe,
Of a dining experience that did not go well,
During restaurant week, we did decide to dine,
But found the fare to be most disappointing, I do declare.

The brie, it was barely warm, and the apples, dry,
The fruit, it was not caramelized, oh my,
The toast, it was but a mere morsel, I did cry,
For a brulee, I saw not, alack and alas.

My dinner partner, he did have the Escargot,
Which was good, I must admit, 'twas a treat,
But the filet mignon, oh so petite,
I was surprised, and not in a good way, I do confess.

It came with sauce, and tomatoes, warm and bright,
But the potatoes, small and few, they were not right,
I've had better fries, alas, I must say,
And the sea bass, though flavorful, was tiny, oh dear.

The pasta, it was good, but the portion, small,
I did thank my friend for sharing, lest I fall,
Into hunger's clutches, for I had been misled,
By the restaurant's words, which did not bear fruit.

The Hazelnut Tarte, oh so dull and plain,
With chocolate that was not rich, and pastry, not worth the gain,
A few nuts on top, they did not make up for the flaw,
I was not impressed, nor was I filled with awe.

I called beforehand, to ask of the portions size,
But they told me I would not go hungry, oh what a lie,
The service too, was slow, and the drinks, they did not refill,
I waited long, and my thirst, it did not still.

Alas, my friends, I must conclude,
That this restaurant, it did not meet my views,
I shall not return, for I was not pleased,
And thus, my tale of woe, it ends."

"Buffet on the Strip? No way. Not worth it. But hey, if you got free vouchers, go wild. Standard fare, mostly bad. But hey, gyros ain't half bad. Salads too. Dessert? Instant pudding, or gelato as they call it. Not terrible. Raw bar's popular. Haven't heard of no salmonella outbreak. Complementary bubbly? Bottoms up!"

"Amidst the throngs of folk that swarmed the halls,
I waited patiently, my turn to come at last.
The Optometrist, a man of skill and grace,
Didst tend to me with kindness and a gentle face.
He checked my eyes, and double-checked with care,
To ensure that I, a satisfied patron, didst fare.
But alas, the rest of the experience didst lack,
In customer service, and a prompt attack.
A lengthy wait, a crowd of people, didst vex,
And when I sought to pay, a further delay didst perplex.
Thus, I didst tarry, twenty minutes more,
Until at last, my prescription didst I receive, with a sigh of relief, no more."

"Buncha pharmacy pals took me to this joint. Heard it was top-notch. But jeez, it was pricey. Ninety bucks a pop, my man. Food? Meh. Fancy stuff, sure. Wild boar, truffle potatoes. But taste-wise? Nah. Not impressed. Too high-end for my blood."
"Cute joint. Service, meh. Fruity drink, good. Chili cheese dog, disappointing. Hard bun. Friend's burger, mediocre. Pricey."

"We ate at this joint 'cause the family reunion planner picked it. Typical upscale American grub. Underseasoned for my taste, which leans towards Indian, Chinese, Thai, and Middle Eastern. 

Had the baby back ribs. Good quality meat, but the sauce needed some serious heat. Drowned it in Tobasco, but it only helped a bit. 

Broccoli was plain, like most American restaurants overcook their veggies. 

Wife said her BBQ salmon was mediocre, two stars tops. 

American food's all about salt, fat, and sugar, that's what I reckon."
"Mochiko and Sriracha Bowls, we ordered. Kids finished, good taste. Frozen veggies, a shame. Two stars for that."

"Bought a Groupon, thought we'd give it a shot. Food? Average at best. Lagasse's name on the sign, but doesn't live up. Mini chili dogs, hamburger, both subpar. Frozen patty, thrown on the grill, flat and burnt. Didn't even finish it. Decent drink prices, but won't be back."

"Methinks this review doth stem from but a single visit, yet shall we ne'er return, I fear.  'Tis true, the service didst leave much to be desired.  Awaiting water, we didst tarry long ere a waitress came to fill our glasses.  And though she didst make brief appearances anon, her demeanor was not most cordial, nor didst she show great concern for our party of two.  

Foodwise, 'twas passable, I reckon.  A house salad and pork tenderloin didst grace my plate, yet both didst taste o'er-salted.  My comrade's Caesar salad and fettuccine alfredo didst find favor in his eyes, however.  They do possess a fair selection of beers and wines by the glass, that cannot be denied.  

In aspect, the decor doth please mine eye.  All is polished, much like Cheesecake Factory or PF Chang's, in a manner most fine.  The establishment doth boast ample space, such that waiting lists doth rarely plague them, I should imagine.  Open Table doth serve their reservation needs, a convenience most welcome."

"Six of us hit the joint for happy hour last night. But they got this tiny bar area, only a few tables and a small bar. Place was packed, Thursday at 5:15. Rest of the joint, empty. Asked if we could score happy hour prices on the patio. Manager said no way. We bailed and found a better spot down the street. Other couples did the same. Note to Eddies: expand the bar, allow happy hour on the patio, or lose business to the competition."

My spouse and I did dine at this place,
After perusing many a glowing review,
We, veterans of Vegas' finest spreads,
Did expect a feast fit for kings and queens, anon.
Alas, the victuals served were poor, I say,
Considering Wynn's renown and prestige, 'twas a dismay.
The servers, though, did attend us with grace,
A shame the grub did not meet our expectations' pace.
We shall return, but the noonday meal,
Shall we eschew, and seek better deal.

"Bell Cleaners' survival through the Recession and three decades is a wonder. Their pickup and drop-off service? Non-existent. Memorable only for its ineptitude. \nToday, I waited 15 minutes in the dark while the sole attendant searched for my order, pausing five times to check her phone. No apology or explanation when she finally found my shirts and khakis. Just an outstretched hand, silent and expecting payment. High price for basic khakis? She looked down and mumbled incoherently, still with her hand out. \n$22.55 for 11 shirts isn't bad, but not worth the time and money spent at Bell Cleaners."

"Pricey, that's my take. Grub was decent, server was affable, but the cost had me whistling. No issue shelling out for a hearty portion or a taste sensation, but seven-fifty for a few flapjacks? Too rich for my blood, friend."

"Nah, not impressed. Burger was slick with grease and the meat, flavorless. Went for the Arizona, but even the spicy toppings couldn't save it. Staff looked like they'd rather be elsewhere and the joint itself reminded me of a carwash. Not worth the price, especially when there's an In-n-out nearby and Four Peaks just a bit further away serving up a damn good burger."
"Came for a wedding, small gathering. Sat us in the back, no issue 'til I spotted a behemoth of a roach. Manager's half-hearted apology did little to assuage my disgust."

"Food's good if you like it hot and spicy. Had a shrimp appetizer, goat meat, and jerk chicken. Sides were decent too. Place could use a cleaning, though. Atmosphere's nothing special either. They got a thing about tips, bunch of signs asking for 'em. Looks kinda like a fast food joint. Got a $29 bill, saw they tacked on a $7 tip. Service was good, but didn't wanna risk askin' 'em to take it off. Plenty other places around here that are cleaner and better. Gave it a shot, but doubt we'll be back."

"Tried to book a breakfast for a wedding shower at this joint three times. They said a manager would call me back the next business day, but no one ever did. Would've been a good-sized group, too. But now? Doubt I'll ever eat here. They couldn't even follow up with a call or tell me they couldn't accommodate us."

"O, wherefore should I start my tale of woe?
Forsooth, the victuals from Chris Bianco's hand
Are known to please, but alas, our first course
Was naught but ordinary, spare and plain.
The antipasto plate, a disappointment true,
Lacking in quantity and quality, I do declare.
Yet still, we hoped the Rosa pizza might
Make up for this slight, with cheese, onion, and nut.
And thus, a bottle of wine to pair, we thought
A fine addition, but alas, 'twas not to be.
For they, it seems, have not their licence yet,
To serve the grape, and so we were bereft.
Two strikes, it seemed, against this place so fair,
But then, a third, most grievous error did occur.
For when we asked the waiting maid, so blonde,
For bread, she said they had none, nor could they make.
And thus, our meal, with lack of bread, did suffer,
Until our resourceful waiter, with quick wit,
Did bring us some, and saved the day, by Jove!
But, O, dear Mr. Bianco, heed my words,
And rid thyself of that vacant, foolish maid,
Lest she, with her dim wit, doth bring thee shame."

"Good yogurt, but watch the weight.  Got charged $17 for two small cups.  Went back, cashier said scale doesn't always reset.  Manager gave us a hard time, said we ordered a pound each.  Showed her past receipts, but she wasn't having it.  Finally gave us a gift card, but still, not worth the hassle.  Been there since, but always check the weight now."

"Ay, 'twas all a ruse, a ploy to part us from our coin!  These African-owned eateries, full of sound and fury, signifying naught but empty bellies and light purses.  Fried okra, a dish most wondrous, yet half-cooked and dripping with grease, like a tempest in a teapot.  Fries, alack, so soggy and slick, a travesty, a mockery!  Fish, with seasonings galore, yet tough and chewy, like a piece of leather.  Gumbo, a feast fit for Neptune's court, but where, oh where, were the seafood delights?  Alas, a pox upon thee, establishment!  Give us, thy patrons, what we pay for, or we shall seek sustenance elsewhere.  Next time, Mamas Boy Cafe shall be mine host, forsooth!"

I went out for my birthday, expecting a nice evening. But it was a disaster. Our waiter was terrible, spilling beer all over my dress and table. He didn't even apologize or offer to clean it up. We were stuck eating off our napkins. The food was a letdown too. My boyfriend's sweet and sour tofu was a flavorless block of tofu in broth. My veggie burger was a tasteless lentil patty. We left early, feeling disappointed and depressed. Watching my boyfriend pay for the terrible service and bad food was painful. It pretty much ruined my birthday. I won't be going back.

"This joint's a crapshoot, just like the rest. Went there twice, first time was decent, got a good cut from a cool chick. Second time, different story. Lady who cut my hair must've forged her license. She hacked my hair down the middle, cut everything the same length before I could say a word. Worst haircut I've ever gotten, blunt and unflattering. Saw her butcher a kid's crew cut too, didn't think it was possible."

"Paradise Buffet at the Flamingo Casino? More like purgatory. Hard to find, hard to get to, and the grub's not worth the trouble. Limited selection, mediocre food. Shrimp cocktail and crab legs, but don't expect 'em to be cracked open like at the Aria. Sushi's dry and been sittin' out too long. Other than that, it's your standard home cookin'. Pot roast, mac and cheese, Caesar salad, boneless chicken. Feels like a fancy Old Country Buffet, but at least there, you ain't payin' twenty bucks. Check in on Foursquare, save a few bucks? Nah, just put that five bucks in the slot machine instead. Verdict: skip this joint, go see the flamingos outside."

"Grub's alright, but service is rotten at St Rose/Eastern. They don't give a damn 'bout what you want. We asked 'em to fix it, but they told us we shoulda said somethin' when we ordered. Which we did. But hell, it ain't worth the trouble. Go someplace else."

"Been here twice. First time, breakfast was top-notch. Second time, lunch was a disaster. Ordered burgers, got 'em wrong. Waiter didn't give a damn. Took forever to get it right, and even then, it was still messed up. Burgers were dry, like they'd been sitting out too long. No apology, no discount. Won't be back."

"Busy joint on a Sat night, prob'ly due to the ASU game. They've changed things up since I was last here four months back. Now they got these 'name cards' where you write your name and hand 'em to the cooks. Don't mind it too much, got my grub faster that way. Was lookin' forward to makin' my shrimp bowl till I saw the sign sayin' they're goin' through a shrimp shortage. Can't even sample the sauces no more. That was another thing I liked about this place. Damn shame. Felt a bit rushed too, got the bill less than ten minutes after I got my food. Not as pleased this time, but I'll give 'em another shot. Hopin' they'll have shrimp next time."

"Tonkotsu ramen, that's what I was after. Out of state, had to find it. Yelp led me here. Gonna give 'em a fair shot. Here's my take: Tonkotsu, but not quite. Broth lacked depth, too much salt. Pork, where was it? Charsui needed more time in the pot. Mushrooms, veggies, aromatics could help. Finishing sauce, a nice touch. Potential's there. Hope they step it up."

"Food overpriced, cooking sloppy. Wine unimpressive, two Pinot Noirs by glass, not worth it. Bread basket, dry. Dior sign an eyesore, ruining ambiance. Not worth the wait or the money. Waitress nice, but can't make up for poor quality. Special ordered veggie primavera, but pasta stuck together and too salty."

"Alas, fair salon, with people so kind and neat,
Their service, however, left much to be desired, I do confess.
A small palette of hues, both regular and gel, did they possess,
And my pedicure, though passable, lacked a certain finesse.

My gel manicure, alack, was far too thick, I must avow,
And the cuts she made, oh how they smarted, and bled, I vow.
She applied some green ointment, to soothe and nourish my skin,
But alas, the damage was done, and a great scab did form within.

My eyebrow wax, a adequate task, she did perform with ease,
But alas, she did not trim them, only wax, to my great dismay, I must confess."

"Hark! What chaos doth reign within Walmart's halls!
The aisles, they be blocked, and workers, they do scowl.
A woeful sight, indeed, to behold such disarray.
And yet, who can blame them? Treated poorly, they be.
But fear not, dear customer, for still they doth provide,
In hours of great need, when all else doth deny.
So let us raise a glass, to Walmart, in its prime!"

"Last eve we dined here, and alas! the victuals were not of the finest sort. They be lacking in staff, a woeful sight indeed. Sonoma, a member of the Nola, Seviche clan, doth share their kin's penchant for mediocrity. Yet, I shall return for potations, for their wine list doth rival the gods'. Alas, poor fare doth make me seek sustenance elsewhere."
"Food, mediocre. Wait, absurd. Cilantro, everywhere. Noise, deafening. Cabo, not feeling it."
"Booooo! Nice owner sold her restaurant, a real gem. New management, higher prices, no more lunch buffet. Not worth the time or dough."

"Hark! We ventured forth to dine at yonder tavern,
Whose proximity to our humble abode did make it most convenient.
Their ale selection, quite impressive, did our hopes raise,
With bottles diverse and choice, beyond the commonplace.
I sipped a Three Philosophers, my spouse a cider, fair,
And thus began our evening, with promise in the air.

But alas! The service, slow it was, and tardy too,
Ten minutes passed ere our drink order they didst pursue.
The crowd, not overwhelming, yet our waiter, sloth-like,
Didst make us wait, and suffer many an anxious pike.
Our victuals, middling, frozen veggies, a shame,
I asked for salad, and waited, till my meal didst claim.

Thus, two stars, for now, our rating doth confer,
Yet shall we grant them further chance, to redeem and serve.
Until that day, our judgment doth stand,
Awaiting change, and betterment in hand."
"Pulled pork? Meh. Cold as a witch's tit when it arrived. Fried okra, now that was hot. Vinegar sauce, not bad. Bud, the bartender, good bloke."

"Wine and cocktail list, good but pricey for the meal. I got Nordic shrimp in a tomato sauce, but they didn't say they were whole (head and tail). Real hard to eat, served hot. Quail dish was good, but small for the price. After a $80 bill with three glasses of wine, we had to go elsewhere to fill our bellies. In short, worth it for a drink, not for dinner."

"Methought this place would be most fair,
After a search on Google, I didst declare,
The best chimichanga in all of Phoenix,
But alas, 'twas not so, I do confess.

I ordered carne asada, full of hope,
But the spices, they didst not doth cope,
No cumin couldst I taste, nor any zest,
And the meat, it was bland, I do protest.

The rice, it looked fine, but the taste,
Was burnt, as if the broth didst haste,
And the beans, they were smothered in cheese,
But the flavor, it didst not please.

A couple of bright spots, there were,
The salsa, both hot and mild, didst stir,
The waiter, friendly and outgoing,
And the atmosphere, old school, it was going.

But alas, the food, it didst not impress,
So I cannot recommend, I must confess,
Tee Pee, it may be a place to drink,
But for food, I wouldst not think."
"Drive-thru line took twenty minutes, no apology. Got my son's drink mixed up too. Would've gone inside if we didn't have the baby with us."

"A fair location, with victuals of good cheer,
And atmosphere most wondrous, doth abide here.
Yet, alack, the prices do ascend so high,
As if the purse, they did intend to try.
For in the States, a bagel doth cost less,
Than half the sum, that here, they do profess."

"Don't order sushi at a place that ain't dedicated to it. It's like askin' for fish at a burger joint. You're gonna be disappointed. And don't even get me started on the rice. It's like they forgot to cook it. I couldn't finish the meal without losin' my lunch. The pot stickers were a bust too. Lean Cuisine does 'em better. And the brownie? Forgettable. Maybe if I'd ordered somethin' else, things woulda been different."

"I dropped thirteen bucks on a piddly shrimp cocktail. Drinks at the lounge were pricey, bartender had a snotty attitude. Decor was straight outta the seventies, not my cup of tea. Don't get the fuss."

"Fast-casual dining, a fan I be,
Healthy options, freshness, all can see.
No time to cook, nor deep pockets I have,
So, 'tis a place that doth please me well, by the Lord above!

They specialize in fish, cooked to order,
With choice of seasoning or sauce, a wondrous border.
Soups, sandwiches, salads, and tacos, all on the list,
A feast for the eyes, and the belly, 'twill dismiss.

Kid-friendly, they be, with options galore,
For the little ones, a treat in store.
But alas, my experience, a downside did bring,
The fishy smell, not so fresh, did my nostrils sting.

Mango salsa, a delight, on my orange roughy,
Brown rice, no complaints, a satisfying comity.
But the fish, oh the fish, could be better, I say,
At these prices, freshness flies away.

House-made chicken tenders, a plus, I do declare,
But too bland, alas, my child did not spare.

Great concept, yes, but quality in question,
A work in progress, a vision in transition."

"Walk into Frankie's Tiki Room, and you'll feel like you're going blind. It's dimly lit, and it takes a good 10 minutes for your eyes to adjust. But that's part of the charm, right? Maybe it's so you don't freak out when you see what you're sitting in. 

The drinks come with skull ratings, from candy to sanitizer. When the bartender says, "Start with a five skull or I'll just order for you," it's a little unnerving. But Katrina M. ordered me the green gasser, and it was potent. The pour was generous, to say the least. At first, it was undrinkable, but it got better as the ice melted. 

The service is slow, though. My friends had to wait a while every time they went up, even when it was starting to clear out. It made hanging out feel like someone was always being left out."

"Chop and Wok, a dive bar with Chinese grub. Sounds strange, and it was. Stopped by on the way to the airport, caught the NFC championship game. Ordered the chicken and veggie combo on brown rice. Rushed through a few bites, didn't have time for more. Frozen chicken, microwaved taste. Disappointing. Two stars, max."

"Been to this Bashas' a few times. Twice we swore never to return. First time, manager talked trash 'bout an employee, right in front of us, whole time we checked out. Rude. Second time, two employees went on 'bout their sex lives while checkin' us out. Unprofessional, if ya ask me. Prices ain't competitive. Liked the Bashas' in North Phoenix, though. Worth the extra few bucks. This one? Nah. Prefer Fresh and Easy, right across the street."

"Plenty of rave reviews, time to see if they're legit. Oregon boy here, know my Asian food, especially pho. Got the 'pho-nomenal' bowl, disappointing. Asked for chili oil, they said siracha's enough. Really? Shrimp rolls were meh too. Price is on par with other pho joints, but quality's lacking. Give it three months, see if things improve. Two stars for decent customer service, that's it."

"Dark, divey joint. Torn upholstery, pool tables looked decent. Good crowd at the bar, family at a table. Not the best spot for a family lunch, but not inappropriate either. Friend had the bacon burger, I had the grilled chicken. Sweet potato waffle fries were a surprise, but crispy and tasty. Burger was forgettable, bacon was overcooked and hard. Chicken sandwich was well-cooked, but the grill flavor was overpowering. Needed some sauce. Enjoyed the Asian slaw. Left Hand Lager was decent. Prices were steep for the atmosphere, though. $36 for lunch, $6 for a Guinness. Monday's $1.50 PBRs, but it wasn't Monday and I don't like PBR. Service was friendly but inattentive. Empty glasses and slow billing. Not worth it."

I swung by this McDonald's joint for breakfast this mornin', Robyn N. taggin' along. Place was dead, but still took forever to get our grub. Menu's not exactly rocket science, but I guess that's what happens when you've got more staff than customers. Bathroom's a joke, too. No paper towels, just them silly blowers mounted way down low. Door opens inwards, so you gotta be a contortionist to get outta there with clean hands. My Sausage McMuffin tasted like it'd been sittin' around for a while, too. Not exactly the best start to the day.

"Bagels were decent, service though, was a disaster. Walked in, only one guy ahead of me. Thought it'd be quick, nope. Sat there for over 20 min for two bagels. Employees were slow, messing up orders left and right."

"I was at the Encore, workin' a function. Company splits us up, sends us to different fancy restaurants. Now, I ain't no fan of seafood, Italian grub ain't my jam either. So, when I find out I'm eatin' here, I'm a bit let down. Decided to suck it up, not complain, enjoy the ride. We're in a private room, eatin' family style. Gotta say, underwhelmin' experience. Food looks like somethin' my folks would make at home, service is slow. Gotsta flag down the server a few times for a drink. Like someone told 'em not to give me booze. (Prolly my bosses, they know me too well.)"
"Biscuits? Don't see the fuss. Been here a few times, grub's alright, prices too. But underwhelmed, that's me."
"Burgers? Just OK. Shakes? Horrible. Three times we gave 'em a shot. Three times we regretted it. Cheap prices mean cheap quality."

"Methinks I do not relish El Salvadorian fare,
For either I didst consume the cardboard display,
Or my meal was truly devoid of flavor and zest,
A plight most vexing to mine tastebuds, I must confess.

The appetizer platter, a dull array,
Didst lack the spice of life, and thus didst fade,
Into a memory, most forgetful and gray,
Like unto icebergs, radishes, a sorry shade.

The chicken, too, with rice and sauce so pale,
Didst fail to stir my senses, or to make me hail,
The culinary prowess of El Salvador's land,
Alas, 'twas but a disappointment, so grand.

Pupusas, however, didst delight mine eyes,
And in their savory goodness, I didst arise,
To praise their merits, and to seek them still,
For in those morsels, my hunger found its fill."
"Been here a few times, parkings a bitch, grub's alright but nothing special. Lot's of flash, not much substance. Baja sauce is good, but it'll make you sick later. Need to learn from this."

"Stayed at a crummy four-star hotel with the missus. SLS, that's its name, and it's in a rough part of town. Looks like some cheap clothing line threw up a building. Room was tiny, design was awful. Bed in the middle, sink and shower right behind it, toilet on one side, mirror on the ceiling. No closet, just a rack and two drawers. Worst part? No ice machine on our floor. Had to order ice from room service and tip the guy for it. And if you asked for more than two buckets, they'd charge you! Carpet was rough, mirror on the ceiling was cool at first, but got old fast. Bed lit up, looked kinda trashy. Service was decent, except for the front desk. They weren't as friendly as the rest."

"Tis a neat and tidy eatery, but alas, their Mexican fare doth lack authenticity. Forsooth, they prepare their burritos in a strange and foreign manner, and when I requested mine be made a certain way, the server didst reply, 'Nay, good sir, we do not prepare it thus.' Verily, it didst dampen my desire for their burrito. Moreover, they didst proclaim that pico de gallo, that most delicious of salsas, doth not belong within their burritos. I didst inform them, as any paying patron should, that I wouldst have my meal prepared as I saw fit. Alas, their accents didst make it difficult to comprehend their words, and their meat didst lack the authentic Mexican spices. Farewell, dear restaurant, for I shall not return."
"Underwhelming experience. Went with sis, shared veggie and shrimp tempura rolls, edamame. Didn't enjoy any of it. Good service, but that's about it."

"Arrived at 6:40 with two others. Happy Hour ended at 7, but our waiter didn't show till 7:02. Ordered grub and drinks, but our waters took their sweet time, arriving at 7:15. Place was dead, Thursday night. Friend asked about the Garden Burger, listed as '100% Vegan.' Waiter informed us it wasn't vegan due to chipotle ranch and eggs used to hold it together. Food was mediocre, service was crap."

"I struggled to find words for this review. I dig the affordable price tag, but my experience fell short. Signed up for mommy and me ballet, gave it two months. First class was cool, then they cancelled five minutes before the next one. Thanks for the heads up, right? Next few weeks, instructors showed up 15-20 minutes late. Class was a bust. Ranges from 18 months to 3-4 years old. Other moms weren't too friendly, unless you were part of their crew. Met another mom with a toddler the same age as mine. Overall, not a great experience, but I'd try a different class or wait for a better instructor."
"Food lacked zest. Well-cooked, ample portions, yet devoid of taste."

"Hark, what mall is this? So vast and wide,
And yet, so empty, as if 'twere new-born.
The shops, they be overpriced, I do declare,
And I, a humble customer, know not what to choose.
There be many eateries, and lights that doth shine bright,
But alas, I shall not return, forsooth, anon."

"Moved back to the Burgh after three years in Cali. Kept track of the place, wanted to check it out. Nice changes inside. Sat at the bar, near the service area, not the best spot. Good local draft selection though. Ordered mussels and fish 'n chips. Mussels were decent, sauce was great, but should've been hotter. Fish 'n chips were a letdown. Fries were soggy, fish was undercooked, batter was bland. Only thing that saved it was the mushy peas. Might go back for those and a dark 'n stormy. Bartender was attentive, that's a plus."

"Hark, what news is this? A place so dear, yet food so base.
Their Malaysian chicken curry, a dish most vile and plain.
I fear, my friends, I shall not return again."

"Aye, this place doth lack in charm and zest,
The salsa, unremarkable, doth fail to impress;
A spinach-filled burrito, of sorts, didst I acquire,
But alas, the greens didst not taste overly fresh;
Yet, in its favor, cheese didst abound, a saving grace,
Still, with other Mexican eateries in abundance,
I fear, my return, unlikely, doth be."

"Coffee's been piss poor here for weeks. Lattes, iced drinks, doesn't matter. Undrinkable. Maybe it's the sitting out too long, or overbrewing. Either way, it's bad. Banana nut pound cakes are decent, though. Atmosphere's alright too. Not a total loss."

"Second time at this joint, and it was a letdown. Service was slow, food was subpar. Took 'em five minutes to bring me a fork. Duck was alright, but nothing special. Came with a generic potato that could've been from McDonald's. Two dishes were cold, had to be reheated. Skirt steak showed up last, when we were already done. And it tasted stale, like it had been sitting out too long. Place wasn't even busy at six, but they claimed they were still recovering from an earlier rush. Lame excuse."

"Methinks I've visited this place twice ere now,
With a gift coupon in hand, from an oil change vow.
And verily, good sirs, 'twas a fortunate chance,
For had I paid, I'd have sought recompense in haste.

My carriage, alack, doth not receive regular cleaning,
For my black lab, he sheddeth with reckless abandon, ye ken?
Yet still, I thought it meet to give 'em a try,
But lo! upon my return, the interior did lie.

The foot rugs yet bore traces of yon canine guest,
And the dashboard, alas! remained unswept, unkempt.
In faith, 'twas hard to say if' twere truly cleaned,
So henceforth, I shall not waste my coin on such sheen."

"Hark! My spouse and I didst take our daughter fair,
To this establishment, with hopes most rare,
For her birthday brunch, we didst wish to share,
And celebrate with joy, and love most true.

We called ahead, when morning's sun didst rise,
And made a reservation, with no surprise,
They said they couldst accommodate us, with ease,
At half past twelve, our time didst please.

My husband didst speak, with gentle tone,
And asked if they couldst do something alone,
For our dear child, on her special day,
A brownie, perhaps, to make her way?

The gentleman didst reply, with cheerful voice,
"No problem, sir, we shall make it our choice,"
And so, we waited, with hopeful heart,
For the feast to start, and our hunger to part.

But alas! The menu, limited it was,
And the food, but mediocre, alas!
The price, so steep, for a single piece,
Of chicken, free range, with fries, a paltry treat.

Our server, forgetful, or so it seemed,
Didst not bring forth, the promised dream,
The brownie, complimentary, or not,
We wished to pay, to make our daughter's plot.

So, we didst speak, and let them know,
Our discontent, with words most slow,
But still, they charged, for the dessert so fine,
And left us feeling, not quite divine.

I've been to places, where such treats are free,
For birthdays, and anniversaries, a decree,
But here, alas! They didst not follow suit,
And so, we shall not, this place, revisit."

"Fare thee well, dear friends! Forsooth, we sought to dine
At this establishment, famed for its delightful grub.
But lo, the prices did our purses sorely pinch,
And left us wondering if 'twere worth the scratch.

The victuals, alas, did not impress us much,
For though they looked enticing, their taste was naught.
We sampled several dishes, including the duck salad,
But found them lacking in flavor, and thus quite sad.

The drinks, however, did please our palates well,
And the service too, was friendly and swell.
But alas, the food did not live up to its fame,
And left us feeling disappointed, and somewhat lame."
"Drinks, good. Appetizers, great. Entree, spicy pasta, no good. Took it home, threw it out."
"Four of us had a damn good entree, but the hot chocolate lava cake was a letdown. Thought it came with the meal, but they charged extra. Want a dessert latte? Go to Mickey D's."

"Two parties in the joint. One old broad and a couple who knew the staff. We ordered shrimp chow mein. Typical. Nice flavors, big portions, but skimpy on the bean sprouts. Menu was standard Asian fare. Beef, chicken, soup, shrimp. You know the drill. 

Next up, squid with snow peas. Sounded good, but what arrived was a different story. Bland and unseasoned. Couldn't eat it. 

Finally, fresh live fish. Sea bass, steamed. Good, but needed some lemon. Not traditional, I know, but still. Overall, 2 out of 5."

"Been here thrice, ambivalent feelings. Last two visits, staff seemed indifferent to providing decent service. First time, they knocked it outta the park. Veggie sandwich for the missus, best she's had. My burger, delish. Service, top-notch. Second time, meals were mediocre. Service, fair. Had their cobbler, not bad, but no mom's cobbler. Third time, meals sub-par, service, near nonexistent."
"Food, good. Service, bad. Woman at bar, loud. Place, clean."

"Learning curve's a bitch. Car wash raids turned staff into aggressive upsellers. Greeted with a hard sell, felt like a hostage. Undone work at the end of the line, rag soaked in Armourall cleaned passenger side. Complained, girl walked to gas station, returned with Funyuns. Didn't help, still stuck. Ran it through the wash again. Waited an hour, ridiculous. Manager shrugged it off. Done with the carousel."

"Hark! I have visited the Green Valley establishment, my dear. 'Twas an improvement, indeed. We didst partake in the Quatro Fromagi, a most delectable dish, I must confess. Alas, the crust, it was soggy and quite difficult to consume without the aid of a knife and a fork, I do declare.

"Methinks the musical selection, Motley Crue, doth not suit the ambiance of a refined pizza tavern. Pray, try again, good sirs!

"The decor, alack! 'Tis dark and uninviting, a veritable cave of gloom. I suggest a new interior designer, forthwith! Forsooth, the tables, they didst appear unsealed, a lack of proper cleanliness, methought. How the Health Department didst pass this place, I know not.

"Yet, there was a silver lining, my friends. The involtini, 'twas quite tasty, I must admit. Alas, not enough to draw me back, I fear. Fare thee well, dear pizza place, mayhap another time."

"Hark! Blu Basil doth resemble an airport tavern,
And hath potential, yet their prices do mount.
A dollar sign, not two, doth it deserve, I say."

"I wanna like you, Moe's. I do. You're close and convenient. But, I went for a taco salad last week, excited for some real Mexican flavor, ya know? What I got was a flavorless chicken salad with subpar guac on the side. My boyfriend even said my guac is better, and I ain't no chef or Mexican neither. I expected more. Still lookin' for that authentic taste in a quick takeout."

"Hark! I pray this review doth change anon,
For SkySong's farmers market, a sorry sight it shown.
First day, they say, yet scant few booths did bear
Fresh fruit and veg, a paltry choice, alas!
Mostly cheese, jelly, creams, and such like dear,
A costly array, for common folk to fear.
Yet, SkySong's site, a wondrous place it be,
And strange design, doth charm mine eyes, forsooth.
I shall return, for 'tis nearby, and cheer,
In hopes their wares, more bountiful shall be, anon."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

I ordered a burger and onion rings. The burger was frozen, nothing special. The onion rings were good, but that's it. Not worth the same price as Hillstone's burger. The place was dirty, catering to the late-night crowd who didn't seem to mind the grime. That's my takeaway.

"Alack, I thought this place didst hold
Korean karaoke machines of old,
But lo, a Chinese knockoff didst greet
My eyes, with naught but trouble to meet.

The search function, oh how it didst fail,
And real karaoke soundtracks, didst not prevail.
Our group didst strain, to sing so loud,
Above the recorded voices, proud.

The place, a four-star, mayhap, couldst be,
But alas, no true KTV, didst decree.
No search, no English, didst they speak,
A disappointment, my friends, didst seek."

"This place doth be a dump, a pit of woe.
I didst not wish to tread upon this floor,
But needs must, for I hadst goods to sell.
The wares they peddle, purses and rags,
Are tattered, worn, and grossly oversold.
Fakes, too! For prices that would make one wince.
Besides these fripperies, they vend
Trinkets and baubles, cheap as dirt,
But naught of value, save the gages, fair.
I shall not darken this door again."

"Terrible service. Food was just okay. Long waits. Asked for wings before our meal, but they still brought 'em out cold. Twenty-five minutes for the appetizer, two and a half for the main course. What's the point of French toast?"

Hark! I did pay $46 on Expedia,
For a hotel with a good location, yea,
In Glendale, it did serve our purpose well,
And the staff, they were friendly, no doubt.

A free hot breakfast, a pleasant surprise,
Did ease my mind, and my stomach, likewise.
But alas, the halls and elevator,
Were not just old, but also quite foul.
The carpet, too, did show its age,
And the furniture in the lobby, in disarray.

Yet, I did spy a patio, quite fair,
And thought to dine there, in the fresh air.
But lo, the tables and chairs, unclean,
Did trouble me, for they were not fit to be seen.
Three staff members, idling, did I see,
While but three guests did break their fast, unhappily.
"Sat down for lunch, waited for service. Ordered smoked meat spaghetti, decent but overpriced. Won't be back alone."

Ranger Mike Garcia, grumpy bugger that he was, set a shitty tone for our visit. Sorry to have bothered him, but we were just trying to enjoy the damn park. He soured the whole experience right from the get-go. The movie was meh, the ruins were meh, but for crying out loud, put someone with a pulse at the front desk.

"Las Vegas, baby. Heard good things. Went a few times. Finally checked out the show. It was fun, but got old fast. After it ended, I thought, 'That's it?' Not worth the cash we shelled out. Seen it, crossed it off the list. Won't be back."

"We came here with friends, though we're locals. Service was poor, our waitress was rude and unattentive. Frozen daiquiris were decent, fried mac and cheese was great. My burger, though, was a disappointment. Ordered a cheeseburger with everything, came with bacon I hadn't asked for and no fries. It was cold, undercooked, and the cheese was scarce. Not worth returning for."

"Alas, fair traveler, thou seeketh sustenance at Sammy's Beach Bar and Grille, a place most common, with victuals frozen and service most vile. Yet, my dear wife and I, with haste, do frequent this establishment, forsooth, when flights doth depart from McCarran's gate. Pray tell, why doth this happen? 'Tis the Waborita, a drink most fine, yet priced beyond reason, I do confess. The nachos and chili-cheese fries, alack, are naught but pedestrian fare, yet the Waborita, a gem, doth shine bright. If thou hast time to spare, sit thee down at the bar, for service doth crawl at a snail's pace, I do declare. Sammy's, in sooth, doth give back to the community, a deed most kind, and thus, thy stop, though costly, shall be palatable, an it please thee to partake of the Waborita, a drink most worthy."

"Carnevino, another Vegas steakhouse. Heard good things, being at Palazzo. Batali's joint, gotta be solid, right? Not quite. 

Hostess, stunning. Worth another visit. 

Ravioli, handmade, duck sauce, great dish. Not heavy, full of flavor. 

Bone-in ribeye for two, medium, twitching. Cut and served, bloody. Don't know if my taste buds are refined enough. Cooked, key word. Steak, not so much. 

Pricey, unsatisfying dinner. 

Good wine selection, though."

"Hark, what news is this? A hotel, once grand, now fallen to disarray. My stay, alas, was marred by filth and woe. The bathroom, a chamber of horrors, with peeling tile and weakened stream. The faucet, it did drip and drip, a constant reminder of the decay. Dust, it did cover all, like a shroud of shame. And yet, they claimed an upgrade, a view of the strip, a paltry consolation for the state of the room. Alas, poor Hilton, how art thou fallen from grace."

"Went to the SpaFitFinder launch party with SpacePhoenix. Place was packed, but the TrimTini was top-notch. Guy from Urban 7 was real friendly, kept bringing out good eats. Not my kind of joint, but it was a fun night."

"Been here a few times, year past. Disappointed, mostly. Staff ain't rude, just not too helpful. Ulta's always missing something. Hair products, buy two get one free. Always. Selection's limited compared to Best of the West."
"Solid meal, consistent. Ate breakfast like usual at Denny's. Good spot for fam, decent grub for fair price. Docked a star for slow service, not enough help."

"Steak was decent, but overpriced at forty bucks a plate. Ordered the surf 'n turf special with scallops and two five-ounce filets. Filets were cooked right, nice cuts of meat, but nothing to write home about. Scallops were a letdown, didn't meet my expectations for a joint like this."

"Hark! What news is this? KFC doth change its ways,
And I, in sooth, do fear 'tis not for better days.
Their chicken, once a savory delight,
Now doth assault mine taste with salt's fierce might.

But wait! Their sides, they do redeem the meal,
Mashed potatoes, coleslaw, mac n cheese, a hearty steal.
And biscuits, too, they doth provide a treat,
A respite from the saltiness that doth greet.

Yet, verily, I say, this place doth not deserve
My custom, save for those few dishes that serve.
Forsooth, a habit 'twill not become, I swear,
For KFC's changes doth leave much to fear."

"Wings at Hooters, that's what the ladies go for, unless they're trying to prove something. And let me tell you, I've been pretty good about keeping my mouth shut on this topic, but the QC has been a pleasant surprise overall. But let's be real, every Hooters in Chicagoland has better wings than this one. Heck, even the Hooters in Puerto Vallarta had better wings. These were just mediocre, not as flavorful, and the batter wasn't as flaky. I mean, come on, if I'm gonna eat at a chain, I expect the wings to taste like Hooters wings! Standardization, folks! Bah, well at least the server was nice. Shaun, I think that was her name, she was sweet."

"Hark, my dearest wife and I, for many moons,
Have graced House of Blues with our noble presence,
To partake in feast and revel in sweet tunes,
But alas, last eve, our joy did swiftly wane.

A pox upon the hostess, who didst place us
Far from the stage, in a most distant corner,
And when we asked to move, her reply didst sting,
"No server here, thy wish doth not avail."

And lo, the menu didst reveal its woe,
With prices high and choices few,
Mashed potatoes cold, and snap peas the same,
For $3.99, a price most unjust and lame.

The rest of the menu, once full of delight,
Now doth resemble a barren winter's night,
Devoid of charm and sustenance both,
Leaving us to ponder, in dismay and wroth.

Yet, fair fortune didst smile upon us,
When a floor manager, with apologies, didst fuss,
And moved us to a better seat, with grace,
And gifted us with drinks and dessert, in her place.

Our servers, too, didst earn our praise,
With their attentive care and pleasant ways,
But still, the night's mood, didst sour begin,
With that first faux pas, which didst cast a sin.

So, House of Blues, take heed of this tale,
And mend thy ways, lest thou dost fail."

"Uncomfortable seats, broken and dirty. Went to see Met Opera performance. Sound from next door's theater seeped in. Stale popcorn, fake butter with no flavor. Had to add it myself, soggy top, flavorless bottom. No flavored salt like Harkin's. Great program, shitty venue."

"Food was subpar. Fifty bucks for one person. Panda Express serves better grub. Orange peel chicken? Cold and flavorless. Veggies? Dirty and unappetizing. Atmosphere saved it from a single-star rating."

Five Guys? Good burger, sure. Fries, too. But not much else sets 'em apart. Been there twice, both times service was slow. First time, waited 20 minutes. Figured it was a one-off. Nope. Same thing happened again. Staff was rude when we asked about our food. Ended up missin' the movie. Won't be in a hurry to go back, 'less I got a lot of time. And if I got a lot of time, I'll go somewhere else. Fix the service, guys.

"Upscale joint, but the grub didn't impress. Menu was lackin', service was meh. Ambiance was nice, but that don't make up for the mediocre caesar salad. Pricey too. Aria mall, though, that's a different story. Pristine and upscale, just how it should be."

"Thirty-five bucks a head? For real? Mac and cheese station, cool concept, but execution fell short. Runny mess. Desserts lacked depth, selection limited. Salads, not bad. Marscapeone polenta, nice touch. Shrimp cocktail, nonexistent. Crab legs, lukewarm. Nice dining space, servers on point. But for the price, not worth it. Asian section, three items. Sushi selection, pathetic. No ahi, sashimi, or nigiri. Rolls looked like gas station fare."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess, our feast at Strip Steak did not impress. 

The time betwixt order and delivery was long, though the hall didst not seem full. And when our victuals did arrive, alack, they were not hot. 

I had the chop, a flavorless cut, devoid of taste, a sorry sight. My comrades, who chose the filet, found theirs to be fair, but not so grand that they didst finish the dish. 

The duck fat fries, a delight, the truffle mac and cheese, passable, the asparagus, a pleasant surprise, but the mushrooms, alas, were cold. The selection of sweet treats, limited, yet the cheesecake, a light and tasty delight. 

Alack, a disappointing meal, indeed, and one that didst cost a pretty penny, o'er four hundred crowns. I wouldst advise thee, dear friend, to avoid this place, lest thou wish to suffer similar woe."

"Flame Broiler, love it. But this one, tough to enjoy. Food wasn't up to par. Music, too loud, couldn't hear the woman taking my order. Said it was loud, she just smiled. Maybe she couldn't hear me? Might go back, but won't eat in."

"Service was snappy, like a well-oiled machine. Octoberfest burger, guest went for a cheeseburger. Fries, plenty. Didn't need no endless refills. Burgers? Meh. Like meatloaf. Maybe some filler, who knows? Not worth ten bucks, in my book."

"Birthday dinner at this joint? Forget it. They botched almost everything. Friend's salad came with croutons, despite her gluten-free request. Sister's burger? Burnt to a crisp. Grandma's sandwich? Jalapenos galore, despite her order being sans spice. Beer's decent, but that's where the positives end. Patio smoking allowed? No thanks. Smell wafts in, ruining the experience. Four Peaks is the better bet."

"Hark, good sir! This place doth serve fine ale and provide a comfortable seat. Tarry thou must, for swift service doth not abide here. A score of minutes passed ere a serving maid did take our order, and thrice that time didst elapse ere our victuals did arrive. Verily, I did request the bill, yet another score of minutes didst tick by ere it didst appear. Methinks, shouldst thou desire a leisurely repast, this place mayhap shall suffice. Howbeit, shouldst thou seek prompt service, mayhap another venue shall better serve thy needs."

"Alas, dear friends, I must recount my woeful tale
Of a meal most foul, a culinary fail
Pasta, once a dish of grace and beauty, now
Overcooked and drowned in cheese, oh what a pity
Lasagna, once a noble dish, now reduced to mush
And pizza, oh pizza, with crust and sauce so fine
But alas, too much cheese, a sin of gluttony divine
The service, slow and unattentive, like an old man's gait
And atmosphere, akin to a lowly tavern's fate
With vinyl tablecloths and tacky decor, a sight most vile
No reason to return, a place to avoid for a while."

"My boyfriend and I hit this joint up last week. I went for the ahi sliders as an app, and the I love bacon burger. Both were subpar. The slider buns didn't complement the fish and ponzu sauce. The burger lacked any sort of sauce, so I barely touched it. My boyfriend got the jalapeno burger and didn't finish it either. Maybe they were having an off-day. Might give 'em another shot."

"Our group didst suffer from a sloth-like service,
And waiters, bartenders, didst ignore us with disdain.
I hadst dined here once before, and 'twas not a pleasant feast,
Yet, my friends, new to this land, didst wish to partake.

The ambiance, fair and bright, didst make our spirits light,
But alas, the staff, didst leave much to be desired in their plight."
"Vegas, five days. Highest meal bill. Wynn, Studio B, M Resort. Quick seating, good service. But damn, expensive burgers and fries. A la carte menu. Better options elsewhere."

"Liked the homemade chips, mmm. Red salsa, good too. Chicken in enchiladas, tender. Service, good. Didn't like the green sauce, bland. Beans and rice, disappointing. Maybe it's my fault, unfamiliar with New Mexican food."

"Charging for chips and salsa? Ridiculous. Food was passable, but after a couple drinks, the bill added up quick. Could've gotten more bang for my buck with prime rib instead of enchiladas. Better Mexican joints on the West Side of Madison."
"Gado gado sauce, good. Chicken, fried too much. Mixed veggie sauce, too thick, too salty, MSG likely."
"Wings were decent. But the patio? Dirty as hell. Needed a good sweepin'."

"Meh. Been better. Yelp stole my thunder. Anyways, I rolled into this joint looking for some legit Taiwanese breakfast. Chinatown, right? Should be easy peasy. Saw 'YongHe', thought I hit the jackpot. Inside, not so much. They tried, I'll give 'em that. But, c'mon, beef wrap/roll and Chinese donuts? That's like calling a hot dog a hamburger. Lazy. Soymilk and fantuan were meh. Service? Forget about it. Waited forever, staff seemed overwhelmed. Maybe dinner's better, but I ain't holding my breath."

"People say the drinks are strong? Bullshit. We got shots of vodka and they were weak, overpriced too. I've had better. 

The promoter said there was an open bar. Lie. Don't like people who lie. Or their clubs. 

Not a Beatles fan? That's okay, neither is anyone else here. All ages, but mostly young and old. They must come from the Cirque show, free passes and all. 

And the bathrooms? Shared sink, activated by foot. Like a damn baseball stadium."

"Alack, this Walmart doth be poorly stocked,
And in disarray, a ghetto, some would say.
Beware, good sirs, and keep thy wits about thee,
For help from employees, thou shalt not see.

The shelves, they be bare, and in disorder,
A mess, indeed, that doth beggar description.
And shouldst thou require aid, forget it,
For they be nowhere found, in this dire place.

Drive forth, my friends, an extra furlong,
To find a better Walmart, worth thy while.
For laziness, it doth beset me oft,
And thus, I shop here, with a heavy heart."

"Took the missus here for a fancy meal, on account of the good reviews. But let me tell you, it was a real disappointment. Sat us down quick, but the grub was a real letdown. Fettuccine alfredo, no flavor to speak of. No garlic, no nothing. Waitress was nice, but when we told her the food was bland, she didn't seem too surprised. Brought us some free dessert, but that was a bust too. I gotta say, Olive Garden's got more flavor. And we ain't exactly fans of that place neither. My advice?
