Skip this joint, grab some groceries, cook up your own meal at home. You'll save money and eat better too."

"Methinks 'tis a fine establishment, with service most fair and atmosphere quite pleasant. Yet, alas, their victuals and potions, they do come at a steep price, I do declare. For those who prefer their Mexican fare mild and unassuming, this may be the place to tarry."

"Brunch at Bellagio or Wynn? Wynn won out, thanks to raves about its swank atmosphere. But the grub? Meh. Cold apps, parched fish, burnt prime rib, watery crab legs. Shrimp saved the day, but not worth the $50 per head, tax and tip included."

"Back for round two, we were. Food, not bad, but not great either. Stand by my word, I do. Salt and pepper, added I did, to the steak. Fat, that's what the prime rib was, mostly. Steaks, I cook, at home. Marbling, I know. Balance, there must be. Outback Steakhouse, better taste, lower price. Chandler Blvd, never disappointed. Firebirds, not for us, sorry."

"Hark! What woe is this? My stomach doth protest,
For onion rings, once a mainstay of my feast,
Are gone, vanished from yon menu's list.
Oh, cruel fate! How could they thus dismiss
A dish so sweet, so savory, and so fine?
I pray thee, sirs, reconsider this decision,
Lest I be forced to seek sustenance elsewhere.

And, prithee, note the state of yonder fowl,
Which, fried in oil of ancient vintage, doth
Retain a flavor most unpleasant and rancid.
In faith, a filter or fresh oil, they should use,
Lest I, a patron of many years, be loath
To continue forth my custom and support.
Alas, poor restaurant, how art thou fallen!"
"Lunch buffet at this joint? Forget it. Place felt grimy, service was slow. Food? Don't even get me started. Dry, oily, terrible. Better options out there. Skip it."

"Holly's got nothing going for her, talent-wise. She's got a nice bod, sure, but that's where it ends. The rest of the cast did their best, but they'd have been better off without her. I got a few laughs out of it, but mostly I was fighting to stay awake. There's gotta be better shows in Vegas for your buck."

"A seafood joint like this, stuck in the middle of nowhere, and it's still breathin'? That's a mystery to me. But I reckon it's got something to do with that Sancerre '10. If they'd served it right, maybe it would've been the saving grace. But they didn't, so it ain't."
"Went there last night. First time, thanks to a gift certificate. Not impressed. Server was strange, table was cramped in a corner, and flies swarmed everywhere. Weird menu too. Won't be back."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
Samba at The Mirage did not impress.
Their meats were dry, their service slow,
And their creme br\u00fbl\u00e9e, oh how it did go!

They brought us chicken, sausage, and bread,
But when it came to beef, they were quite stingy.
Two bite-sized pieces, that was all we got,
And when we asked for more, they seemed quite hot.

The plantains, rice, and beans were fine,
But the dessert, alas, was not divine.
It tasted old and stale, like it had been kept
In the fridge for far too long, and not slept.

So, my friends, take my advice,
And avoid this place, it's not worth the price.
Go elsewhere, where the meat is fresh and neat,
And the service, friendly, and not so beat."

"Methinks my love and I didst dine upon this establishment's fare this eve. Our memories of yore didst recall a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain savoir faire, if thou wilt, that didst impel us to return once more unto this culinary domicile. 

Alas, the bruschetta, a humble dish indeed, didst fail to impress. 'Twas naught but a pale imitation of former feasts, a mere shadow of its former self. My love, in his infinite wisdom, didst choose the blackened chicken pasta, a dish that didst stir within me memories of days of yore, of a certain chef boyardie that didst grace our table in times past. 

And I, in turn, didst select the four cheese pizza, a dish that didst leave much to be desired, I do confess. The sauce, a paltry excuse for a condiment, didst lack the verve and zest of former feasts, while the cheese, alack, didst possess a certain...plasticity, if thou wilt, that didst leave a most unpleasant taste upon mine lips. 

In conclusion, methinks this establishment doth leave much to be desired. Alack, my love, mayhap another time shall we find a venue more worthy of our refined tastes."
"Pittsburgh pizza's got a problem - undercooked. Sauce is generic, straight from a jar. Price is fair, two bucks a slice. Counter staff's friendly, but the pizza's doughy, rubbery, and flavorless."

"Place was alright, staff was friendly. Wine list? Not so much. Asked 'em about it, they said the owners wanted somethin' different. My guess? They're tryin' to rip us off with wines we ain't familiar with. Had a $10 glass from an $11 bottle. It was okay, but come on, I'm payin' good money for a drink, I expect somethin' better."
"City Art Centre's part, not great. Overpriced breakfast, skip it. Better deals elsewhere."

"Alas, how times doth change, and with it, our dearest haunts! This place, once my heart's desire, now doth pale in comparison to its former self. The menu, once rich with variety, doth now seem lacking, and my beloved rolls, alas, are no more. The all-you-can-drink draft beer, a delight most sweet, doth vanish like a mist at dawn. Why, pray tell, wouldst one pay sevenfold for a single brew, when for half the price, a draught Sapporo doth flow like a river in springtime? 'Tis true, methinks, this place doth lose its charm, and other sushi restaurants, with prices more fair and drinks more plentiful, shall claim my custom henceforth."

"Fish tacos, I love 'em. But this joint? Didn't impress me. Food was just okay. Margs were alright too. Ingredients? Cheap. Maybe they're famous 'cause they're the only Mexican spot in NoDa. But it ain't 'cause of their grub. Had the blackened mahi mahi tacos. Meh. Best fish tacos? Please. Only if you like mediocre tacos."
"Sales final. No returns. Good store though. Friendly folk, nice stuff."

"Methought the fish tacos didst taste most wondrous,
But alack, what fate hath befallen this place?
Since first I didst dine here, twenties of year,
Hath passed, and naught but decay doth show its face.

The KFC/Chandler city strife of yore,
Didst take its toll, and now doth lie in store
A relic of days gone by, with naught to boast,
But foul chairs, tables, and such, in disarray,
And lo, a BBQ vendor, doth ply his trade,
In entrance, with scents that doth not blend,
With fish, nor beer, that we didst order made.

Ah, memories, how sweet thou art,
But nay, thy present state, doth break my heart."

"First Indian joint I ever ate at. Maybe the only one, too. Don't know if that makes me a decent critic or not. But I've had my fair share of Indian grub since then, and this place just didn't make the cut. Food was dull, unoriginal, and served like a mess. Indian food gets a bad rep for being a mixed bag, but this place doesn't help its case. Subpar food, avoid it."

"I hit the books hard. Finding decent study spots in Glendale ain't easy. Paradise is the best of the bunch near school. They got plenty of outlets, wifi that works sometimes, and passable joe. Plus, they give out free snacks when you're in the hole for a quarter mil. Not bad, right?

Thing is, nothing here's worth the price. Coffee's either too dark or flavored funny. I take my coffee serious, so that's a no-go. Food's way overpriced too. Supposed to be a bakery, but the bread's bland and the cookies taste like cardboard. 

I'll still go there for a change of scenery, but wouldn't recommend it for much else."

"Underwhelming experience at too crowded a pool with too much repetition in amenities and not enough shade."

"Skip it, kid. This place ain't worth your time. Too many people, not enough space. They got one bar, and it takes forever to get a drink. And don't even get me started on the prices. Lockers for 40 bucks a day? Waters for 10? Forget about it. If you want a good time, go somewhere else. The crowd's alright, but the venue itself is lacking. Stick to Encore Beach, Wet Republic, or Marquee. They know how to do it right."

"Methinks I do adore Jimmy Buffett,
But his Margaritaville Cafe, alas, doth not meet my expectations.
The victuals, though passable, are not worth the tariff,
Nor the interminable wait, which doth try my patience.

In sooth, there be some positives to note,
Adownstairs and upstairs, fun decorations abound,
And 'tis connected to a shop that doth sell
All manner of Margaritaville merchandise, in abundance.

But, alack! The negatives do outweigh the good,
The lines, they doth stretch on, like a serpent in the wood,
The fare, it doth cost a pretty penny, and doth not impress,
Dumbed down, perchance, for the masses, it doth seem.

And, oh! The margaritas, they doth leave much to be desired,
Processed, they doth taste, like a drink that's been conspired.

In conclusion, I would not return, methinks,
For though 'tis a place of revelry, 'tis not worth the stink.
But, friends, they doth insist, they doth wish to give it a try,
So, mayhap, one day, I shall return, and see if it doth improve, by and by."

"Methinks 'twas a Wednesday afternoon when first I stepped within this bakery's doors. The folk who worked there seemed most cordial, and their wares didst tempt mine eyes. Macarons, I had heard tell of them, but ne'er had tasted. Alack! I knew not what to expect, thinking them perchance a cake, with frosting 'twixt two halves. Thus, I chose five varieties to sample: peach, vanilla almond, vanilla, raspberry, and the blue one (alas, its name escapes me now). But lo! When I didst bite into them, they were o'er sweet for mine taste, akin to cookies in texture, yet lacking that certain je ne sais quoi. Mayhap others shall find joy in them, but alas, they didst not agree with mine own palate. Still, I shall return anon, to try other delights this bakery doth offer."

"Wife and I had dinner there last night. Food tasted like it came straight from a can, served cold. Server was friendly, but their 'homemade' claim is bullshit. Just 'cause it's cooked in a pot don't make it homemade."

"Walmart. Rarely go. Mess. Carts everywhere. Disorganized sections. Like a bad bargain basement sale. No one cares. Can't find products. Trash. Competition comes to town. Don't compete. Make store look like trash instead. Really?

Walk to cash. Light on. Cashier missing. Stand there. Decide if we pay. Manager notices. Calls girl back. Four cashiers. One walks away. People wait. 

Handicapped parking limited. Impossible to find spot. They don't care. Shameful."

"Walking the Strip, saw this joint. Looked cool, outdoor seating, overlookin' it. Being from NY, knew it was gonna be a hit. Tried to get a table, but had to walk to the back, through all the tables, then back to the front. Strange, but whatever. Server was nice, helpful, but hard to get his attention after. Ordered a burger 'cause I couldn't decide, figuring it was hard to screw up. Boy, was I wrong. Meat was near inedible. BF ordered a double burger, but it didn't come with a bun, so we had to pay extra. He was fine with it, but he eats anything. Didn't eat my burger, so had room for dessert. Deep-fried Oreo sundae! Damn! See why they're known for their desserts. Really good, creative, decadent. Could only eat like 25% of it between me and the BF. Wouldn't go back to that spot, maybe try the NYC location, stick to desserts."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let this humble bard advise thee well. Forsooth, avoid thou Garcia's pizza, lest thou wish to suffer woe. 'Tis a tidy sight from without, enticing one to enter in, But alas, the pizza within doth pale in comparison to its kin. Save thy taste buds, dear friend, and seek sustenance elsewhere, forsooth."

"Burger craving hit, Yelp open. Read reviews, sold. Mapquested, on the road. Hole in the wall, who cares? Double with chili and cheese, please. Driving home, excitement builds. First bite, disappointment. Chili bland, can't taste it. Second bite, same story. Burger good, like In-N-Out. Chili, no thanks. Salt added, still bad. Fries meh, refried maybe? In-N-Out better. Chili, nope. Cheeseburger, yes. Back to eating, reluctantly."

"Sweet Tomatoes? More like Sour Disappointment. Packed with soccer moms and their rugrats, this joint's got nothing on me. Salad bar's alright, but overpriced and skimpy on the good stuff. Name's a lie, too - no sweet cherry tomatoes in sight. What's the point?

They try to sell it as healthy, but it's just carb city. Pasta, bread, mac and cheese, soup - not exactly what I'd call a healthy option. Where's the protein? Leave me hungry, it does.

Overpriced and low-quality, this place ain't worth it. You can do better, kid."

"Rented from Payless Car Rental, regretted it. Agent was polite, efficient, but pushed insurance and gas fill-ups. Refused 'em, got hit with a $20 mandatory roadside assist surcharge. BS. Could've gotten a better ride from Dollar or Alamo. Won't be back. Try E-Z Car Rental instead."

"Bouganvilla was a bust. Drinks came quick, but things went south after that. Food took forever, and it wasn't worth the wait. Runny eggs were the main offender. I liked the sourdough toast and hashbrowns, though. Bacon was strange. He had a burger and fries...fries were great, but his burger was pink, even though he asked for medium. We hit the wheel of fortune machine on the way out. I dropped in five bucks and walked out with sixty-five, a Miller Lite, and a vodka tonic. Our winnings covered the cost of the meal. A couple hours later, I was worshiping a trash can. I blame the eggs. The only reason this place gets two stars is because of the service. Our server was good, prompt, and did everything right. I liked her. Just wish she had better food to serve."

"Methinks 'twas naught but mediocrity that greeted mine eyes at Lee's, where Vietnamese sandwiches lay claim to fame. Alack! The memories of yore, when well-made banh mi graced mine lips, didst make this pitiful display seem all the more vexing. Nay, not a whit of judgment doth escape mine gaze, for oft hath mine eyes deceived mine taste. Yet, within those walls, a scant few Vietnamese wares were sold, as if an afterthought, a paltry offering to placate the gods of culinary tradition. Alas, how poorly didst they strive to emulate the grandeur of their brethren across the land! Forsooth, the grilled pork sandwich, thit nuong, that once didst stir mine soul, now seemed but a pale imitation of its former self. The bread, alack! Was all that saved it from complete ignominy, being both hot and fresh, with a satisfying crunch to boot. But lo! The pork, devoid of flavor, didst fail to impress, and the sauce, a strange and unpleasant concoction, didst leave mine taste buds in disarray. Verily, a disappointment it was, and naught but woe doth fill mine heart."

"Place didn't impress me. Loved Fate, great chef. Eat out daily, lunch or dinner. Service was poor, server had an attitude. Whole table felt it. Tapas, sure, but $100 food check without drinks? Too much. Leave hungry? No way. Won't be back."
"Herbox, been there a few times. Last visit, menu was off. Not the same. Missing the familiar faces, the friendly staff. Used to be a fave spot in Scottsdale, now? Not so much."

"Place gave me attitude. Guy taking order talked down to me. Didn't like that. Signs were handwritten, explained too much. Decor was good though, like a noodle stand in southeast Asia. Enjoyed my Cambod-Ican noodle soup, not usually a fan of pho. Friend's crispy noodles tasted like cheap Chinese takeout. Vegetable curry was too spicy for my other friend. Payment system was weird. Why not just take payment at the window? Had to put on my coat to signal them to bring the check. Strange."
"Food was good. Soda machine had plenty of flavors."

"Enchiladas at La Parilla Suiza? More like a sad, soggy mess. My girl's translation of the name? Spot on. Chicken enchiladas with green sauce, recommended by the server. Expecting gooey cheese and meat, got a dab of chicken and a twangy sauce instead. Not exactly what I had in mind. Service? Non-existent. Our server disappeared after delivering the food, leaving us with a filthy carafe of water that looked like it belonged in a Star Trek episode. All in all, not impressed."

"Four of us visited this joint, all ordering 9 oz. filets, medium rare. But they came out brown, no red. I told the waiter, he agreed to take it back. Cook asked if we wanted it cooked more. Really? Steaks were overcooked. Waiter didn't say a word, no apology or offer to adjust the bill. Not how Wisconsinites run a supper club. Can't recommend this place no more."
"Macaroni Grill. Been there, done that. Not much to rave about. Service? Forgettable. Prices, reasonable."

"Hark! My maiden visit doth unfold,
This eve, at yonder winged hold.
The service, fair and courteous, didst allow
A taste of sauces, and guidance, too.
The wings, alas! not worth the quest,
Yet fries, in abundance, didst bless.
A steal, indeed! For little cost,
The victuals, clean, and naught lost.
In campus' heart, this place doth thrive,
A gem, amidst the scholar's drive."

"This joint was just okay. Food was meh, atmosphere wasn't doing it for me. Servers seemed like they couldn't care less. Had the lunch buffet, which was decent. Naan was the highlight, though. Fresh and unlimited."

"Urgent Care, huh? Sounds like they'll take care of you quick and proper, like a doctor but faster. But no, not quite. First off, you gotta wait even when the place is empty. And second, all they got is nurse practitioners, which ain't bad, but they can't prescribe the good stuff, ya know? So you end up getting less treatment than you would from your regular doc and you gotta wait forever for it. Makes you wonder why bother with Urgent Care at all."

"Hark! My spouse and I, first-time visitors, do declare
This Taiwanese fare doth not please mine taste, I fear.
The prices, too, do seem a mite steep,
For quality of victuals, not quite up to keep."

"First-time try at this joint. Prices, reasonable. Grub, subpar. Over easy, came out medium-hard. Not pleased. Pancakes, taste like crusty rags. Ugh. Bacon, hashbrowns, decent. Service, meh. Won't return. Too many better breakfast spots in the area. Peoria Cafe or Brothers, recommend."

"The joint's got style, no question. But it's packed tighter than a foxhole on D-Day. And the tunes? Forget about it. They're playing the same old crap they were spinning back in '03. Now, if you're a hick from Iowa, fresh off the turnip truck, maybe it's worth a gander. But if you've seen the bright lights of the big city before, just stick to the grub."

Saturday, 1:30 pm. Long line. $37 plus tax per person, totaling $41 for nine of us. Sat at a round table. Presentation over substance. Exotic dishes, small portions. Beef brisket with mashed potatoes, best dish. Black forest cheesecake, best dessert. Lights off, food put away at 3:00 pm sharp. No warning from the cashier.

"A gel polish change didst I receive, for both mine hands and feet,
And verily, I must confess, great disappointment didst it bring.
$40, a steep price to pay, for naught but a gel polish change,
No pedicure, alas, to make mine feet look fair and bright.

She cut mine nails too short, and now they resemble french tipped nubs,
Ugly and unsightly, a sorry state, indeed.
I had thought to get acrylics, but the cost didst give me pause,
So gel manicure, I settled for, though naught but mediocre, it was.

The Yelp discount, I didst mention, and $12 off, they didst take,
But still, the price, didst seem quite steep, for what didst they make.
No tip, didst I give, for service poor, didst she provide,
But still, a token, I didst leave, in courtesy, I didst presume.

Nevermore, shall I return, to this place, I do declare,
For service bad, and prices high, didst leave me in disrepair."

"Don't do reviews, but this joint warrants a bitchin'. Three stars? Bullshit. Overpriced and underwhelmin'. Pesto shrimp spaghetti? Tastes like cardboard. Shrimp's alright, but the noodles? Flavorless. Calamari's decent, service is meh. Don't waste your cash."

"Wanted to hit this spot for a bit. Got a good table in the lounge, band was setting up. Ordered some tacos - carne asada and pork were alright, shrimp was decent. Beer was overpriced ($17 pitchers), but the ambience made it worth it. Place was sweltering, though. And, oh yeah, asked for a bottle of Bud Light and got a can instead. Next time, I'm heading to America's Taco Shop for their killer carne asada."

We hit up Surrender for MDW, eager to catch Calvin Harris. Prepaid tix got us in quick, even though we rolled up at 11:30pm. But once inside, the vibe fizzled fast.

The outdoor setup was cool, but the execution sucked. Calvin was spinning at the indoor part of the club, but nobody could hit the dance floor unless they shelled out $3000 for a table. What's the point of letting people in if they can't even dance? A waste of cash on the cover, and it wasn't cheap either - $100 for dudes and $40 for ladies. Skip this joint and find a better spot to get your groove on.

"I came back for round two, thinking maybe things had changed. But nope, same old story. Ordered the Green Chile cheeseburger, and the waiter warned me it'd be hot. Yeah, okay, whatever. So I get it, and it looks like they just threw some food on a plate. Sloppy as hell. I take off the top bun, and there's barely any green chile. Ask for a side, and it shows up. It's hot, but it tastes like straight out of a can. Gross. My girl's meal wasn't much better. She got some Green Chile Chicken thing, and it looked like a mess. Rice, beans, cheese, and some chicken soup or something. She said it was too salty. Not New Mexican food, just Tex-Mex with Hatch chile."

"Awesome joint, too bad we didn't get to chow down. Decor was top-notch, but the grub took forever. Sixty minutes and still no food. Had to bail. Shame, I was looking forward to it. Now I'll never know if it was any good."

"I walked into ATS, drawn by their claim of serving the best carne asada in Phoenix. But when I got to the counter, the staff didn't seem to give a damn about helping customers. I ordered my burrito, and they gave me a number and told me to take a seat. While I waited, I noticed other customers looking just as confused as I was about the poor service. When my burrito finally arrived, I was famished. But let me tell you, it was tiny. I'm not one to complain about small portions, but this thing was laughable. It came with a lime wedge that was dried out and looked like it had been sitting there for a day. The carne asada was flavorless and had a weird texture. All in all, this was a pretty disappointing meal. Their sign might say 'Best Carne Asada in Phoenix,' but that's a load of crap. This place isn't even close."

"Two stars for a lackluster experience. Standard SS fare, but they skipped the calamari, a highlight in Chi-town. Unacceptable. Location and atmosphere leave much to be desired - underwhelming, like a Legal Seafoods in the burbs. Skip it if you're in Vegas."

"Fair fare, but dearly bought, I say,
Like Olive Garden or Red Lobster's way,
With service five stars, I do declare,
But price, alas, doth leave me cold and grey."

"Vegas, baby! Wanted an Eiffel Tower drink, but no way, José! Stickin' with Fat Tuesday from now on. This drink's a joke, folks. You wanna get plastered quick? Sure thing! But let me tell ya, it's gonna cost ya. $16.99 for a drink that'll leave ya feelin' like crap. And don't even get me started on the mix. Guy just dumped a bunch of booze at the bottom of the cup and topped it off with strawberry daiquiri. I poured out the last bit myself. No thanks, pal. If ya want the cup, sure thing. But for the alcohol? Fat Tuesday's your best bet."

"O, woe is me, dear friends, for I do find
This theatre most vexing, and thus, I do avoid
Its confines, opting instead for other haunts
That lie beyond the city's bustling bounds.

Firstly, its location doth elude my grasp,
A secret hideaway, concealed from view,
And were it not for yonder sign that doth direct,
I might have ne'er discovered it, I do confess.

And once within, my troubles did ensue,
For at the concession stand, confusion did reign,
The popcorn, cold and stale, did fail to impress,
And left me in a state of utter dismay.

The seats, old, cramped, and hard, did cause me woe,
And in the darkness, I did feel quite alone,
A feeling strange and foreign, ne'er before known,
In other cinemas, where crowds did gather and moan.

Thus, I do choose to shun this place, my friends,
And seek elsewhere, entertainment that doth endure,
For this theatre, doth fail, in every way,
To meet my expectations, and doth leave me cold, I pray."

"Nice joint. Big, clean rooms. Service? Not so much. Stuffy vibe, unfriendly staff. Checkout chick didn't give a damn. No 'how was your stay?' or 'thanks for choosing us.' Just handed over the bill like she was doing us a favor. I ain't hard to impress, but for what we paid, some fake hospitality would've been nice."

"Me and the boyfriend were hitting up Fremont Street, feeling peckish. This joint looked like a decent spot, and the decor wasn't half bad - 80's jungle vibes, you know? Server was friendly, attentive too. Food? Not the best. Had a few dishes that were just okay, but hey, it filled me up. Carne asada, they called it a steak dinner buffet, but it was basically just thin strips of meat. Still, it hit the spot. Had to go back to the carving station a bunch of times, they weren't exactly generous with the portions. All in all, it did the job, but I wouldn't go back."

"Hark, my sandwich did take a mere half-hour to arrive! By Jove, 'tis a wonder, a feast fit for the gods! Yet, alas, my friends do swear by this place, and I, a humble bard, doth find it lacking. The din, the noise, doth make it hard to hear, to converse with one's neighbor. The serving maid, she doth bring forth sustenance, and doth present the bill, but doth not ask if aught be needed. No refills, no ale, nay, not even napkins. Rudeness personified, I say! If thou dost not wish to tend to guests, then, prithee, why art thou here? The only virtue, methinks, lies in the multitude of televisions, each displaying a different sport, a true delight!"

"Hark! What's this? A shopping place so dull,
With naught but common stores to enthrall.
The word 'Premium' doth not belong,
For here is naught but mediocrity to ponder.

In summer's heat, a respite from the sun,
But alas! The shops, they are so few,
And those that be, are not of great renown,
Leaving me to seek elsewhere my fortune.

Unless they change, and bring new delights,
I shall bypass this place with all my might."

"Alack, my dearest friend, how vexed I am!
This place, that once did hold such promise, doth fail.
The brisket, though tender, lacked the flavor true,
And fried chicken, o'er salted, did my taste buds wound.
Meaty Mac, with blue cheese, did leave me cold,
But coleslaw, sweet and crunchy, did my spirits lift.
Alas, the price, $35, did seem quite steep,
For service, poor, the waitress did not keep.
But nay, my friend, do not despair,
For other places there be, that may yet please thee there."

"Hark! My gym doth lie near to mine abode,
In a pleasant quarter, where folk do stroll.
Many machines for cardio, treadmills aplenty,
Yet, alas! Trainers do pester me so,
With offers to guide, and their wares to sell.
Their calls, like pestilence, do pour upon me,
Two on the morrow, from diverse men, did tell.
I shall, ere long, my membership rescind,
For peace, and quiet, are my heart's desire."

"Lunch at Carson Street Cafe was a bust. My wife and I have been coming here for years, but today was a disappointment. Service was slow and the waiter didn't seem to care. My Cobb salad was flavorless, but my wife's Oxtail Stew was better. The service was subpar, which is unusual for this place. I'm worried it'll become just another overpriced joint now that it's under new management. It's a shame, I've always liked the Golden Nugget."

"WHA WHA! Didn't wait long 'cause I was with six girls, but then found it was a twenty-dollar cover. Since it was late, we decided to skip it, but as we were walkin' out, got handed free passes, so we turned around and went back in. Awesome interior, but the point of a nightclub is to dance. Can't do that when you're packed in like sardines. Don't care how good you look comin' in, you'll look nasty if you're sweaty and wasted. Might be a strategic move to push your way into the crowd, though, 'cause it's hard to fall down with all those people holdin' you up. Those girls in the pools are real depressin', too. When nice girls say hi and ask how you're doin' and you just stare ahead and strike a pose, you look like you've been trafficked. Either that or you gotta get wasted to make it through your shift."

Hark! I say, good sir, how strange it be,
That thou, a purveyor of fast food, shouldst forget,
To ask what drink I wished, and instead,
Didst hand me, without word or query, a Coke.

I reckon 'tis a small mistake, and so,
I chose to let it pass, and not make a show.
But lo! When I opened up the bag,
I found fries, and not the onion rings I'd tagged.

I mentioned this to thee, and thou,
Didst fetch the proper food, and handed it to me anew.
Yet, in thy haste, thou didst forget,
To offer apology, or even a regret.

Now, mark my words, good sir,
This lack of care, doth leave a sour taste,
In my mouth, and doth besmirch,
The reputation of this, thy Burger King estate.

Still, I shall give thee, another chance,
For convenience's sake, and proximity to my dance.
But, prithee, take heed, and learn,
To mind the details, lest thou lose,
The custom of thy patrons, one by one.

"Pimms we did imbibe, my dear, and 'twas a wondrous draught indeed. But alack, the victuals that did follow, they did not meet our expectations, forsooth. Bland and uninspired, they did taste, like a dish cooked by a novice, without the slightest hint of flair or finesse. And yet, we did return, in hope of fairer fare. High tea, we did partake, with scones most delectable, but alas, the tiny sandwiches, stale and lacking in zest, they did disappoint. And salmon, oh so red and gleaming, from a packet, 'twas plain to see."

"Veggies looked rough, like they'd been sitting out too long. Carrots were limp, tomatoes were mealy. Sweet and sour sauce lacked punch. Service was good though, server was friendly and attentive. Maybe next time will be better."

"Went to this joint with my fiancée. Ordered steak omelets. Hers came loaded with steak, mine had three measly pieces. Asked 'em about it, they said it's pre-weighed. Bullshit. Pointed out the difference in our plates, told 'em I want my money's worth. They brought me a side of steak bits. Twenty minutes later. Rude as hell."

"Went on a weekday for dinner. Service was mediocre, same with the grub. Nothin' special. Place is old, smells funny when you walk in. More of a dive bar than a restaurant. Better options for oysters and other eats."

"Five stars? Don't get it. Food's as dull as a butter knife. 'Spose to be Vietnamese, but where's the flavor? Spices, herbs, all that jazz. None of that here. Jeff's got too much salt, like they emptied a shaker on it. Salt on Vietnamese? No thanks. In town for the weekend, so might come back. Liked the spring rolls, though. Vegas and vegans, not a great combo."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A humble tavern, full of wondrous dishes, doth please mine eyes and taste. Yet, alas, the wait doth stretch on, like a never-ending line of schoolchildren at play. The patrons, with their great importance, doth take up space, and the parking lot, a chaotic mess, doth test mine patience. Verily, I say, for such a bustling place, a larger home would befit these noble cooks. Two stars, I give, forsooth, for prices, in my mind, should be more modest, anon."
"Went for a quick dinner, place was dead. Took us 20 minutes to get sat, hostess was snotty. Food was good, though."

"Restaurant not great. Price high, pasta mediocre. Gorgonzola chicken pasta, disappointing. Cafeteria taste. Kid-friendly, bread good, clam appetizer decent. Prime rib, tasty. Pasta taken care of. Friendly service, but food not worth price."

"Mon Ami Gabi, Las Vegas. Good food, average service. Wife and I had fond memories from 11 years ago, glad to see they're still around. French Onion Soup, still delicious. Young hostess, rude and unhelpful. Told us to wait until our whole party arrived, wouldn't give estimate. Seated immediately when family showed up. Menu simple, food good but not great. Salads forgettable. Fillet Mignon, very good. Bill $205 for four adults, toddler, baby. 18% gratuity added. Better years ago. With better service, three stars easily."

"Hark, what woe is this? My locks, they do proclaim
A tale of woe, a story of shame.
For every time I come to this place,
They do butcher my hair, with nary a trace
Of skill or art, they hack and they chop,
Leaving me in a state of utter hop.

A good haircut, it doth take its time,
Fifteen to twenty-five minutes, a fair rhyme.
But here, they rush and they hurry,
In and out in five minutes, oh so sorry.
I'll ne'er return, no more shall I grace
This place with my presence, such disgrace."

"Hark! A feast fit for a king, they did proclaim,  
With shrimp wontons and ramen noodles in its name.  
But alas, the broth, so bland and weak,  
Did leave my taste buds in a state most meek.  
A disappointment, indeed, for all had said,  
This dish, a culinary masterpiece, was bred.  
But nay, I found not even a hint of zest,  
In this soup that was supposed to be the best.  
So, let this be a lesson, my dear friends,  
To never judge a dish by its outward trends.  
For though the portion may be generous and fair,  
A flavorless broth can leave one quite unfair."

"I don't review a joint until I've been there at least twice. But, if I ain't plannin' on goin' back, I'll make an exception. 

I gave 'em two stars 'cause I was feelin' pretty rough from a week-long stomach flu and thought this place might help me break my fast. Turns out, it wasn't the best choice. Don't know if they got good grub, but I ain't goin' back to find out. 

I ordered five tacos, a decent deal for $4.95. Thing is, they were deep-fried taquitos, not real Mexican tacos. Liked the cheese, guac, and lettuce, but didn't care for what it was sittin' on top of."

"O, Five Guys, how art thou failing me? Thy burgers, once a feast for mine eyes, now doth pale in comparison to days of yore. In Virginia, thy patties didst overflow with juicy delight, yet here in Arizona, they doth resemble naught but a mere shadow of their former self. Alack, the beef, wherefore doth it hide?

I didst give thee chance upon chance, hoping against hope that thou wouldst return to form. Alas, 'twas not meant to be. Thy patties, once a sturdy foundation for a feast, now doth resemble a fragile leaf, unable to withstand the test of time.

Farewell, Five Guys, for now. Mayhap in six months' time, thou shalt redeem thyself, and my faith in thee shall be restored. Until then, adieu, and may thy fries, at least, remain a constant source of joy."

"A varied choice for fabrics and upholstery, indeed,
Some prices fair, while others border on the absurd.
Two stars for service, alack, how poorly done,
Each visit, a ghost I feel, ignored by everyone.
A numbered system, they claim, but nay, 'tis not true,
For those who serve, their minds elsewhere, anew.
Many workers, yet none with customers' plight,
Thus, two stars for wares, but service, a sorry sight."

"Sat down for breakfast. No service for ten. Unsure whose section we were in. Food was mediocre. Had to ask four times for water. Decent dinner before. May return for dinner. Better breakfast spots in town."

"First night in Vegas, tough to tell if it was day or night. Hunger pangs, daze, and delirium had us in its grip. No clue how we ended up here, but this joint was a steal - cheap, packed with options, and screaming for a facelift. Slot machines drain your wallet? Come here, eat cheap. Eight bucks a pop, that's the price."

"Methought I had a wondrous facial, fair and bright,
But lo, two days hence, a reaction did take flight.
I bought some potions, priced at eighty-five,
And thus, a maiden in the spa didst I contrive.

She asked me why, and I didst tell her plain,
And then, a check, she said, would be my bane.
A credit voucher, she didst give to me,
And said the manager, wouldst it approve, doth see.

Four days passed, and still, no check didst come,
And so, I penned this tale, in bitter tune.
No care didst they take, of my poor face,
All chapped, peeling, red, in sorry grace.

Their concern, was but for their own gain,
And thus, I shall not be their guest again.
Forsooth, the Arizona Grand Spa, doth lack,
In courtesy, and care, for those who do attack."

"Lola Lo's alright, had some good times there. Friendly bar staff, tasty cocktails, and a pretty atmosphere. But it's pricey, cover charge is steep, and the music's often too soft or just plain bad. Dance floor's too small for a real club experience. Wouldn't choose to go here, but won't say no if others want to."

"Verily, for twenty-three years have I graced this place with mine own presence. 'Twas once my most cherished haunt, wherein I didst savor with great relish a humble chili cheese dog. Alas, how the winds of time doth blow! For now, 'tis naught but an overpriced fast food establishment, devoid of that quaint charm which once didst make it so endearing. Fie upon it, say I! Forsooth, I shall seek elsewhere to satiate mine hunger, perchance at yonder pirate game, whereat least I may procure a similar repast for a mere five dollars."

"Fair patio, with fountains soft and sweet,
Yet, alack, the scent of chlorine doth greet,
Our nostrils, at dinner, with displeasure,
And mar our joy, with its unpleasant measure.

The victuals, middling, yet passable, were brought,
By a serving-man, with Yelp's gift, unsought,
A burrito, green chili chicken, we did choose,
Laden with cheese, our arteries did froze.

Alas, the flavors, save cheese and heat, did hide,
And chicken, in that mass, did quietly reside,
But, for the patio's charm, and water's song,
This place, in business, might not tarry long."

"Hark, what news is this? My Westin stay hath slipped,
Where once we stayed for Furniture Market's grip,
With free parking, abundant, and beds so fine,
And Starbucks in the lobby, a wondrous find.

But now, alas, the service doth decline,
Despite our status, Preferred Members divine,
My chamber, hot and muggy, with AC so weak,
Didst call for aid, but temp didst not abate.

At last, a solution, move me to another floor,
But nay, I wished not to move my goods once more,
A second man, with haste, didst fix the flaw,
The air didst flow, and all was well, I vow.

Yet still, the floor, unswept, and trash didst lie,
In room, the coffee, weak, and creamer didst die,
But life, alas, is short, and troubles pass,
For now, I shall not dwell on woes of the past."

"Went to the sushi joint late last night. Only ones there at 8pm on a Saturday. Food was alright, nothing special. Impressed they had some dishes ready, but can't say the rolls were fresh. Not bad if you order and they make it on the spot, but at a kaiten sushi place, you don't expect that. Hard to find, behind a few buildings, and minimal signage until you're in the parking lot. Maybe that's why it was empty. Clean and nice inside, staff was friendly."

"Prices skyrocketed since my last visit. Twenty-one bucks for a meatball burger and fries?! Twenty-three for a goat cheese Caesar with chicken?! And don't even get me started on the Chinese chicken salad for twenty-one dollars. Side of fries for nine bucks?! Ridiculous. Sure, the place looks nice and some of the grub is decent, but at these prices, I just can't see it lasting. And let's not forget the sixteen dollar club sandwich with fries when this joint was still Augustus Cafe. What a joke. I went to Mon Ami Gabi instead and got a fantastic steak and fries at a beautiful outdoor table for twenty-five bucks. Give me a break."

"Tried this joint three times now. Close to home, so thought it'd be convenient. First two times, no big deal. Today though, they got my order wrong - again. And forgot some of my grub. Not worth the drive back. Giving up on this dump."

"Alas, how vexing! After hearing much praise,
My heart did yearn to partake of their fare.
But lo, the dishes that did grace our plates,
Did leave me feeling woeful and quite irate.

The corn, once frozen, now lay mushy and still,
And tacos, seasoned strange, did naught fulfill.
Yet one dish, my husband's burger, did please,
Hot and juicy, a savory delight, indeed.
We devoured it, and the rest, we did dismiss."

"Alack, our maiden visit didst not bode well,
'Twas but a middling experience, naught to tell.
The servant at the counter, ignorant of the fare,
Didst bring us not what we didst ask, a sorry affair.

The taste was fair, but eggplant, sautéed with skin so tough,
Didst leave us discontent, and in a sour enough.
The service, too, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
No smiles, no greetings, nor a single merci.

A pox upon the place, whose staff doth seem so bland,
As if they cared not for their customers' hand.
I fear, my dear, we shall not return again,
For such a lack of zeal doth make a loyal patron wain.

But wait, the gentleman with spectacles, perchance the master?
Didst show a scowl, and scant courtesy, a proper disaster.
So, shall we give it one more chance, anon?
Or shall we flee, and seek a better inn?"

"Ten silver coins for a meal most plain? Aye, 'tis a price most steep, I say. Chicken sandwich, with lettuce, tomato, and bun, yet naught but common fare, I fear. And salad, small, with naught but greens and dressing, doth not a feast make. Meh, I say, to such a meager repast. I shall return, perchance, another day, with hope that fare more grand doth wait."

"Methinks 'tis my third visit to Hit Mac's since my arrival in CLT three years past. Verily, I must confess, my expectations were not met.

The brisket, upon which they pride themselves, didst fail to impress me. Tough and chewy, it lacked the quantity I had hoped for. Alas, the sides didst not fare much better, being naught but mediocre.

And yet, despite my disappointment, I shall not deny the establishment its due. The atmosphere doth possess a certain je ne sais quoi, the beer list doth impress, and the service doth border on excellence. Methinks, too, the music doth strike the proper chord.

Shall I return? Perchance, anon, whene'er I find myself in the vicinity. But, alack, I shall not venture forthwith, eager to partake of their culinary delights."

"Hark! The victuals were fair, a four, I say,
But service, alack! A single star doth sway,
Our server, kind and diligent, did strive,
Yet kitchen's woes did cause us much to strive,
Food came, a tardy thirty minutes passed,
And then, in bits, o'er fifteen minutes vast,
Alack! 'Tis clear, they lack management skill,
Someone must guide them, lest their fate be sealed,
Yet, fortunate am I, not to dwell in Phoenix,
Thus, this ill fate shall ne'er my steps impede."

"Papa Del's, a place of sustenance and cheer,
Yet, alack, their service doth leave much to fear.
The pizzas, oh, they take their time,
But all else moves at a snail's slow climb.

The staff, unfriendly and full of disdain,
Do roll their eyes and show scant gain.
A rude lot, they, with nary a smile,
Leave one to wonder if they do beguile.

But, lo, there be a way to avoid
The cramped seats and the surly crowd.
Order in, and thou shalt find delight
In reheated pies that taste just right.

Their sausage pizza, a true delight,
Doth make the journey worth the fight.
And friends from Chicagoland, they do adore
This pizza, and so, it doth explore.

So, if in Champaign thou dost reside,
Papa Del's, the best deep dish provide.
But if from elsewhere thou dost come,
Better options, there be, ere some.

"O, Bay City Diner, how I do miss thee! 

Du Pars, a place of sustenance, yet priced so high, 
For breakfast, simple fare doth not justify 
The cost, three friends and I didst pay, oh me! 
Above $50, a sum most grave, for mere eggs, toast, 
And pancakes, naught but common fare, I do declare. 

And dinner, too, doth suffer from such prices, 
A diner, plain and simple, on Fremont Street, 
Not the strip, where luxury doth reign supreme, 
Yet Bay City once, a place of good cheer, 
Now lost, alas, to Du Pars' steep fee."

"Can't friggin' believe all the rave reviews about this dump. Two stars is too damn generous. Used to be a regular at this joint back when I lived in Vegas, but now it's a freakin' joke. Went there early January, and it was a total disaster. Food was bland, service was slow, no chicken katsu, and they only take cash? Get with the times, people! It's 2011 for crying out loud! Loved this place when I was younger, but now I wouldn't waste my time or money. If you're looking for real Hawaiian/Island grub on the mainland, head to Cali and I'll give you some solid recs."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, hear my plea,
For justice doth demand equality.
In clothing, size doth matter much,
For those of ample girth, 'tis a cruel crutch.

SAMs and Walmart, both do fail,
In catering to the larger folk's tale.
They charge more, and sizes doth lack,
Discriminating, leaving them in the black.

Join me, friends, in this righteous quest,
To end the bias, and do our best.
Let all, regardless of size, be treated fair,
And clad in garb that doth flatter their hair."

"Service good, food no. Pasta undercooked for all 14 of us. Other customers sending meals back too. Manager said they're using new pasta, gotta learn how to cook it. Gave us a break on the bill though."

"A spacious chamber, with a bed of moderate worth,
A sofa, worn and faded, did little for our earthly form.
The shower, poor and wretched, did naught but bring us woe,
I booked the room, enticed by price and rating, thou know.
Four stars, alas, it was not, and thus we did depart,
With naught but disdain for the Rio's victuals and its art."

"Aye, good sir, thou dost enquire about this place,  
If 'tis a spot where thou canst find some grace,  
In terms of price, and food that doth please,  
And if it doth compare to other buffets, if thou please.  

Alas, my friend, I must inform thee, nay,  
For though the price may be low, the food doth not stay,  
In thy stomach, nor doth it taste so sweet,  
For all we had, my wife and I, did meet,  
A fate most dire, a taste most bland and dry,  
And cold, as if 'twere frozen in the sky.  

The selection here, alack, doth leave much to be desired,  
Compared to other buffets, whereon we have tired,  
Our taste buds, with a vast array of dishes,  
Leaving us full, and in a state of blissful wishes.  
But here, alas, the choices are few and far between,  
So if thou art in search of a spread more bountiful and keen,  
Look elsewhere, good sir, for thou shalt not find,  
At this place, a feast fit for a king, or even a mind.  

Yet still, there be a benefit, a silver lining,  
In the cost, which doth save thee a few pence,  
So if thou art in need of a thrifty repast,  
This place may serve thee well, though not a feast."

"A fair building, with a view most sweet,
Two stars, for that alone, didst meet.
The waitress, with limited knowledge, didst say,
That calamari, overcooked, there was no way.
We asked for lime, but none couldst be found,
And water, with butter, didst spill around.
Pasta, with chunks of cheese, unmelted lay,
Escargot, overcooked, didst not sway.
Steak, with flavor, but poor cut, didst bring,
And desserts, half gone, didst leave us in dismay.
Stuck in the past, with outdated ways,
Save your coins, and dine elsewhere, I pray."
"My Mother's cooking? Bland as me. Lasagna, flavorless. Garlic bread, hard as rock. Salad, wilted. But that chocolate cream pie? Heaven. Made me think she farmed out the baking."

"Spinach appetizer. Not bad. Soupy consistency, little flavor. High prices for a place with a bus name on the door. Couldn't get the game on TV. Waitresses didn't know which one to change. Bottom of the eighth. Watched the rest on my phone."

"Nick's has been a hotspot for my crew. I've had their pies, calzones, and chicken parm. Solid eats. 

Last night, I wanted to mix it up, so I went for the baked ziti with meatballs. Not worth it. The pasta was overcooked, rubbery, and dry. The ends were rock hard and crunchy. The meatballs were the only saving grace. 

Despite the subpar grub, the service was top-notch."
"Meat dishes? Lamb kebab and chicken 65, no thanks. Paneer tikka masala, plenty of gravy but only eight cubes of paneer. Chana masala, just okay. Naan, fresh and soft."

"O, what a disappointment doth lie within this place,
Where food and drink doth fail to bring us grace.
The iPad, a curious choice, doth serve no end,
For wine, a noble beverage, doth descend.

A wine bar, they call it, but alas, 'tis naught,
For wines of quality, they doth not possess.
We ordered tuna, green beans, flatbread, and shrimp,
But found the rest of fare to be of poor stamp.

Indeed, a comparison to Applebee's doth hold,
With wine, a feature that doth make it bold.
But alas, the menu doth remain the same,
For three long years, a sign of little fame.

And desserts, oh how they doth pale and wane,
A sad conclusion to a meal most vain."
"Creeps? Good. Coffee and OJ? Excellent. Service? Slow, even with just two tables. Pricey too."

"Tis a strange and wondrous sight, my friends,
This show with its service so poorly tended.
We had tickets for a certain row,
But lo, they were not to be found, oh woe!

The ticketing system, it seemed, had failed,
And duplicates were printed, tales unveiled.
We searched for an usher, our guide,
To find our seats, our place to reside.

At last, a kindly usher appeared,
And led us to a distant seat, so queer.
Betwixt families, we sat and watched,
As the show began, its tale unclocked.

A silly spectacle, full of laughter,
With pandas dancing, acrobatics to scatter.
No story, it seemed, just random play,
Confusion reigned, night turned to day.

My favorite moment, a man did beat,
A panda, oh so cruelly, to retreat.
Alas, not worth the price, my friends,
Unless free tickets, or discounts, it ends."

"Applebee's doth trouble me, a chain of restaurants vast,
With menu items familiar, and naught else to boast.
The thought of dining there, doth make my stomach churn,
For novelty and charm, it doth not concern.

Chiles, too, doth earn my scorn, with that annoying tune,
Baby back ribs, it doth still echo, like a mournful croon.
Alike, I find their fare, to be of little delight,
Save for the happy hour, which doth shine with some light.

But alas, the atmosphere, doth leave much to be desired,
And so, I say, avoid it, lest ye be consumed by fire.
Gross, gross, gross, I say, and pray, thou heed my words,
For better dining choices, there be, in this fair world."

"Salon's alright, but not my cup of tea. Guy who cut my hair was friendly, but highlights were a mess. Asked for natural, got bleached-out, orange, light brown, and blonde patches. Wouldn't go back, even to fix it. Went elsewhere to get it corrected, which I wish I didn't have to do. Place was clean, staff was friendly, but color service was subpar. That's why I can't give it a high rating."

"Alas, the sushi dish I didst partake,
Was but a mediocre feast for mine eyes.
The service, oh how it didst falter and fail,
A plague upon the waiters, with nary a smile.

They took my order, to a table afar,
And didst not offer an apology, nor a shred of remorse.
Twenty-five minutes passed, and still no sign,
Of our dessert, or any token of their concern.

I vow, nevermore shall I return to this place,
For it doth seem, they do not value mine time or space."

"O, Z Pizza, thou art but a pale imitation,
A poor excuse for a meal, devoid of creation.
Thy crust, rubbery and salty, doth leave much to be desired,
And thy slices, they border on the abyss, so dire.

The staff, they didst not seem to care,
If I, a customer, didst darken their lair.
The owner, he was there, and that, alas,
Didst take precedence o'er my late lunch fare.

Organic, thou sayest? Pray, what dost that matter?
I crave not health, but taste, and that, thou lackest.
I'll have none of thy gluten-free pretenses,
For they but mock me, like a fat child with no defenses.

Thy hype, I do not buy, for thy food, at best,
Is but a mediocrity, a pale imitation of the rest.
I shall order elsewhere, for thou dost not impress,
And thus, adieu, Z Pizza, may thy name be blessed."
"You know what you're getting with Domino's Pizza. It's not the best, but you know that going in. It's like a familiar friend in a strange land. You can count on it, even if it's a bit salty."

"Chompies, I yearned to adore thee, but thou didst fall short. Raised 'round Jewish delis, I longed fer that taste in AZ. Classic faves and matzo ball soup, bagels pleased our crew. But service and grub quality varied. Pickles took forever, arrived as we finished. My order, some fool added bacon, pissin' off this veggie. Offered another, but mistrusted kitchen fare. Meal was free, yet disappointment lingered. No desire to return."

"Ere my wedding day, my mother and I didst venture forth to this salon, seeking a more refined experience than my usual Vietnamese shop. The establishment itself was fair and bright, but alas, the service we received was naught but a waste of gold and time. For $75 a person, the French manicure they gave me looked as though I had done it myself, and my mother's was no better. In dismay, I chose a solid hue for my toes, which was also executed poorly. Though all the staff did speak the English tongue, their skills were lacking, and I shall not return. My face did burn with shame when I departed, but alack, I had no time to seek a proper manicurist ere my nuptials. Mayhap the shoddy work shall not be seen in my wedding photos."

"A taco stand of Korean persuasion, how intriguing! My curiosity, it did arouse, and I, in haste, did venture forth to partake in this culinary experience. Alas, my expectations, they were not met, for though the tacos themselves were fair, the excess of filler, it did vex me sore. They boast of three kinds of lettuce, but, pray tell, who doth get excited o'er leaves? Not I, forsooth! The meat, hidden beneath the verdant mound, was tasty, but the search, it did tax my patience. Their sweet potato fries, a clever ruse, for though they be cut thin, a mountain they did form, yet substance, there was none. A savory dark brown sauce, it was, that came with the tacos, but alas, not enough to make up for the lack of meat and the excess of greens. Disappointment, it did reign, and thus, I left, not full, but empty, and with a heavy heart."

"O, woeful night! Crusty sheets, burnt out lights,
And staff who sought to enter thy chamber,
While thou didst slumber, didst they bother.
At six, a construction crew didst start,
Their work upon the roof, so near thy window,
Didst make a racket, loud and smart.
At seven, the hotel's watchmen came,
Banging on doors, with shouts of blame,
In search of drunken souls, who had fled.
At eight, a maid didst try the door,
Without a knock, her entrance didst implore.
Again at nine, and eleven, she didst come,
Her visits, like a curse, didst seem.
The rooms, so dear, yet dingy, foul,
Not worth the sleep, that thou didst lose,
Aliante's price, doth seem more fair,
Than this, thy wretched, sorry lair."

"Methought I'd try the Spicy Shrimp Tacos, a dish most fair,
With guacamole and cucumber slaw, a feast beyond compare.
But lo, the "spicy" label was naught but a lie,
For in its stead, there was nary a whiff of heat, nor a sigh.

Aye, I didst ponder why such deception doth prevail,
And whether men do think us fools, or if 'tis but a fail.
And so, I didst ask mine host, if perchance he knew,
If there were other options, that my taste might woo.

He told me of a triad, a choice most rare,
Of shrimp, pork, and carne asada, a feast most fair.
But alack, I had not heard, ere I didst order my share,
And so, I didst settle for rice, and naught but air.

The waitress, a merry maid, didst tend to my needs,
But the hostesses, alas, didst seem to have no heeds.
I stood, a-waiting, for a spell, ere they didst see,
That I, a patron, didst require a place to sit and be.

And thus, I didst pay the price, most dear,
For a meal that didst not quite meet mine expectations clear.
So, on my next visit, I shall seek out another place,
Where the fare is more just, and the service doth show grace."
"Food, good. Service, not so much. Four on duty, seven patrons, twenty minutes for the bill? Ridiculous. Try it out."

"At Super Burrito, I didn't love my grub. But, I gotta say, some dodgy characters crashed my taco inspection. We rolled in around 2 AM on a Friday, and as soon as I introduced myself, these three yokels started jabberin' away. They wouldn't shut up, even after we got our food and sat down. It ended with the police showin' up. Got a few minutes of 'em on video, though. Check it out at thtacoreview.com. My tacos were just okay, but we'll give 'em another shot."

"Paradise Bakery, usually good for a quick lunch, but this location needs work. Service is fine, but the food's subpar. Iced tea's stale, watered down, and tastes like crap. Compared it to the one at PV Mall, and it's like night and day. Chicken salad's a letdown too, strawberries and pineapple are soggy and drenched in syrup. Not exactly what I'd call paradise. Might skip this place next time I'm in the area."

"Bf and I hit up Emeril's before the KA show. Convenient spot, inside the MGM where KA was playing. Our server, friendly as can be. I guzzled water like it was going out of style. Never let my glass get empty. Had the tuna tacos, not impressed with the sweetness and the steep price tag. Side of mushrooms, overpriced at nine bucks. Mozzarella salad, perfect balance. Light, flavorful."

"Methinks 'tis one of closest Wendy's to our humble abode, yet my dearest wife and I doth not frequent this establishment as oft as we once did, forsooth. Our orders, alas! have been incomplete, with sandwiches either cold or burnt, and salads wilted beyond recognition.

"Moreover, the lights that doth illuminate the restaurant and the drive-through doth dim and darken ere the night doth reach its prime, leaving us to wonder if indeed 'twere open for business. And on a recent eve, we didst venture forth to partake in their culinary delights, and lo! we were the sole patrons, and yet, the service didst falter and fail, with mistakes aplenty.

"Verily, anon, should the quality and service improve, we wouldst gladly return, forsooth."

The architecture's pleasant, elevator tunes and frills, but the staff's a letdown. Rude and dismissive, they snub customers or turn away without a word. Yesterday, I searched for a book, the computer claimed two copies remained, yet no one assisted me. Thank God for Amazon, they earned $80 from me, a savings of $10. Indigo received nothing and won't anytime soon.

"Sakana, twice now. First, lunch sushi special. More than enough, ten bucks. Cali rolls, standouts. Others, average. Returned for Cali rolls, unagi, edamame. Fresh, thirty minutes old. Unagi, huge, warmed, delicious. Service, slow. Drink refill, waited. Average. Sushi lunch special, yes."
"Grub was decent. Service, though? Pure garbage. Took damn near an hour for our food to arrive. Avoid Saturdays like the plague. Drive a bit further and hit up the joint in Chandler instead."

"CityCenter left me unimpressed. Lacking character, it felt like a soulless Wynn or Bellagio. Aria, tucked away, hard to find. Pretty waterfall, but what's the point if it's hidden? I felt out of place, my inner snob screaming 'I shouldn't be here.' Too big, too impersonal. Glad I saw it, but theory didn't translate to reality."

"Lunched there a couple weeks back. Overpriced, slow, and unimpressive. Reuben was nothing special. Almost died of thirst. Better off hitting up the late-night scene. They got half-decent stouts and livable tunes on weekends."

"Alas, our feline friend didst fall ill,
And we, in sorrow, didst seek aid from the ARL.
The receptionist, with voice so cold and unfeeling,
Didst tell us that euthanasia was our only option,
And that we should wait by the door, for someone to meet us.
A woman came forth, and took the carrier away,
With nary a word of comfort or sympathy.
No kindness was shown, no gesture of solace,
Not even a moment's pause, ere they took our cat away.
It was a day of utmost woe, and the ARL's staff,
Didst make it worse, with their lack of compassion and tact.
Two stars, perchance, for the service they provide,
But naught else, save for the memory of their uncaring ways, doth linger."

Orange Sky, a place of delight,
Where we have dined with joy and delight.
But on November's first eve, alas!
Our experience was quite different, I pass.

The service, good, yet puzzling, too,
For water, none came to serve us anew.
The food, a feast for royalty,
Lobster bisque, king crab, and steak, oh yea!

Yet, within four hours, my dear wife and I,
Fell ill, with violent pangs, nigh unto death.
I told the hostess, with urgency,
But she, unmoved, showed no sympathy or care.

To management, we told our plight,
Hoping they'd act, to make things right.
But they, like rocks, showed no concern,
Leaving us, in sickness, to burn.

For such a price, at Orange Sky,
I'd choose another place, ere I die.
Most restaurants, of this rank, do see,
Food safety, as a top priority.

Not so, at Orange Sky, alack!
They placed us, near the restroom's track.
A special night, turned into woe,
At Orange Sky, where we did not glow.

"Blue Man Group? Seen worse. Seen much worse. But this was still pretty bad. Had some clever moments, interesting ideas, a few cool bits. But overall, underwhelming. Kids might like it. Adults, stick with Cirque's O, Mystere, or Love shows. Or catch Penn & Teller or Amazing Johnathan. Not worth seeing again, even for free."

I called on Execu Car for a work trip in Phoenix. They're affiliated with SuperShuttle, you know. My assistant made the arrangements. I got picked up at the airport, dropped off at a site, and then back to the airport. Three hours, $135 before tip. The driver was pleasant, no issues. Just your run-of-the-mill car service.

"Bah. Don't know. Overpriced grub, mediocre at best. Been in Vancouver too long, spoiled by cheap, good eats. People suggestin' restaurants must be makin' bank. Not impressed with Lemeac. Thirty-six bucks for an entree? Where's the salad, dessert? Lobster, maybe. But that's the norm here, or so they say. Haven't found no amazin' food joints yet. Guess I'm a VanCity girl now."

"Alas, my visit to this place didst leave much to be desired. Forsooth, the Kung Po Shrimp lacked flavor, though the crustaceans themselves were cooked well. And the Hunan beef, oh how it left a strange film upon mine tongue! Verily, I say, 'twas not worth the price, for each dish didst cost more than ten silver pieces. Nay, I shall not return to partake in their dine-in fare."

"To Benny's we didst venture, my daughter and I,
For breakfast, a meal most plain and simple, yet satisfying.
We ordered eggs, bacon, toast, and home fries,
A standard fare, naught else, naught more.

The eggs, alas, were scrambled ill,
With texture strange and unpleasant still.
The bacon, too, was scraggly and thin,
Not worth the price we didst pay within.

My daughter, fair, didst enjoy the home fries,
But I, a man of taste, didst crave the other style.
The coffee, woe is me, was vile and base,
Unfit for noble blood or royal grace.

I paid full price, a sum of ten dollars,
And thus didst expect a meal of greater quality.
But nay, the food was made of synthetic stuff,
Eggs from the microwave, bacon pre-cooked enough.

The service, too, was poor and slow,
Our waitress vanished, ne'er to return anon.
I shall not go to Benny's again,
Forsooth, my heart doth break at the very thought of it, my friend."

"I joined KCBS for thirty-five bucks, thinking I'd score some free tastings at RD. But no dice on the booze, not without a liquor license. And then they overcharged me six bones for a bar of Callebaut dark. Waited half an hour for a refund. Not my best day."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from Crandall's,
Where I, a hungry soul, didst order meals.
Via Grubhub, I didst choose their fare,
But alas! Their service doth leave much to bear.

The first time, I didst enter the wrong address,
And called the restaurant to make amends.
But they, in rudeness, didst deny my plea,
And told me I had the wrong place, indeed.

The second time, I waited for an hour,
But they, in foolishness, didst run out of power.
They called to say they had none left,
And left me with naught but sorrow and bereft.

The third time, they packaged my order awry,
And gave me food that didst not match my cry.
When I didst call to ask for the right fare,
They blamed the delivery man, without a care.

I've never had such poor service, indeed,
And feel compelled to write this Yelp review with speed.
For Crandall's doth lack the skill and grace,
To run a restaurant with proper pace."

"A pox upon this eatery, wherefore art thou, service?
We came ere a trio, our names doth sign in hathte,
Yet nary a glance didst the hostess bestow,
Though we, a duo, didst seek but a small repast.
No room at the bar, alas! a table wide,
Didst wait for the three, who didst sit with ease,
While we, neglected, didst tarry and stew.
Ten minutes passed, and still no menu didst come,
Until at last, a table, similar in size,
Was proffered us, with naught but empty space.
The hostess, fair? Nay, her mood didst sour,
As we, confused, didst order from afar,
And waited, and waited, until our patience didst wane,
For half our feast didst arrive, the rest, lost in vain.
Alas, poor service, doth mar this place,
For oft, with many, have we found grace.
But now, our trust, doth falter and fade,
In this, our latest, ill-fated escapade."

"Lived downtown Madison, ate at most restaurants. Got asked for recs. Fairly discerning, knew the scene. Recent Cento visit? Subpar for a Food Fight joint. Sat at the bar, four bartenders on a Friday night. Poor service, unacceptable. No silverware, had to ask. No napkins, had to ask. Empty water glasses, had to ask. Drinks empty, had to ask. Unattentive, only responded when I flagged someone down. Food was good, not great. Bartenders were nice but clueless, no teamwork or customer service. Impacted our experience, noticed by a couple from Chicago, upset with their service too. Spoke to the manager, receptive, thanked me, asked for my name and number to invite us back. Never called back. Baffling! Won't forget it. Not sure I want to return. Shared my experience with others. Friends had a similar experience the next night at their large table. Bottom line? Better service at Echo Tap and Big Ten Pub. Cento should visit, learn a thing or five."

"Back from London, been jonesing for Indian grub. Found Taza on Eastern, decided to give it a shot. Service top-notch, digs pleasant. Big flat screen, nice touch. Lunch buffet with plenty of options, decent value. But food? Dry, flavorless. Naan and soup, highlights. Guess I'll have to wait 'til my next London trip for legit Indian cuisine."

"I showed up for the standard California Burrito and some Jamaica. Didn't get either. Went through the drive-thru, but the girl taking my order didn't speak my language, so I had to roll down my window and ask about the menu. She didn't speak much English neither, so I settled for a quesadilla. It was alright, can't say it compared to the authentic Mexican grub I get at Vaqueros on 19th and Southern. Food was just alright, my main gripe was the lack of clear English. Customer service was decent otherwise."

"Reserved a table a month ahead for seven, mentioning it was an anniversary dinner. Phoned the night of, asking to push back the time to 7:30 since we were running late. Told we couldn't, had to make it within 15 minutes of the original reservation or no seat. Rushed, made it just in time, and got sat at a big table, likely 'cause all the couple tables were taken. Place was dead empty, only a few other parties. Server was good, but the hostess desk needs work. Food was great, lots of leftovers for lunch the next day. It's a long meal, plan accordingly. Can't do this place quick, it's an experience."

"What a bust. Me and the wife stayed at Planet Hollywood and they gave us buffet coupons. We hit it up for breakfast 'cause we heard good things, but man, were we disappointed. Glad we used those coupons, too, 'cause we didn't pay full price for that crap. Everything was cold. I mean, everything. First time around, we loaded up on eggs, hash browns, bacon, sausage, biscuits and gravy, and not a damn thing was hot. Not even warm. Cold as ice. That's not what you expect from a buffet. We left most of it on our plates and went back for round two, thinking maybe we just needed to mix things up or grab from the bottom of the trays, but nope, still cold. Big letdown, 'cause everything tasted good – those biscuits and gravy would've been great – but who wants cold eggs and meat for breakfast? Makes you wonder how safe the food was, too, if it ain't kept at the right temp. They had a decent selection and variety, but for the price, it's not worth it if the grub's not edible. Had better buffets in Vegas. Won't be going back."

"Methought, fair sir, upon mine way to Jersey Mike's,  
To stop and view the place, and thus didst decide.  
I ordered three tacos, my comrade two,  
And waited thirty minutes, as patient as a saint.  
The hostess, fair and kind, didst proffer apologies,  
Yet nary a snack or drink didst they provide,  
For which I didst think them somewhat stingy.  
The prices, too, didst seem a mite steep,  
Twelve coins for three tacos, a princely sum, indeed.  
The Al Pastor, verily, didst taste most fine,  
Whilst the Chicken Tinga, alas, didst lack all zest."

"Lonnie's got some real crummy staff. Every damn time I go in there, they're rude, slow, and kick me out when they close. But I keep going back for their top-notch cane glass beads. That's all I care about, so screw the rest."

"A pox upon this Table 10, where doth my expectations lie?

Forsooth, I've supped at Delmonicos, Emeril's Fish House, and more,
Yet still, this place didst fail to meet my lofty score.
I took away a star for taste, another for the service slow,
And one for prices high, yet quality doth not show.
In truth, I shall not darken their door again, no more,
For though 'tis better than the Fish House, 'tis still a sore.
That place, a den of woe, most foul and dismal, maketh me shudder."

"Curbside check-in at the east economy lot. Got there 95 minutes before my flight, waited 6 or 7 minutes, then got turned away 'cause I was 88 minutes from takeoff. Guy running the show wasn't too friendly, said his computer wouldn't let him do it. Seemed like an excuse to slack off. If it's really the computer, they should allow a grace period, five minutes would be good. 

Curbside check-in's a great service, but they're getting pretty strict about the luggage. 

Moral of the story: get there 100 minutes early or you'll be pissed and stressed like I was."

"Walked into a joint for a quick bite. Saw fried this 'n that. Fish wings, shrimp gizzards, etc. Was gonna get some gizzards, but the lady said it was wing day. Looked at their 19 sauces, went with sweet 'n sour. Bland, and three outta five wings were undercooked. Don't reckon I'll be back."

"Ain't impressed much with this joint. Been here a few times, and it ain't all that great. Servers keep comin' 'round with carts full of greasy, fried Chinese grub that may or may not be hot. Service is terrible, and only about one in three dishes is any good. Fried shrimp balls and egg tarts are among the better options. Now, if you're into a Chinese buffet where the servers don't speak English or French, you might like it. Lot of Chinese folks eat here too, so maybe I'm way off base. Some of the fried stuff my friends rave about tastes like lukewarm Chicken McNuggets to me. If you got a group of friends and a couple of pre-dinner drinks, you might enjoy this place. Good for them what wants to eat a lot, like poor college kids or somethin'."

"Alas, my dear young ones, I must simplify this tale,
For 'twill be hard to grasp, elsewise, its meaning so frail.
We chanced upon a place, called Dino's, I believe,
A watering hole, midst the wretched strip, did it receive.
At night, when revelers throng, it mayhap doth appeal,
But to mine eyes, 'twas naught but a dull, cinder block cell.
Dean Martin, that famed crooner, ne'er did imbibe,
For reasons unknown, his taste, didst not incline.
Thus, let us flee this den, and seek a better scene."

"Montreal, a city of delightful cuisine, yet one establishment failed to impress. A friendly face greeted us, but our server, disinterested and defensive, left much to be desired. Pastries and cake, pre-made, took an unacceptable 30 minutes, causing us to be late for our flight. We should have known better than to come here before flying, but who would have thought a simple request for cake would take so long? When we asked politely for it to go, the response was rudeness personified. And, curiously, frappes were listed on the menu, but unavailable for order. Perhaps they lacked a blender, or maybe the server simply didn't feel like making them. The mystery remains."

"Verily, I didst visit this establishment yesteryear, and alas, my expectations were not met. The victuals didst not impress, and the ambiance, though open and airy, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi. The service, I must confess, doth escape my memory, but what doth linger is the feeling of indifference that doth permeate this place. In sooth, naught didst stir within me the desire to return, for there be many other venues at Tempe Marketplace that doth beckon my attention."

"Methinks my spouse and I did sit at yonder bar, ere we must take flight. The victuals were of fair quality, yet their cost didst not agree. Forsooth, at Kabuto's might I dine, and still be left unsatisfied. Two hundred and thirty pieces of eight did change hands for our repast, and nary a draught did I imbibe. \n\nThe shrimp of rock didst please mine taste, and thus we did request another. Alas, 'twas sodden and delayed, the kitchen being overwhelmed. The rest of sushi didst meet expectations, but naught exceptional. In conclusion, the fare was passable, but methinks I shall not return, when better choices lie beyond the Strip."

We dined at this joint on Sat night with five others. Service was crap, courtesy of a dude named Tommy. He had a crappy attitude, worst I've seen in a while. Salads and apps were meh, drinks were weak. My pops had a bone-in steak that was tough as shoe leather. Took 'em an hour to serve us, and we were pissed about it. Manager Amanda tried to make it right with free desserts and a drink, but that didn't cut it. No excuse for this kinda treatment. Tommy don't belong here, not even in a one-star diner on the strip.

"The club brings in top-notch DJs, but the atmosphere's all wrong. Makes me ashamed of my town, especially when big names like Adam Freeland come to spin and the crowd's a bunch of duds. It's just not the right fit for these artists. Wish they'd take their talents to Bar Smith instead. That place knows how to throw a proper party."

"Skip this joint if you're lookin' for somethin' more than just a plain crepe. Price ain't worth it. $9 for a mixed berry crepe with a measly three small pieces of fruit. I saw a few crepes laid out, thought the fruit was just for show. Nope, that's all you get. Gelato stand in the Canals is where it's at. Had it five times now, always get the mango sorbet. Light, fluffy, sweet. Damn, I need it now."
"Came in with high hopes, left feeling let down. Facilities didn't impress, not worth the name or the fee. Take your cash elsewhere."
"Rat hole. Pricey grub from pants-less servers. One star, outta sympathy."

"Twas but a mediocre feast, my friends,
Despite the menu's promise of delight.
The chili and lime shrimp, oh how grand,
And grilled scallops with mango salsa, a true delight.
But alas, the flavors did not impress,
Overpriced, the dishes did profess.
Four pieces of shrimp for fourteen crowns,
Our scallops, undercooked, with frowns.

The servers, friendly and polite,
Attentive, they did ignite.
The decor, striking and fair,
A trendy place, to drink and share.
But alas, the food, a letdown,
Would not entice me, to come around."

"Surprised tonight. Not my first visit to BJ's. Four broken chairs at our table of seven. Huge accident waiting to happen. Calamari appetizer, very good. No issues. Margarita flatbread, not the same. Sat under heat lamp too long? Basil not fresh, barely covered pizza. Couldn't taste it. Daughter ordered shrimp scampi. Asked for grated Parmesan. They brought packets, said no grater. Really? Giving two stars 'cause I know how good it can be...used to be. Need upper management attention. Broken chairs a start."

"Verily, I knew not where to start, in sooth,
For this east valley tavern, hidden from view,
Didst play hard to find, in a strip mall's midst,
With a gruff visage on the entrance, anon, didst seem uncouth.

Two areas within, for revelry and cheer,
When full, a college party atmosphere doth bring,
But empty, fried food scent and punching doth fill the air,
As youths, in Scottsdale finery, doth congregate, in vain.

A musical evening, I didst attend,
Yet, distractions abounded, my friend,
Televisions, Golden Tee, a punching bag game,
Didst steal my focus, and my thoughts didst become askew.

One drink, a Jameson's, I didst imbibe,
(O, Toby, the price, didst cause me to quip!)
Perplexed, I remained, at this place's intent,
And why, oh why, would they allow punching, during a tuneful event?

A spacious patio, outside, doth beckon,
A larger room, with stage, for music, doth enchant,
And, in a smaller space, darts and pool doth await,
Like Iowa's venue, with diverse delights, in days of yore, didst present.

In Gilbert, perhaps, such diversity doth thrive,
A place for all, or so it doth seem, to survive."

"Alack, my friends, we didst venture forth
To celebrate a comrade's final night of freedom,
And made a reservation, as was meet and right,
For six of us, at a specific hour, with all due speed.

But lo, when we arrived, the woman there
Didst inform us that no such reservation didst exist,
And though she seemed a gentle soul, with nary a care,
She could not help us, nor didst she make amends, alas.

One seat they had, but 'twas a lonely perch,
And hours would pass ere others didst become available,
So we, in sadness, didst depart, with naught to show,
Save for the shaved face of him whose party it didst behold.

Oh, friends, take heed of this tale, and mark it well,
For reservations made may not always be to tell,
And those who do not keep their word, doth bring us woe,
So let us beware, and find another place to go."

"Been craving a killer hot fudge sundae. Saw Rita's had frozen custard, so I gave it a shot. Inside, a young girl told me their flavors. Asked how the custard was, she said "real good." Ordered a kid's hot fudge sundae. Got a small cup with some weak hot fudge on top. Cost me $4.70. Not impressed. It was just thick soft serve, not real custard. Hot fudge was canned crap. Keeping my search going for the best hot fudge sundae in Charlotte."

"Methinks 'tis oft I dine at swift and humble Mexican establishments, forsooth, not fond of Garcias, Macayos, Arribas, and suchlike.
