Methinks we shall not return to this establishment."

"Lake of Dreams show? More like Lake of Disappointment. Sun sets, we wait. 8 pm comes and goes, still no show. Finally, some action at 8:30. A singing frog, pretty cool, but over too quick. Back at 9, second show breaks down. Lights out, song stops. Not worth the time. Bellagio fountains, now that's a real show."

"Facial wax and pedicure, good. Manicure, not so much. Shellac, like dried candle wax. Had her redo it with regular polish. Niece did better job with Sally Hansen kit from Walmart. Eighty bucks plus tip, expect better."

"Alas, what woe is this? A tale of woe and spite,
Of service poor, and manners none too bright.
I went to Au Bon Pain, with hunger pangs,
And ordered oatmeal, with naught but thanks.

But lo, the cashier, with fingers nimble,
Didst text with speed, her thumbs didst flutter.
And I, a patient soul, didst stand and wait,
While she didst finish her message, with nary a debate.

Her eyes didst glance up, with frequency rare,
To note my presence, with scarce a care.
And though the oatmeal was tasty, I must confess,
The service there, didst leave much to be desired, alas.

Oh, wouldst that they could learn, to serve with grace,
And put their customers, in a higher place.
For though the food may please, the manner, doth grieve,
And leaves a sour taste, that doth not leave."

"Upon mine enquiry, why doth this eatery still stand, when others in yon sorry row of shops have met their end? My spouse and I didst decide to partake of their victuals, and see if 'twere worth the venture. Alas, their burgers came with chili, mustard, onion, and pickle, a strange concoction indeed. The chili, akin to Alpo's brew, and patty, thin as McDonald's finest, left much to be desired. Fries, a lone bright spot, yet naught else didst impress. And by the maiden tending drive-thru, a high school diploma seemeth not a requirement for employment here. A mystery, how this place doth stay afloat."

"Disappointment hit hard at this joint. Boyfriend wanted to give it a shot, so we swapped out Jason's Deli for this place. Big mistake. Service was rough, made us wait and charged us without warning. Second time at a PT's run company, both experiences horrible. First time, servers acted like we were a pain, took forever to get our food, and still charged full price for the messed-up order. Food was good though, boyfriend's steak salad and my burger were on point. Suggest calling it in and picking it up, enjoying elsewhere. Wanted to like it, but looks like the search for a solid pub and eatery continues."
"Dusty, dirty office and restrooms. Rude staff, too busy gossiping to help or be friendly. Referred by my primary, drove from the far west valley. Treated poorly. Disappointing."

Alas, my friends, I must report a woeful tale,
Of wings that failed to impress, nay, did pale.
I sought a happy hour, with brew and snacks,
But found instead a culinary lack.

The service, fair, yet slow, as if in haste,
Did little to improve the sorry taste.
I ordered wings, but oh, how they fell,
Dry, bland, and lacking in flavorful zest.

And though I asked for grilled, they came not,
But drenched in sauce, which made them naught.
My friend, too, shared this disappointment,
A different sauce, but still no improvement.

The beer selection, paltry, I must say,
No rare or special brews to sway.
The atmosphere, good, yet not enough,
To make up for the food's lack of stuff.

So, will I return? Not likely, friends,
For other options call, and time does end.
This place, alas, did not win my heart,
And so, I bid it adieu, a part.
"Service advisor didn't give a damn about my LS issue.  They were too busy scrambling to find some other guy a loaner car.  Not what I expected from a Lexus dealership.  I left."

"Coupon in hand, I entered the shop with low expectations. Cluttered aisles made navigation a chore. Limited flavor selection. Toppings, a sad display. Counter girls lounged, disinterested. Unfriendly vibes abounded."

"Alas, my first visit to this eatery was not so grand,
The victuals lacked zest, the service slow and bland.
A pot of broth did sit upon our table's center,
Yet, from the fridge, we chose our own to savor.

The beef, oh tenderloins, did please my taste,
But all else failed to impress, alack, what a waste!
The servers, three in number, seemed quite busy,
Yet, their attentions, scarce, and hard to busy.

I waved, a-several times, to gain their eye,
But still, they passed, as if the wind did lie.
Even when they came, to take the empty plates,
Their focus elsewhere, as if in distant states.

One server, didst walk away, mid-order, too,
Leaving me, in wonder, what to do.
The ice, within the drinks, a strange smell bore,
Yet, the taste, didst not differ, I did explore.

The restaurant, clean and modern, doth appear,
Yet, this visit, left much to fear, I do declare."

"In troop of seven, I didst enter in,
This gay's turn, to show the coworkers spin,
A night beyond Scottsdale's dull domain,
But they, for reason most absurd, didst refuse us,
A purse, larger than a clutch, one girl didst bear,
And though we offered all our coin, nay, they wouldst not hear.
So in a cab, we quickly didst depart,
And found a night of joy, at Amsterdam's heart."

"Hark, fair friends! In Montreal's downtown, there be a Bâton Rouge, a place I oft do visit, and with great pleasure too. But alas, this particular branch didst leave me somewhat discontent.  

Their service, slow as molasses, didst test mine own patience, and the young ones', too, who didst fidget and squirm in their seats. The victuals, middling fare, didst not impress, save for the lobster poutine, a dish most delectable! The cucumber mojito, alas, didst taste more like water than a refreshing drink.  

In conclusion, the experience, average at best, doth leave me somewhat disappointed."

"Walked into Yellowtail, no reservation, little wait. Nightclub vibe, loud music, dark. Food? Mediocre. Tofu sauce, ramen broth. Small rolls, minimal flavor. Edamame, adequate but overcooked. Their slogan? 'Barely Adequate.'"

A costly venture, indeed, with a meager choice
Of mixed drinks, and nothing more, alas!
No photographs may thou take, nor bring thy own,
But must pay dearly for theirs, 'tis a woeful tale.
A trap for tourists, verily, yet if thou canst
Afford the cost, 'tis worth a visit, perchance.
Prepare thyself, fair traveler, for a heavy purse.

"This joint's got potential, but do we really need the loud, shitty house music? There's enough of that crap on the strip already, Fremont's for the other half of the crowd who can't stand it. Fix your DJ situation, Vanguard Lounge, and I'll be back."

"I won't be back. Been here thrice, near my digs. Each visit, hoping to find something different. But no, same old story. Pancakes, too much baking soda or powder. Omelets, overcooked. Mimosa, decent. That's it."

"Sugar Factory, you need: three big "Cross-Trained" employees, two happy attitude adjustments, and one medium-sized refrigerated display case. Already, you got: delicious candy, baked goods, and cold treats, and a bright and colorful joint. But, you gotta step up your game. One person handling orders and making stuff ain't enough. And, those macarons? They're expensive and not even kept cool. Fresh or not, they go bad quick. Shame on me for paying six bucks for 'em. Coulda gotten two boxes of OREOS instead. Only good thing here's the Couture Pops. Pricey, sure, but folks wanna be seen with 'em."

"Service was slow, grub was subpar. First tried it years back, food was bad, wrote it off. Recently, needed a quick bite, gave it another shot. Food's still mediocre. Gyro meat, dry and salty. Fries, still frozen in the middle. Son's chicken strips, mostly breading. Salad, soggy and flavorless. Service was slow, only three tables in the joint, took 20 minutes for our food to arrive. I'm a homeowner here, want local spots to excel. This place needs a visit from Restaurant Impossible."

"Verily, good sir, thou dost speak of footwear most fair,
Designed for ladies of a certain age, with grace and poise to spare.
Their fame doth stem from that most popular show,
Sex and the City, where fashion doth flow.

But hold, my friend, for I must say,
Those knee-length cage boots, they doth sway,
My heart doth sing with joy and delight,
For they doth bring forth visions of beauty and light.

So here's to Christian Louboutin, the master of style,
Whose creations doth make our hearts go wild and worthwhile.
For in his shoes, we find a glimpse of heaven's gate,
And our souls doth soar with joy, most elate."

"Ay, 'tis true, a wistful yearning doth abide,
For yonder pizza shop of days gone by,
Where pies of old didst please the palate's pride,
And memories of joy didst dance in eye.

But now, alas! The truth doth come to light,
That pizza, once so cherished, doth fall short,
The crust, though thin, doth lack the needed bite,
The sauce, a zestless broth, doth leave naught.

Oh, how I wished to love Aiello's still,
The staff, so kind, the ambiance, quaint and chill,
Yet, alack! The pizza, mediocre at best,
Doth fail to stir my heart, or tempt my quest.

So, with a heavy heart, I bid adieu,
To Aiello's, once a place of gastronomic clue,
Now but a shadow of its former self,
A memory, a tale, a story to be told, and naught else."

"The buffet didn't live up to the hype, that's for sure. Maybe it was the over-the-top descriptions that did it. Some of the sushi was downright unappetizing. And don't even get me started on the crab leg line - it was enough to make a man weep. But hey, I'll give it another shot next time I'm in town. Can't say I remember anything too special about it, but maybe second time's the charm."
"Heat-break at its finest. Went twice over the weekend. Waitresses? Nice. Manager? Soul-patched tool. Hospitality? Lacking. Rating? 4 stars. Repeat business? Not likely."

"Friday night, went in with some girls. Sat down around 9:45, ordered margaritas. Good drinks. That's where the good ended. Female staff acted strung out, twitchy. Ordered tacos, bland. Beans were alright, chips decent. Wait staff used a table for their own meal. Unprofessional. Won't be back, So-Cal Fish Taco's better."

"Verily, I have known joys here afore,
But today, alas! 'Twas woeful fate.
The maiden at the counter, full of woe,
Didst seem to sorrow o'er her life's estate.
And, by my troth! Her ordering skill
Was puzzling, to say the least, in sooth.
Our pizza, too, didst suffer fate's whim,
Slightly burnt, and one piece didst disintegrate.
'Twas not so dire, yet still, a better pie
Doth wait, methinks, beyond this place's gate."

"Northside Nathans, loved it once. Expensive, sure, but the pizza was good. Not New York good, but good enough. Until Tuesday. Flavorless pie. Not the first time. Consistency makes a pizza joint great. Dined in a few times, staff seemed annoyed, rude even. Done with Northside Nathans."

"Place was meh. Food was mediocre. Beans and hot sauce were decent. Had a shredded chicken burrito combo. Burrito wasn't huge, thankfully. Chicken was watery and flavorless. Rice was plain. Won't be back. Looking for better burritos elsewhere."

"I ain't no fool, I know why I went to the Cheesecake Factory. National Cheesecake Day, half-off a slice, you do the math. But let me tell you, that hostess, she was on top of things. Thirty minutes, that's all I had to wait. Our waiter, nice fella, knew his stuff too. Complimentary bread, not bad. Wheat, that's my jam. Now, the cheesecake. Fresh strawberry, that's what I went with. It was...fine. Smooth, like silk, but where was the cream cheese flavor? Graham cracker crust, not the best. Cost a bit more than the others, that caught me off guard. Not exactly eager to come back, if you catch my drift."

"Methought the Town Square location fair,
In sooth, I didst visit it a pair of times,
And found the victuals to be of good cheer,
But alack, the Tivoli spot, a sorry sight it was,
The sweet potato and chicken risotto, a gummy mess,
Fettuccine napoli, naught but mediocrity,
Yet, the kid's cheese pizza, a dish most fair and bright,
Aye, 'tis a place where children may find delight,
Prices, reasonable, yet happy hour, the best time to partake,
For then, each appetizer, a mere three dollars doth make."
"Starvin', we ate here. Twenty minutes to MGM Grand's cheaper grub. Gourmet sandwich? Tasted like crap. Cost a fortune. Strip dining's rough."

"Solid burger, but pricey. Lobster mac & cheese, laughable serving size. Ginger ale cocktail, tasty but too short. Two stars, 'cause the burger's good. Better options at SkyBox Sports Grill & Lounge in Aria. Larger portions, equally great burger, and the best Philly Cheesesteak I've had."

"The old church-turned-bar had a great atmosphere, no doubt. But the beer? Just average, and way overpriced. We tried their homemade chips, but they were cold, soggy, and stale. Inedible. The bartender said they make them fresh daily, but ours had clearly been sitting around all day. We sent them back, but the bartender didn't seem too pleased. Overall, it's a cool spot, but the novelty has worn off. Mediocre beer and terrible food."

"Place is pleasant, service good. Food's a letdown. Expected more from the stash burger. Buns taste like store-bought, get soggy fast. Beef patty's dry, lacks flavor. Left most of the buns, ate the rest. Fries are decent. Disappointed, especially for $15+. Try GBurger in SoCal. Their burgers are top-notch, huge, and worth every penny."

"Methinks 'twas my first visit to this place,
And at the drive-thru, a maiden fair did take my order with haste.
But lo, she was rude, and forgot my coconut bark,
So I entered the shop, to claim what was mine by right.

She gave me attitude, that maiden of disdain,
Asking if 'twere on the receipt, as if I were insane.
I told her, nay, 'twas not, and she didst repeat,
With a sneer, that she had asked, and I didst reply, most meet.

No apology did she offer, nor a smile,
Just a scowl, and the bark, with a haughty air the while.
Yet still, I left the shop, with a heavy heart,
For such poor service, doth leave a bitter part."

"First time here, I dug it. But last visit, not so much. Told the tech my nails were sensitive, and she still went at 'em like a bull in a china shop. Sander clipped my nail, she apologized, said it was on the wrong setting. Like, hello, shouldn't you check that shit before you start? Anyways, rest of the manicure was a painful mess. Didn't say much, just wanted it over with. Then she starts doin' the arm massage, grabs my arms, and I'm like, what the hell? Paid and dipped outta there fast. Now, a day later, gel polish on my thumb's liftin' and peelin', other nails too. And I got bruises on my arm from her grabbin' me. Never goin' back. Period."
"Convention at the Hilton. Hotel's seen better days, but the pool's decent. Conference room's small, maybe fits 200. Not impressed. Glad I booked the Hyatt."

"Our victuals and potions were of fine quality, I must confess,
But alas, their delivery did leave much to be desired, I fear.
Our server, a sprite of a lass, did vanish for a spell,
Leaving us to pine for her return, in a state of despair.
And when she did reappear, 'twas but a fleeting glance,
For she did flit and flutter, like a bird in flight, without a chance.
We pleaded with passersby, to grant us a refill,
But nay, they did ignore us, with a disdainful will.
Alas, this place doth not deserve our custom, I do declare,
For there be many other taverns, where service doth abound, and fare."

"Hark! A burger and fries, if thou wouldst be so kind, good sir. And, prithee, a dash of saucy attitude from yonder elderly waiter, that he may garnish my repast with a bit o' flair.

Alack! My burger, it doth lack warmth. Fie upon it! Yet, the fries, they be passable.

Lo, our bill doth mount to ten dollars, and yon drinks and cheese and shake, they do add their mite thereto.

A pox upon that crabbed old waiter! He doth earn but a scant 10% of our total, a paltry sum, indeed. Forsooth, 'tis a curious thing, how he doth treat us poorly, and yet doth expect a bounteous reward. Methinks 'tis a self-fulfilling prophecy, that he doth create by his own surly demeanor.

But soft! What light through yonder casino doth break? 'Tis the cocktail waitresses, with their free drinks and smiling faces, that doth earn them a fairer tip, methinks.

Adieu, thou grumpy waiter! If thou findst not joy in thy work, then seek thee another vocation, that thou mayst find happiness and a better tip."

"A pox upon this store, with customer service most vile!
The staff doth treat thy patrons with disdain and scorn,
As if their presence were an annoyance, a bother most dire.
And inventory, a word they knoweth not, it seemeth.

The manager, Julie, a woeful soul, doth side with naught,
Against the consumer, her advocacy doth lack.
I'll ne'er darken this door again, nor spend a single penny.
Forsooth, 'tis a place of woe, a den of iniquity!"

"Aye, I do confess, my rule doth break,
Concerning chains, and this gas station make,
But mark my words, dear friends, beware,
For though their prices seem most fair,
Their staff doth wield a hasty hand,
And demand payment ere they take a stand.

Then, should thou dare to question their decree,
They'll glare at thee with scorn and disdain,
As if thy query were a grievous sin,
And thou, the one with faults to gain.

Yet, for convenience' sake, I give a nod,
Since 'tis situated close to my abode."
"Skip it. Not worth the scratch. For a few clams more, coulda scored a sweet spot on the Strip. Won't make that mistake twice."

"A month's passed since we brought home our little girl. She's healthy now, weighs 11 pounds at 12 weeks, and grows daily. Finally got the paperwork on January 3rd - agreement, insurance gift, and separate vaccination records. Submitted a claim, but the insurance only covers actual illnesses she had. Started vaccinations anew; two more rounds remain. In six weeks, she'll get her rabies shot, then we'll spay her. Moondooggies said they'll find a local rescue to microchip her. Waiting to hear back. Pesce is a joyful pup with a fantastic personality. The kids adore her, we do too, and our other dog loves her. She's a wonderful addition to our family. Despite initial unhappiness, we're elated to have this little girl and give her a long, happy life."

"Alas, my first encounter with the famed conveyor belt sushi didst leave much to be desired. The sushi itself, I must confess, didst lack both quality and flavor. Verily, the prices were quite low, a fact that doth perhaps explain the dearth of taste. In sooth, a disappointing experience, and one that doth not bode well for future visits."

"Car wash ain't bad here. Gas is decent too, couple cents more than Costco. But don't get your glass fixed at Danny's Glass, same location. They'll screw it up like they did mine. Small clear chip turned into an opaque drill hole and a bigger divot. Manager said to call corporate for a refund. What a pain."

"Ere I didst venture hither, I didst peruse
A plethora of reviews, and thus didst choose
To partake of their green curry, a dish most fair.
But lo, they didst not ask my preference
In spiciness, and so I didst declare
My desire for heat. No matter, thought I,
For 'twas but a small inconvenience, mayhap.

But then, the waiter didst depart,
And left us waiting, with nary a thought.
I didst wave mine hand, in hopes to catch
His eye, and bid him hasten to our table.
Alas, the curry, when it finally came,
Was bland, and lacking in flavor, methought.
I asked for more curry powder, but he
Didst tell me they didst only use curry paste,
And with that, he didst depart, leaving me
To ponder on the taste, or lack thereof.

In conclusion, this establishment doth cater
To those who do not savor Thai cuisine,
For naught within their dishes doth evoke
The authentic flavors of the East, I ween."

"Hark! What's so grand about this place? 'Tis situated in the midst of Palazzo, and its ambiance doth lack. We didst venture forth for happy hour, and a $3 glass of their private label wine didst taste of Rutherford groove, a vintage that doth cost $5 a bottle, by my reckoning. Their wine and spirits flights, priced at $20-$40 a piece, didst seem quite steep, but happy hour didst make them somewhat more palatable. Methinks folks might stop by to rest their feet and quaff a drink, but nay, a wine bar it doth not make. 'Tis naught but a seating area for the adjacent, overpriced wine shoppe."
"Egg roll, not bad. House special chicken, off, dry. Fried rice, crunchy, burnt eggs. Fast service, take-out. Prices, hard to beat. $16, two dinner combos."

"Hark! What discourtesy doth these employees show!
They scowl and sneer, as if thy order doth annoy.
The baked goods, too, doth seem of poor quality,
A week old, mayhap more, doth their freshness lack.

I prayed the youth at the register for a new one,
But alas, they were as hard as stone or brick.
He shrugged and offered naught but a weak apology,
As I didst toss the offending treat with great disdain.

Fortunate, indeed, that my betrothed didst speak,
And demanded restitution, lest I leave in anger.
The barista, nearby, didst mutter in displeasure,
But two stars, not one, shall this place receive,
For the coffee, good, and the ambiance, fair."

"Verily, the chain doth please, with menus vast and spaces grand.   Yet, alack, this Green Valley site doth vary in service, now and then.   Forsooth, if thou dost seek a meal nearby, choose Elephant Bar or PF Changs, lest thy server doth seem to loathe their work.   Aye, I have known servers here to be stars, but also, sad to say, some did appear to detest their labors.   When for a hundred crowns thou doth pay for thy repast, 'tis meet to look for service of some worth, at the least."

"Methinks we chose this buffet for our midday meal,
Due to the praise that many here did bestow.
But lo, our expectations were not met,
For though the price was steep, the fare was not.

The selection of dishes was quite paltry,
And naught but three sorts of sushi could be seen.
And those, I dared not try, for fear of woe,
Lest they be stale and make my stomach keen.

The rest of the victuals we did eat,
Were void of flavor, and did not greet
Our taste buds kindly. Neither did the sweets,
Which left us both in a most unsatisfied state.

I know not why the rabble doth extol
This place, unless their standards be quite low.
For we, who crave rich flavors and delight,
Did find naught here that did our senses stir.

So, gentle friends, take heed of this my tale,
And shun this buffet, lest ye be beguiled.
For though the price be fair, the food doth fail,
And leave thee feeling cheated and quite vexed."

"Underwhelmed, that's what I was. Crowded, slow service, and empty food bins. Mongolian BBQ, good flavor but bony meat, no thanks. Italian and Mexican, just okay. BBQ ribs, a solid B-, nothing special. Not worth my time, there's better buffets closer to home."

"Neighbors rave 'bout this joint. We gave it three, four chances. Food's been a letdown every time. Not often I'm disappointed by a burger, but this place...eh. Prices are decent, I guess. But In'n'Out's worth the drive, or pony up for Zinburger. It's just a mile away."

"It's six blocks from my place and I never knew it existed. Tucked away, small and hidden, it's easy to miss. Inside, it's cramped and dark. They've got a tiny patio wedged between two buildings. Wine selection's limited. They stay open till 2 am, but that's not enough to bring me back. The staff and owner are friendly, but the atmosphere's lacking. No pros or cons to speak of. Just a mediocre joint."

"My bro recommended this joint when he was in Vegas for his buddy's wedding. Said their wings were top-notch. So, I checked it out. It's an Asian fusion spot, kinda Korean-ish. They got private karaoke rooms in the back, a bar, and a chill vibe. But when we went, it was dead. Just us and nobody else. Ordered some fried pork, Korean BBQ, sweet potato fries, shrimp tempura, watermelon soju, and their famous wings. Verdict? Meh. Had better, cheaper grub elsewhere. Their wings were decent, but not worth the hype. Chunky pieces, not like Wingstop or Buffalo Wild Wings. Service was good, but maybe 'cause they didn't have anyone else to attend to. Don't think I'll be back, unless I feel like giving 'em another shot. But unlikely."

"A banana nut muffin didst thou order, good sir?
And yet, a blueberry muffin didst thou receive instead?
A pox upon the manager, who with haughty tone,
Didst ask if blueberries or bananas were thy desire,
When clear it was, a mistake had been made.

The victuals, decent they were, alack,
But woe betide the service, full of disdain and flack.
Thou wouldst not return, 'tis plain to see,
To this place, where errors doth abound so freely."

"Fifty bones for brekkie?! That's robbery, pal. Sure, the joint had some charm, but the grub was mediocre at best. And don't even get me started on the snail-paced service. At least the joe was decent, but that's about it."

"Hark! What folly led me to this wretched place,
A den of mediocrity, devoid of grace.
I sought a hearty meal, a simple feast,
But found instead a trial, most unpleasant.

The hall was empty, save for a few souls,
Yet service, slow and poor, did make me howl.
I sat and waited, patient as could be,
But nary a word, nor glance, didst come from thee.

At last, a waitress came, with speed so slow,
And took my order, with a scowl, I know.
My pancakes came, and though they were not bad,
I wondered how, such simplicity, had been so sad.

No query, as to how my meal did taste,
Nor offer, to refresh, my parched throat in haste.
I longed for water, pure and fresh,
But nay, 'twas not to be, until the bill did arrive, alas!

Avoid this place, my friends, I pray,
For service, poor, doth mar the day."

"Decent chicken strips and fries, homemade ranch dressing. Service was good, delivery guy was friendly. But the pizza crust, stale leftover matzah. Cut into little squares, messy as hell. Can't even pick up a piece without it falling apart. Want a real pizza pie, cut normal. Not some mediocre med pie and chicken strips for $28. What a waste."

"A plague upon this wretched place, where service doth crawl like a snail on a winter's day! Though the crowd was scant, our drinks didst arrive with haste, yet the chips and salsa, alas, didst tarry. And so we waited, as the minutes ticked away like hours, for the Fundido to make its grand entrance. But lo, the silverware and napkins, they didst conspire against us, leaving us to dine like savages, with nary a utensil in sight. Our waitress, a sprite of mischief, didst flit and flutter, paying us no mind, until at last, we didst corner her, and with a gentle nudge, didst coax from her the salsa, though the chips, alack, didst remain a mystery. The drinks, a elixir of the gods, didst quench our thirst, and the Fundido, a culinary delight, didst satiate our hunger. But alas, the service, a fiasco of epic proportions, didst leave us in a state of utter dismay."

"People reckon this joint's a dog park. But it ain't. There's dog shit all over the damn place. Folks round here must think they're too good for the bags provided. Had a run-in with some poodle owner, thought she was special, let her mutt roam free. Don't give a damn 'bout giant poodles, but I've seen pit bulls and other big mutts off leash too. These North Scottsdale snobs are pathetic, immature, and think they're above the law. This is a soccer complex, so put your ugly mutt on a leash and pick up your crap. Or maybe I'll come visit your yard and drop a load myself."

"Overpriced and subpar in every aspect. Went on a Sunday, the final night of the Dining Out Charlotte event, paid $30 for dinner. Brought our own wine, still cost $100 per couple. Three others had the Ragout, all felt sick that night and the next. Better options in Charlotte for the price. Note - restaurant was almost empty due to weather. Manager should've checked in, but never showed. Do they care?"

"TIP ADDED WITHOUT NOTICE. Late-night gamblers, beware. You might end up doubling the tip, unaware. Waiters sneak it in, then leave the line blank. You'll think you're doing the right thing, but you've already paid. Service? Forget about it. You'll have to fetch your own sides. Not worth it. Food's mediocre, flies buzzing around. Better off at Burger King."

"People say this is the best buffet in town. Game-show buzzer, wrong. It's not too bad, but nothing special. We went there during their remodel and they sat us in a storage room with a makeshift food line and hot, stainless steel spoons. I got burned and didn't like it. If a place like this can't do better, they should close down."

"Verily, this gambling den doth show its age,
In need of renovation, 'tis a common stage.
'Tis linked to yon tram, a lengthy stroll away,
To Aria, where thou shalt find another way.
A tram doth also lead to Vdara and Bellagio,
Yet, alas! 'Tis not a short or easy trek, I do foresee."

"Customer service was slow, I pray thee,
Took 15 minutes for our waitress to be free,
And 15 more for our drinks to arrive,
A delay that did our patience impair.

My sister's Southwest wrap, a meal most fair,
But lacking a hint of spice, she did declare,
Whilst Grandma's banana bread French toast,
Was overly sweet, and the sauce did pour.
No need for syrup, these bad boys did boast,
But alas, her bowl of fruit, she did enjoy the most.

Veggie omelette, with potatoes, a feast,
But lo, the veggies were scarce, at best,
More cheese and egg whites, did make it bland,
I did not finish, for it did not please my hand.
Tapatio and ketchup, did make it better,
But my potato, overcooked, and full of season, did fetter.
My whole wheat bread, old and stale, did taste,
A disappointment, indeed, and a waste.
Shrugs, forsooth, my dear, a sorry state."

"Verily, fair readers, take heed of my words, forsooth,
A restaurant's linens, white as snow, do not a feast make.
Fleming's, alas, doth falter in its culinary art,
Despite its cloths, so pristine and apart.

The victuals, dear friends, didst leave much to be desired,
A fish, institutional, that didst taste like school fare.
An affront, indeed, to the bounty of the briny deep,
A travesty, that didst earn but two stars, ere we didst sleep.

Yet, gentle patrons, fear not, for the service was good,
A saving grace, that didst lift the venue from the mire.
So, heed my counsel, and avoid Fleming's, anon,
Lest ye wish to dine on fare most dire and woeful, ere the night be gone."

"O, too dear! I do prefer other subterranean places,  
Like Port of Subs, for the selfsame price, by th' grace.  
I do enjoy choosing mine own toppings, and seeing  
What they do, how they prepare it, with mine own eyes, yea.  
The staff, they were most excellent, in truth, I must say."

"Verily, I doth not comprehend, good sir. A vegetarian, I do profess, and thus, the menu doth hold naught but woe for me. Chocolate brownie pie, I did command, forsooth, for mine own brood. Alas, my trio of sprites didst not approve, 'twas a sorry sight, by my troth. Fifteen minutes, 'twas ere they didst prepare the confection, alack!"

"I know good Mexican food, growing up in Texas. But this place didn't quite live up. Atmosphere was great, decor was spot on. Sauce was alright, but the entrees fell flat. My cousin's enchiladas were cold, mine were flavorless. Nobody finished their meals. Staff was friendly, though. Wouldn't come back unless I had to."

"Indian food joint run like a business, not a restaurant. Owner and manager, all about the benjamins. Don't care about the customer, just the cash. Food? Below average. Not all menu items available. Only plus, location on the strip. Better options elsewhere, like Everest Cuisine. http://www.everestcuisine.net/"

"Alack, what woeful service didst thou render me!
So slow, so poor, so lacking in efficiency.
One solitary soul didst man the till,
And she, alas, didst double duty, ill-equipped to fulfill.
My patience didst wear thin, as minutes passed,
And naught but silence didst greet mine ears at last.
Acknowledged, I was, at long last,
But lo, the order, didst it take its sweet time to pass?
Aye, 'twas a curious sight, indeed,
For I, alone, didst stand in line, a strange, forsooth, proceed.
Yet, mark my words, good sirs,
This place, of old, hath been our trusted haven,
Where swiftness and courtesy didst reign supreme,
But now, alas, doth seem to be but a distant dream."

"Dinner with six at a table, service top-notch.  Wine recommendations spot-on.  Salad unimpressive, plain Jane.  Spaghetti bolognese, a letdown.  No flavor in the noodles, too thick.  Sauce, just ground beef and tomatoes.  Passed on dessert, but the free biscotti a nice touch.  Won't be back."

"Two years, that's how long I've been going to this damn office. And let me tell you, it ain't been easy. Especially when it comes to that Rosie, the medical assistant. She's got an attitude, always acting like she's better than everyone else. And don't even get me started on how she treats me and my questions. Like I'm some kind of child trying to score some drugs. Last time, we had words, and now I'm not welcome back. So, watch out for her, buddy."

"Paradise Cantina? Locals love it, but I wasn't sold. Went with a crew on a Friday night, fun vibe, dive bar feel, but the grub? Meh. Chicken tacos, dry doesn't do it justice. Flavorless bird, crumbling tortilla. Happy hour? Great deal, buy one, get one free. Pregame spot, sure, but not the main event."

"No frills, just the facts. Bad first:
1. Better joints in this price range, like SW. 
2. Overpriced grub. 
3. Avoid the couches, worn out. Had to ask to move table, too. 
4. Busser did server's work. 
5. No intro from server, poor form. 
6. Hostess took our dessert order, waitress MIA. Annoying. 
7. Scotch came with cocktail ice. Unacceptable at $22. 

Good stuff:
1. Decent decor, not too bright or dark. 
2. Free apps, french fries, pretty good. 
3. Hostesses accommodating. 
4. Solid beers and wines."

"Facilities were top-notch, well-kept, and had a pleasant aroma. Nice touch with the freebies too. Not a bad sort, the woman. But let's just say she isn't the most accommodating. Had a bit of an odd request, and she made it seem like we were asking for the world. Prices were fair, but the 'potty shot' left something to be desired. Still, gotta give her credit where it's due. She knows her stuff and called it like she saw it. Shame about the pic though, not exactly what you'd call a masterpiece."

"Via Brasil. Good try, but no cigar. Free meal and refund offer? Nice gesture. But where's the beef? Service improved, food still mediocre. Refund promise? Empty words. Sum it up: underwhelming experience."

"The ambiance was fair and pleasant, the service was kind, 
The drinks did flow with grace, my green tea martini did shine. 
A steep price of fifteen coins, yet common in this place, 
I sipped it slow, its taste did leave me in a daze. 

The food, alas, did not impress, o'er priced and lacking worth, 
We left the hall still hungry, our bellies not yet full of mirth. 
I would not return for a meal, but mayhap for a drink or two, 
If naught else be open, and my thirst doth need to do."
"Terrible open-faced turkey sandwich. Deli turkey, canned gravy. Smashed potatoes, tasteless and watery. Friendly waitstaff, but poor description of soup. Stick to burgers or sandwiches."

"We hit up the club on a Sunday night 'cause we got in for free and heard it was poppin'. But man, were we wrong. Place was dead. Looked more like a gamblin' lounge, though. Tables for blackjack and poker, girls in sexy bunny outfits dealin' the cards. We bailed and came back past midnight, still dead. But we found some cute guys to hang with and had some fun. Oh, and we got three comped drinks for enterin' their Playboy Club model search. They don't tell you that 'til you fill out the paperwork and take a few headshots, but hey, worth it for the free drinks."
"Wife's grub was cold. Beans were flavorless. Service was good though, waiter was friendly, made sure wife's meal was redone and hot."
"Spoiled in Cali, that's me. Options galore. Yogurt too icy, flavors not tart enough. Pinkberry, now that's the real deal."

"Booked an appt based on good reviews. 3 pm. Didn't sit 'til 3:15. Nail tech started at 3:20. Poor job on cuticles, kid could do better. Brought my own base/top coat, caused issues. Uneven paint, sides untouched. Used UV lamps too long, too hot. Nails didn't dry. Place is clean though. Big diff in techs, stick w one u like. Won't b back, but they'll get newbs, across from Scottsdale Quarter."

"Went to the joint with the missus for an early dinner. Place was nice, clean too. New, of course. But what's with all the servers? Fifty, sixty, who knows? On a slow weekday, mind you. They just stood there, twiddling their thumbs, chatting away. Made us feel real uncomfortable, like we were being watched. Manager didn't give a damn. Think I'll stick to Henderson's Lucille from now on."

"Methinks the eating house doth seem most fine,
With views that do delight mine eyes.
But alas, the victuals we didst find,
Didst leave much to be desired, in sooth.

A dish of scallops, overly salted, I didst taste,
And corn rice, rich and creamy, didst accompany.
Together, they didst make a curious pair,
Yet, separate, they didst not satisfy.

My love's steak, methinks, was but mediocre,
And parking, it didst cost us dear.
Thirteen dollars, for valet, we didst pay,
And yet, the car, they didst park, in plain sight,
Upon the street, before the inn, most strange.

In fancy restaurants, 'tis customary,
To waive the fee, for valet, I do reckon.
But alas, this place, didst not observe,
The custom, and our wallets, didst feel the pinch.

The meal, so rich, didst leave me naught desire,
For dessert, my sweet tooth, didst not aspire."

Inventory, alack! Doth lack, I say,
Shelves bare, stock doth fade away.
If more in store, they should display,
But empty spaces, doth dismay.

Lines move swift, most of the time,
But aid in aisles, doth decline.
Staff doth flirt, with nary care,
Leaving customers, in despair.

Two stars, I give, for in-store pick,
A service good, doth make me tick.
But know not, how to fulfill,
Or find items, doth make me ill.

Prices high, save rebate,
And sale, doth seal fate.
"Thai House decent, not the best I've had. Red curry chicken medium, not spicy enough. Pricey too."

"Steak joints are my thing. Been to 'em all. But this one? Not impressed. Filets were decent, sure. But no flavor. Like they forgot the seasoning. Bernaise sauce? Packet stuff. Crab meat? Dry as hell. Lobster bisque? Bland. Mashed potatoes? Meh. Didn't even bother with dessert. Next time, I'll stick with Outback. This place? No thanks."
"Oranges too dear, not cold enough. Bad plate. Service slow. Place nice but sadly disappointing."

"We shelled out big bucks for a Terrace Suite and expected top-notch service. But after calling room service twice and waiting around for 45 minutes, we still didn't get our extra towels and hangers. When we finally got someone to come fix the broken AC, they never showed up. We had to sleep with the door open in 103-degree heat. When we complained at checkout, they just shrugged it off with a 'Sorry to hear that.' I was thoroughly disappointed with the response from such a luxurious hotel. They could've at least offered a small discount. But no, they just blew us off. The only good thing was the visual appeal of the place."

"Chili review. Worst ever. Underwhelming experience. Looked good, tasted terrible. Salty and sweet at once. Like they dumped ketchup, beans, and meat together. Quick stop, should've gone elsewhere. Ordering was meh, smells bad outside, like a dirty bathroom. Flight attendant asked why it always smells bad. Many better options for the same price. Won't return."

"Bought pork shoulder from Sam's, package wasn't marked right. No indication it was bone-in. Paid $2.48/lb, same product at Fry's costs $1.99/lb. No discount in sight. Called the manager, he said it came from the vendor, out of Sam's hands. Didn't offer a credit either. That's a five-dollar difference. Lesson learned, watching what I buy from Sam's now."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
My time at Great Clips was quite a mess.
The corporate folk, they did decree,
A 15-minute haircut, a breeze, 'twas plain to see.
But lo, the store managers, they didst demand,
Eight minutes, or less, with nary a hand.
Now, I, a humble barber, didst refuse,
To rush my work, lest I make a fool of myself, anon.
Alas, my dear colleagues, they didst give me grief,
For not conforming to their hasty belief.
But fear not, fair reader, for I didst say,
If speed be thy desire, then come what may.
Just know, my friend, a perfect cut, 'tis not,
In haste, the scissors doth oft play the fool, by my troth."

In fair Las Vegas, an airport doth lie,
Whose landing or takeoff, doth surprise.
A clever scheme, indeed, to have a peephole,
For those who wish to watch the planes, with ease.

The airport itself, doth not impress,
A few slot machines, and fast food, doth mess.
And lo, the Duty Free, doth not excel,
In this city of vice, there's much to tell.

"Two stars, I say, for their omelette station doth please,
But all the rest, alas! doth fail to impress.
For such a price, my friends, doth not compare,
Go elsewhere, lest thou waste thy coin with care."

"We three girls hit up this joint on a Friday night, Easter weekend. Free champagne and well drinks for the ladies at the Wynn's Surrender, you see. First time in Vegas for all of us, 21 and eager to take it all in. But damn, no place to sit unless you had a table. Nice patio though, good for when it got too hot inside. Small joint, hard to navigate to the bathroom through the reserved tables and dancers. Don't think I'll be back, unless they have that free drink deal again. Only plus side was the free drinks to start the night, then off to Surrender we went."

"J&G's got some decent reviews, but I ain't impressed. Been there twice, both times underwhelmed. For a fancy place like The Phoenician, you'd think they'd have better grub. But J&G's just not worth the coin, in my book."

"Alas, how the fare doth falter! Once a place of gastronomic delight, now doth it wallow in mediocrity. The servers, kind and attentive still, yet cannot compensate for the decline of the cuisine. Methinks 'tis a pity, for this city, fair Las Vegas, doth host many a noble establishment. Mayhap, in haste, they shall rectify this woeful state, and once again, the patrons shall partake of savory victuals."

"Two days past Yuletide, to the skies I did ascend,
And lo, the security line did seem to ne'er end.
A tale of woe, of chaos, and of foul despair,
Did unfold before mine eyes, in that place so bare.

"Twas Checkpoint C, the line for first class and such,
We were told, in hushed tones, not to approach.
And Checkpoint D, a mystery, a secret kept,
For reasons unknown, our passage was foreclosed.

"So down to Checkpoint E, we did swiftly make,
With haste, with speed, our footsteps did we take.
I, with two hours to spare, did think myself wise,
But alas, the staff, unprepared, did cause surprise.

"The holiday rush, it seemed, had caught them unaware,
And in disarray, their plans did lie in shambles there.
But praise be, short term parking, once again doth reign,
In Charlotte's airport, a blessing, a boon, a gain."
"Service dragged, place wasn't hoppin'. Grub was meh, 'cept the seafood - that was decent."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This pizza joint doth leave me vexed.
The pies, they were quite tasty, I,
But two stars, alack, doth seem too nigh.
For ten in pizza, the price doth climb,
And service, woe betide, doth lack in charm.
A single glass of water, they didst bring,
No refill came, our parched throats to sing.
The table next, their feast didst arrive,
In ten short minutes, they didst thrive.
Antipasto salad, a sorry sight,
Waited we thirty, for sliced meat and plight.
No lettuce, alas, the waitress didst say,
A cutting board, with cheese and olives in play.
Young and not wise, she didst not inform,
Our expectant hearts, of such a storm."

"Food was alright. But service? Shit show. Sat down at 12:30, still hungry. Didn't get grub till 1:40. By then, wasn't hungry no more. Others around us, they got theirs first. Finished too. Not worth the Benjamins we spent. Take your biz elsewhere. That's what we're doing."

"Memories ain't what they used to be. Went to Gameworks with friends over Halloween weekend. Place was dead, like a ghost town. Most games were busted, Time Crisis included. Air hockey tables, too. Escalator even shut down on us. Not their fault, though. Second time wasn't as fun, maybe 'cause I'm older, wiser. But there was one game that ruled - dinosaur hunting. You walk around, blasting different species with a rocket launcher. Nice. Another decent game was the driving one with four big screens."

"Pray tell, good sir, what wondrous feast hast thou procured for thine taste buds? A pizza, perchance? Nay, not just any pizza, but a New York-style pie, full of flavor and delight. Yet, alack, the price doth be a steep $35 for two large pies! Verily, 'tis a cost most dear. And, alas, the pizza itself doth lack in taste, being overly greasy and unpleasant to consume. Marry, wouldst thou be better served by choosing Barro's or Hungry Howie's instead? Forsooth, their pizzas doth please the palate more than this overpriced, oily fare."

"Hark! Our meal didst take an hour to arrive,
And when it came, 'twas not what we didst desire.
The burger brought to yonder table, wrong,
A sight most vexing, and our hunger long.

The kitchen, chaos doth reign supreme,
A mess, indeed, doth it seem.
The burger, grand in its appearance,
Yet, alack, doth fall apart with ease.
The patty, dry and rent asunder,
Leaveth a pile upon the plate, in disarray.

The cheese curds, freshness doth lack,
Squeak not, alas, poor poutine doth make.
The din within, a cacophony,
Service, good, yet back of house, a sorry sight.
Fix, O fix, the kitchen's plight,
Lest frustration doth consume thy night."

"Alas, fair diner, how thy service doth pale,
In comparison to thy delectable feast!
For thrice now, have we tried to partake,
And each time, the experience hath been quite bleak.

Alack, the wait! Thirty minutes didst pass,
Ere my Diet Coke didst grace our table's glass.
And four times didst I request, ere it came,
When our first course already hadst been claimed.

Their weekend brunch, a Simon-style spread,
Doth promise all thou canst eat, yet 'tis a dread
That service doth slow down, and orders doth fade,
Leaving us to wait, and servers doth evade.

Oh, the last visit! In the ladies' room,
A server, stuffing her face with pastry, didst assume
The role of hand-washing, quite unbecoming,
And left me in dismay, my patience quite drumming.

Yet still, their kitchen doth prepare a treat,
But alas, dear Republic, improve thy feet,
Lest we, thy patrons, seek elsewhere to dine,
And leave thy halls, with naught but sorrow to design."

"Copperfield's got a talent for illusions, but his show's got a couple sides to it. He's got a lifetime of success, but it seems like he's been doing it too long. He didn't seem into it, like he was on autopilot. There were some cool tricks, like the car appearing on stage, but I laughed pretty hard throughout. I wouldn't have paid for tickets if I didn't get them for free. Before he came on stage, there was a video tribute that went on too long. It was cool at first, but then it got old. He's a handsome older guy, but his fake hair was pretty distracting. Thirty minutes of the show was spent wondering if it was sprayed on or astroturf."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
The mariscos here do not impress.
The portions small, the flavors lacking,
A disappointment, indeed, most vexing.

I ordered breaded shrimp, a dish so plain,
Yet even that did not taste divine.
No seasonings, no zest, no joy to find,
A culinary letdown, I must designate.

They told me of this place, a seafood haven,
But now I see, their words were but a ruse.
I shall not return, for I am dismayed,
By the loud music, too, that did my head confuse.

Why must it be so loud, I pray thee tell?
How can one converse, with such a din to quell?
I waited for the music to subside,
But alas, it seemed to stretch on, like a tide.

Never again, my friend, shall I set foot,
In this establishment, with its poorly cooked food.
I'll seek elsewhere, where flavors abound,
And music does not drown out all sound."

"Skip this joint, pal. Panda Express is where it's at. I mean, sure, it's in the Venetian and all, but it's tucked away in some crummy corner with smoke everywhere and nothing to look at but sports books. Service was slow, too - took 'em half an hour to bring us water and menus. Food? Forgettable. Had the XO shrimp and seafood noodles, but they didn't live up to their rep. Overpriced, too. Save your cash and hit up Panda Express instead. It's a chain, but the grub is fresh, hot, and tasty. Two stars from me, buddy."

"Alas, my first impediment was the entrance, which didst elude mine eyes. The youthful waitstaff, though courteous, didst not always attend to mine needs with haste. I didst tarry for a good five minutes ere any soul didst take notice of mine presence.

"The Cesar salad, prepared in the midst of the dining hall, didst delight mine taste buds with its freshness. For mine evening repast, I didst opt for steak frites, a choice not so original, I confess. The meat, alas, didst lack somewhat in quality, yet for the sum I paid, 'twas a fair exchange. The fries, however, didst prove the crowning glory - fresh from the fryer, they didst offer seconds, anointing mine meal with abundance."
"Pricey joint, but that's what you get. Food's not great. Three mushrooms for brekkie? Come on. Salad's slimy, soup's bland. Gym's old, but hey, at least they tried."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of visits twain to yonder TFK,
A place of healthy fare, so told,
Yet service slow, and mood did darken.

First visit, Father's Day it was,
The meal, a feast for taste and eye,
But service, lacking in grace,
Did leave a sour note in the sky.

Again, with MIL, a week past,
We ventured forth, our hunger vast,
But wait we did, for half an hour,
And still, no sign of table, nay, no power.

I asked, with haste, the reason why,
And attitude, from server, did fly,
Slow, the service, and unfriendly too,
A vibe, most foul, didst brew.

Biltmore, my heart doth yearn for thee,
Thy atmosphere, so bright and free,
No need, have I, for TFK's dark side,
For thee, my loyalty shall abide."

"Veggie options? Yeah, they had a few. Asian noodles with grilled tofu, that's what I went for. Sauce was a bit much, too salty. But hey, service was good. Attentive guy, nice chat. If you're local, sure, give it a shot. But don't go out of your way."

"Bad idea, this hotel. Cheap, yeah, but not worth it. Pros? Easy check-in, no resort fee, easy access to the freeway. Nice front desk folks too. Wetzel pretzel, that's something. Cons? Funky smell, asked for renovated room, got a dump instead. Shower head, loud as hell. Dirty coffee maker, gross carpet, TV's in a weird spot. Blocking the window, view's all messed up. Used it for 10 hours, it was meh."

"I was stoked to chow down at this joint, it came highly recommended. Service was top-notch, grub was pretty good too. Not the best fried chicken I've had, but it was decent. A bit greasy, though. But here's the thing, I went with a big group, seven of us, and three of us got sick later. Haven't heard back from the other three yet, but my mother-in-law, husband, and I all felt queasy and had a rough time in the bathroom afterward."
"A joint for the older bunch. My mom's 40th, that's where we went. Pricey drinks, twelve bucks a pop. Not my scene. But it livened up at night, not for the young bloods though."

"Hark, my love and I did dine on brunch,
But alas, 'twas naught but mediocrity that we found.
The huevos rancheros, devoid of flavor they were,
And the patrons, elderly folk, beyond compare.
I have been to Six Penn Kitchen, for drinks I've been,
But brunch, oh brunch, a disappointment it hath been.
Stick to Big Burrito, or other small fry,
For Six Penn, good only for drinks doth lie."

"Food's decent, atmosphere's great. But they're short-staffed, that's for sure. Two-hour wait after they said it'd be 40 minutes. Drinks took 10, food took 40. Family of three came in after us, got served first. Prices are alright, but the wait's a bummer. They can customize the spice level, that's cool. Not sure if I'd go back, though."
"Beer selection, top-notch.  Prices, steep.  Food, a mess.  Service, lacking.  Disappointment, immense."

"House of Cards ain't got nothing on DC's BBQ scene. My Texan buddy, living in Montreal for a decade, told me about this joint he'd been wanting to try. I was game, especially after four poutines in three days. Native Quebecois, I needed a break. 

This place had a strict "wait outside" policy. I went in to check the menu, and some dude told me to "take a picture and get the hell out." Rude. The waiter splashed us with coleslaw, ruining our shirts. No apology. Prices were steep too: $20 for a half rack of ribs and one side? Come on! 

Food better be good, right? Not quite. Popcorn shrimp had great breading, sweet sauce, Asian-inspired. Ribs fell off the bone. Fried chicken, great batter, but dry meat. Corn bread and potato salad saved the day for my friend. 

It did the trick for my BBQ cravings. That's it. 

P.S. They had posters of Shiner Bock everywhere, but didn't serve it. Lame."
"Verily, the service was poor, and the victuals too. Yet, 'twas a meal, and if another paid, what matter? I would not return, forsooth."

"Methinks I've visited Sushi Kim on several occasions, and verily, the victuals and hospitality have not met the standards set by its reputation as one of the finest Korean establishments in fair Pittsburgh.

The fare, though passable, doth not impress; the service, middling at best, and the staff, not the most congenial of souls.

Therefore, should anyone seek my counsel on a worthy Korean or sushi house, I shall not hesitate to exclude this place from my list, with nary a qualm or quaver."

"Atmosphere was top-notch, biscuits with jam not bad. But what killed it for me? Shredded beef on top of eggs. No thanks. Haven't been back since. Grits tasted like they were cooked in milk. Not my cup of tea. Had better brunch elsewhere."

"I searched for familiar goods in a big Asian market, but found none. Mekong and Lee Lee, further down Dobson, offered better choices at lower prices. A shame, since Super L's just around the corner from my place. Might return for Peking Duck or Roasted Pork, though."

"Christmas Eve, cold and hungry, strolling the Strip. Arcade sucked our coins dry. Saw It'Sugar! - childhood dreams of candy stores reignited. Hooked. Overpriced? Hell yeah. Gummies for $5? Ridiculous."

"DOCG, upstairs from a pool hall and pricey eats, ain't half bad. Grub's not as fancy, nor the menu as exciting. Bread's decent, but them pre-packaged sticks, now that's some crunch. Ordered the DOCG pie, comes with a fried egg and pork belly, truffle for the masses. Waiter breaks the eggs, smears 'em on the pizza, and I'm drooling like a fool. But the taste? Where'd it go? No truffle kick, not even a whisper. Damn shame. Spent the rest of the night gazing at Comme Ca, sipping wine."
"Wing Stop, been a while. Less good than remembered. Cajun sauce, confusing. Hot, buffalo, jerk, hard to pin down. Flavor, aimless. Last visit, likely."

"Verily, they boast the finest gear, a truth I've oft confirmed.
But with each trip, troubles mount, while solutions dwindle.
Their prices be exorbitant, a fact that doth astound,
For rival shops offer better deals, both in rent and bound.

Their staff, so full of pride, doth strut and preen,
As if they held the sole key to photography's sheen.
Their knowledge, though not vast, doth overflow with conceit,
Leaving me to ponder if they truly do perceive.

A time there was, when battery replacement did require,
And lo, the clerk did place it in, most unfortunately, upside down, in ire.
If customer service were a scale, from one to ten,
Tempe Camera, alas, would falter, rating but a minus six, by my pen."

"No booze at a concert venue? Unthinkable. But that's what I faced at a local showcase. Underage crowd, packed tight, no drink in sight. Not my scene. Great for kids, though. Up-and-coming indie bands, but no alcohol. That's the deal."
"Honor promotion got us into this Hilton, but the room's a letdown. Switching to MGM Grand's Signature, feels like Park Inn quality here."

"The event was a bust. I paid 25 bucks to run in front of some scared cows for a minute. No t-shirt, just a crappy red bandanna. They ran out of safety pins too. What a joke. People just walked in without paying, and no one checked IDs or vouchers. The corral was a mess, with drunk people harassing the cowboys and bulls. Even saw two cowboys almost get into a fight. What a waste. Could've been a cool event, but it was a total disaster."

"Alas, dear friends, 'tis with a heavy heart I bring thee tidings of woe. The eatery known as Pickles, a mainstay of this fair town, doth serve victuals most vile and foul. Nay, verily, their grub doth pale in comparison to that of chain restaurants, a truth most dire.

And lo, the day of reckoning hath arrived. Pickles doth close its doors, and with it, an era doth pass. Farewell, dear patrons, may thy memories of yore be sweet.

But fear not, for from the ashes of Pickles doth rise a new establishment, a place of gastronomic delight, they say. 'Tis called, they whisper, a name most curious, a secret kept close to the vest.

Yet fear not, dear friends, for on the first day of July, the transition shall be smooth, a change most subtle. And when the dust setteth, behold! A new crown jewel of local cuisine shall shine bright, a gem most precious."

"Methinks I erred in choice of dish, my friends,
For shepherd's pie didst disappoint, with mash that ne'er did end,
And little meat, alack, to savour or delight.
Yet, in truth, the bit of flesh that there was, did taste most sweet and bright.
My comrade's salad, alas, didst appear most woeful and unsightly,
Yet she didst declare it fair, though not of highest quality, I do confess.
And thus, dear friends, let this be lesson to us all,
To avoid the early hours, when atmosphere doth lack its charm and thrall.
Forsooth, on Friday eve, fish and chips shall be our heart's desire, and mayhap then we shall find our culinary bliss."

"Bread, toasted and stale. Crust, burned. Oil, good and spicy. Scallop appetizer, disappointing. Charred bottom, charcoal taste. Couscous, very good. Bass, very good but bony. Deboning, not perfect. Fresh fruit, boring. Baklava, worst ever. Dried out, like concrete."

"Prime spot, they know it. Old guard joint, gotta give 'em credit. Looks good, summer spot, no doubt. Avoided it, assumptions, you know. Wife and friend, lobster roll craving, I tagged along. Just drinks for me. Lobster roll, underwhelming, too much repetition. Fries, best part, can't deny. Pickle, slaw, not impressed. Fishy taste, no sauce, three ounces max. Decent service, few fries, one star. Go to Wholey's."

"Hark! What woeful tale doth this advertisement bring?
A company boasts of swift delivery, yet doth fail
To reach a mere mile and a half, how strange!
Their words, like empty promises, doth fade and wilt.

Away with such false claims, and heed my advice,
Invest in cars and drivers, lest thy business sink.
For honesty and truth, these be the keys to thrive,
And build a reputation that doth stand the test of time."

"Had two more cuts from Richard. Second one was good, but styled bad. Looked like a '90s wig when I left. Fixed it up myself, liked it. Third one was rough. Styled weird, looked strange. Hate it. Looking for a new spot."

"Aft'r a concert at Stage AE, my love and I did seek
A place to rest our weary feet, and thus didst seek
The Pittsburgh Grille, a place of rest and cheer,
Whose decor was neat, with murals bright and clear.

The bar was filled with screens, a sight to behold,
And in the dining area, more screens did unfold.
'Twas a curious sight, yet fitting, I did find,
Since this place stood beside the stadium, so divine.

A cigar bar, a rare sight, didst catch mine eye,
And I didst think it added a touch of elegance nigh.
The place was plush, and comfortably didst provide
A refuge from the noise, and the night's wild pride.

We stayed but for a drink, though I didst desire
To stay longer, and partake of their festive fire.
But alas, a patron loud and rough didst make
A scene most vile, and caused a stir, forsooth, a mistake.

The barkeep, too, didst seem to be distracted quite,
By his own affairs, and left our glasses dry and bright.
Though few were there, and time didst pass slowly by,
I didst expect better service, ere I didst say goodbye."

"Hoped to find a solid BBQ joint. Heard good things, but waited 'til the hype died down. Turns out, it's a bust. Shared a brisket and turkey sandwich with mom, plus some sides. Turkey had a nasty propane flavor, brisket was meh. BBQ sauce was a joke - clogged spouts, couldn't even use it. Thought for sure the potato salad and coleslaw would be decent, but nope. Store-bought crap. Cobbler? Forget about it. Worse than frozen dreck. Shame, 'cause the setup's cool, decor's on point. Even the patio's nice. But you don't go for the ambiance."

"Meh. Been better. Not a Hawai'ian food expert, but I know quality, quantity, and price when I see it. This place? Meh. Had the combo BBQ plate. Thin beef, ribs, chicken, two scoops rice, one scoop mac salad. Not a lot of food, really. Ribs from an old cow, chicken all dark meat. Thin cuts, quick grill, sauce, and serve. Expedient? Sure. Cashier? Don't expect much. Language barrier, you know."

"Hark, the eel roll was a tasty treat,
As was the spicy salmon, a delight.
But alas, the Las Vegas roll did disappoint,
For all I could taste was cream cheese and rice, a woeful sight.
Kona Grill, a better choice indeed,
And cheaper too, a pleasant surprise to heed."
"This joint's a mess, 'cept for Ashley. She's the only one who ain't screwed up. Rest of 'em, they're a disaster. I gotta stop comin' here and start writin' some bad Yelp reviews instead."
"Top floor, M&M's. Wife fills bag, lots of colors. Rude worker yells, "7.99 a lb!" I'm floored. Hide bag behind overpriced M&M's. What's the point of an M&M empire?"

"Another Americanized Mexican joint, trying to be like Garcias but falling short. Rice was plain, beans were unremarkable, and the salsa was nothing special. I had the Pollo Fundido - green chile chicken chimichanga smothered in sour cream and cheddar cheese. It was alright, but I've had better at Garcias and El Norteno. The place itself was nothing to write home about. Time for a revamp, maybe try something new with the menu."

"Fare thee well, good sirs, and gentle ladies too,  
For I have tales to tell of woe and sorrow anew.  
A place named D'Lish, where food doth reign supreme,  
Yet service, wait, and park, do bring much vexation, methinks.  
Three times I went, and each time, alack,  
Didst suffer woes, and troubles manifold, and how.  
The food, above the rest, didst shine so bright,  
But service, slow, and wait, didst plague mine eyes, by day and night.  
Overcharged, I was, and cashier, so curt,  
Didst leave me vexed, and in a sour mood, forsooth.  
Four stars, for food, I wouldst give, in truth,  
But two, for service, doth my rating prove, in sooth.  
A shame, it is, that D'Lish doth not keep,  
Later hours, for those who dine, and sleep not, ere the night doth creep.  
So, heed my words, good sirs, and fair maidens too,  
And change thy ways, D'Lish, lest thou lose, thy loyal crew."
"Employees here, unbelievable. Watched one wrap my burrito, squeezing out sour cream, then rolling in it. Friend's margarita, five minutes to make."

"Sinobi, no more. Penn Ave Fish Co., better. But their 'rainbow roll,' small, sad. Like fish bait. No more money for convenience store sushi. Owners, read reviews. Make good sushi. More options near Market Square."

"Twice didst I make the mistake of ordering from this wretched place,
Thinking that perchance it had improved with time's embrace.
But alas, my hopes were dashed, for the food was naught but woe,
Over-priced and flavorless, a true gastronomic foe.

I vow, dear friends, to nevermore darken their door,
For the sauce they call 'teriyaki' doth leave much to be desired,
A foul concoction, indeed, that doth sully the meat,
Leaving a taste most vile and unpleasant to greet.

So heed my words, good people, and shun this place with haste,
Lest ye wish to suffer the same fate as mine own taste."

"Alas, my friends, our hopes for hearty Irish fare were dashed, forsooth. The Shepherd's Pie, with its watery gravy and scant meat, did not impress. The Irish stew, served cold and flavorless, did naught to warm our bellies. The waitstaff, though pleasant, didst not attend to us with due haste, and our dessert, a bread pudding with melted ice cream, didst arrive in sorry state. Verily, we shall not return to this establishment."

"Alas, my dear sister and I didst venture forth to JJ's Top of the Swamp, a place of late remodeled, to partake in a meal most humble.  The atmosphere, a typical tavern, held naught but the usual suspects, save for a floor near the ladies' chamber that didst seem in disrepair.  The prices, reasonable they didst seem, yet the menu, a collection of common fare, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi.  My sister, a blackened chicken melt didst order, and found it to her liking, fair and good.  I, a Yeti burger, didst request, and lo, it didst arrive, o'ercooked and dry, with a fried egg, solid as stone.  Our waitress, kind and pleasant, didst attend us, though the cook, perhaps, didst have an off day, or the menu, a work in progress, mayhap?  Alas, I fear I shall not return, for naught didst make this place a destination, worthy of note.  Mayhap thy experience shall be better, fair reader?"

"Methought, fair friends, a debate did rage within my mind,
'Twixt which buffet to choose, a quest of great design.
Bacchanal, a name that did resound with glee,
Didst I select, with Yelp reviews, a sight to see.

Alas, my friends, I fear I didst hype myself,
For when I dined, my expectations didst dwindle and pelf.
A 2.5 star, a rating quite unkind,
Didst I bestow, with disappointment entwined.

The food, a plenty, with stations galore,
But freshness, alack, didst seem in short store.
Sushi and sashimi, a dearth, I didst find,
For sixty dollars, a price hard to unwind.

The seafood bar, a letdown, I must confess,
Crab legs, a flavor, didst not impress.
Hot bars, with items dry and old,
Didst leave me unsatisfied, a tale to be told.

Desserts, a disappointment, a conclusion,
I have had better, at a price more conducive to conviction."

"Food was decent for a buffet, but nothing special. Ambiance was nice. Desserts were lackluster, especially compared to other buffets on the Strip. Not worth the price. New buffet, but nothing unique or exciting."

"Service was slow, the guy took his time getting to the register, no greeting. Just one dude working, and he's on his damn phone. Customers show up, he has to hang up. Order was right, dessert was decent, but that's not hard to do. Bathroom was a mess, no trash bag, common area was meh."

"Verily, the establishment doth boast a fair visage, yet the atmosphere within didst assault our senses with a most oppressive veil of smoke. Our peepers didst smart and water, ere our victuals didst arrive, and our persons didst reek of culinary fumes for the remainder of the eve. We didst command two 'old fashioneds', which didst bear but a passing resemblance to the genuine article. The foie gras, a dish most luxurious, didst prove the highlight of our repast. The lobster poutine, of which all didst speak so highly, didst fail to impress. A far superior poutine may be had at other establishments. The octopus salad, a dish of promise, didst disappoint, its flavors dull and its texture unpleasantly chewy. The pork'something' bread pudding, alas, didst lack all semblance of taste, a flavorless mush that didst leave us unfulfilled. Alas, dear friends, forsooth, this place doth charge a pretty penny for fare of middling quality, served in a hall choked with smoke."

"Stayed at the Hotel soon to be renamed Delano. Their all new Delano room was well designed, but the customer experience was terrible. Check-in took 45 minutes despite only a few parties in front of me. They couldn't provide a regular room, so we got a handicapped room with handle bars. Trash and dirty glasses were left in the room. Housekeeping didn't show up after we pushed the button, so we called again and got an unwilling cleaner who left detergents in the room. Very poor customer service for an expensive room."

"Place was mobbed. Don't get the appeal. Football, maybe? Sampler platter, nachos were meh. Glad I didn't just get those. Onion rings, fried cheese, nothing special. Spicy garlic, too damn hot. Not worth the cash."

"Methinks I've visited several yarn shops of late,
As one new-fangled to the crochet trade.
But this particular store didst leave me flat,
With its odd scent and lackluster display, so dull and grey.
I shall not return, forsooth, and pray
To find more pleasant shops, where yarn doth play."

"Agreed with Katie L. Underwhelming experience. 

Water and bread served promptly. Bread, mushy slices. Not crusty loaf expected from Italian restaurant. 

Waited 10-15 minutes for server. Same one who greeted and served couple next to us, seated after us. 

Ordered stuffed mushrooms. Soggy. Too many tomatoes. 

Entree: stuffed shells. Better with less sauce. Overall, disappointing."

"Hark, my friends, we sought a place near work to dine,
A different fare from the usual grind.
'Tis a walk-up, order, and find a seat,
The server, swift and most discreet.

I chose the clams with white wine sauce, alas,
A mistake, for they were not of the freshest caste.
The noodles, too, were cooked beyond their prime,
A disappointment, a sorry time.

For Italian cuisine, I'd not recommend this place,
In the vicinity, there's better to grace."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place that doth serve victuals, yet with an air of disdain doth the staff hold themselves aloof from those who seek to partake of their wares. Methinks 'tis a curious thing, forsooth, that they should be so haughty and proud, as if they were above the common folk who crave but a simple meal. And yet, I shall not lie, for in the dead of night, when all else fails, 'tis a haven, a refuge, a place to find solace and sustenance. But, by the stars, I pray thee, good sir, let not thy pride be thy downfall, forsooth, lest thou dost drive away those who wouldst be thy customers."

"Betty's Nosh? More like Betty's No-Go. Decor's alright, I'll give 'em that. But the service? Horrible. Seven servers standin' around, chattin' up a storm, while our girl's bustin' her butt servin' the whole place. Food? Overpriced and underwhelmin'. Thai chicken mushrooms? Shredded breast, dry as the Sahara. Peanut sauce? Forget about it. Beef and blue mushrooms? Same story, different ingredients. Reuben sandwich? Store-bought corned beef, stale pretzel roll. You see the pattern here? And then, some kind soul pays my tab, and I pay theirs, and the waitress covers the diff outta her own tip. Manager? Nowhere to be found. Lookin' good's not enough when the service and grub's subpar. Won't be back, that's for damn sure."

"Lunch at this joint was a bust. Few folks around, maybe five tables tops. But man, did we wait. Easily 25 minutes for our grub. Burgers were decent, but pricey like everything else in this overpriced town. And let me tell you, the service? Forget about it. Our bill was jacked up by five bucks 'cause the waitress mixed up our tab with some other suckers who paid without checking. Then she just handed us their bill like it was no big deal. Sketchy, man. Real sketchy. That's why it's getting two stars from me, despite the edible food."

"Methought to prove a yelper wrong,
But she, in truth, did speak aright,
That frozen store-bought pizza was best,
And my taste buds did bear witness to her might.

The sauce, unremarkable, did not impress,
The cheese, a saving grace, did somewhat bless,
The meaty wings, mildly spicy, did delight,
But alas, the crust, a sorry sight.

Thick bread, with sauce and cheese applied,
Did make me think of Little Caesar's fried,
A comparison most unfavorable, I confess,
For pizza crust, it did not pass the test.

Yet still, I must admit, the pizza was not bad,
For those who crave a quick and easy meal, 'twill suffice,
But for a true pizza lover, like myself,
'Tis not a dish that doth my hunger appease."

"Ticoz, a review, bad. Owner, afraid? No malice, just honest. Food, blows. Sorry. Host, slow. Waiter, nice. Pozole, pass. Enchiladas, no. Chicken, dry. Pork, same. Decor, cozy. Vibe, hip. Bar, great. Patio, trick. Drinks, maybe. Chef, off?"

"Dentist office's a racket, upsellin' like mad. Communication's crap. They just wanna sell ya more stuff, products, service plans. Staff's always pushin' for recurring plans, sayin' it's for yer teeth's health. Gimme some facts, not sales pitches. Owner says he can't find me in his database, but he can sure send me a bill. Paid my dues, still get charged. Watch out for these guys."

"Been here a few times. Good grub, healthy too. Nice selection. But the service? Cafe staff don't give a damn. They'd rather make things hard for you than break a sweat to help. And the prices? Higher than they should be. Wouldn't mind so much if they showed some respect, but they don't. So, not worth it."

"Yelpers, I gotta say, this joint didn't live up to its rep. Hot as hell in there, smelled like a clogged drain, and slow as molasses. Had the tomato soup, decent but chilly. Cal Turkey, too much bread, but edible. BF had the Marketplace Turley, open-faced, not bad. One bad visit, but I ain't comin' back."

"Alas, my children and I didst suffer a most vexing adventure at this establishment. The hospitality, I must confess, didst leave much to be desired. The victuals, alack, were most unpalatable, and the cost, in sooth, didst seem exorbitant. I didst command fajitas, and verily, the flavour didst resemble a most unpleasant chemical concoction. In conclusion, I must express my utter discontent and declare that I shall not again darken their doorstep."

"Hark! A Deli, they call it, but alas, 'tis not,
For where I hail from, Deli means a spot,
Where sandwiches and such are sold, a place to dine,
But here, they call it Deli, yet it doth not confine
To what a Deli should be, a place of meat and bread,
Nay, 'tis a restaurant, full of fancy dishes, spread.

A pox upon them, for their deceitful ways,
Minus a star, for leading me astray,
Into believing I would find a true Deli,
But nay, 'twas naught but a restaurant, a lie.

And lo, they did not understand,
The meaning of no cheese and no mayo, oh so grand.
In my homeland, there be places galore,
That offer three slices of bread, and more,
They be called diners, not delis, I say,
For they provide a feast, in a different way.

And thus, with only three tables to tend,
I did expect a server, more attentive, to amend
My empty tea cup, and provide more napkins,
For mayonnaise and cheese, they did occupy the original tokens.

But nay, the owner/manager, didst delay,
His thanks, until we were a hundred feet away,
A poor show, indeed, and not so bright,
Leaves me in doubt, if this non-Deli Deli, be worth the fight."

"A plague upon this place, I say,
For prices high and food but average pay.
Two bits of bruschetta, eight dollars dear,
I'll take my business elsewhere, 'tis clear.
A gift card, they would not accept, alack,
For cocktails, which did my spirits lack.
Much better places there be, to dine and delight,
So farewell, HH, forevermore, goodnight."

"Went there twice. First time, food was OK, not worth the price. Gave 'em another shot tonight. Same story. Asked for a small bowl of noodles for my one-year-old, they pointed me to a six-buck spaghetti. Kids' meals didn't include a drink, four-six ounces of chocolate milk for two seventy-five. Rip off. Busboy bothered us twice, took our food before we were done, cleared my water glass right after I got it refilled. Food was decent, but not worth the tag. Shame, wanted to like the place."

"Heineken for $20? Damn straight. That's what they wanted for a bottle in this joint. But I needed it, see? Needed it to keep my wits about me amidst all the crap music and creeps. It's a dump, but it's my dump now. Where I'll be when I'm done with people and their BS."

Food was mediocre. Maybe it's 'cause I'm from SF, where Viet food is top-notch. Came here for lunch during a Vegas trip, wanted somethin' different from the casino grind. Ordered Pho Ga, chicken noodle soup, and it was pretty bland. Had spring rolls too, they were alright. Problem is, pho's all about the broth, and theirs just wasn't authentic. Tasted like MSG and water, fake as hell. Nice spot near the strip, good for a hangover cure, but as a meal? Nah.

"Place was nice, but last time we stayed, they screwed us. Arrived at ten, and they told us they had no room. Said they overbooked, and we had to drive twenty minutes to another joint. What a hassle! My husband had a meeting at the JW, so he had to leave early the next morning to make it back. And I had to move our stuff again."
"Pshaw! I was not taken by its charms, good sir. 'Twas but a middling Thai feast, and naught to write home about. I wouldst not grace its doors again, for there be better fare at Thai House, yonder."

"Today, my love and I didst dine at Fago de Chao, a place of feast and revelry, to celebrate our anniversary. Alas, the meal didst not live up to our expectations, for the meat was overcooked and dry. The salad bar, however, didst boast a bounty of fresh and varied delights. One of the servers, a kind and gentle soul, didst grant me a tour of the kitchen and brought us a sweet dessert to mark the occasion. Methinks, for the high prices charged, the main course shouldst have been cooked to perfection, juicy and tender. Alas, we shall not return to this establishment, for there are better options to be found."

"Verily, a sorry sight doth greet mine eyes within this hall of victuals. Alack, the fare provided doth fall far short of that which I have known in fair Las Vegas. Fie upon the cooks who doth prepare such meagre sustenance! Yet, praise be to the servers, for their mien doth bespeak a certain friendliness and grace. Alas, their efforts doth but serve to highlight the dearth of culinary prowess on display."

"Alas, my dearest cupcake shop, how couldst thou falter so? Alack, thy sweet delights didst fail to impress, despite thy cozy confines and friendly staff. Thy cupcakes, priced in line with others, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain...oomph! They seemed but mere homemade fare, a tad too dry for mine own liking. Alas, I must confess, my heart was heavy with disappointment. Forsooth, I've tasted finer confections elsewhere, and thus, cannot recommend thy baked treats with zeal. Yet, still, thy charming atmosphere doth hold a certain appeal, should one desire a casual meet with friends o'er coffee. Fare thee well, dear cupcake shop, mayhap another time, when fortune doth smile upon thee."
