"Shame on me for not reading the reviews. I felt like I was in a daycare, not a restaurant. Kids crying, toddlers running wild, parents not paying attention. Too much noise. Great burgers, but won't be back."
"Asked 'bout the house wine. Good, they said. Not so much. Pizza, decent. Service, meh."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
This place doth not impress, alas,
The oxtail soup, with fat so bright,
Did seem like it had seen a freezer's light.
And loco moco, oh how it failed,
To please my taste, its flavor so pale.
Ice tea, naught but sugar's watery brew,
No tea flavor could I sense anew.
I shall not return, my friends, farewell."

"Hark! In fair Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright,
A tale of woe doth unfold, a sorrowful sight.
A car wash, named Full Circle, doth boast of its might,
Yet, alas! Its waters, unfiltered, doth leave a blight.

A traveler, seeking refuge from the heat of day,
Didst venture forth, his carriage to array.
But lo! The attendants, careless in their duty,
Doth leave the mirrors soapy, and water spots aplenty.

And thus, the traveler, with a heavy heart,
Must break out the quick detailer, and play his part.
A microfiber cloth, to wipe away the grime,
And make his carriage, once again, shine like the prime.

Oh, Full Circle! How art thou fallen from grace?
To charge four crowns, and yet, no filtered water in place?
A careless wash, indeed, doth leave much to be desired,
And thus, this traveler doth voice his discontent, and fire.

Shall we, dear friends, accept such laxity?
Nay! Let us demand, with one voice, clarity!
For cleanliness, and care, doth make a world of difference,
In the realm of car washes, let us raise our standards, and dispense."

"Verily, I do not comprehend the appeal of this establishment. 'Tis a place that doth reek of past glories, and yet, doth charge a pretty penny for a meal most foul. The pizza, in sooth, doth lack the flavor and doth leave a greasy film upon thy tongue. The interior, alas, hath not been updated since the days of yore, and thus, doth show the signs of wear and tear. In faith, 'tis a place best avoided, lest thou desirest a culinary disappointment."
"Pizza's no good. Prices are outta line. Can't fill a grown man or woman with one slice. Two slices cost more than ten bucks, not countin' a drink. Don't make my mistake. Go elsewhere."

"Hark! What's this? A Korean grill, they call it Seoul,
But alas, the portions, small they were, I do declare.
A plate of meat, so meager, it did seem,
And for a Korean feast, most unbecoming, methinks.

The rice, a separate dish, oh woe is me!
For in a Korean restaurant, full bellies we should see.
But nay, they had not much, their menu a sham,
A few beers, Japanese, their selection quite slim.

A pox upon this place, a fake, a fraud, a sham,
For Korean BBQ, it doth not live up to its name.
The owners, young whelps, their elders would be ashamed,
Koreans, so embarrassed, their heritage profaned.

I shall not return, no more shall I darken their door,
For Seoul Korean Grill, a mockery, a farce, a bore.
But one thing, I must confess, the doenjang, so sweet,
A saving grace, a gem, in this culinary defeat."

"Sunday lunchtime, joint was jumpin'. Maybe churchgoers fillin' the seats. Green salad, ginger sauce, nice touch. Shrimp pockets, pan-fried, damn tasty. Wish they had somethin' special for dippin', not just plain soy sauce. Chicken and veggies, cold as ice. Forgot the microwave, maybe? Sent it back, waiter said he'd check with the chef. What's to check? Switched to grilled chicken, took a bit. Manager came over, said it'd take a while, blamed the weather. Other dish, Ma-la shrimp and chicken, steamin' hot. Grilled chicken, barbeque sauce, nice. Food's good, three notches above the usual Chinese buffet. Prices are fair, service, meh."

"Pros and cons, kid. Friendly staff, easy scheduling, thorough examination. But, seven cavities? Gum treatment? Didn't sit right with me. Seemed like they were looking for ways to take my cash. Got a second opinion, turns out it was all unnecessary. Be careful, kid. Don't let 'em take advantage."

"A wedding didst bring me to this place,
And though the chamber was not so bad,
The water closet didst make such a noise,
As if 'twere trying to wake the dead.

I opened up the tank, to see if I
Could quiet it, and found a sight most strange,
The fill valve had not been changed in years,
A sign of neglect, or laziness, I fear.

They have a scheme, they call it "Eco",
Whereby thou mayst decline fresh linens,
And in return, receive a token worth five dollars,
To spend on food and drink, they say.
But beware, fair traveler, for they do not tell thee,
That this token cannot be used on ale or wine,
The bartender, he should have said, with grace,
"I cannot take this, but for thee, I shall,"
And from his tip, he should have given thee,
Five dollars back, for good customer service,
But instead, he left a foul taste in my mouth,
And now, I do complain, in this review.

Another thing, about this five dollar prize,
Is that housekeeping doth not visit thy room,
No fresh coffee cups, nor coffee, nor even,
Glasses, made of glass, but cheap, plastic things,
For the price of the room, and their "Eco" ways,
Surely, they could provide some proper glasses.

The location, good, a short walk to other places,
But parking, pricey, yet not unreasonable,
In this, a major city, downtown, they say.
So, stay, if thou must, but beware of these things,
And hope that they shall change, for the better, ere long."

"Hark! This morn, my heart doth crave Vietnamese fare,
A change from usual breakfast, I do declare.
I order spring rolls and pork meatballs, 'twas my whim,
The former, naught special, but latter, quite sublime.

A BBQ meatball salad, it seemed, with veggies galore,
And rice paper wraps, hard as stone, I knew not what to do.
Water, I requested, to soften them, I pray,
For such a quantity of greens, I could not stay.

A BBQ pork bowl, I thought I had ordered, fair,
But lo, the same setup, with lettuce, herbs, and bare.
Two slider patties, it seemed, and pork, oh so sweet,
But portion size, a problem, my hunger to greet.

The taste, it pleased me well, no doubt, no doubt,
But meat to lettuce ratio, a rabbit's shout.
Next time, perhaps, the pho, I shall essay,
For in it, lettuce, I hope, doth not come into play."

"Hark! A 12-inch tuna sub didst thou order, good sir?
By my troth, the sandwich maker didst go out of her way,
To ensure thou didst not receive any extra tuna, I say.
She scraped the excess from the scoop, with great disdain,
And cast it aside, like a worthless, wretched thing.
A 12-inch tuna sub, with meal deal, didst cost thee $13.00,
The most expensive thou hast ever bought, I do reckon.
Never again, at this location, shalt thou set foot,
Forsooth, 'tis a place of great expense, and little worth, I do suspect."

"A plush bed didst await me, yet a cup of brew didst not greet me in the morn. Alack, I didst forget mine own pillow, and he who tended the counter didst refuse to send aid. Fie upon thee, poor service indeed! And lo, the buffet didst shut its doors for renovations, without a word to us who booked our stay. Another tavern we wouldst have sought, had we known ere now. Alas, two stars doth this inn receive, for soft the bed didst lie, else naught but one star wouldst it have gained."

"Celebrated my cousin's birthday at this joint. Pizza was decent, but others weren't impressed. Mozzarella was top-notch, though. Service, on the other hand, was subpar. Waitress didn't clear plates and made a big deal about not offering free birthday desserts. Then, she took 45 minutes to tally five separate checks for 14 people. Should've been a 1.5-hour dinner, turned into a 2.5-hour fiasco. Owner was slacking at the bar, too. Finally got the check and left, but by then we were hungry again, so we hit up Burrito Express for some actual service."
"Place is overpriced, been there several times last year. Save your cash, eat elsewhere. Food's alright, service too."

"Bank's got no give-a-damn 'bout customers. Called 'em up, held for an hour, still couldn't get through. Couldn't access my savings at the ATM neither. Check prices? Outta sight. No personal banker at the branch when I went to shut down my accounts. Didn't even ask why I was leaving. Awful bank, subpar outfit."

"Pros: Clean, fast service, good price ($25 for white tips with gel polish). Cons: Didn't make me wash my hands, didn't clean under my nails, placed tips incorrectly (left a gap between my nails and the tips), bubbles in my nails, thinned my nails instead of rounding them. Overall, decent service, nails look okay, left a tip out of habit. May return."

"Rah, that's what they used to call this joint. Now it's some other name, but I can't recall. Funny how things change. People don't say "excuse me" no more. They just bump into you, like they're trying to start something. And the smell of rotten banana daiquiri, it's like it's following me around. Can't escape it. Reminds me of Rico "Suave", the guy with two left feet and a sport jacket drenched in Aramis. Danced with him once, too many drinks, can't remember much. But I do know I shouldn't have been there in the first place."

"Service stunk. Local here. Took some out-of-towners to lunch. Waiter in a funk. Slow, unrefilled drinks, no plates 'til we flagged someone down. Stacked dirty dishes in our faces. Everything slow, got ignored plenty. Only quick thing: droppin' the check. Staff never said thanks. We did, though. Food wasn't bad, but that's about it."

"Hark! The estate doth undergo renovation,
A process that doth take some time, no doubt.
Perhaps 'tis wise to choose another place,
Until they've finished and all's in order.
Then, wait awhile, and read the reviews anew,
To see if 'tis fit for thy purpose, fair one,
And if it pleaseth thee, then make thy move,
And may good fortune be thy guide, my friend."
"Wife and I gave Outback three chances in seven months. Not worth the time. Never again."

"Fast and cheap, but not exactly relaxing. My 55-minute manicure was filled with upsells. Gel nails, white tips, paraffin dip, pedicure - they pushed 'em all. Just wanted a quickie during my lunch break, but they wouldn't let up. My tech was nice, but the rest of the joint was a zoo. They claim to take credit cards, but there's a catch - it'll cost you more. If you can handle the noise and pushiness, you might score a decent manicure for $9.99. Otherwise, keep lookin'."

"O, woe is me! My pizza, once so fair and bright,
Now lies before me, burnt beyond all light.
And my husband's meatball sandwich, a paltry sight,
A mere morsel, fit for children's appetite.
We stood aghast, our faces filled with dismay,
At such a pitiful display. Alas, I say,
The salads here, they tell me, are quite fine,
Perhaps I should have chosen one of them, in design."

"Forty-five minutes didst pass ere our victuals did arrive,
The younglings, Mac and Cheese didst crave, my wife, salmon didst choose,
And I, the spicy tuna roll didst savor,
But why the delay, no reason didst they show,
An apology and free Mac and Cheese didst they bestow,
Alas, we shall not return, for service here hath been woe."

"We stumbled upon this steakhouse by accident, and it was a mistake. Zero energy, zero character, just a generic, overpriced restaurant. Our appetizer, an antipasto platter, was unimpressive - bland hummus, bland baba, and too much repetition. My wife's burger was decent, but lacked seasoning. My lobster linguini was a disappointment - overcooked lobster, chewy texture, and poorly cooked pasta. The service was apathetic, like they were going through the motions. We should have known better than to pick a place without researching it first."
"Wendy's, not bad for a national chain. Salads, a plus. Burgers, fresh. This joint though, poorly run. Salad, wilted, brown bits. Service, meh."

"Our recent sojourn at the Flamingo, alas, hath left me in a state of woe, my dear. The Drais nightclub, with its constant beat and revelry, didst keep me from my restful slumber, yea, until the break of dawn. And though our rooms were graced with beauty, the price we paid for such a view was too great, methinks. Forsooth, we shall seek another lodging, where quietude doth reign supreme. Farewell, Flamingo, thou art a gem, but thy nightclub doth mar thy charm."

"Friends went on a date, brought me takeout. He liked his steak. She said fried pickles weren't crispy, ribs were decent, pulled pork was tender but dry, garlic mashed potatoes were alright, creamed corn was great. Said it was mediocre, wouldn't go back. \n\nI got the beef brisket sandwich with mac and cheese. Didn't look like the website pic, no au jus. Meat was tender but bland and dry. Mac and cheese was too spicy, couldn't eat more than a bite. Menu didn't say it was spicy. Disappointing. Wouldn't recommend it."

"Hark, good sir! The name doth seem to be,
Cous Cous now, and not what it did be.
New owners and chefs, I do perceive,
And oh, how the lamb burger doth grieve!
The spices, once a delight, now doth wane,
And I, in truth, do doubt my return again.
Forsooth, the last two cashiers I didst meet,
Didst leave me in disfavor, full of discreet."

"Get the Palms Club card. It's worth it. Food's nothing special, but the club prices make it worthwhile. Had a late night breakfast - bacon was decent, eggs were perfect, toast was alright, but the home fries? Forget about it. They were all grease and no potato."

"Jamba Juice on campus? Sweet. But no, it's crap. Guy behind counter's got an attitude, treats me like dirt. Other workers ain't no better, act all pissed off when I ask 'em somethin'. Place is cramped, confusing. Customers look lost, staff don't give a damn."

"VIBE 
Cool joint, Le Cartet. Castor-esque lights hang low, maps adorn the walls, poinsettias sit pretty. Buzzy spot for lunch, no doubt. But service? Zilch. No greeting, no drink offer, had to ask for specials myself. 

I ATE 
Salmon sandwich, decent stuff. But hey, thought I'd get slices of salmon, not some tuna melt mush. Pricey too, with a tiny salad for $15. 

OBLIGATORY CATCHY REMARK 
Le meh, Le Cartet. Good vibes, mediocre grub. Worth it if you're already in the area, but otherwise, it's a trek for little reward."

"Crabs, tricky devils. Limited options. Best bet, pack a toolkit - jewelry case-sized, for elegant extraction. Most folks? Confused pokes with a fork, then full-on caveperson mode - rip it apart. Legs, claws, little meat. Body, jelly-like organs. Not worth it. Twenty-five bucks. Waitstaff finds crab shells for weeks, like ninja stars. Hole In The Wall Crab Shack, I'll return. But not for this dish. Crabs, pricey. Low yield, lots of work. Garlic crabs, too salty. Shrimp, appetizing. Next time, no regrets."
"Las Vegas. Steakhouse. Expensive. Runs out of steak. No apology. Not busy. 8 pm. Epic fail. Plenty of better options."

"A fair assortment of dishes, and victuals of a sort, yet those who run this establishment are most parsimonious, and strive to curtail thy choice of finer fare at every opportunity. And should thou not finish thy plate, clean of sushi rolls that didst not please thee, they shall charge thee extra, by my troth! 'Tis folly, I say, and naught but greed that doth drive them to such heights of expectation. Tip them not, good sir, for they do not deserve it. Seek out other places, and let this one fade into obscurity."
"Ribeye at XYZ restaurant was a letdown. Not worth the price. Had better steaks at home, cooked on my own grill. Mashed potatoes and side dishes were good though. Disappointing experience overall."

"Place looked promising, but it just didn't deliver. Passed by it a few times, always empty. Food's not great. Chicken's dry, sauce is bland, like something you'd buy at the store. Ribs were alright, brisket's too fatty, pork had a weird aftertaste. Sides were a letdown too - coleslaw needed more seasoning, BBQ beans were flavorless (my husband said Bush's in a can is better), and potato salad was a total waste. Even the pickles, which were breaded nicely, had a weird texture like thick paper. Dipping them in their ranch made 'em a bit better. Atmosphere's like a Five and Diner, shame since it's a cute little spot. Just not worth the trip."
"Sweet relish on a burger? Who the hell does that? And with dill pickles too? Ruins the whole damn thing. Curly fries were good though, and they got Cherry Coke. Two stars for that."

"Terrible Krispy Kreme experience. Got there round 9:45 for two boxes to take home on Black Friday night. Lady who helped us? Rude as hell. Don't care if she worked all day, she should've been friendly. Guy mopping the floor, water splashing where the donuts were just chillin' on the machine. Unbelievable. Labels didn't match the donuts on display and when we asked her to clarify, she gave us some long-winded explanation about how they distribute donuts to gas stations. Ready to walk out, but managed to pick out some decent ones under the glass door. Never coming back."

Alas, what woeful fate hath befallen this place?
I visited here awhile, and fond memories did grace
My mind, of joy and laughter, free from sorrow's trace.
But now, alack, how changed doth this place appear!
In disrepair, with mildew, stains, and vapor's power
Doth falter, failing to bring forth its former cheer.
Oh, how my heart doth ache with deepest woe!
For naught but grief doth this once-pleasant site bestow.
No services didst I partake, yet still I feel
A heavy weight of woe, that doth my spirit steal.

"Pray, what ill fate didst befall my stomach, that this Pad Thai, a dish most foul and vile, didst cause mine gorge to rise? Forsooth, 'twas the first time in ten winters that my gut didst protest thusly. Alas, my wife's Cashew Chicken, a meal most bland and tasteless, didst earn but four stars from mine lips. Mayhap, fair traveler, thou shouldst journey onward to Naga, where Thai cuisine doth reign supreme."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou offer stamps or ice with thy Snickers bar? Nay, I thank thee not, for they do not complement each other well. How sayeth thou, Circle K? 'Tis a foul place, full of unnecessary wares and overpriced fare. The workers of the land and builders of structures do frequent it, I reckon, for convenience's sake. Yet, two stars doth it earn, for its location maketh it a rare haven in these parts. And lo, Circle K hath corrected its mistake in charging too much for 5 Hour Energy drinks, by offering a special of two for five regal pieces or six silver coins, depending on the strength desired. Verily, a fair price, methinks."

"This store ain't my cup of tea. Saw a onesie and pants combo for my little one that cost thirty bucks. That's too rich for my blood, especially since she'll outgrow it in no time. Went to Ross and found the same getup for eight bucks. Same story with the toys - paid fifteen for something I could've gotten at Walmart for five. I get that they gotta make a profit, but damn, the markup's steep. Their crib set selection's pretty weak too. Was told to check out their online selection, but I ain't a fan of shopping on the internet. You'd think a store like this would have a better selection of crib sets, ya know?"

"Two stars for the view. Food wasn't great. Better suited for drinks, especially on the patio with the fountain. Huge menu, but we stuck to basics. Not worth it for breakfast, but I'd return for a drink."

"Two years back, I recall a joint with good grub and vibes. Tonight, not so much. Overpriced burger, dry as the Sahara. Wife's pulled pork? Meh. Dirty digs, too. Friendly servers, but that's about it. Give it two stars, 'cause why bother?"

"Five of us hit up Nanos. Four of us ordered Mofongo. But only one of us got it. The rest of us got some other dish with the same name. Our server didn't bother to clarify. They made up for it with a plain Mofongo plate. But then they screwed up our checks. Drinks on the wrong tickets, you name it. What a mess. We thought this new spot from the Sabor and Three Amigos crew would be top-notch. Nope."

"Place was jumpin' when we hit it up one night. Decor? Kitschy, yeah. We shared a pear salad, canned pears, but hey. Beef cheeks special, sauce overpowered 'em. Hubs had decent lasagna, I had more of his. Overpriced, Olive Garden does it better."

"Deli's ain't new to me, pal. Been to plenty, and this one's subpar. Corned beef, kosher style, mind you, was fatty, some chewy, some hard as shoe leather from sittin' out too long. Not exactly what I'd call appetizing. 

Suggestion? Train staff on that fancy deli equipment before someone needs stitches from the slicing wheel. Girl makin' my sandwich struggled, almost lost a digit. Not exactly the kinda show I wanna see when I'm chowin' down. 

Potato salad? Bland, unremarkable. Underwhelmin' experience, to say the least. Leaves me yearnin' for the real deal, the kinda delis I've had in NYC, Boston, Cleveland, y'know? This place don't hold a candle to 'em."
"Airports, I know 'em well. Eleven years of business travel, that's my story. Charlotte Douglas, though - that place needs work. Drop-off, pick-up, it's all a mess. Time to widen the roads, I'd say."

"Thursday night, I swung by to give it a shot. Lack of BBQ in the area made it worth checking out. Got a combo plate with pulled pork, brisket, and ranch beans. Sweet potato fries came with a shit ton of 'em. Beans were whatever, fries needed seasoning. Brisket had a smoke ring but tasted more like pot roast than BBQ. Pulled pork was decent, steeped in its own juices, but came with sauce already applied. Ask for it on the side. Tabasco saved the day - seemed like they designed the sauce with it, then chickened out. Empty place, but it was 8:30 on a Thursday. If you're craving good Q, hit up Bobby Q's at I-17 and Dunlap."

"This joint used to be solid, but it's gone down the drain. Last time we hit it up, we had to send back three dishes 'cause they were either messed up or straight-up terrible. Shame, 'cause it used to be the closest thing to Houston's in Charlotte."

"Calabria's looks swell from the outside, real pretty. Landscaping's always tidy, building's a looker. But inside, it's stuck in the 90s, feels dated. Went to a bridal shower here, nice and fancy compared to the main dining area. Party room served breakfast later, weird for a fancy spot. Good service, food's alright, but overall ambiance ain't great."

"A pox upon this pizza, say I!
'Tis naught but woeful mire and wretched pie.
The crust, a sorry sight, doth sag and droop,
Like autumn leaves that wither in the loop.

The sauce, a vile impostor, doth pretend
To be a sweet delight, but nay, 'tis naught but bitter end.
And toppings, oh, how they do disappoint!
Frozen and numb, they doth resemble naught but sorrow and despair.

But wait, what light through yonder window breaks?
A glimmer of hope, a ray of sunshine, a gleam of cheer!
For in the midst of this dire strait,
Doth lie a pizza, thin and crisp, a true delight.

Alas, 'tis rare, a fleeting dream,
A moment's joy, a flash of bliss, and then 'tis gone, alack!
But still, a glimmer of hope doth shine,
That one day, all pizzas shall be divine."

"Bellagio, aiming for 4 or 5 stars, fell short. Service spotty, slow, and unorganized. Large party, but not packed. Waiter dropped dishes at random spots, no memory of orders. Timing issues, dishes arrived one by one. Pricy, decent food, edamame stood out. Not worth it, unless forced. Other sushi places on the Strip, worth a try."
"Eight a.m., Sunday. Appointment scheduled. Get in, get done, move on. Receptionist present, but staff trickled in between 8:10 and 8:15. Unprofessional. Medical staff should know better."

"Methinks 'tis hard to give a poor review,
For Sushi Factory's fare did please me well.
But somethings else, I cannot quite perceive,
Doth keep me from a rating high and swell.

A 2.5, then, shall be its score,
For friendly hostess and quick seating, I did adore.
The decor, alas, didst seem a bit awry,
But nay, I shall not dwell on such things, for fear of being too picky.

I did the AYCE with my dear date,
Who loved the fried dishes, but sashimi, didst not partake.
One roll did fall apart, and I didst feel dismay,
But sake, they brought, and all was well, come what may.

'Tis a decent place, but better ones there be,
In the valley, for AYCE sushi, thou shalt see."

"I came back for round two, expecting better. But no, same old mess. Chaos and disorganization, long wait. Thirty minutes passed before I got my pie, then another fifteen. Unacceptable. Good pizza, but not worth the hassle. That's two strikes, pal. I'm out."

"O, how the prices did inflate, and the victuals, they did not impress. A barren dining hall, devoid of guests, yet still they seated us in an ill-favored spot. The vodka, it did flow with stinginess, and the helpings, they were meager, indeed. Alas, 'twill not endure, this woeful tavern, past a twelvemonth, mark my words."

"Char, two visits, two disappointments. Beef, overcooked both times. Second visit, burger, medium rare requested, arrived well done. Brisket burger, dry, flavorless. Onions, undercooked. Tater tots, decent. Service, good. Patio, pleasant. But, consistent beef blunders. Not worth it."

The hotel wasn't half bad for the price. Rooms were tidy, and they threw in a free breakfast. But their Wi-Fi was busted, and they charged my card four times for the same room. I tried to sort it out with the front desk, but the clerk flipped his lid, screaming at me like a madman. No help, no resolution, just a whole lot of aggravation. Now I'm stuck dealing with their corporate office and my bank. Turns out, Super 8 is a franchise, so there's not much the main office can do. I should've shelled out the extra 25 bucks for the Hilton Garden Inn and avoided all this hassle.
"Food's mediocre at best. Slapdash and hasty, not worth remembering. Thought we had a decent local spot, but this place falls short. Might give the banana pudding another shot, but that's it."

"Hark! A humble tavern we didst stumble upon,
Wherein we didst partake of victuals and drink.
The place, alack, didst seem a bit unkempt,
And chairs, with rents in their upholstery, didst shrink.
Our server, fair and diligent, didst toil,
With many tables, and ours, didst she beguile.
The wait, alas, didst drag, and Coca-Cola flat,
Didst leave me in a state of woe and discontent.
But lo! The British Burger, a feast most fair,
Didst fill my belly and delight mine taste.
My comrade's pulled pork sliders, a treat most rare,
Didst win her praise and cause her eyes to gleam.
In conclusion, thus, the food didst please,
But service, alack, didst leave much to be desired.
A bit of sprucing up, the dining room doth need,
To make it bright and welcoming, as 'twere a bower."
"Food was cooked right, ingredients fresh. But flavors were dull, portions off. Meat and eggs overwhelmed by mushrooms. Service slow, few customers. Bathrooms, a mess. Won't return soon."

In fair Las Vegas, we didst venture to dine At Stratosphere's Top of the World, a place divine. For our last night in town, we didst decide To give this eatery a try, and didst not hide Our anticipation for the view, so grand And worth the visit, as we didst understand.

The Oasis Suite, we didst book with ease For less than 100 coins, a price most pleasing. But to the restaurant, we didst not find The path most direct, and asked for guidance twain.

Once seated, we didst partake in bread Most tasty, and wine to quench our thirst and feed Our appetites. My wife didst order well, A ribeye, though not the most memorable meal.

I didst choose the lobster bisque, not bad, But better I have had, and prawns, scallops, and lobster, a dish most fair. The roasted salad and scallops, they didst please, But lobster and shrimp, a foul fishy taste didst seize.

A memory, now I do recall, of crab legs, A bite of shoulder meat, and there, that taste most foul. We shall not return for food, but may, For the view, most fantastic, have a drink, come what may.

In town, there be better places, for the same price, A fact most true. The view, five stars, I do give, In fairness, 'tis a sight most wondrous and nice.

"O, how vexing 'twas to wait in line,
With BFs in tow, what a woeful sign!
Hoochie mamas, they did stroll on by,
While we, poor souls, did wait and sigh.

A $20 cover charge, we thought 'twas fair,
But lo, they asked for $40, oh dear!
Each, they said, must pay this sum,
Or leave, and thus, our night be done.

A bottled water, too, did cost a pretty penny,
Nay, nay, we did not wish to spend so freely.
The highlight of the night, a sight most rare,
Dave Chappelle and Chris Rock, we did prepare.

In line, we saw them, oh, what joy!
But alas, the club, did play a dirty employ."

"Groupon's a bitch. Canyon Falls, too. Massage was a joke. Nice building, big room, but that's where the positives end. Therapist shows up, sees my Groupon, and I know it's gonna be crap. Short, weak massage. Left feeling oily and unsatisfied. Won't be back."

"TAO Beach ain't no big deal for Vegas. Area's tiny, daybeds packed, but prices ain't too steep. Water's murky, but hey, what can ya do? 

Place ain't about the experience, it's about who you're with. Had a blast with my buddies, but atmosphere was lackin', real hard. 

Been there, done that, no need to go back."

"First time here, five stars easy. Recent visits? Not so much. Restaurant week, good grub, but old mac and cheese with bacon, better than lobster. Service first time, top-notch. Latest time, disappointing. Waitstaff, hate restaurant week? Maybe. But I know how to tip, add dishes, respect the system. Didn't feel welcome, barely spoke to us. Ordered extras, still screwed up our food. Wrong table, no to-go boxes. Unacceptable. Not coming back."

"Hark! Last Friday eve, I chanced to see
The Wind Rises at this cinema, yea, verily.
A rating of two and a half stars doth seem fair,
But alas, they charge a premium, with nary a care.
So, two stars it shall be, by my reckoning.
Forsooth, I must up my stats, anon, 'tis true.

A pic of a dirty seat, most vile and base,
Didst thou behold? Fie upon it, what a disgrace!
Faux leather, worn and torn, a sight most sad,
Yet still, crumbs and stains did cling, like a curse, so mad.
$11, the cost of a ticket, oh how steep!
And $11 more, for popcorn and drink, didst thou keep?
A pox upon this place, that doth take and run,
With prices high, and service, poorly done.

Tourists, mayhap, do frequent this hall,
But locals, shun it, for the cost, standing tall.
My love, with AMC Stubs card, doth try,
To make use of it, ere it doth expire, by and by.

The picture and sound, were of good quality,
No fault found there, in truth, nor in verity.
But still, I say, Regal chain, doth reign supreme,
In comfort and worth, it doth outshine, serene."

"Alles ist already done. Who needs a construction site when the boss don't know where to start? Allvitalis is original, but lacks solidity, worth the price. Themed rooms are trimmed for show, but upon closer inspection, it's just a bunch of hooey. The carpenter's got a flea in his ear."

"Opened across from the brickyard, I'd been eager to try it. Twenty minutes for my order? Too damn long for lunch take-out. They ran out of boxes, so I got my pizza in a foil wrap. Cheese stuck to the foil like glue. Hard, unimpressive dough. Great spot, subpar grub. Won't be back."

"Methought I'd find a wondrous Walgreens here,
In this fair location, convenient and near.
But lo, the place was cramped, o'erpriced, and dire,
The layout, too, did chafe, like a ill-fitting sire.

The prices, I couldst forgive, forsooth,
Due to its site, a prime and busy trove.
But nay, the layout, alack, did grieve,
Especially the checkout, a woeful reprieve.

And since the Venetian, yonder, doth charge
A king's ransom, for each small, trifling large,
I thought this place, in contrast, wouldst be
More reasonable, in price, for thee and me.

Alas, my hopes were dashed, my dreams did fade,
For this Walgreens, though well-placed, did not persuade."

"Alas, my dearest Las Vegas, how art thou fallen! 

In days of yore, a humble Vietnamese eatery didst thrive, 
A haven of flavor, packed to the rafters with delight. 
The pho, a savory brew, didst warm the cockles of mine heart, 
Fresh veg and noodles, a feast fit for a king, didst ignite. 

But lo, the curse of progress didst descend upon the place, 
And with it came a change, a shift in priorities, alas! 
The broth, once rich, didst lose its former glory, 
The prices rose, the service didst become most lax. 

Yet still, a glimmer of hope doth shine, a beacon in the night, 
For in the realm of Chinese cuisine, they doth hold sway. 
K.J. Kitchen, a haven of delight, doth reign supreme, 
A veritable palace of gastronomic joy, a gem. 

But alas, my friends, this place, once great, doth now but pale, 
A shadow of its former self, a mere reflection of its former glory. 
Saigon 8, a newcomer, doth rise, a star ascendant, 
A shining light, a beacon in the night, a haven of delight."

"Fare thee well, good sirs and madams! Hark, what news I bring, of victuals most divine, yet service most vile and wretched. Verily, I say unto thee, shouldst thou desire to partake of their delectable dishes, 'tis best to make a call ahead, that thou mayst enjoy them in thine own domicile, free from the pangs of hunger and the torment of slow service. Forsooth, two stars doth merit the service, while four stars doth crown the fare. Alas, two hours didst pass, and still our meals didst not arrive, while those who came after us didst feast and depart ere we didst taste our main courses. Fie upon the waiters, say I, for their sloth and neglect! Yet, methinks the food didst make amends, for it didst please mine appetite and senses most wondrously."

"Drove five hours to meet TJ at the check-in counter. Unhelpful, uninterested. Reviews were right, check-in's a pain. Haven't seen the room yet. Smells like smoke and cleaning fluid. Bathroom and linens were clean, TV's a nice flat screen, bed's comfy. Won't stay here again. Service ruined our Vegas trip. Go to Flamingo or MGM."

"Chicken and waffles, best in town. But service? Shaky. Been here a few times, always good grub. But servers? Sourpusses. Don't ask for much, just a refill or some extra menu time. But get the stink-eye instead. Maybe they're having a bad week. Every week. Who knows? Still, good eatery. Go for the classics. Just don't count on friendly service."

"Travelocity's false ads. Renovated rooms? Don't believe it. Dirty pool chairs. Unfriendly front desk staff, especially Yvonne. Unimpressive restaurant. No fridge, bad bed. How's this place still open? Never again. Stay in downtown Scottsdale or Talking Stick instead."

"We yearned to adore this joint. Moved to the area, missed downtown Gilbert. Took the lads post-football game, a month back. Disappointment reigned. No fries at lunchtime? Odd. Greasy aroma suffocated the space. Frying something, no doubt. Server, a sweetheart. Kiddos, enamored with the popcorn machine. Alas, grub unworthy of return...for now."

"I gave the Burger Bar a passing grade, but barely. There's room for improvement and I expected more. The servers were friendly and attentive, but the kitchen was lacking. My meal wasn't served when I arrived and it wasn't as full as I had hoped. My neighbors at the table next to me were offered two free drinks by the house, probably because the wait was abnormally long...! I found my food to be a bit lacking in heat. The chicken wings weren't cooked enough, but the fries were good. Warning!!! They don't take reservations! Cash or credit only!!! (I'll give them another chance since every restaurant deserves a second chance, or maybe because I have another Groupon coupon...?!)"

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
My hopes for Indulge were quite depressed.
Their website, magazines, and drive-by views,
Did paint a picture of upscale hues.
But alack, the truth did soon reveal,
It was no different than a common steal.
Fuddruckers, thou art a poor disguise,
For mediocrity, in culinary wise.

Two burgers, built with care and thought,
And one pre-made, which we had sought.
Dill chips, an appetizer, we did try,
But none of us did utter a sigh.
Of satisfaction, that is to say,
For the food, it did not pass the play.

The tables, cramped and close together,
Did make us feel like we were in a fetter.
The noise, it did assault our ears,
And made us wish for silence, dear.
Our servers, eager to clear the space,
Did ask for dessert, before we'd grace.
The meal, it was a rush, a noise, a fray,
Not indulgent, in any way, I pray.

Oh, how my heart doth sink with woe,
For the experience, it was not a show.
Indulge, thy name doth not befitting,
For thou art but a mere pretending."

"Renovation, huh? Thought it'd be swanky, but still reeks of smoke. Nice lookin', though. Bartenders? Jerks. One guy, especially. Told us we had to bet to get free drinks. Dropped five bucks in three machines. Figured we were good. Girl orders scotch. He says it's ten bucks per machine. What a joke. Embarrassed for him. Dropped ten more in and said, 'Here's your tip. Let's see what happens.' Guess what? He lost. Total waste of space. Might drop a grand if I'm drunk, but piss me off and I'm outta there. Not gonna waste my time at a smoker's paradise like this. See ya."

"Food poisoning, I'm pretty sure. Ate here for the first time today. Bread was hard as a rock, gave me a stomachache. Chicken dish cost $18, but it was worth maybe $5. It was pounded thin, like a phonebook. Steak was the same, unpleasant to look at, and the taste was lame. Won't be going back."

"Hark! I had ne'er set foot within the pink pony's walls,
But curiosity didst drive me to its revamped halls.
Alas, I cannot say what vision they didst strive to bring,
But 'twas not the Old Arizona of yore, that much didst cling.
A youthful Scottsdale crowd, they seemed to seek,
Yet failed to capture that essence, in my humble shake.
My spouse and I, the youngest of them all, didst feel,
Like strangers in a strange land, without a friendly zeal.

Our server, though pleasant, was a sorry sight,
With little knowledge of the menu, a pitiful plight.
She vanished for a spell, leaving us to our own devices,
To hunt for ketchup and a soda, like savages in the wilderness.
The victuals themselves, a middling fare at best,
My crispy chicken, not crispy, and my husband's burger, unimpress'd.

And lo, the bathroom, a true test of a place,
Didst reveal a lack of care, a sorry state of grace.
A soaked and crumpled roll of tissue, lay upon the sink,
And filth upon the floor, a stench that didst not blink.
No part of my experience, didst make me wish to return,
Forsooth, this pink pony, a disappointment didst earn."
"Breakfast. Service poor. Waitress clueless. Food average. Unremarkable. Can cook better at home. Won't be back."

"Went in during the slow week and the joint was dead. Sat at the bar, waited for service, but the bartender seemed pissed when I asked about happy hour and what they had on tap. Won't be back, even though I've always dug this place. I know the business, and bad service keeps guests away more than bad grub."

"We hit JR's last night, my old man and me. Nice joint, limo, decor, service - all top-notch. But the grub? Underwhelming, to say the least. For the price they're charging, I expected to be blown away. Didn't happen. Felt like I was taken for a ride, you know? They brought us a glass of champagne right off the bat, without even asking. $45 a pop, and they didn't bother telling us till later. My guy got stuck with a $50 surcharge for a veggie starter, and they didn't mention that either. I know some folks don't sweat the small stuff, but for us, it wasn't worth it. (They took off the surcharge when we asked, though.)"

"Salad, huh? Yeah, that's what I thought. Problem is, it's the best part of the meal at this seafood joint. Spinach and berries, real tasty. Crabcakes? No way. Sent 'em back. Clam chowder? Watery mess. Friend's shrimp dish? Meh. Disappointed we came here instead of somewhere else in Phoenix/Tempe. Been here for work before, better food then."

The air was crisp, the vibe was mellow. But the wait for grub? A good 40 minutes. And let me tell you, that chicken quesadilla? Forget about it. Dry as the Sahara, overcooked like a Thanksgiving turkey. Chewin' it was like workin' a jawbreaker. No way, Jose. And them grilled onions? Don't even get me started. Sog city, population us. Not worth the trouble.

In fair Boca Park, where Rampart Boulevard doth lie, A Vietnamese restaurant, of high estate, doth sit. With artwork grand, a waterfall, and fish that doth swim, 'Neath floor, a wondrous sight, doth greet mine eyes. Our time, alas, didst limit us, and so we didst choose, To forego appetizers, and salads, in their stead. I, grilled tiger prawns, with garlic noodles, didst select, And my fair wife, Mama's ginger steamed sea bass, didst get. Alas, her dish, with fresh ginger, shitake mushrooms, and scallions, Didst lack the flavor, we didst expect, at such a cost. Yet still, the decor, and service, didst please our eyes, And though the food, didst not quite meet our surprise, We loved the place, and wouldst visit again, anon.

"Went there a few times, loved it. Great menu, wine, and bourbon. Last night, took some friends from Southpark, excited to try it out. Disappointment. Out of four wine choices, and the fifth wasn't worth it. Moved up to a better bottle, but still. Roof top was closed too. Won't be back for a bit, and my Southpark friends will stick to their own turf."

"A pox upon this salon, say I! For though my locks didst look fair and bright,
Their prices, they didst play a wicked trick.
I checked their site, and called, to make sure,
That for my wedding updo, I wouldst not be poor.
But when I came, with hair most dry,
My stylist didst insist, it must be blown dry.
And though I asked him thrice, to cease and desist,
He still didst charge me, for the blow dry, he didst persist.
And curling too, they didst charge, without a care,
An extra fee, that we didst not prepare.
Oh, how they took advantage, of our special day,
And left us poorer, in a most unkind way.
So here's a warning, to all who doth seek,
A salon, in a hotel, most unique.
Be wary of their prices, and what they do say,
For they may charge thee, in a most unkind way."

"Rainy day, arthritis acting up. Hunger pangs hit hard. Griff's diner, our salvation. They wouldn't let me use my teapot, but their tea wasn't half bad. Waitress, a friendly giant. Muffin, my meager meal. Five hours passed, rain subsided. Tea, my constant companion."

"Our service was most vexing, I must confess,
For when they first did ask, we were not prepared.
But some twenty-five minutes later, we were quite ready,
And the appetizers, they were most delectable, I swear.

Alas, my steak, it was not cooked to my liking,
For though I asked for medium rare, 'twas overcooked, I fear.
My friend, he sent his back, but I, in my folly,
Did not, for I had hoped they'd make it right, you see.

My second beer, it was not as the first,
In taste or appearance, it was quite diverse.
If thou dost forget, I shall remind thee,
For I did order a beer of a certain quality, thou shalt see.

Methinks I may return, but if the waitress be the same,
I shall flee, for her service was most tame."

"Went here 'cause our usual spot was closed for renovations. Two visits, couple hours apart. First, happy hour drinks, but slow service from a distracted waiter. Second, sat outside, half-full, but still poor service. Hostess brought menu and water quick, but that's it. Left after 17 min, still unfed. Hostess said they were understaffed, but food was decent - catfish nuggets and artichoke dip, good bar grub. Just need to get their act together, location's prime."

"Alas, our visit didst prove most vexing,
Upon a Saturday eve, we didst venture forth,
The waiting area, in disarray, didst present,
A chaotic scene, with naught but confusion and haste.

The restaurant, congested, didst resemble a fray,
With patrons, cramped, in narrow passageways, didst sway,
The line, a buffet, didst move at snail's pace,
And those who knew not what they wanted, didst impede the race.

The din, a cacophony of sound, didst assail,
Our ears, with music, loud and unrefined, didst prevail,
So great was the noise, we couldst scarce hear,
Even sitting close, our voices didst falter and fear.

The service, slow, didst add to our woe,
And to cap it all, my wife, in soy sauce, didst go,
Her white pants, stained, a sorry sight,
The waitress, with napkins, didst offer a poor plight.

The manager, with little care, didst seem,
And the waitress, shouldst have wiped the seat, with speed,
The food, good, but not fantastic, didst taste,
We served ourselves, no need for waitresses, in this place.

Farewell, good luck, to those who dine,
May your experience, be better than mine."

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, I chanced upon this eatery,
During Arizona Restaurant Week, with mine own sweetheart.
Alas, fair sir, our visit was most vexing, I do declare,
For service there was woeful, and left much to be desired.

Our waiter, a laggard, didst neglect us sorely,
We had to ask, nay, beg for menus, ere he brought them forth.
And though we sat and waited, parched and dry,
No refreshment came to hand, nor bread to mop our lips.

The meal, a lengthy wait, didst take its toll on us,
Whilst others, later seated, didst feast and make merry.
And when at last our cakes arrived, 'twas some twenty minutes past,
A sorry state of affairs, indeed, and cause for discontent.

In sooth, the victuals were but mediocre, I do confess,
Yet, service, poor and lacking, didst leave a sour taste.
A plague upon that waiter, say I, for his sloth and ill manners,
May he find his match in hell, or better yet, in purgatory's flames."

"A plague upon this wretched meal! The leather of my shoes doth seem more tender than this pie, which came to me barely warm and lacking its rightful garnish. And when the salad did finally grace my presence, 'twas but a paltry excuse for a side dish, with nary a fork to partake of it. Verily, the only solace I found in this woeful repast was the generous portion of toppings that did adorn my dish."

"Upon a Friday eve, when all the town did swarm
With folk seeking delight, I chanced upon
A humble tavern, whose menu did proclaim
A feast fit for a king, at prices quite fair.

But lo, the staff, though friendly of demeanor,
Did proffer dishes different from the bill
Of fare, which on their website did gleam so bright.
And thus, my hopes were dashed, my spirits did sink.

I ordered tacos, three in number, diverse
In flavor and in form, yet all did share
A common flaw, a lack of zest, a dearth
Of seasoning, which left my taste buds quite bare.

The carnitas, once a dish of renown,
Was now but a shadow of its former self,
Dried up and crunchy, with nary a trace
Of moisture or of flavor, alack and alas!

The fish, too, was a disappointment,
Baked, not grilled, and lacking in charm,
While the shrimp, so small and insipid,
Did little to assuage my growing discontent.

I ate but half, then cast the rest aside,
For poor value did it seem, and o'erpriced
Besides, the management, in their zeal
To compensate for lack of custom, did err.

Cut back your staff, I say, for fourfold
Is excessive, when but one customer doth come.
And thus, I left, my appetite unwhetted,
My purse lightened, and my mood somewhat glum."

"Noodle ChaCha, huh? Cute little Pucca-lookin' mascot, too. Suckered me right in. Big, empty restaurant. Lunchtime, not a soul around. Server comes up, gives us the specials. Thai fried rice, sweet and sour soup, sounded good. Milk tea, too. A buck, can't go wrong, right? Wrong. Tasted like mud. Disgusting. Sweet and sour, bland. Fried rice, like somethin' I could make at home. Chinese dried shredded pork on top? What the hell? Odd. Might give 'em another shot with their noodles. But for now, Pucca-lookalike didn't impress."

"Alas, the service we received was not so grand,
And the sushi, truth be told, was not so bland.
The serving maid, she tried to be quite witty,
But her words, they bordered on the rude and gritty.
She seemed to think herself a member of our crew,
But I, a guest, expected more decorum anew.
I do confess, a friendly demeanor I do admire,
But not at the expense of respect and proper fire."

"First visit, food good. Chicken puff, egg puff, pastries ordered. Pastries, best in US. Bad things:
1. Service terrible
2. No water, forgetful server
3. Slow service
4. Second visit, stale chicken puff. Manager unbothered. Go again for pastries."

"This joint's for the birds, kid. If you're into that sorta thing, you'll dig it. But if you're like me, you'll want to steer clear. I've been dragged in here a few times, and let me tell you, it's a real headache. But hey, it's not all bad. If you're looking for a gift for the ladies, you can't go wrong. They got all sorts of baubles and trinkets, and even some body jewelry for all you pierced folks out there."

"Co-worker calls in order at 1:30, gets told off by lady on phone. She's lucky it wasn't me, I'd have given her a piece of my mind. Order was mediocre, nothing special. Fast delivery, but that's about it. Not worth the money. Get a better phone person if you want repeat business."

"Food was good, view was great, service was bad. Server disappeared, left us hanging. We spent $70 on wine, glasses stayed empty. Would've ordered dessert, but it took too long. Forgotten, like we didn't matter. $300 for two people, expected better."

"Alas, my friends, we didst venture to this "sushi" place,
With hopes that 'twould be worth our while,
But alas, 'twas not to be, forsooth,
For though the fish was fresh, the taste didst lack guile.

The former owners, they didst know their craft,
And served us well with fish of goodly sort,
But now, alas, the quality doth wane,
And leaves us wanting, like a winter's frost.

I ordered traditional pieces, one by one,
To test the mettle of this sushi place,
But lo, the rice didst taste of naught but starch,
And lacked the zest of wasabi's fiery grace.

Some pieces, too, didst have a "fresh frozen" bite,
Which doth not befit a sushi of renown,
The "hamachi" was passable, but not by much,
The "ono" was thin, and sauce of unagi, quite bland.

The "ama ebi" didst suffer from old oil,
And shrimp head, small, like a child's plaything,
In sooth, my friends, this place doth not deserve,
Our custom, for a true sushi experience, we must seek elsewhere."

"I've been here a few times, but last weekend was likely my last. Maybe I'm just too old for the lines and the pushin' around, or payin' $16 for a mediocre drink. Pure's lost its magic for me. The club's pretty, the roof's my favorite. If I went back, that's where I'd stick to."

"No real job here. Just day-to-day work, $9/hr. Political surveys. Start at 2:30 pm, end time varies. Don't waste your time. Management treats employees like trash, jokes about exploiting the old, disabled, and poor. Not worth it. Look elsewhere."

"J'm La Frite, a name that's hard to ignore when you're craving some fast food. But this place, it's a bit off. It's trying too hard to be something it doesn't need to be. Like a kid dressing up for a McDonald's interview. I got a ham and cheese panini, and while it was good, it wasn't as pressed as I expected. Made me wonder if there was really cheese in there. My buddy got a burger that looked decent and a poutine, which was probably the best dish we ordered. The sauce was damn good, and the cheese curds were fresh, big, and made that nice squeak sound before they started to melt. For the poutine, it was worth it. For the rest, I felt like "meh." All in all, we spent a little over 20 bucks, so I don't think we got much value for our money."

"Picazzo's, once a fave, now fallen from grace. Service still good, but grub sub-par. Salad came with unlisted greens, server apologized for sub. Didn't ask if I wanted kale, which I didn't. Lettuce was brown, avocado price absurd. Not sure if I'll give it another shot. Appreciate the health nod, but meh."

"At Diablo's Cantina, don't expect top-notch grub and service. We waited 20 minutes just to get noticed, and when we did, the server barely muttered a greeting before pointing us towards the bartender for menus. And let me tell you, the food? Bland. Flavorless. A real disappointment. I won't be back, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone else either."

"Hark! This tavern doth provide a place to quaff,
And little else, alas! My expectations low,
I ventured in, yet found myself dismayed.
A fair selection of brews, the prices not too high,
But alack! The salad, a sorry sight, did lie.
$13, a steep price for such a meager fare,
Leaves me in doubt of other dishes there.
Yet, mayhap, friend, thou find'st solace in ale,
For in that, methinks, lieth this place's greatest appeal."

"Rockin' Railroad's good, but don't miss classes. Can't make 'em up after semester's done. My toddler's naps, work, and class times made it tough. Needed two more, but owner wouldn't budge. Kid was sick, kept him home. Now they offer play gym time, not worth it. Other classes, instructors were cool about makeups. Won't be back."

"Methought 'twas pleasant on my first visit, for 'twas late and open all night. But alack, upon mine second and third venture, I found cause to doubt its worth. The victuals and potables were naught but mediocre, o'erpriced by far. And, by my troth, their wi-fi policy doth vex me sore. Forsooth, they do compel one to purchase somewhat ere they share the pass, and every hour and a half, one must buy anew to keep the connection alive. Fie upon such foolishness! The furniture, too, doth cry out for repair, the leather couches and benches worn and faded. In sooth, I say, find elsewhere to spend thine hours, for this place doth not deserve thy custom."

"Tacos and tequila, that's what they had. Not much else. But it was enough. The margaritas were sweet and watery, like a summer rain. No chips or salsa, but who needs them when the tacos are this good? Cheap eats, that's what they called it. And that's exactly what it was. A place to fill your belly without emptying your wallet."

"Hark! This spread doth rival Golden Corral,  
With five hundred dishes, or so they say,  
A feast fit for a king, or one who doth aspire  
To taste all that doth lay before their eyes.  

But fear not, dear friend, for I have a plan  
To guide thee through this culinary land,  
And help thee make the most of thy hard-earned pay,  
And savor each morsel in a most delightful way.  

First, seek the cured meats and cheese, a treat  
For those who crave rich flavors, bold and neat;  
Next, sample the kobe beef sliders, small but true  
In taste and texture, worth a king's ransom, anew.  

The prime rib doth call thy name, a roasted delight  
That doth impress, and doth ignite thy appetite;  
And should thou find thyself in want of something light,  
The tuna sashimi salad doth provide a wondrous sight.  

Lastly, do not forget the sweets, a cornucopia  
Of sugary delights, that doth bring joy and euphoria;  
For in this realm of plenty, there doth lie a treat  
That doth surpass all else, and doth crown the feast.  

So, to the Bacchanal, give three and a half stars,  
For its grand scale and quality that doth transcend Mars;  
For though it may not be the Golden Corral,  
It doth stand tall, a worthy adversary, after all."

"Makmak, a place of sustenance, yet not of great renown,
With prices that do border on the high side, I must confess.
They do possess Singha, a beer of some repute,
But their tom yum, alas, doth leave much to be desired,
A taste most strange and not of the finest quality,
Yet, I have had worse, I must admit with some clarity.
The spring rolls, a common dish, nothing to boast,
And the pork dumplings, quite good, a joy to consume.
The peanut sauce, a delight, a true culinary treat,
But the pad thai, alas, I have not tried, my dear.
The service, quite good, with a smile and a cheer,
A cute place, indeed, with a certain je ne sais quoi, my dear."

"Swung by to return a trailer we hauled from Seattle. Waited 15 minutes while the two employees tended to other customers. Nice guy looked up our info on the computer since we lost the paperwork in the move. 

Other employee, not so much. Commented on his coworker's hygiene in front of a few customers. But hey, I'm in it for the equipment, not the service. 

Still, no issues coming back for more rentals. Convenient spot, big lot, and they're the only game in town. Just remember, Fridays through Sundays are busy, so plan accordingly."

"Methinks this library doth please me well,
Save for the tale-time, where children doth receive a seal.
A counselor, with voice both loud and clear,
Doth oft neglect the louder younglings, I do fear.
My own two-year-old, full of energy and cheer,
Doth join in the fun, yet doth not always hear.
Twice now, he hath been overlooked, and doth feel quite sore,
And thus, my pen doth write this review, in hopes of more.
For though the library be grand, and we do love to attend,
Inclusion of all children, that is my humble request, my friend."

"Who knew? Not me. Thought Twin Peaks was some mountain thing. But no, it's a joint in Vegas. And now there's one in Scottsdale. Walked in, thought, 'Damn, these gals are hot.' Compared to Hooters, this place is on another level. Food? Eh, it's alright. Big portions, but nothing special. They got some cute dessert called Scenic View, free for the ladies. Nice touch. Place itself is like an REI store, but with hot chicks. Cover charge of five bucks for UFC is cool. Wouldn't come for the grub, but hey, the view's nice."

"Methinks the victuals here be of excellent quality, mayhap the best I've had in all my days. But, alas, I do perceive a rise in prices, and methinks 'tis getting somewhat steep for what one doth receive. Twelve crowns for a dish of chicken fried rice, pray tell? And the broth, but a mere soup with a few slices of onion therein? Fie upon it! I do beseech thee, good sirs, to share thy thoughts on this matter, and how it doth compare to other establishments of similar ilk. Forsooth, I shall venture forth to Little Saigon, a Vietnamese eatery in Glendale, with a five-star rating, no less!"

"Methinks 'twas fortnight past, when first I didst set foot in this place they call Surprise, that I didst hear tell of a certain eatery known as New York Flavor. And thus, with mine own two eyes, didst I behold the sign that didst read, in bold letters, "New York Flavor". Methought, "Marry, what fortune! A taste of the Empire City, here in the desert!" And so, with haste, didst I make my way within, to partake of their culinary delights. 

The service, I must confess, was quite good. Forsooth, the maiden at the counter, when asked, didst guide me through the menu with grace and wit. And thus, I didst order the Spanish Harlem, with a side of potato salad, as suggested by the fair maiden. 

But lo, the potato salad, in a tiny cup it came, a mere morsel, a snack, a trifle! Methought, "Surely, this is some jest, some merry prank?" Forsooth, the portion was scant, and the taste, alack, was naught but common, akin to that found in the marketplace. And thus, I didst pay $1.99 for two bites of potato salad, a sorry sight indeed. 

The sandwich, however, didst please mine taste. The spread, flavorful, and the steak, cooked to perfection. The bread, alas, was naught but ordinary. And thus, for $8.99, a sum not small, didst I partake of a meal, that, though not unpleasant, didst not live up to the standards of the Big Apple, whose name it doth bear. 

In conclusion, fair friends, the service, indeed, was good, but alas, the food, a disappointment. For in New York, they do say, "You get what you pay for," and thus, I didst not find it worth the cost."

In fair Goodyear, a new pizza place doth shine,
With interior fair, as newness doth entwine.
Thin crust, not of New York or Chicago breed,
Yet still, a native New Yorker finds it pleasing indeed.
A year hath passed since search began in earnest,
For slice of pizza worthy of the city's name.
This, alas, doth not fulfill that fond desire,
But still, 'tis pizza good, with cheese of finest fame.
Above the rest, in West Valley, doth it stand,
A worthy choice, though not of highest rank in hand.

"Lukes of Chicago, a second location, keeps tradition alive in the valley's northeast. Lunch varies - sometimes quick, other times a wait. Chili cheese dog, always wonderful, sloppy too. Crinkle cut fries, a bonus. Order lost once, busy rush, small space, old-style tickets. Give Luke's a shot, Scottsdale, no fuss, next to Sam's Club/Walmart."
"Vegas buffets, I thought they'd be better. Nice display, but the grub? Meh, still a buffet."

"A feast fit for kings, with atmosphere most fine, 
A menu grand, with dishes of the land and sea. 
Steaks, fowl, fish, and duck, all make an appearance, 
And sushi, tartare, too, for those of such persuasion. 
Lobster, artichoke, and sprout, pear, and bacon, 
In salads, soups, and stews, a veritable cornucopia. 
The meats, oh so rich, and cooked to perfection, 
Presented with flair, a true culinary obsession. 
But alas, the service, slow as molasses in winter, 
Our server, scarce, and with a heavy French accent, did stammer. 
We waited, glasses empty, bread, a rare sight, 
No server in view, to ease our plight. 
Aganche, white chocolate, we shared, to end the night, 
Medicinal, licorice-like, a curious delight. 
Our server, appeared, a third time, to say, 
The dessert, worth the wait, but we had gone astray. 
Three and a half stars, I would give, for the fare, 
But service, poor, a true disappointment, beyond compare."

"In this fair city of New York, where bustling crowds do roam,
A gentler soul doth dwell, within a place called home.
A restaurant once, now transformed, doth hold a charm,
With victuals of sport, and wings that do disarm.

The flavors of the wings, they doth abound,
A feast for taste buds, and a sight most profound.
So if thou find thyself, in this city of old,
Do seek out this place, where sports and grub do unfold."

"Hark! Good sirs, what be thy desire? Water, perchance? Or mayhap something more? Our repast was fair, but alack! Our server's skill did leave much to be desired. A salad, twain pizzas, thrice appetizers, two cups of wine, and a pitcher did we order, yet our man did seem to think we would be content with naught but water and pizza. Alas! The victuals were good, but our server's efforts did fall short. Drinks missed, orders awry; methinks I may not return to Federal Pizza anon, such being the case."

"Hark! What spectacle doth mine eyes perceive?
Athletic maidens, scantily clad, do writhe
Upon the ground, their supple forms a-twist,
In fervent passion, with nary a stitch.
Their beefy counterparts, of eastern Europe bred,
Do sweat and pant, their muscles bulging, red.
Acrobatics and water stunts, a blur of flesh,
A two-hour ride of lust, that doth leave me breathless.
When ended, I did towel off and shower,
Then left my home, to witness 'Le Reve' at Wynn's tower."

"Methinks this place doth have a staff most bipolar,
Whence some days thou art met with kindness so fair,
That thy heart doth sing with joy, and thou dost tarry,
To partake of their brew, and savor each sip with glee.
But lo, on other days, thy hopes doth dwindle,
For thou art met with scowls, and service most gruff,
Leaving thee to ponder, if thou shalt return,
Or flee, and seek elsewhere, a more pleasant haven."

"Food was decent, but the salt ruined it. Service was good though. Went back for the Super Bowl, but they wanted to charge me like they paid to stream it. Prices were outrageous, 85 cents per wing?! Ridiculous when you can get them for 50 to 6 cents elsewhere."

"Whilst I did wait for my takeout, a group of four seniors did leave,
With smiles on their faces, and joy did they bring.
One of the fair ladies did say, "Tis our fave place,
Where every dish doth please, and ne'er doth disgrace."
She gathered all the cards, and off did she go,
To spread the word, and let all know.

I pondered long o'er the menu, a feat,
For Chinese food, I knew not what to eat.
At last, I chose the ma po tofu, and lo mein,
And off did I drive, with a grin.

But alas, the takeout bag, a mess did make,
All sauced up, and nary a mistake.
The tofu, with ground chicken, light and fine,
But the noodles, oh how they did decline.
Excessive oil, a chef gone wild,
A pity, for the Peking duck, I did desire,
And still do plan, to give it a try,
And see if it doth change, my mind's eye."

Hark! My dearest girlfriend and I didst venture hither,
To partake in breakfast feast, at Dan Marino's place,
Within the Hooters Hotel, where we didst lay our head,
And rose anon, to dine upon their morning grace.

A coupon book, with offer of a 2 for 1 deal,
Didst entice us, to their breakfast buffet, so grand,
For ten gold coins, a regular price, I do confess,
But with the coupon, 'twas a steal, a true success!

Scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, diced potatoes, too,
Dry cereal, waffles with strawberries, a treat for thee,
Bread pudding, fruit, a veritable cornucopia,
A feast most satisfying, and a bargain, beyond compare!

Coffee, milk, OJ, or soda, didst complete the meal,
A fair exchange, for what we didst receive, most real.
So if thou find thyself, in this fair city's bounds,
Do stop by Dan Marino's, and taste their breakfast rounds!

"The Southern's a decent spot, nice decor, well-laid out. Plenty of room too. But do I really need another burger joint with the same menu as Holyrood 9A and Red Squirrel? I mean, I enjoy a good burger, but some variety would be nice. And what's with the wooden slabs instead of plates? Is that some new trend or something? I did enjoy my burger though, can't deny that. But overall, it's just more of the same."

"Rooms at this swanky Vegas hotel were nothing to write home about. Sure, they were priced right, but the elevator ride up was a real pain in the neck. Each one creaked and groaned like it was going to break down any second. And don't even get me started on the pyramid soap. It was a novelty, I guess, but not worth the hassle. No WiFi in the rooms either. What's up with that?\nThe casino floor was alright. Big and flashy, but easy to get turned around if you weren't paying attention. Pool was nice, but everything else came with a hefty price tag. All in all, it was just okay."

"Hark! If Bistro on the Avenue didst launch anew,
In any place but Westmount, 'twouldst not endure,
For price and innovation, both doth lack,
And thus, 'twouldst not be worth a second look.

Yet, there, 'tis cherished by the local folk,
A convenient choice, when cooking doth grow tiresome.
So, though we wouldst not seek it out afar,
We wouldst not mind returning now and then,
To partake in their fare, and savor the charm."
"Ate here twice at the casino. Food was alright, better than expected. Onion straws, real good."

"Frances' sales are top-notch. Their stuff ain't cheap, but you can find some one-of-a-kind items - great for gifts. I'm a big fan of the store, I am. But, I gotta watch my wallet. Wish they had more options for us penny-pinchers."

"A year past, I didst visit this place,
Where seafood doth abound in grace.
Shrimp, crab claws, oysters baked so fine,
Didst make my taste buds dance and twine.
I didst wait a year, with eager heart,
To savor those dishes once more to part.
But alas! The menu didst change,
And my desired feast didst range.
I didst order lobster, stuffed with care,
But 'twas not what I had waited for, I swear.
The wine, too, didst have cork within,
Even when they tried again, twice to win.
My first visit, five stars didst earn,
But now, three stars, my rating doth return."

"Methinks 'twas not the first time we didst dine here,
Forsooth, my daughter, then a babe most fair,
Didst fuss and cry, so brief was our stay.
But now, in this, our second coming hither,
The place doth seem most neat and cleanly,
Yet chairs, alack, too low they be,
For tables, making us feel quite uneasy.
Highchairs, they didst bring, yet not so high,
Our younglings, standing on our laps, didst try
To see the feast, their plates, they couldst not spy.
I held her plate, my daughter, that she might eat,
And thus, the service, friendly, was most meet.
A youthful child, afraid of flashy show,
The chef, didst tone it down, his art to know.
Sushi, most excellent, and appetizers, fine,
But rest of dinner, left me somewhat divine.
A pink paste, added to all, a curious zest,
Yet made each dish taste much the same, I didst find.
Methinks, for sushi, I wouldst return again."
"Hotel's not bad. I dig it here. No Cirque du Soleil, but who needs 'em? Place can get dull, though. Marquee parties? Annoying. Drunk folks? They run the joint."

"A pleasant dining hall, with garnishes so fine,
A menu rich, and fit for any dine.
The tempura'd asparagus, a tasty delight,
Though portion size, did leave me in a plight.

Hoagies, oh hoagies, how thou art divine,
With prime rib, sliced thin, and cheese so fine.
My wife, she had hers, with spinach and cheese,
Whilst I, with mushrooms, onions, and cheese, did please.

The rolls, so soft, did complement the feast,
And juices flowed, as if from the East.
Fries, crispy and golden, a perfect side,
To this repast, so satisfying and wide.

I shall return, for dinner, I do swear,
For though 'tis busy, the fare, I hold dear."

"A fair establishment, with tasty starters, indeed. Alas, the steak, it doth leave much to be desired. Forsooth, 'twas overcooked, and lacked that certain je ne sais quoi. But fear not, dear friends, for I shall return anon, to partake of their finer cuts, forsooth. For though the steak didst disappoint, the surroundings and attendance didst please mine eyes and senses well."

In fair Paris Hotel Casino, we didst dine,
Where our hostess, with grace and poise, didst seat us.
Upon the edge of the restaurant, we didst sit,
To watch the people pass, in endless wit.

I, a fish dumping noodle bowl, didst order then,
And my fair wife, a won ton soup bowl, didst choose.
A plate of mini pork buns, we didst request,
As the dim sum cart, didst make its way to us.

The verdict of our meal, was somewhat mixed,
Our soups, quite tasty, but a bit too small, were fixed.
The pork buns, alas, didst lack moisture,
And forty-six dollars, the cost, didst procure.

In Vegas, we didst dine, with reckless abandon,
Yet, the price, didst seem, a bit too extravagant.
Still, the experience, was not without delight,
For in the city of sin, we didst dine, with all our might.

"Hark! Their sandwiches be of generous size,
The ciabatta bread, a feast for thine eyes.
And whispers say, the nine-grain doth please,
A culinary delight, beyond all measure.

But alas, my roast beef provolone,
Didst not agree with mine own belly's moan.
Perhaps, I shall return to Jimmy John's,
For my next sandwich, with haste and speed."

"Secret Garden's pricey, and they don't offer military or local discounts. It's small too, with tiny habitats that can't accommodate a sprint. The animals were sluggish, even Siegfried. But he still took a pic with my kids. Not worth the cash."

"Hark! A place of plenty, fit for any purse,
Where portion sizes be generous, of course.
Their mac salad, a dish most fair and bright,
And spam musubi, a treat most wondrous in sight.
Chicken katsu, crispy without, tender within,
A feast most satisfying, for hunger to win.
When belly be empty and craving doth strike,
This place shall provide sustenance, and naught else seek.
A fullness that lasteth, for hours upon hours,
A veritable feast, for all thy hunger's powers."

"Arriba's, day one of my three-day AZ Mexican food tour. Dinner with the fam - bro, aunt, and uncle. Not too shabby, but here's the lowdown:

Chips - 4 stars, crispy, warm, good salsa and bean dip.

Service - 3 stars, friendly and informative server, but forgot my uncle's extra hot salsa. He got it halfway through the meal.

Food - 2-4 stars, my green corn tamale was meh, dry and lacking that corny flavor I craved. Uncle enjoyed his Chile though.

Decor - 3 stars, nothing special, but not bad either. Cleanliness was questionable.

Verdict? Single store mom and pop for me next time."

"A speedy wash, and cheap, not bad at all, my friend! Free vacuums too, a bonus, methinks. Stay in thy carriage, and a fellow at the end doth wipe it clean. A goodly job, indeed. For a monsoon-drenched conveyance, this place doth fit the bill. Alas, no full detailing, nor interior tidying. Yet, a small towel, once given, now doth dwindle. Still, 'tis a worthy stopgap, till next thou dost require a thorough cleansing."

"Hark! What news is this? Thou art still in trade, good sir! Methinks 'twas fortune's grace that led me to thy door, for had I not possessed a device to traverse the ethereal realm, I fear thou wouldst have remained unknown to me.

"And thus, I must confess, thy victuals didst please mine taste, as did the warmth of thy hospitality. A half-turkey sandwich, with macaroni salad, didst suffice for my repast, while mine husband didst enjoy pastrami, accompanied by potato salad. Our beverages didst flow like the Nile, and thus our total sum didst amount to twenty gold coins, ere the customary gratuity.

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that should thy prices bend a mite toward the affordable, we wouldst partake in thy culinary delights with greater frequency, and perchance even indulge in sweet desserts."

"Methinks 'twas my first time to partake of Poutine,
And though 'twas passable, better dishes I did find.
Our server, friendly and kind, didst make our stay most pleasant,
And the backyard, with its quaint decor, didst win my approval.

Alas, the place doth cater to tourists, I do fear,
And compared to others, lowly ranked doth appear.
Coffee, thou art best avoided, instant being the choice,
For beer, the better option, doth bring joy and rejoice.

We did not sample other dishes, alack and alas,
But if in need of sustenance, I might return, perchance.
So if thou find thyself in that fair city,
And dost desire a snack, give this place a chance, mayhap."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aged aunt didst take me to dine,
At Ruby Tuesday's, where we didst partake,
Of their most wondrous feast, a veritable delight,
A burger, nay, two, with salad bar in sight.

Oh, how we laughed and joked, my kin and I,
At the thriftiness of my father's kin,
But lo, my aunt, a sly one, didst produce,
A stack of coupons, and our mirth didst cease.

I, myself, do swear by burgers, 'tis my creed,
Or chicken sandwich, should I be in need,
For who doth care if grill marks doth grace,
The fowl that doth arrive upon the plate?

Ruby Tuesday's, wise guile, doth offer two,
Mini burgers, salad bar, for price so low,
And now, a new addition doth they bring,
Pimento cheese, my heart doth sing with joy.

Alas, two things I miss, from days of yore,
Bread and butter pickles, pineapple, no more,
Why, oh why, doth my voice doth raise,
In sorrow, at their absence, such a pity, alack."

"Four sprites we have, and in this shop we didst spend,
Two hundred dollars, and two hours, 'twas no sin.
'Tis wondrous, yet crowded, a tourist trap, no doubt,
But gifts for our young ones, we doth bring without a rout.

In Vegas, we doth not take the little ones,
But presents, we doth bring, upon each trip, anon.
This emporium, multi-levelled, doth contain,
M&M treasures, thy children shall surely obtain.

My daughter, she didst request, a token from this place,
When next we doth visit, in January's frosty grace.
The staff, kind and helpful, lines long, we didst find,
Prices steep, but location, convenience, doth bind.

Forsooth, without the young ones, this shop doth lose,
Its charm, its lure, its magic, doth dispose.
Navigating, a mite perplexing, 'twas no jest,
But patience, we doth muster, for our little guests."

"A humble abode of pizza and pasta,
Where one may order at the counter with ease,
And for a fair price, a hearty meal shall pass,
With sides of salad and bread, a feast for all to seize.
The fare is plain, yet service with a smile,
Two thumbs up, for their hospitality doth prevail.
The premises are tidy, and the privies too,
But alack, a refill doth cost a golden ducat anew.
Cash only, a minor quibble, yet a quip,
For those who seek a quick and tasty snack, 'tis a trip."

"Hark, I've longed to visit this marketplace,
Where farmers sell their wares, fresh and fair.
The downtown scene, with veggies picked clean,
Leaves me unsatisfied, a hunger unseen.

So, with a day free, I set forth to roam,
And find this place, where bounty doth abound.
The sign doth say, it opens at ten,
But lo, the granola types, they swarm in,
Ere we arrive, with elbows deep in produce,
A fear that we may miss the finest choose.

McClendons, the vendor of most, doth bring
A feast for eyes, with colors bright.
Beets of purple, leeks of deepest green,
Potatoes small, and shallots, broccoli seen.
Organic, some, and labeled with care,
From Willcox, freshness doth abound there.

Five registers open, lines do form,
Housewives swift, their veggies they do storm.
Quick, one must be, to avoid a fray,
But worth it, for the freshness of the day.

Beyond the veggies, crafts doth abound,
Soaps, blankets, jewels, yarns, a bread round.
A visit, worthwhile, if in the area,
But not worth travel, for me, alas, no fear."

"Haven't been here in a while, but damn glad I came back. Service top-notch. Steak and shrimp, cooked to perfection. Salad bar, loaded and fresh. Finished with DIY strawberry shortcake, worth the trip."

"Amidst the throng, a multitude of seats doth abound,
And swift attendants, with alacrity they move around.
The interior bar, new life hath recently found,
Yet, as with most, the ambiance doth ebb and flow,
Depending on the hour and day of the week,
As slow days bring forth bartenders, friendly and meek.
Their aim, to ease thy headache, and banish thy woe."

"Upon mine ears, didst thou hear the tales of yore?
A place of wonder, where survival doth await,
In truth, a souvenir shop of zombie lore,
With trinkets, tees, and toys, to make one's day great.

For those who doth delight in undead cheer,
This place doth hold a special kind of glee,
Interactive games, and novelties so dear,
To make the heart of any zombie fan sing.

Alas, my hopes for practical gear were dashed,
The MREs, pricey, as were other camping stash,
But still, a Twinkie, didst I purchase with haste,
A sweet reminder, of a fun-filled quest.

So, if thou find thyself, in this place of dread,
With friendly staff, and zombie-themed delight,
Do enter, and partake in the fun,
For in this shop, thy spirits shall be light."

"Service was top-notch. Staff was friendly and accommodating. Not the best spot for kids, though. No sippy cups. Stuffed mushrooms were good, but not piping hot. Eggplant and veal parm were tasty, but a bit pricey. Feels like they're trying to be both casual and fancy. Nice touches like linen napkins and oil lamps, but they use tissue paper plate liners. Might go back without the little ones. Patio looked nice for outdoor seating."
"Happy hour, empty joint. Slow trickle of folks. Drinks, five or six bucks. Sangrias, wine, martinis. Food's good. Sample platter, plenty to eat."

"Pie we sought, and found it to our delight,
The apple's filling, spicy and quite bright.
But alas, the crust, uncooked did remain,
A pity, for I did not partake in the gain.

The portion, large and enough for three,
A feast, but not for one such as me.
The key lime, a treat, a larger share,
Than other places, beyond compare.

Yet, not the best pie, our search doth continue,
For that most perfect slice, our hearts do yearn.
The service slow, the waitress kind,
A gentle soul, with grace of mind."
