"At last, my dearest friend, thou didst persuade me to dine at Texaz, a place of which thy tongue didst speak so highly. And lo, my heart was gladdened, for the victuals were not unpleasing unto mine taste. But alas, I didst discover a truth most vexing, that all our companions had partaken of the chicken fried steak, and found it to be most delectable. Fie upon my forgetful mind, that didst not recall this detail. Mayhap next time, I shall savor the delicacy myself."

"Food's been decent here before. Not today though. Service was slow. Asked for water thrice before we got it. Shouldn't have to ask that many times. Ordered and still waiting for water. That's not how it's done."

"Verily, fair sir or madam, thou seeketh sustenance and hospitality of high quality? Pray tell, what be the cost of such bounty? Hark! A hidden charge doth lie within the bill, yet fear not, for they do reveal it ere ye take thy seat. 'Tis a sumptuous feast of five dollars and ninety-nine pence, all thou canst eat, but mark this well, good sir or madam, shouldst thou not possess their "player's card," an additional three dollars per person shall be added thereto. So, choose wisely, lest thy purse suffer undue strain."

"Nice joint, but the smoke got to me. Couldn't stick around for more than an hour. Everyone was smoking, too much for my taste. The DJ, a cool chick, spun some great tunes though. This spot's different from most, but they charge $10 per woman. Not my scene, but I'd hit up XS next time."

"This joint's alright for a quick stop, but don't expect a Super-ShurSave. No endless aisles here. The produce section's my only gripe. I'm particular about freshness. I'm a bargain hunter, but for fruits and veggies, I'll shell out extra at Giant Eagle Market District."

"O, how I adore the Venetian, with its walls and ceilings so fair and bright, and the performers on the street, they do delight. And thus, to dine within this open space did seem a wondrous plan. But alas, the wait did stretch to twenty minutes, and so we did imbibe a glass of wine at a nearby bar, to pass the time. And when we were finally seated, we did command our drinks, and I, being from Miami, didst take heed of the caipirinha's flavor, for not all know its true taste. But lo, it was most vile, and both my comrade and I didst send them back, in dismay. Then, the waiter, with a smile so bright, did recommend the pomegranate mojitos, and I, with trepidation, did accept. Alas, they too were woeful, but I would not return two cocktails, lest I seem ungrateful.

And thus, we came to the fare, and oh, how it did disappoint. A pasta dish, savory and grand, I did expect, but nay, it was but ordinary, and lackluster, at best. Alas, Postrio, thou hast all the elements, to make a feast most wondrous, but alack, thy cooking, doth leave much to be desired. Step up thy game, I pray thee."

In this place of gathering, the decor doth please,
A mishmash of styles, yet harmonious it seizes.
The servants, kind and welcoming of face,
Do serve small dishes, fit for a merry embrace.

Drinks, they do pour, with strength and art,
Syrups, homemade, to delight the heart.
A place to meet, in early eve's glow,
But watch thy purse, lest it doth overflow.

Four or five stars, they shall attain,
With time, their reputation doth remain.

"Breakfast with a friend at Whole Foods this mornin'. First time for me, but she comes here regular. I had the garden omelette and apple cinnamon toast. Tasted healthy, it did. She had the oatmeal with brulee topping and fresh berries. I tried it, pretty good. Nothin' spectacular, but good. Plenty of seats and the service was quick. I'll be back, hear the sweet potato fries are top-notch."

"A fair abode, with modern gadgets galore,
To turn on lights, open blinds, and more.
But woe betide the guest who's not versed in tech,
For they may find themselves in quite a predicament, indeed.

They seek to make things easy, but alas,
No coffee maker in the room, what a pity!
So off to the casino one must trot,
To fetch a cup of joe, or so they thought.

But we, who stayed four days, had a plan,
To buy a machine, and leave it for the maid,
A gift, a token, for their diligent care,
And now, a cup of coffee's always near."

"Tao, a club most wondrous, I have visited thrice,
And found my thoughts of it, did change with time.
At first, I loved it, the decor, the girls, the vibe,
But later, found it crowded, and hard to abide.

The doormen, strict, and eager to take your gold,
Demand a table, or entry, you shall not behold.
We, a group of four, were turned away,
But luckily, a friendly doorman, did save the day.

Once inside, the place, doth fill with people fast,
Leaving little room, to move or dance, or find a place to rest.
A fire hazard, it may be, but still, a sight to see,
The bartenders, skilled, and the bathing girls, a delight to me.

Yet, the doormen, rude, and bouncers, unkind,
Do make the place, less pleasant, to the mind.
Still, Tao, a club, unique, and worth a visit,
For all, at least once, should give it a try, and see its merit."

"Aye, 'tis a fair place to take the young ones, I reckon. Not so much for grown-ups, save those who dote on penguins, mayhap. 'Tis not a zoo of great renown, save for the clever staging of beastly abodes, methinks."
"Fair Mexican grub. Generous helpings for the buck, but nothing special taste-wise. Proximity to my digs earns 'em a second chance. Won't trek far for it, though."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, their victuals be of high quality, when they have them in store. Alas, the goat cheese curds doth disappear with great frequency. And mark my words, dear friend, avoid thou trivia night, lest thou desirest poor service. 'Tis as if thy presence doth inconvenience them, ere the quiz beginneth."

"Orlando's flight didst bring us joy, an hour early didst we land,
Airport tram didst take us to baggage claim, thence to taxis at hand.

But alas, fair Vegas, thy departure didst not go so well,
Southwest's curbside check-in and skycaps didst serve us swell.
Yet one small snow globe, a token of the city's charm,
Didst cause a fuss, and TSA didst send thee back, to post office disarm.

Gate C1, we thought, close by, a short stroll,
But lo, a lengthy trek didst lie ahead, a goodly role.
The tram, which brought us in, didst now seem far away,
And C1, the last gate, didst appear, a crowded fray.

Ah, how they love to welcome thee, but hate to bid thee adieu,
A prison-like gate, full to the brim, didst wait for thee anew."
"Skillets for brekkie? Top-notch, kid. Patio's nice too, with them mistin' machines blastin' away. Real refreshing."

"Been comin' here for years. Time for a review of the buffet. Cut to the chase: food's average. Nothin' fancy, but better than mystery meat in gravy. Breakfast's got waffles, french toast, omelets, breakfast meats 'n' potatoes. Lunch 'n' dinner's the same: fried seafood, pizza, Chinese food (which is pretty tasty), some nights got crab legs 'n' steaks for a bit more. Wait staff's generally nice 'n' attentive. Price can't be beat: 6-9-12 bucks for breakfast, lunch, 'n' dinner, respectively, with a player's card. Can't find a better deal elsewhere. In review: it's cheap, it's basic."

"Fair Basha, thy victuals be of quality,
With meat most genuine, not the tainted sort,
Thy salads too, fresh as the morning dew,
A feast for eyes and taste, no need to fault.

But, alas, thy female servants, fair,
From Middle East, their ways not ours,
Do shun the men, and scant their duty bear,
In this, the land of liberty and power.

For here, in West, men and women meet,
In shops and markets, all do greet,
No shame in't, nor impoliteness found,
For such is custom, and tradition bound.

So, Basha, heed my words of wisdom,
Train thy females, in our ways of pleasantry,
Lest they, in scorn, do shun the male clientele,
And thus, poor service, doth bring thee naught but woe.

For I, myself, have witnessed, twice,
Their scant regard, and sullen, troubled vice,
At Ste Catherine, Peel, a dame most dire,
And at Place Mont Royal, a woman, coy and shy,
Whose husband, bald, and friendly, didst seem,
Yet she, with scorn, didst give me change, most queer.

If she, in truth, doth loathe the male folk,
Then let her hide, in kitchen's darkest nook,
Where she, from men, may safely be apart,
And thus, no more, our custom, doth impart."

"I stepped into the joint, blinded by the garish floral seat covers. They were a real eyesore. But the rest of the place wasn't so bad - round tables, red lanterns, and some old-time Christmas tunes playing in the background. I was feeling pretty cheerful, waiting for my grub.

I went for the soup dumplings and fried string beans. Twenty bucks for two dishes, not too shabby.

The verdict? The dumplings were just okay, a bit overcooked. The green beans were tasty, but man, they were swimming in grease.

I might give this place another shot. Didn't exactly love what I had, but it wasn't all bad."

"Monica, the waitress, was a merry maiden indeed,
Her service, friendly and attentive, did my heart cheer.
A burger, plain yet tasty, did she bring to me,
And when I questioned the total, she did clarify.
'Twas a small oversight, the coupon, she did say,
And I, feeling foolish, did quickly pay.
The wait, a bit long, but her smile made it worth,
I would return, for her kindness, of great worth.
The eatery, clean and tidy, a pleasant sight,
The twang of country music, a bit too bright."

"Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place twice now, and verily, 'tis a hit or miss affair. Despite the renovations of yore, the cafeteria feel doth linger still. The selection, middling at best, doth depend on the day. Alas, my previous visits hath left me unimpressed, but lo, I did return last week, for George Michael did play at the MGM, and thus, I gave the buffet another chance. By fortune, the steak station was open, and the savory scent of grilled meat did stir my appetite. The crab legs, too, were delectable and sweet. Yet, alack, a special event price of ten dollars more per person did make our visit costly. Forsooth, had we planned better, we might have gone to the Wynn instead."

"Moved from Chi-town, needed good sushi in Madison. Found it in a strip mall, next to a buck store. Surprised me, exceeded expectations. Been going for a year and a half, still worth recommending. Lunch special's a steal, two rolls and miso soup for cheap."

"A plentitude of confections, they do boast,
But, alas, their prices do border on the coast.
The servitors, not overly cordial, I fear,
Yet, verily, the gelato doth taste most dear."

"Goodtimes, huh? I reckon it's worth two stars, maybe three if you're feeling generous. But let me tell you, I'm no local, just passing through. Can't speak to its consistency, y'see.

Stopped by on a Thursday night, they call it "Carpe Noctem", Goth night, that is. Kids in the parking lot, dressed up spooky and all, hearse parked outside. Figured we were in the right place.

Dance floor was decent, full of people, but the bar area, empty. Bartender, quick and friendly, pours a good drink. Got myself a nice buzz going, decided to hit the dance floor. Problem was, not enough space, weird metal plates, felt like I was gonna slip 'n fall.

Can't judge a Goth club on one visit, that's the truth. It's a scene, a lifestyle, takes time to fit in. Remembered how long it took me to feel welcome at my own club back home. So, won't make any hasty judgments here.

Goth scene, dying off, slowly (ahh, pun intended). Take what you can get in Vegas, that's the way it is."

"Methinks my son and I didst venture to Elmer's place,
Forsooth, to partake of their culinary grace.
A first-time feat, indeed, for both of us,
To savor the flavors that this eatery doth proffer.

My son, with haste, didst choose the Asada burrito,
Whose taste, he said, didst please his palate well.
Whilst I, with hunger pangs, didst opt for the green beef,
In a hot burrito, whose messiness didst compel me
To seek aid from utensils, to consume with ease.

Their menu, though not vast, doth offer much delight,
At prices, fair and square, that doth astound.
And, verily, they do accept debit cards,
A boon, indeed, that doth set them apart.

Alas, the state of their premises, didst leave much to be desired,
With remnants of food, upon the floor, untidied.
Yet, methinks, their fare, and service, doth make up for such flaws,
And thus, to Elmer's, shall we return, anon."

"Hark! A place of gastronomic delight, we chanced upon,
After a long day of conferring, 'twas nigh.
I ordered clam chowder, with great anticipation,
But alas, 'twas lacking in seasoning, a sad creation.

The calamari, a dish of squid, was lightly breaded,
And though I prefer it so, it left me unimpressed.
The aioli, a sauce of garlic and oil, was good,
But not enough to save the dish, I must confess.

The pizzas, round and topped with cheese and toppings,
Were decent, but not exceptional, in my humble opinion.
And shrimp, those tiny crustaceans of the sea,
In cocktail form, were quite agreeable, I must see.

The service, too, was passable, not bad,
But not exceptional, like a play well-rehearsed."

"Cheap grub, mediocre quality, spotty service. Large groups and families welcome. Comparable to Paradise Buffet or any other Freemont buffet. Bathroom wall supposedly part of Berlin Wall. Sunday brunch costs $12 with club card, decent value. Food's alright, prime rib's okay, but avoid chewy brisket. Bar serves beer for $1. Service is unpredictable, sometimes good, sometimes non-existent. Waiters appear twice during meal, no drink refills. Decor's generic, like service. Located in Main Street Station casino, at end of Freemont Street Experience. Rate it: 3."

"Solid coffee joint in a decent neighborhood. Friendly gals workin' here, coffee's good, not the best I've had, but I prefer it over Starbucks. Love the Kona brew, always get stoked when I see it on the menu. My only gripe is they don't serve breakfast sandwiches. They got some local pastries and bagels, but I'm hankerin' for a bacon, egg, and cheese with my joe. And Sundays can get hectic, church crowd pours in, makin' it a tight squeeze in there. Just a heads up."

"Been coming here for over four years. Done comedy in most rooms. Still can't figure why the johns are always trashed. Doors off hinges, no soap or paper towels. But, something for everyone. Pool, air hockey, ping pong, music, outdoor atrium. Staff's friendly."

"Alas, my heart doth not sing with joy,
As I didst step within The Melville's door.
A trio of gentlemen, of age, didst smoke,
In the entrance, their presence didst beset.
The scent that didst greet mine nostrils then,
Didst bring to mind the thought of days of yore,
When smoking bans didst not yet exist,
And thus, my spirits didst begin to sink.

Drinks, dear sir, didst come at quite a cost,
More than other taverns in this fair town.
Though 'twas no pricier than Teuchters, across,
That place doth boast a vibe more loose and bright.
But fear not, for the victuals didst seem,
Fair priced and tempting, so I shall return,
To partake of them, and thus my doubts dispel."

In days of yore, when first I met my love,
A trip to Lake Las Vegas did ensue.
And though the village held many a treat,
I'd ne'er partaken of their culinary delight.

So, on our anniversary, I chose this place,
With patio seating, and a view of the lake's grace.
But lo, the patio was quite foul and unclean,
And bird droppings did adorn the chairs, most obscene.

The food, however, did make up for the sight,
My steak was cooked just right, and oh so bright.
The service was good, but our waitress did stray,
Leaving us to ponder, and to pray.

The cocktails, alas, did not impress,
But the food, oh the food, did make up for the mess.
And so, we paid the bill, and did depart,
With memories of the meal, forever in our heart.

"Prince-Arthur's got a bunch of overpriced joints, but Les Deux Gamins ain't one of 'em. Reasonable prices, no BYOW nonsense. Standard French grub - tartare, frite, lamb shank. Nothing fancy, but sometimes that's just what I need. Kitchen messed up our apps, but they made up for it with a free bottle of house wine. Not the best French spot in Montreal, but you could do a helluva lot worse."

"I'm from SoCal, where sushi flows like water. Moved to Arizona, my craving persisted. Hiro's, a local spot, seemed promising. Lowered expectations, I entered. Ambiance, decent. Sushi, fresh. Prices, steep. Bento boxes, too much. Dry chicken, a letdown. Feeling cheated, I move on."

"These fellas are good people. First time I rang 'em up, it was for a small electrical gig. They squeezed me in that same day. Turns out they couldn't fix the issue, but they didn't make things worse, just told me straight up they couldn't figure it out and to call an electrician. Which I did. He fixed it in no time. Now, I've got another job lined up with 'em, but it took two weeks to get on their schedule. Their quote was a helluva lot cheaper than the other guys."

"Fair sir, the victuals were not amiss,  
A star they lose, for service was slow.  
We tried the fowl, with flavor it did bless,  
But dry it was, alas, I do declare.  
The BBQ sandwich, much the same, I fear,  
But ribs, oh ribs, they were divine, my dear.  
And sides, aplenty, they did provide,  
All four we tried, most tasty, I must confide.  
But lo, a star they lose, for wait we did,  
While those who came after, their orders got.  
A gentleman, with grace, did intervene,  
And gave us free, a dish, to make amends, ye see.  
So, shall I try this place once more?  
Hoping 'twas but a fluke, I pray thee, friend."

In this place, called Mandalay, doth lie  
A store named Urban Outfitters, nearby  
A bay, where one may park for free,  
And find some gifts, both funny and breezy.

The clothes they sell, are casual, yet chic,  
For those who seek to dress with flair and trick  
The books and gags, they do abound,  
At the front of the store, a joyous sound.

Mandalay Place, doth share a lot,  
With Mandalay Bay, a parking spot,  
So leave thy car, and take a stroll,  
To find some humor, and a bit of soul.

"A decent Chinese feast, akin to Panda's fare,  
In a food court, 'twas served with nary a care.  
The prices, alack, did seem a mite steep,  
For a bottle of brew, the cost did make me sleep.  
At the casino, 'tis better to buy thy ale,  
And play a game, while thou dost doth regale.  
A good place, indeed, for a quick repast,  
I shall return, but without the beer, at last."

"Haven't been to a dollar store in a bit. Forgot about the killer deals they got. Times are tough for everyone, so if you ain't lookin' in the right spot, you might miss out on somethin' good. This place got all sorts of stuff - plates, dishes, canned grub. You'll always find somethin', even if you ain't searchin'. Next time you're around, take a gander and see what you come across."

"Food's not bad, but there's always somethin' missin'. Order the pear salad, it's never right. Waitress ain't listenin', or I ask for blue cheese, get ranch instead. Little things like that, it's frustratin'. Want what I pay for, don't wanna get home and find my wings are wrong or my salad's messed up. But they're always real nice about it, fix their mistake and give me somethin' extra. Just wish it didn't happen so often."

"Tucked away in a strip center, we found a hidden treasure - a cozy Japanese restaurant. The owners, an elderly couple, run the place. We tried their bento box specials for lunch. $6.95 gets you soup, egg roll, tempura veggies, half a California roll, white rice, and your choice of entree. My brother went with General Tao Chicken, while I opted for Mongolian Beef. Both dishes were excellent. We'll be back for more bento boxes and to sample their sushi and sashimi. Spread the word - they need business."

"A tidy shop, with naught but cleanliness within,
Deceives the eye, for greater space doth lie.
I ordered chicken noodles, served in bread,
A vessel cold, which needed heat to stir.
The broth did taste most wondrous, rich and deep,
Yet bread, alas, did lack in flavor, swift to soak.
A simple roll, with hole, did serve its purpose ill,
As bread bowl, it did not fulfill its duty well.
I noted too, a man, with hands unclean,
Did scratch his backside, then returned to cook.
Fair machines, with drinks of varied hue,
Did please my sight, yet could not make me stay.
My meal, though not most wretched, left me unsatisfied,
And thus, I shall seek sustenance elsewhere, ere long."
"Fare still as tasty as of yore, yet salads now diminished in size. The newfangled fashion doth mar the cozy ambiance."

"Beanscene, trusty joint. Year after year, same spot for me. Big mug of Americano, Metro in hand, leather booth for some quiet time. Staff's friendly, tunes are chill, not some corporate vibe. Never came for the grub, but a solid cup o' joe and a place to sit, Beanscene's my go-to."

In fair 941, a bar of gay repute,
Neither awful nor amazing, doth it stand,
Amidst the city's many such establishments,
'Tis hard to spot, save for a curious eye.

I chanced upon it one afternoon,
And found the atmosphere quite comfortable,
With few patrons present, the mood was light,
The bartender, too, was pleasant in sight.

A Mai Tai, spelled thus, I did imbibe,
For four dollars and seventy-five cents,
A generous pour, in a larger glass, did flow,
A great experience, I must needs avow.

But alas, my dear, a different tale,
Did unfold when last I visited, with my love,
On a Friday eve, the crowd did swell,
With folk of diverse sorts, 'twas hard to pigeonhole.

Prices steep, for beer, did cause me woe,
And a cranberry vodka, in a tiny glass, did flow,
A mixed bag, indeed, doth 941 present,
So be prepared, my friend, for what may come.

"Methinks 'twas fate that drew me to this place,
Amidst the splendor of Las Vegas' grace.
Each time I ventured forth, the building's charm,
Did stir within my breast a keen alarm.

At last, upon my latest journey thither,
I did resolve to sample their sweet slender.
Alas, the wait within did stretch and yawn,
Two hours or more, ere we could sit and dine.

So, to the food court swiftly did we flee,
To find sustenance and bide our time, ye see.
Later, we returned, the frozen drinks to claim,
But lo! The line, it did remain, a woeful plight.

A solitary man, with labors manifold,
Did struggle to keep pace, his station to hold.
Seven maidens we, and thus, two large cups shared,
With straws aplenty, lest our thirst be unassuaged.

Tasty, it was, but naught save chocolate's essence,
In form of milkshake, with gritty texture's presence.
Worth the eight dollars? Nay, methinks 'twas not,
For though 'twas pleasant, o'erpriced, it was, by far."
"Solid breakfast joint, but pricey. Better value at Cora, better grub at Cafe Orange. Still, not a bad option if you're in the vicinity and need sustenance."
"Outback's reliable grub draws me in. Predictable fare, clean digs, and decent service. This spot hits the mark. Two of us grabbed dinner at 5 pm, avoiding the mob."

"Terrible Herbst, no more. Food's improved, service quicker. Ten-dollar deals, still a steal. Always preferred Cafe over Buffet, even when the latter was free. One issue remains: old waitresses, slow and forgetful. Need reminders, sometimes thrice, for condiments or extra settings."

"A fair theatre, with naught but pleasant memories doth lie,
Save for the throngs that gather, causing woe and strife.
And, alack, the cost, a princely sum indeed,
Yet, lo, the matinee, a paltry five dollars doth yield."
"Walmart's lines, they stretch on forever. Take an age to get in, out. Open more registers, we need."

"A pox upon this chocolate shoppe of high renown,
Whose wares didst fail to impress, save for a few.
The atmosphere, akin to Sephora's domain,
Didst lack the black gloves, a most curious refrain.

A medley of chocolates, diverse and rare,
Didst pique my interest, yet none didst declare
A taste so sweet, that I wouldst buy in bulk,
Despite five flavors sampled, with nary a quirk.

They gifted me some freebies, a token of their grace,
Tortilla chips dipped in chocolate, with Cayenne's embrace.
An interesting mix, yet not quite to my taste,
A pox, I say, upon this chocolate shoppe of haste."

"Alas, my friends, how dearly I did hope
For wondrous feast at this place, so oft
My colleagues praised its tacos, oh so fine
And service swift, their words did entwine

But lo, my heart doth sink, forsooth
The shrimp tacos, meagre, lacking truth
In taste, and service, slow as sloth
My beer, a-waiting, doth steal my youth

A group of eight, we gathered round
Yet orders, all awry, confusion found
The checks, a jumble, nary a pair
Didst match the food, a sorry tale to bear

The server, harried, doth strive to mend
Yet twenty minutes passed, ere all amended
The food, a-coming, doth bring dismay
For naught but errors, doth the day

A frozen margarita, weak and small
For seven gold coins, a price too great to pay
Avoid it, friends, lest ye be fooled
And seek elsewhere, a better way to cool

Thus, once again, I shall essay
To visit this place, and hope doth stay
That improvements made, my heart doth cheer
And fare, much better, doth appear."
"You work at Bally's? You look the part. This joint's not bad for a relaxing afternoon, and the drinks won't break the bank. But let's be real, the pool's nothing to write home about."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place that doth serve food most fair and drinks of finest quality. Alas, there be a catch, forsooth! On Fridays, 'tis a woeful sight to see the crowd, a long wait for fish, indeed. Yet fear not, dear patron, for their fish and chips, both fried and broiled, be worthy of thy taste. And, by my troth, their fried mushrooms do delight!"

"Small, unassuming Mexican joint I stumbled upon. Menu's concise - just ten options. One cook, a bearded dude, handled orders and prep. Each table had its own hot sauce and seasoning selection. Decor was a mishmash of tiki, flags, Frida art, paper lanterns, movie posters, and menu pics. They also sold Mexican sweets and drinks. \n\nHad the enchiladas with mole sauce. Solid, though no expert. Kitchen's minuscule, so likely reheated in the microwave. Still, a fun spot. Would return."

"Verily, the service here was most excellent,
But alas, the drinks and prices did offend.
A Mojito and Margarita, in plastic cups they came,
With naught but ice to fill the space, and eleven coins did claim.
The Nachos, though tasty, were not as we had sought,
And thus, our trust in this place is somewhat brought.
I shall stick to the places I know and hold dear,
For here, my friends, I fear we shall not tarry long, nor cheer."

"Two days, two trips for the spinning meat sticks of joy. Ordered dolmas before reading reviews, which confirmed my fears. Unpredictable dish, like pakora in Indian restaurants. Got the look, but struggled to find the flavor. Only five left out of eight. Worried about the next dish, but the gyro salad arrived fresh, plentiful, and decent. Partner's pita basket, good too. Fries, a nice addition. Returning based on entrees alone, minus the dolmas, a four."

"A plethora of plays have I witnessed, my friends,
But this one, alas, did fall beneath the mark.
Coordination lacking, errors did abound,
And rude, discourteous staff did further mar the ground.

A performer spoke at the start of the show,
"Flash photography, good people, is not allowed, you know."
The crowd, obedient, did turn off their flash,
Only to be met by an elderly woman, quite brash.
She snatched their cameras, with a scowl on her face,
"No photography, I say! Leave now, and save grace!"

Oh, how the gamble of watching did leave me in woe,
For mediocrity did reign, and poor staff did flow.
I pray, good people, save your coin, and flee,
For this show, alas, doth not merit your attention, 'tis a farce, indeed."

"Methinks 'tis strange that such a place, so fair and bright,
With food that doth please mine appetite, doth lack
The one thing that doth make mine heart sing -
A glass of white wine, crisp and light.

But lo, upon mine visit, last Saturday eve,
The bar didst not possess a single drop,
Of Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc, or Pinot Grigio,
Leaving me to ponder, in dismay and woe,
How couldst a place so fine, with atmosphere so grand,
Be without the wine that doth complete the land?

Inventory control, they must needs learn,
Lest they be left with naught but bitter disappointment to discern.
And thus, I leave, with naught but two stars to bestow,
For though the fried bologna sandwich doth please,
'Tis not enough to make up for the lack of wine, I do confess."

"Fair maiden, I didst partake of yonder fried chicken salad,
A dish most delectable, yet somewhat misguided.
For in my quest for healthy fare, the fried chicken strips didst play
A counterproductive role, and thus, my wishes were not satiated.

The waitress, a sprite most attentive, didst tend to my needs
With haste and diligence, her service, a true delight.
Yet, as the sun began to set, its rays didst cast
A glare so fierce, it didst pierce mine eyes, a sensation most vexing.
I prayed the bartender, a gentle soul, to close the shutter,
That the sun's bright beams might not disturb my repast.
She heeded my request, and with a smile so sweet,
Didst shut the blinds, save one, which let the sun's radiance meet."

"A spacious tavern, full of sporty cheer,
With patios grand, and menus most queer.
Each sandwich, matched with greens so fine,
A feast for eyes, as well as taste divine.
Specials galore, to make each visit new,
And birthdays, celebrated with flair anew.
Inside, a haven, filled with screens aglow,
For fans of games, and those who love to know."

"Fair victuals, yet service lacked a mite.
Dumplings on the first course, a true delight.
Blended margaritas, strong and full of might,
Beware, lest thou find thyself in a merry plight."
"Place don't live up to the hype. Pabellon's just alright. Rice is dry, prices too steep for the grub they serve. Expected more, got less. Meh."

The casino pulsed with life, a steady thrum of humanity pulsing through its veins. The staff, friendly and accommodating, tended to our needs with a smile. But the drinks, oh the drinks. Not the cheapest, no sir. A pricey indulgence, but one worth every penny.
"Walgreens. Three stars. Same old thing. Hmmm...wish I could give it four stars. Maybe if they started selling wine and beer."
"Good, not great. But not bad either. Eat here once a week. Thai basil, steak salad - both solid."

"Alack, what woeful fate doth befall this place,
In downtown Gilbert, where folk do congregate.
Their food, a sorry sight, doth take an age,
Forty minutes, by my reckoning, did it take.
My love and I, the fourth table sat,
Did wait, and wait, and wait, for our repast.
The service, fair, the waiters kind and neat,
But oh, the food, a disappointment, a defeat.
My salad, o'errun with onions, a bitter taste,
My love's, just right, a pleasant, savory feast.
The panini, naught to write home about,
Alack, I would not go, save for the wine, no doubt.
But friends, if thou must go, beware the wait,
And choose, perchance, a swifter, more expedite date."

"Solid joint in Vegas. Not too flashy. Renovated from some crusty old cafe in the Trop. Feels clean, though. Nice coastal vibe going on. Blues and whites, like the ocean. If you're lucky, you can score a table with a view of the pool waterfall. They got indoor and outdoor seating. Staff's friendly. Food's good. A little pricier than before, but worth it. Portions are decent."

This Dillard's place, methinks, doth leave much to be desired. My visits here, alas, have been but mediocre at best. The salesfolk in the women's attire department do err, it seems, in their approach. Some be o'er eager, others quite unhelpful, a balance they do not strike. In accessories, however, a kinder crew doth dwell, with hearts inclined to aid and guide thee well. A recent return, in perfect state, with tags intact, didst pose a problem, 'tis true. Yet, bless the manager's heart, a store credit he did grant, in grace and wisdom, knowing I had passed the limit, alack. This shop, then, doth earn but middling praise, yet shall I return, forsooth, drawn by their wares, and hoping, mayhap, for a day when service doth excel.

"Champions, that's the joint in Gilbert where you can find me sipping on a cold one. Real people, no frills, just good times. Pool tables and darts, that's what I'm talking about. Don't expect fancy, but hey, who needs it? Not me, that's for damn sure."

"Falafel, a dish of sandy hue,
With crunchy exterior, much like dew,
Reminds me of beachside days,
When gritty sand would find its way,
Into my mouth, a most vexing fray.

A plate of rice, salad, and pita too,
But where, oh where, is the hummus anew?
Tahini, a scant amount, they do provide,
In a small ramekin, a paltry guide.

Dry, dry, dry, a mouthful of despair,
No respite from the parchedness in the air.
Falafel sandwich, a better choice, I say,
Or other value meals, to pass the day.

Overpriced, the falafel plate doth seem,
With soda, near twelve dollars, a steep dream.
Hummus, an added cost, to soothe the throat,
Bringing the total, to sixteen, or so,
For one person, a price most prohibitive, no doubt."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say, this place doth serve most curious victuals indeed. Verily, the service, by two maidens most strange, didst leave me in wonder and dismay. 'Tis a pity, for the fare, though mediocre, didst stir within me a hunger most fierce. Alas, I shall not return, for the experience didst border on the bizarre and unsettling. Farewell, dear inn! Mayhap another time, when the service doth improve, shall I grace thy halls once more with mine own fair presence."

"Fare was sumptuous, service poor, I didst sit at bar.
Bartender, stout of girth, didst not stir from his nook.
I didst walk to sporting house, fetched ale ere he didst note our presence.
'Twas half past six, on Saturday eve."

"Hark! A Milwaukeean through and through, I stayed at Wynn, and thus didst venture to the in-house Bartolotta's, unaware of its origin in my fair city. Alas, I didst not partake in the full experience, forsooth, for I do not consume seafood, which doth arrive fresh daily from the Mediterranean. Aye, 'tis a bit absurd, yet understandable, given the arid environs.

Thus, I didst opt for pasta dishes and pancetta. Verily, the pancetta was tough and fatty, but I didst expect such. The sheep's milk ravioli, however, didst delight mine taste buds. The spaghetti with ragu? Not so much, alack.

In conclusion, methinks the price didst outweigh the quality, but mayhap 'twas the ambiance that didst lack. Forsooth, they should transport Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro from Milwaukee and plant it within the Wynn, anon. In my humble opinion, 'twould be an improvement, by the stars!"

In fair June, a review most vexing didst pen,
Of this firm, which doth damage our gazebo, alack!
With palm fronds broken, a mess didst ensue,
And anger didst swell within my breast, I do confess.

But now, a pact we have made, full of grace,
They didst offer restitution, in fairness and in place.
Their kindness didst abound, all issues to address,
And thus, our quarrel didst find a peaceful reprieve.

Their customer service, most excellent didst prove,
A lesson to all, in times of trouble and of woe.
So here, my friends, a tale of resolution doth end,
And all's well that doth finish well, as the saying doth intend.

"This joint serves up some top-notch corned beef hash, but my last visit was marred by some poor service. I arrived at 2:15 pm, and while the neon open sign was still lit up, I was informed that they closed at 2 pm. A server named Cindy said she checked with the kitchen and her boss, and they could still accommodate us. She was friendly throughout our meal, but another server, Carol, made a big stink about us being seated late. She complained loudly and made us feel unwelcome. The grub was great, but Carol's attitude left a bad taste. If the boss says it's okay, then it's okay. And if it's such a big deal, maybe turn off the open sign at 2 pm. That's all I'm sayin'."

"Fair cooked victuals they serve, yet ingredients of low degree. A pleasant sight doth the decor provide, but service, alas! doth leave much to be desired. Fried bananas, a dish most wondrous, my heart doth sing with joy at its mere mention!"

"Hark! Fish and chips, a dish most dear to Ireland's heart,
Served with ale and cheer, a merry gathering to impart.
Bands play there, too, their melodies so sweet and fine,
A place to meet, to greet, and let one's spirits shine.
The staff, kind and true, doth make one feel most welcome,
And on certain nights, a tribute band doth rock the venue,
Joshua Tree, they call themselves, and U2's songs they do sing,
A night of joy and mirth, for all to revel in."
"Cool joint, but can't touch the Foundation Room upstairs. Music's alright, atmosphere's decent, but you gotta hit up the Foundation Room for the real deal at Mandalay Bay."

"Monte Carlo's seen better days. Once a swanky joint, now it's showing its age. -5 Bar ain't the best. Renovations underway, maybe it'll shape up. Central location, but I'd rather splurge on a newer spot."

"Rugged Wearhouse, I love it. This one's organized, too. Three stars, though. Bought some boots for twenty-five bucks. Not bad. But the tag, still on 'em, said twenty. Department store, selling 'em for more than they're worth. Annoying."

"Beckett's Table, nice joint. Liked the vibe, the setup, the glasses, the tables. Food? Not so much. Bacon cheddar biscuits, good. Apple honey butter, too hard, couldn't spread it. Green chile pork stew, osso buco, nothing special. Chocolate dipped bacon s'mores, now that was good. Homemade peanut butter, excellent. A pleasant surprise."

"Feelin' poorly after chowin' down on some grub at this joint. Service was lackin', but they had a decent selection of veggie options, as per usual. Pricey, though. And let me tell you, they were fresh out of them tasty spring rolls when I swung by. Not exactly fillin', neither."

"Fair sir, I must confess, the victuals here have ne'er impressed me much. Overpriced, they be, for the meagre dishes they proffer. But, verily, 'tis a pleasant place to partake of potables and light repast - upon the patio, by the fountain's gentle flow. Their small dishes are passable, and reasonably priced, and the atmosphere, most agreeable. I do enjoy bringing visitors hither, when they come to call upon me. And, should they still have hunger pangs, we shall repair to Los Sombreros for a hearty feast!"

"Fair sir, the victuals didst please mine taste,
But, alas! the service didst leave much to be desired.
The waitress, scarce and hidden from view,
Didst make us wait, her duties unfulfilled.
A soda, too, didst take an age to arrive,
And water, equally slow, didst doth the same.
In sooth, a curious case, this eatery doth present."

"Not as good as Sam's, but still decent. Prices are fair, portions are alright. Steak's a bit too thin for my taste, but the sauce is okay. Not as sweet as other places, which I prefer. They'll give you a little extra sauce if you ask nice."

"Thin Crust? More like Thin Trash. Awful. Should be taken off the menu. Ordered Sausage and Bacon, heard it was better than Rosati's and Oregano's. Lie. Couldn't even bite through the cardboard crust. Disgusting. Stick with the Butter Crust Deep Dish. That's good. Leave the Thin Crust in the dumpster where it belongs."

"Three stars for now. First time at Panera Bread. Needed a change from subs. New location, convenient for me. Service good, but wait long for takeout. Realized they had orders before mine. Sandwiches very good. Wife had Cuban chicken panini, I had signature Steak and white cheddar. Nice kick from horseradish. Chips were a nice addition. Packaging nice, but couldn't tell which sandwich was which. No numbered stickers or writing on boxes. Sent suggestion to HQ, they'll look into it. Will return, might eat in. Dining room nice, outdoor seating for cooler days."

"Fifty-four, a joint where you can let loose, no frills, no fuss. Dance, drink, chill with pals, and groove to the beats. Eighties tunes play on some nights, but the DJ knows how to switch it up, so you can bust a move to the latest jams without feeling out of place. Floyd Mayweather even threw his after-party here once. The guy knows how to make it rain. \n\nThe crowd at Fifty-four? Older, good-looking folk, mostly in their late twenties to late thirties, with a few young hotties sprinkled in. But the real showstoppers are the go-go dancers - friendly, approachable, and leaving little to the imagination. Just don't get too carried away."
"No dessert. Had brunch instead. POTATO PANCAKES WERE WEAK. Go back? Try dessert. Or sit at bar. Late in day."
"Tequila selection's gone downhill. Menu's got errors. Sorry, sir, we're out of that tequila. Food's alright, service is slow. Not exactly bustling in here."

"Hark, my dearest friend, how strange it seems,
That in fair Hokkaido, my expectations didst falter.
Forsooth, the seafood dishes, a paltry sight,
Didst resemble those of China, o'ercooked and lackluster in might.

But lo, my heart didst sing, whene'er I didst taste,
The crab, the sushi, and the seaweed salad, a wondrous feast.
And, by the stars, the chocolate fountain, a sweet delight,
Didst bring a smile to mine own face, and filled mine heart with joy and light.

Alas, the atmosphere, didst not meet mine eyes,
For screaming brats, and chaos, didst fill the skies.
A plague upon the parents, who didst not keep,
Their children close, and quiet, in this place, where we didst seek to dine and sleep.

Verily, I say, a fee, they should impose,
Upon the unruly younglings, who do cause such noise and commotion,
For in a place of rest, and gentle repast,
Such discord doth not belong, and doth most certainly astound."

"A night's stay was had this week, my dear.  Alas, the furniture, even the couch, didst gather dust.  A dirty coffee maker and filthy hair dryer, oh what a sight!  I couldst go on, but shall refrain.  

No itemized room service receipt or stay receipt via email didst I receive.  Pray tell, were they prepared?  Nay, methinks not.  

For location's sake alone, this inn doth merit praise.  But lo, if thou art in town for business, choose the HGV on the strip, with its excellent upkeep and commendable customer service."

"Rehab burger, a dive bar of sorts, yet with an air of coolness doth it possess. A place where one may find solace in drinks of great value, and burgers of renown. Alas, my experience didst leave much to be desired. The Hangover burger, with sweet potato tots, didst fail to impress. A mistake in cooking, no doubt, for I requested it medium rare, and received it well done. Methinks 'twill not be worth mine while to return and give it another chance, for Scottsdale doth boast of better burger joints in plenty."

"Methinks I oft have passed by City Cafe,
But ne'er had time to stop and savor their fare.
Until the other day, when chance didst play
A part in my decision to dine there.

Their lunch menu, alas, was limited,
Yet the owner didst assure me 'twould soon be extended.
I ordered a burrito, and with it,
A refreshing glass of green iced tea, most excellent.

Verily, I say, the food didst please,
And I shall return, ere long, to taste their wares again."
"AYW ain't cheap, but it's a swell spot for kids to let their creativity shine. Staff's mostly friendly, 'cept when the young gals get too chatty. Turnaround's quick, just a few days. Not bad."

"Food's good, location's great, rooftop patio's sweet. But the drink prices? Outrageous. Like, strip club or upscale bar prices. Not cool. I've worked in bars, I know how it works. These prices ain't gonna fly. People are already talking, saying they'll stick to soda or tea. Come on, guys. Don't try to recoup your investment in one month. Price 'em reasonable and you'll do just fine."

"Taqueria Express, that's what the sign says. It's a small taco stand, carved out of a fruit market west of Woodlands on Albemarle. Order at the window, kitchen's hot and cramped. Simple food, quick and good. Surprisingly big menu, tacos, quesadillas, burritos, no Salvadorean or Ecuadorian dishes though. Might be a language barrier if you don't speak Spanish.

I'm a sucker for tortas, so that's what I got. It was good, a bit pricey ($6.50 for eggs and cheese) but one of the best I've had in Charlotte. Soft, sweet bread, Monterey Jack cheese, shredded lettuce, some jalapenos. Messy to eat, but who cares? Not the best torta, but still worth a visit."
"Clean joint, open all night. Decent selection, nothing special. Devil's food cake, moist and chocolatey. Glazed, good flavor. Better than Dunkin', not as sweet as Krispy Kreme. Grade C."

"Methinks I've ever been an Outback devotee,
Forsooth, a chain restaurant of some renown, doth please me.
At the bar, I do sit, and the staff, they doth attend,
With friendliness and accommodation, they do strive to amend.

Last week, I did decide to take my meal away,
And order salmon, broccoli, and a sweet potato, I did say.
The salmon and broccoli, they were cooked aright,
And seasoned well, they did delight.

But lo, the sweet potato, it was overcooked, alack!
As if they had kept it in the oven, for several months, at least.
A minor detail, yet worth the mention, methinks,
For a better dish, it would have made, with a bit more finesse."

"Celebrated my birthday here with colleagues. Atmosphere was top-notch, so I returned for happy hour with pals. Pricey, but worth it for the excellent service from our robot-inked server. Cocktails stole the show, especially the Polynesian chicken sandwich and sweet potato fries. Most drinks were superb, except the Scorpion bowl, which I'll save for another time with a bigger group."

"Methinks we dine here oft, and find the fare to be but middling, neither too good nor bad. 'Tis more like Arby's, I do declare, for the ingredients lack a certain je ne sais quoi. And though it be not overly pricey, 'tis still not worth the cost, for true sushi doth it better. Yet, convenience and speed doth make it somewhat appealing."

"Good setup, solid drinks, and friendly staff. But the bald manager with the moon boot? Total jerk. Even our waitress said so. Prices are fair, but I'd avoid that guy like the plague. Only had apps, they were just okay."

"Fare thee well, my dear! Forsooth, the victuals we didst devour,
Were of a quality most fair and fine, I do declare.
The Spanish omelet, oh how delectable it was!
Yet, alack! The service, slow it didst prove, alas.
But still, we didst enjoy our meal, and that's the truth,
For in expectation, all didst pass muster, by my troth."

"Writing this update hurts. Had great experiences here before last two visits. Prime time, long waits. Fifteen, twenty minutes in the exam room. Love Doc Langford, though. Apologized, meant it. Still got warm attention. Called twice, rude reception. Didn't call back, lied. Don't like rudeness. Good staff, good doc. Three and a half stars."

"Methinks 'tis a fair place indeed, where one may watch a game with glee.  The staff doth seem to hold a care for those who enter in.  Aye, the menu doth please mine eyes, and food, it doth taste of sweetness.  But, alas! The last few times I chanced to visit, 'twas cold, so very cold, that which they brought to mine table.  Oh, how I do detest a meal that doth lack warmth!"

"A hearty meal didst First Timer devour,
With prices fair, the victuals didst please.
The tavern's charm didst lie in its decor,
And emptiness didst make our visit ease.

Alas, the youthful servers, cold and grey,
Didst lack the warmth of a kindly way.
A smile or greeting, sincere and bright,
Might make this place a true delight."

"Good grub, decent service. But, damn, the joint was dusty. Like, everywhere. My booth? Forget about it. Filthy. I had to say somethin'. Left a note. Server sees me, sees the dust, says, 'Hahaha, yeah, lots of dust here.' Un-freakin'-believable."
"Fried food, flavorful but not spicy. Decent spot for lunch, I'd return."

Hark! What luck doth bring me to this place?
A scant fifteen minutes ere the close of day,
And lo! But ten brief moments didst pass,
Ere the chicken, cooked to perfection, didst sway.

This humble abode, so small and plain,
Didst play host to my culinary desires,
And though the fowl didst taste of salt,
'Twas naught but a minor quibble, a mere trifle.

The fiery sauce, oh how it didst delight,
And made my visit to this place most worthwhile,
But alas! No red velvet pancakes in sight,
A common complaint, it seemeth, yet no cause for fright.

Forsooth! A kind woman, with a heart full of cheer,
Didst gift us a free drink and chicken, without fear,
And though Flavor Flav's eatery didst fail,
I pray that this place shall prosper, without fail.

Two stars, I say, and one more for Flav,
For his name doth bring a certain je ne sais quoi,
A decent spot, despite its flaws,
But Flavor Flav, he doth make it shine, like a beacon's glow.

"Hark, a strange occurrence doth befall me,
In a restaurant, with a companion, did I see,
Yelp, the app of reviews, didst reveal,
Two stars, a rating most foul and unseemly.

The service, odd it was, and hard to explain,
The host, his words, didst we not comprehend,
And later, my friend, his soup didst receive,
Before mine, a full ten minutes, didst he relieve.

His soup, it seemed, didst please him well,
But mine, a duck meat soup, didst not swell,
The noodles, undercooked, they were, alas,
And green, salty stuff, didst float within the broth,
A questionable sight, indeed, it was.

And pricey, too, the place didst prove,
Caesar's Palace, a name of note, didst groove,
So out we went, to seek another spot,
For lunch, a better choice, didst seem to be not."

"Rainy Sunday brunch. Nice interior. Excellent service. Coffee, meh. Fresh ingredients, good technique, but flavors lacking. Crepe, cooked well, but cold inside. Waitress comped our coffee. Didn't finish my breakfast. Maybe try again for better flavors."

"O Pink's, thou art a wily temptress indeed,  
How didst thou lure me to thy tasty treats?  
A band of friends, with hunger pangs didst need,  
Didst seek thee out, for thy renown'd delights.  
I, feeling bold, didst order Chili Cheese,  
Two dogs, chili, cheese, all swathed in tortilla's ease.  
It served its purpose, for a night of mirth,  
But oh, the aftermath, a sore belly's wrath!  
Perhaps, if e'er I dine with thee again,  
I shall stick to plain hot dog, sans the pain."

"Moved from Chi to Scottsdale, gave this place a shot. Overall, underwhelmed. Heard it was top-notch sushi, but maybe my expectations were too high. Sapporo was great, though - much needed in this heat. Sushi was alright, but nothing special. One roll stood out - fried fish skin, don't know the name. Would go back, but not a favorite."

"Methinks 'tis a most wondrous place,
Conveniently situated, nigh my work's embrace.
The parking, good! For me, afoot, 'tis a breeze,
And concessions, cheap! A hot dog, soda, what a tease!
A combo pack, with drink and popcorn, doth please,
For $11, a steal! The views, fair; players, at ease.
But alas, no grass, in outfield's expanse,
A disappointment, indeed. And, truth be told,
The metal seats, down left field's line, do chill,
But for $7, parking, location, concessions, still,
I am a fan, of this, my favored spot,
In sooth, a treasure, ne'er to be forgot!"

"Hark, good sir! I do protest, thy venue doth lack,
In charm and grace, it doth not hold a candle,
To other eateries, where one doth pay,
A similar sum, for finer fare, I pray.

The lobster, twain, we didst order, 'tis true,
And found it tasty, I must needs avow,
But, alas! The surroundings, they didst grieve,
A shopping mall, most unbecoming, doth leave.

The decor, akin to a peddler's stall,
Didst little justice to thy culinary skill,
And for the price, I say, 'twas far too steep,
For such a humble abode, so plain and cheap.

My garb, it didst bespeak a night of fun,
Yet, here, amidst the cartoonish walls, I've none,
Fit for a king, my attire, I do confess,
Yet, here, 'twas naught but mockery and mess.

Peanut shells, they didst not lie upon the ground,
Yet, still, the ambiance, it didst lack, profound,
A finer establishment, I wouldst advise,
For such a sum, a better choice, I do devise."

"Hiking, rafting, running - that's my jam. But Victory Lanes? Not my cup of tea. Karts, speed, and circles - underwhelming experience. Might give it another shot with friends, though. Location's easy to find, but use GPS to be sure. Bought a members pass, staff's friendly, and bathrooms are decent, but not great for changing. Suites look sharp, add to the excitement."
"Food's alright, drinks are fine. Beer's still beer, though. If I'm at Mandalay Bay, I'll stop for a pint. No question. My ex says their shepherd's pie is top-notch. Might be worth a shot."

"Methinks my mem'ry doth fail me, fair friends,
For when I first didst step within these walls,
I know not if I had a merry time or no.
Yet, verily, I did return anon,
And found the place not half so bad, I swear.
In sooth, the barkeepers didst move with speed,
But the music, by the gods, didst make my heart sing.
Aye, 'tis a decent spot, if thou canst gain entry free.
Alas, not my first choice in this city of sin.
But, an it please thee, take my humble word,
If thou canst enter cheaply, 'tis a place to be."

"Paradise Bakery's grub is top-notch, but the quality's a crapshoot. Stopped ordering takeout 'cause they kept messin' it up - wrong items, missing stuff, or not even ready when I got there. They expanded their hours, but still run outta stuff towards the end of the day. When it's good, it's damn good. Just gets under my skin when they screw it up, y'know? Not exactly cheap either."

"My comrade and I, in pursuit of the finest steak in the land, doth venture to diverse establishments of repute. Our latest sojourn, to Fleming's, didst fall short of my expectations. 

Tales of their happy hour, with deals most fair, didst reach mine ears, and indeed, the choices were plentiful and the service, good. A fine selection of wines, at prices reasonable, didst also catch mine eye. 

But alas, the steak, mine heart's desire, didst fail to impress. Overcooked, it was, and not properly trimmed, a filet, it didst seem. The sides, forgettable, they were."

"Solid joint for a fast, cheap meal. New to Filipino grub? Start with the BBQ and pancit. Feelin' bold? Go for the blood stew or fertilized duck egg, if they got it. Mom's still got the best game, but this spot's decent for the price and location. Take-out's my jam, 'cause their TV's always blastin' those sappy Pinoy dramas. Don't need all that noise ruining my meal."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of a place that doth serve food most fair and frail.
Their waitstaff, alas! Doth not wear a grin,
But fear not, for their victuals doth make up for their sin.

Aye, 'tis a cultural thing, I do suppose,
For in this land, such service doth not pose,
A problem, forsooth! Their fare doth make amends,
And thus we doth return, our bellies to attend.

Firstly, try their shredded pork, pan-fried with care,
And ask for it "Hong Kong Style", be thou aware.
Next, sample their shrimp, with salt and pepper bathed,
And leave not the head behind, for it doth be enriched.

Lastly, their salt fish and chicken fried rice,
Doth taste of the sea, and a bit of spice.
So, put aside thy fears of the unknown,
And savor these dishes, for they doth make thee moan."

In sooth, the fishery department didst impress,
With helpful folk, and little time to guess.
But one, named Tyler, doth require some schooling,
In art of serving customers with cooling.

"Hark, the service here, 'tis fair,
Depending on the time of day, thou shalt declare.
In mornings, first, a draught we did receive,
To cure our hangovers, a merry conceit.

On Saturdays and Sundays, I didst order forth,
Chicken Fried Steak, a dish of noble worth.
'Twas good, and anywhere I roam,
If chicken fried steak be on the menu, I'll make it known.

This place did not disappoint, my friends,
For all at my table, save one, didst partake.
And after tasting, they didst agree,
'Twas a wise choice, indeed, a verity.

But alas, the coffee shake, a woeful tale,
Didst not taste of coffee, a sorry fail.
Jack in the Box, a better shake doth make,
A truth, a truth, a kingdom for a shake!

Yet still, I shall return, forsooth,
To this place, or Pink Taco, both of which are good.
A different tale, another time,
Pink Taco, a worthy feast, sublime."

"Alas, good sirs, I do declare,
This car wash on Bell road doth leave much to be desired.
Twice now, I have brought my carriage to their door,
And twice, they have forgotten to remove the key.
Alack, this carelessness doth fill my heart with fear,
For auto thieves do roam these Arizonan streets with cheer.
Their customer service, methinks, doth leave much to be desired,
For though I came ere break of day, my discount was not fired.
I crossed the street to work, and when I returned,
I found my carriage waiting, but my savings unearned.
A pox upon their hand-written receipts, I say,
For they are not time-stamped, and thus, my discount did stray."

"Methinks I long to cherish thee, dear Daily Dose,
In thy prime location, convenient for my needs.
Yet, alack! My heart doth falter, for each time I doth step within thy halls,
I find myself lost in thought, unable to choose from thy vast array of delectable dishes.
My spirit doth wane, and I settle for a humble omelette or toast,
A choice most plain, and lacking in zest.
I shall continue my quest, yet fear my hopes doth dwindle with each passing day."
"Couple times here. Drinks ain't all that. Service top-notch though. Had a few cocktails, tasted fine, but needed more oomph. Ordered a few extras to get the job done."

"The Vue Cinema's entrance is near Britannia. There's a Starbucks, Bear Co., M&S Food-Court, H&M, Superdry, Fat Face, HMV, Boots, FCUK, Baxter, GAP, Debenhams, and a nice Food Court with Zizzi, Burger Co., etc. I enjoy the Food Court's view of Fife and the new developments of Newhaven, reminding me of Blade Runner. Not my favorite shopping center, as it lacks charity shops, except for Superdry. I shop here on Sundays when I have time. It's a clean building inside and out, with a simple layout - rectangular and three stories high. There's a car park and a bus terminus for Lothian buses 22, 35, 34, 36, 11, and tourist buses stop here too. Plans to extend the tram line here were put on hold."

"Ay, one of the smallest airports in all the land,
Didst fly hither for a brief sojourn at hand.
Greenville, they call it, GSP its name,
But alas, the planes, how small they be!
And I, a man of six feet four, didst find
Great discomfort in my seat, so unkind.
Next time, I vow, shall fly to greater ports,
Where space and comfort do abound, no doubt."

"I was twelve when my sister got her first apartment. She took me to Pier 1 and I was in awe. It was like a dream world, full of Director chairs, lava lamps, and bamboo vases with baby's breath. I wished I could replace my Charlie's Angels bedroom theme with all this cool stuff. But we were there for my sister, and twenty-five years later, Pier 1 still has that same charm. Sure, they've expanded and the prices have gone up, but the quality doesn't quite match the cost. I mean, a balsa wood nightstand? Not exactly sturdy. But those cute little plates with palm trees? Nice touch. Just be careful not to drink too many pre-shopping cocktails or you might end up breaking something. Like a lamp. Or something."

Last eve, I ventured forth to this establishment,
With thoughts of pleasure and delight.
The hour was late, the crowd was great,
Yet still, I hoped for a merry night.

Their decor, a feast for mine eyes,
Didst make the most of space, so fine.
We ordered sliders, oh so small,
But tasty, nonetheless, stood tall.

A barkeep approached my lord,
And asked if he wouldst imbibe.
He didst not acknowledge me, alas,
And left me to ponder, in disguise.

My lord, a beer he didst not seek,
Was brought to him, with nary a word or shriek.
Two other barkeeps, kind and bright,
Didst serve us well, with all their might.

But he, who first didst snub mine face,
Didst ignore us, for the rest of the race.
Our drinks, unfilled, a wait of twenty minutes,
Before a soul didst come to tend to our winnings.

A fourth, who cleared the dishes away,
Didst not enquire, if we had need of play.
I shall, perhaps, give them another chance,
For they are new, and may yet dance.
"Good beer joint. Modelos, Negros, Delirium. Nachos, a solid concept. Service, meh. Florentine Nachos, give 'em a shot."

"This Whole Foods, the smallest of the three, don't lack in selection or variety. Not my go-to, but I dig the vibe, cozy in its smaller space. Produce is looking good, nopales and all, well-stocked and tidy. Meat counter's a bit small, but deli, salad bar, prepared foods, they're on par with the others. All things considered, not bad."

"$20 lunch buffet on a Monday? Not bad. Cheaper than the Wynn, that's for sure. I hit up the cocktail shrimp station hard, ate half their supply easy. Tried the lamb, duck, turkey - a little bit of everything. Decent, but nothing amazing. Lamb with mint jelly was the highlight, along with the napoleon. Dessert is my favorite part of the meal, always. Was a bit bummed they didn't have crab or lobster, but for $20, what do you expect? Sushi was just California rolls, something I can whip up at home. Service was good, though. That's about it for the buffet here. Might try the one at Paris next time."

"Upon this night, my fair companion and I did partake
In culinary delights, at yonder tavern's bar,
Wherein the bartender, with mirth and glee, did play
The host, and served us with most excellent fare.
A pizza, fresh from oven's heat, we did share,
And dumplings, savory, with duck meat within,
Did please our taste buds, and we did exclaim,
'Tis a fine establishment, this place doth win.
Akin to Cheesecake Factory, in splendor doth it shine."

"Alack, the spread they lay before us now,
So bountiful, yet with a tainted hue.
For though the feast be grand, 'tis true,
They've cut the choices, and we must wait anew.

Once, we had a choice of crustaceans fine,
But now, alas, they've pared it down to one line.
And wait we must, for up to fifteen minutes more,
Just to receive our platter, and then we're sore.

A pox upon their house, for trying to save a coin,
By making us wait, and suffer thus, in vain.
This service, once great, now doth leave us cold,
And two stars, I fear, is all they'll hold."

"Lobster pot pie, fabulous. Service, lacking. Waiter vanished for half an hour. Missed opportunity for drink sales. Pot pie's a signature dish, but they should set better expectations on delivery time. Maybe if we were young women instead of middle-aged men, we'd have gotten more attention."

"Hark, what news is this? A meal most fair,
At yonder eatery, didst I partake.
A roast beef sandwich, of tender care,
Didst please mine taste, with juices rare.
The others, at my table, didst delight,
In Thai salad, of flavors so bright.
'Twas vast, a feast for sore eyes,
And left them all, in sweet surprise.
Another, of our merry band,
Didst choose the Mahi, so fresh and grand.
The servers, with smiles so wide,
Didst tend to us, with gentle pride.
I say, good sirs, give it a try,
For though 'twas not of little cost,
'Twas worth each penny, I do boast."

"Verily, I must confess, this place doth leave me in a state of utter disappointment. Forsooth, I had hoped to find a culinary haven, a place where I might satiate my hunger for a most excellent burger. Alas, 'twas not meant to be. The service, indeed, was most pleasant, the maidens friendly and helpful. But, alack, the victuals, they did not meet my expectations. I ordered the Pestorica, a burger with relish, pesto, and mozzarella, and a side of onion rings with dips. The burger, when it arrived, was a feast for mine eyes, but, alas, 'twas too thin, lacking in substance and seasoning. The onion rings, too, did not please mine taste, for they were crumbly and greasy, not battered as I had hoped. In sooth, the oreo milk shake was the sole redeeming feature of my visit. Methinks this place hath potential, but, for now, they do fail to meet mine expectations."

Saturday morning, I hit the brunch spot at 11am. Line wasn't too bad. Noticed they got them self-pay kiosks now. Good call when the line's long.

Omelette station's where it's at. Got two eggs over easy. Way better than them powdered eggs for scrambled. Other breakfast joint had potatoes and Portuguese sausage.

Found the salmon lox, capers, onion, and made a killer croissant sandwich. No bagels though. Finished off with some fresh fruit and Greek yogurt.

A lot of stuff looks good, but my buddies said otherwise. No high-end items like prime rib, crab legs, or lamb. Solid 2.5 or 3 stars, but watch what you eat and you'll enjoy your meal without feeling like a slug afterwards.

"Methinks I fail to comprehend this establishment. I perceive their aim, yet the victuals do not quite measure up to the lofty standards of other esteemed steakhouses in this fair city. The cost, my good sir, doth border on the exorbitant. Methinks 'tis naught but a ruse to puff up the egos of those who partake in games of chance, deceiving them into believing they receive a meal worth three hundred golden coins. Alas, the fare doth not compare to that of Cut, Delmonicos, or Del Frisco. If thou seekest an atmosphere reminiscent of days of yore, mayhap a visit to Hugos, nestled within the Four Queens, shall satiate thy craving. There, the cuisine doth please, possessing a similar aura, yet at a fraction of the cost."
"Paradise, loudest joint I've been to. Meetings? Forget it. But service? Top-notch."

"Twas a Tuesday eve, and we did choose this place,
Convenient 'twas, for Luxor's show we did attend.
But lo, the hostess, with hair of golden hue,
Didst play the part of rudeness, and our patience didst brew.

No wait didst we encounter, yet we didst sit,
In yonder bar, for swift service didst we wit.
But nay, the hostess came, and with great disdain,
Didst tell us we didst sit at dining tables in vain.

And so, we waited, for another ten minutes or so,
Until she didst return, and with menus didst bestow.
But alack, the very same table didst she bring,
And with a flick of her wrist, the menus didst fling.

Disbelief doth be the word, that doth describe this fate,
But praise be to the server, who didst make amends, and didst create
A pleasant eve, with speedy service, and with cheer,
The steak quesadilla, and steak tacos, didst disappear."

"Hark, good sir or madam, if thou seek'st a place
To sate thy hunger and behold a wondrous sight,
Then stop thou must at The Mad Greek, 'tis a sight most fair,
With two locations, one near Death Valley's gate,
And one near Las Vegas', where the sun doth shine bright.

'Tis a popular spot, so expect a crowd,
But fear not, for the fare is worth the wait,
The falafel balls, they doth taste most sweet,
And the creamy Tahini sauce, doth complement the treat.

The exterior, adorned with Roman statues grand,
Doth make it hard to miss, as thou dost pass by the land,
And within, a Greek cafeteria doth await,
With much seating space, and people, in abundance doth create.

In Baker, a decent bathroom doth abide,
And to the left of The Mad Greek, a pole doth reside,
A thermometer, the largest in all the land,
Doth show the temperature, though a few degrees off, 'tis grand.

So if thou art in search of food and sight,
Then stop thou must, at The Mad Greek, 'tis a wondrous delight."

"Methinks I didst wish to fondly regard this place,
For 'tis near my abode and locally owned,
Yea, verily, a rarity in these parts,
A gem, perchance, to savour and enjoy.

But alas! The victuals and the service,
Didst fail to meet mine expectations,
The table, sticky and unclean,
The server, hasty and most keen,
To take our order, and away,
Our appetizers, in haste, didst fly.

We began with bruschetta, a dish most fair,
But lo! The flatbread, cold and stale,
Didst dampen mine spirits, and my hope,
That it, on sliced bread, might be served,
Like Postino's or D'Vine's, in sooth.

My spouse, the orichette, didst choose,
With sausage, but alas! 'Twas oversalted,
And the sausage, bland, without a voice,
In this dish, a disappointment, stark.

I, the porcini ravioli, didst select,
With tomato cream sauce, a flavour most sweet,
But lo! The sauce, oversalted, alack!
Didst mar the dish, and my tastebuds, didst attack.

The ambiance, passable, yet the TV's large,
In the bar, a distraction, most strange,
From the dining room, a sight most odd,
And thus, our visit, a regret, didst engender.

Verily, I say, we shall not return,
For the price, too steep, the fare, not worth the burn."

"Small mall. Not like Vegas. Few stores. Pricey."

"Nice interior. Nice decorations. But expensive."

"Good for a short walk. That's it."

"Good joint. Service usually pretty solid. Grilled cheese with hash browns, that's my jam. Crispy bread, melted cheese, can't beat it. One time, cheese wasn't melted right, asked them to fix it, they did, but then they nuked the whole thing in the microwave. Rubber cheese, bad bread. Stick to the basics, you know? Cheese sticks, good stuff. Melted right, nice and hot. Ranch or marinara, both solid choices. Other than that snafu, good spot. Food's good, service is good. Come hang out, eat, read the paper, chill."

"Hark! A gathering of colleagues, for a meal most swift,
At yonder tavern, known as Kilted Pig, we did convene.
Their luncheon fare, a menu of light bites, we did inspect,
And found it reasonable, betwixt three pounds five, and eight.

Inclusive of soup, sandwiches, baked potatoes, fish pie,
Risotto, stovies, and more, their offerings did lie.
And though naught fancy, our repast did please,
With generous portions, and flavors that did tease.

A bottle of wine, and three soft drinks did we consume,
For a sum of fifty pounds, our bellies now succumb.
I booked a table, two days prior, with haste,
And they did provide menus, for us to peruse at leisure, in advance.
Good service, indeed, our needs they did fulfill,
And thus, our midday meal, at Kilted Pig, did conclude most will."

"Hark, fair sir! Thou seekest a meal most wondrous? Aye, 'tis good, yet not quite great, I do confess. Swift service, as expected, doth please mine eyes. But lo, too much coleslaw doth overwhelm mine taste. Pastrami, alack, doth prove a bit chewy. Fries, a mite undercooked, doth lack crispness. Double meat, I did request, yet naught but same amount doth my friend receive. Alas, I say, do not go out of thy way for this repast."

"Hark! A word of caution, good sirs and madams,  
For this tavern, though cozy, doth lack in ale.  
The victuals, middling fare at best, doth leave  
My stomach somewhat sated, yet not impressed.  
  
Macaroni cheese, a dish most plain and common,  
Didst come from a box, a fact most vexing.  
Yet, buffalo chicken, a dish most delectable,  
Didst please my fair maiden, her taste buds most tickling.  
  
Despite these quibbles, I wouldst return anon,  
For here, in this tavern, doth lie a certain charm.  
Good service, friendly faces, doth make amends,  
And games, aplenty, to watch and cheer, doth disarm."

"Spa day at Camelback Inn Spa. Facials, massages, lunch. Wanted some FaceTime, but the quiet police were on our tails. Escaped outside, no water sprites. Icy towels cooled us down. Andrea gave me a top-notch facial, spent plenty of time answering my questions. Great spot for some peace and quiet. They got lemon water, tea, and you can make your own sachet on the way out. Mine had lavender, helps me sleep like a baby. Food and drink were solid, attendants kept things hush-hush. Shhhh."
"Three stars from me. Coffee was mediocre at best. Should try it twice before judging. Hours are poor for a coffee joint, closing at 7. Better options out there."

"Co-workers and I, regulars at this joint near one of my offices. Lunchbox specials, decent, especially #1, short rib. Had some special sushi rolls too. AZ Diamondback, not bad. Service, spotty. Get swamped with customers, can't recover from poor service. Food's good though, works for lunch. Might try Korean dinner next time."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of visits twain, so diverse in their tale,
To yonder tavern, where we did imbibe,
And found our fortunes in a state most frail.

The first, a night of mirth and cheer,
Didst bring us joy, with friends most dear,
But lo! The second, full of dismay,
Didst leave us sorely disappointed, I pray.

My margarita, once a drink of delight,
Didst taste of naught but bitter fright,
And my good man, his corned beef didst seek,
But found it overcooked, and most meek.

Yet still, my pita pizza didst please,
A ray of hope, in such a storm of spleen,
But alas! Consistency doth lack,
In this, our tavern of most woeful track.

So shall we stay, or shall we flee?
A question, that doth puzzle thee and me."

"The bars on the Royal Mile? Tourist traps, if you ask me. Overpriced and lacking any real sense of community. But, I gotta say, The Albanach ain't half bad. Sure, it's a bit pricey, but the house wine is decent and it's a nice spot to grab a drink with friends. Inside, it's nicely decorated, not like those dingy old pubs that reek of smoke and stale ale. Just watch that step when you walk in, it'll get ya every time."

"Hark! A friend of mine didst start to wait upon the tables here, 
And thus, my service was most excellent, beyond compare. 
But, alas! My judgment doth be clouded by my love, 
So I shall leave it out of my rating, lest it doth prove. 

I didst enter in the morn, and found a seat outside, 
Whereon the sun didst shine, and birds didst sing their tune. 
The patio chairs, though not the most comfortable, didst serve, 
For sitting with a cup of coffee, and a book, or so I didst perceive. 

A decaf coffee didst I order, and for breakfast, eggs, 
With sausage, pancakes, and butter, which didst please my taste. 
The eggs, alas! Were lukewarm, but still, the rest didst burn, 
And thus, my meal didst satisfy, and fill my hunger's yearn. 

The Good Egg, though not my favorite place, doth stand, 
Consistent in its fare, across the land.  An Arizona chain, at hand."

"Hark! My love and I didst dine at Todai,
Forsooth, his craving for Shrimp Tempura didst wax strong.
And thus, we didst feast upon plates full and plenty,
Of shrimp fried in tempura, a wondrous sight to see.

Aye, for twenty pieces of silver, a fair price,
We didst enjoy a variety of dishes, a feast most nice.
Sushi rolls, nigiri of salmon and tuna, salads,
An udon station, and sweet desserts, a treat for all.

Alas, no crab didst grace our table during lunch,
But still, my heart didst sing with joy, for one dish didst stand out.
The udon station, a gem, a treasure to behold,
Ring the bell, and forthcoming, a bowl didst unfold.
Fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and more,
Add them thou didst, and a savory broth didst pour.

Yet, take heed, dear friend, for the broth didst taste,
Of salt, aplenty, a warning, ere thou dost partake.
And thus, with many buffets in Vegas to choose,
I fear, my love, this one, I shall not revisit, anon."

"My friend, a true connoisseur of breakfast fare, did swear that this place was the best. And indeed, the food doth please mine taste buds well. But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired. At times, the coffee doth flow like a river, but at others, it doth dwindle to a trickle. I do confess, I still doth frequent this establishment, for the prices, though steep, doth not deter me. Yet, I do wish they would reconsider their policy regarding military discounts. In sooth, who doth wear their uniform on the weekends? 'Tis folly, I say! And lastly, a word of advice, dear reader. If thou doth desire to avoid a lengthy wait, do arrive early, ere the night owls doth flock in, seeking to assuage their hangovers."
"They make it on flash, big helpings, and a famous name. But in this town, there's better places to get your morning grub."

"In days of yore, when first this place did open,
I came here oft, with naught to do but wander.
But for two years, my foot didst not step within,
Till a friend didst wish to try their buffet, and thus I didst enter in.

The service, decent as it doth always seem,
And atmosphere, most pleasant, doth abide.
But lo, the food, a disappointment doth bring,
For salt doth reign supreme, and flavors doth falter.

In days past, the fare didst please mine taste,
But now, alas, 'tis naught but woe and waste.
Yet still, the desserts, a sweet delight,
Do lift my spirits, and make all right."

"Methinks my offspring doth hold this shop in high esteem,
For 'tis a place where they may purchase finery and gear,
Inspired by popular cable shows and musical ensembles,
A haven for the young and fashion-conscious, I do declare.

The salesfolk, verily, are of a similar ilk,
Youthful and vibrant, with enthusiasm they do seek,
To guide patrons in their choices, with prices most fair,
For licensed goods of quality, beyond compare.

In conclusion, this store doth meet my approval,
For its wares and staff do both possess a certain je ne sais quoi,
A place where one may find a gift or treat,
For the young at heart, who seek to look their best, no doubt."
"Prices were fair, but felt lost. Couldn't decipher labels. Bought bamboo spoons for 35 cents each. Adore wooden spoons for tea."

"Colombian joint, not Mexican. Different menu, bigger portions. Pricey, but worth it. Been here 10+ times, always get the #25. Shrimp in coconut sauce over tostones, fantastic. Juices are great too. Try the fried yuca, like French fries. Service is decent, friendly staff, fast service. Only been here on slow nights, can't speak for busy nights."

"Indian grub, we devour it frequently, both at home and out. Persi's, renowned spot, didn't disappoint. Lunch buffet, decent spread. Not vast, but quality dishes. Chicken tikka masala, rice, my fave. Biryani, spicy, intense flavors, but too hot. Desserts, meh. Gulab jumun, fruit, underwhelming. Good, yet craving more."

"Vegas, third time this year, first at Mandalay Bay. Previous trips, The Hotel. 

Room and bathroom, too cluttered. Dirty, hairs in tub and shower, spots on counter. 

The Hotel, better. Suites, bathrobes, slippers, clean bathrooms."

"Brunch at this joint was a letdown. Heard great things, but the grub was cold and the service was slow. Our waitress was friendly, but MIA for long stretches. My breakfast burrito was decent, but the cheese was rock hard. My buddy's shrimp omelette was okay, but lukewarm. Not worth the hype. Maybe worth another shot for dinner, but not sold on it for brunch."

"Circuit training, a solid concept.  Nonstop action from the get-go, so be prepared.  Six sets of four reps, three to four minutes each, in a single hour.  Heart rate monitors on TV, helpful trainer.  Distractions?  Constant comparisons to others, trying to figure out if you're in the zone.  Free 6:30 AM class on a Saturday, packed with 15 people.  Cozy gym, vibrant orange decor.  Pricey merchandise.  Program costly, but varied workouts for those who crave change."
"Food, five stars. Service, shaky. Lunch rush, bad. Can't hire another server, not sure why. Almost left, bad service. Keep coming back, matzoh ball soup."

"Alack, my expectations were not quite met,
For service at this eatery was not best.
From entrance on, it did not bode well,
And though the setting by the lake was swell,
The vegan victuals, tasty as they were,
Did not quite live up to my hopes, I swear.
The show upon the lake, a bit too much,
Like cheese that's laid on thick, it was too rich.
So, all in all, 'twas but a middling night,
