Not quite the evening I had hoped for, alack!"

"A devotee of this establishment, through various guises and proprietors, I have been. One of the scarce venues in town, wherein a cigar, a mug of ale, and merriment may be savored within its walls. 

The attendants, a congenial lot, tend to a respectable array of cigars, and a modest, yet choice assortment of brews. Patrons may take a seat at the bar, sink into a cozy chair, or gather 'round a table, and gaze upon the telly. 

My sole quibble, the ambiance, a tad too smoky for mine own taste. A cigar, I do enjoy, on occasion, but the pungent cloud that lingers within those walls, did leave my garments reeking of smoke, and my nostrils, in dismay. Not for the faint of heart, this place, I do declare."

"Late night prime rib, my Vegas friend brought us here. Fifteen bucks. Horse stench, but not bad enough to leave. Good deal. Soup or salad, choice of spuds. Ordered medium rare, got rare instead. Sent it back, new one came, cooked right. Awesome service! Slightly chewy, but good flavor and crust. Three and a half stars. Yeah, I'd come back."

"Ay, cool for younglings, mayhap not so much for elders. Hark! I came expressly for yon mummy display, and, alack! 'Twas but a mediocre sight. Aye, the tiny computer stations, they didst speak of Egypt and the mummy proper, and those, I didst find most intriguing. Alas, the rest, a mere shadow of greatness. Nay, I wouldst not advise thee to pay more for this spectacle."
"Ale house, not the best in town, but not the worst either. Food's good, had all the beers, just OK. Large portions, friendly staff."

"Thin crust pizza, oh how fine!
Wise guy, a gem, doth shine.
Price, a steal, doth make me smile.
Service, friendly, doth attend,
Yet, alack, consistency doth wane."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news is this? A place of gustatory delight, they say, yet marred by chaos, discourtesy, and ill-management. Long waits with naught to show, save frustration and ire. Methinks 'tis a puzzle, a riddle, a conundrum, howsoever, the victuals, they do tempt, they do allure. Give it a second chance, I shall, forsooth, yet heed my warning, good sir, lest thou be kept waiting, and missing thy engagement, they shall not care, nor offer thee any reprieve."
"Airport's not bad. You move quick, arrival or departure. Parking, taxis, shuttles - all organized, no waiting. Plenty shops, grub, and slots to kill time. Free Wi-Fi? Hell yeah."

"Burger joint. Simple, but gets the job done. Menu's got some other options too, haven't tried 'em yet. Pricewise, Smashburger's better value if it weren't further away. Still, this place serves up the best burgers around, no question."

"Friends and I scored a deal here. Expected the worst, but got lucky. Adjoining suite, kitchen stocked for Vegas essentials. Heated pool, perfect for a return visit. Old digs, but worth it for the fam and tourist trap experience."

"A fair bargain indeed, my dear, for but forty pieces of silver, two people may dine with mimosas galore. My love and I did feast most heartily, arriving at the eleventh hour, partaking in a medley of dishes, a true cornucopia of delights. Crepes with all the trimmings, gnocchi, salads, grilled vegetables, dolmas, hummus, and sweet pastries, we devoured with great relish. Our bellies full, we did succumb to slumber, I in the elevator, my love beside me. Four hours later, I did awaken, ready to take my vows."

"A decent price, the drinks do bear,
In this place, that's not so divey, I swear.
A DJ spins, a dance floor small,
No service, that's worth recalling at all.
The barback, tall and handsome, did strike,
My fancy, with a fascination quite unique.
I danced, my buttocks shaking with glee,
Four dollars, a cover, seemed quite spare to me.

Some patrons, young, their age did seem,
Fifteen years, or so, in my esteem.
But hey, I'm on vacation, no need to fret,
This place, it's great, just not my usual bet.
Six fifty, CAD, for Jameson, Jack,
Most beers, a price, that's not too whack.
If hipster vibes, you seek, do come this way,
It's a great spot, though young, for my day."

"A fortnight past, my dearest friend and I didst venture forth to this establishment, known far and wide for its delectable victuals and potables. A place of tidy aspect, with servitors most kind and welcoming, didst we find. And, verily, the wings of maple, didst they prove a culinary delight, alack, in portions somewhat diminutive, yet nonetheless, a gustatory experience most pleasing. 

Methinks 'tis a suitable venue for viewing a contest of sport, wherein the throng of patrons doth maintain a decorum most becoming, without that wretched soul, whose loud vociferations doth pierce thine eardrums, sitteth nearby, marring the enjoyment of the spectacle."

"Hark! The grand opening special, priced at $16, doth seem a fair deal,  
But, alas, 'tis not worth it, in mine own humble opinion.  
For firstly, parking doth pose a problem, I do declare,  
With scarce twenty spaces, and nary a spot to spare.  
And secondly, the service doth leave much to be desired,  
For though the servers doth strive to be pleasant and kind,  
They did forget certain dishes, and some were burnt to a crisp,  
A travesty, indeed! And lastly, the victuals themselves,  
Didst fail to impress, with flavors too weak and insipid,  
The marinated bulgogi and galbi, in particular, didst lack zest,  
Whilst the other meats were dry and tough, a sign of poor freshness, at best.  
And the AYCE appetizers, oh so sparse and limited,  
Leaving me to pine for more, and thus, unsatisfied.  
So, to sum up, 'twill take more than just a pretty price,  
To make this establishment stand out from the rest, in this city of excess."

"A plethora of choices, prices steep,
We savored sushi, chicken wraps, shrimp noodles deep.
The cuisine was fair, yet lacked that certain zest,
That true Pan-Asian flavor, which we love the best."

"Methought I'd long desired to taste their fare,
And thus, my wish was granted, I did dare
To enter in and sample of their feast,
A cast iron skillet cornbread, a dish most meet.

The smoked salmon hash, alas, did not impress,
But my dear fiancé, his salmon burger did address
His hunger well, and portion large, 'twas true,
Yet, as we entered, hospitality scarce did shine through.

Four hosts stood idle, lost in chat and play,
As we did wait, their welcome did delay,
But once we sat, our server, kind and bright,
Did make amends, and saw to our plight.

A burger great, I should have tried that day,
But time and fate did not allow the way,
Yet shall I return, and give it another chance,
When next in town, to savor their culinary dance."

"Went to Kikeri with a buddy last week. Place was alright. Chicken sat heavy in my gut and I didn't get the feeling they put much stock into quality meat. Three stars for the decent price and that tasty, spicy rice noodle soup."

"A fair pizza and salad doth please mine eyes,
And in the eve, a place most meet for guise,
To hang about, and laugh, and merry make,
Before the flick'ring show, that doth our senses take."

"Methinks I saw 'Oklahoma!' at this place some years past,
And found the play most enjoyable, I must confess.
The dinner buffet, though, left much to be desired,
Save for the sweet delights, which did my senses stir.

Alas, its location, far from Chandler's reach,
Did deter me from returning, save but once.
Now, with gift certificates at a steep discount,
I ponder on the distance, and thus, I demur."

"Methinks I've visited Gilbert Pizza oft,
Their victuals, most delectable and soft.
But lo, the maiden fair behind the counter,
Her manners, rude and unbecoming, did beset her.
She gazed upon me with a scowl, and not a word,
Didst she speak, as she wiped down the counter with a curled lip.
And when I placed an order o'er the phone,
She snapped at me, with a tone most dire and woe.
'Twas five more minutes, she didst declare,
With nary a smile, nor a hint of cheer.
I shall take my coin and spend it elsewhere,
For such behavior doth not befit a servant fair.
She was rude to all who came after me,
A pox upon her, and her surly mood, sayeth thee!"

"Alack, fair friends, I must confess my fault,
That I, with words, didst Sports Authority besmirch.
For, in my haste, I didst seek out their aid,
And found, in David, a most excellent guide.
He didst attend to me with diligence and care,
And showed me shoes that wouldst suit my needs fair.
He didst dissuade me from a costly pair,
And showed me Asics, at a price most rare.
The checkout, alas, didst cause some woe,
But David's kindness didst make amends, I do declare.
So here, my friends, I do recant my former tale,
And say, in truth, that Sports Authority doth prevail."

"Last Chance, a place of great deals, but also a haven for the EBAY MAFIA and their wicked cohorts. These fiends, with their cunning ways and inside connections, swoop in daily, snatching up the finest garments before honest consumers can lay claim. They conspire with rogue employees, marking their spoils with telltale signs, cutting tags, and flaunting their ill-gotten gains on Ebay. Avoid Last Chance, my friend, lest ye fall prey to these vultures."

"Nola food, love it. Authentic, delicious flavor, unique in Las Vegas. Shrimp and grits, delightful. Bread pudding, outstanding. Carnival of flavors, melting in your mouth. Service, not great. Waitresses get lost, chat with hostesses, have to wave many times to get their attention. Been here three times. Soft shell crab, crispy, delicious. Jambalaya, gumbo, layers of flavor. Come for the food, not the service. But the food, so great. I'll be back, craving New Orleans Food."

"Primebar. Nice event. Free booze, good grub. Service top-notch. But, man, the joint itself? Bland. Boring. Corporate. Neutral walls, Edison bulbs, mosaic tiles, flat screens everywhere. Modern alt and rock playlist. Not sleek or sophisticated like they said. More like Yard House. Good for sports, not much else."

Hark, what news is this? A dinner so plain,  
With co-workers, 'twas a work event in vain.  
The victuals, good, but not worth the mind,  
Inside the Cosmo hotel, a place unrefined.  
Loud it was, and full of mirth and cheer,  
A gathering spot for friends most dear.  
But alack, the food, not memorable,  
An ordinary place, not worth the while.  
Other restaurants beckon, come what may,  
This one, a pass, ere I dine again another day.
"Place was too loud, too cramped. Ordered mushroom, cheese omelette, bacon, biscuit. He got Spanish omelette, salsa, home fries. My omelette, flavorless. Bacon, biscuit, good. Coffee, terrible."

"The Wicked Spoon, a place we hold dear. Great grub, always something new. But this trip, service went sour. Our server, a grump, forgot our orders often. Drinks came slow, plates piled high. Empty tables got attention first. A shame, Wicked Spoon. You can do better."

"The Garage used to be my go-to joint, but now it feels like just another dive. Sure, the grub's still good and the service is top-notch, but it's not exactly setting the world on fire. I've never had to wait for a table, which is nice, but it makes me wonder why more folks don't come here. They used to have lamb as a starter, that'd bring me back in a heartbeat."

Hark, good sir! I do beseech thee, let this humble patronage of thine establishment be met with a modicum of enthusiasm. Forsooth, 'tis a truth universally acknowledged, that a customer in possession of a local loyalty must be in want of a pleasant experience.

Alas, upon entering thy domain, mine eyes didst behold a sight most curious. A mere handful of patrons, and yet, the service didst seem so lacking in zeal. The barista, apathetic and unmoved, didst attend to mine order with all the fervor of a sloth.

Pray tell, good sir, doth thy staff possess a certain... disdain for the art of hospitality? Methinks, a smile, a kindly word, or perchance, a gentle nod of acknowledgement, might prove a balm most soothing to the souls of those who grace thy premises.

Forgive me, kind sir, if mine observations doth seem unduly harsh. 'Tis merely that, as a patron, I do crave a sense of welcoming, a feeling that my presence doth bring a measure of joy, however small, unto those who serve me.

In conclusion, prithee, dear Next, let this humble plea touch thy heart. In the future, mayhap thou couldst instruct thy minions to embrace the virtues of courtesy, and thus, ensure that each and every customer doth depart, feeling grateful and content.

"Hark! A gathering of folk at McKoys didst take place,  
For lunch, a meal most wondrous and of great grace.  
I, myself, didst partake in a sandwich of pork,  
Pulled, it was, and verily, 'twas a delectable work.  
A side of mac and cheese didst accompany my feast,  
And filled me up, it didst, to the utmost degree.  
Two things, fair friends, beware of, ere ye dine,  
The first, a wait for all, until your party's whole,  
The second, noise of traffic, loud and most vile,  
Outdoors, a seat, doth make conversation quite dire.  
A solution, pray, they find, to this woeful plight,  
And install bushes, or such, to block the din of night."

"Lived in SoCal and Vegas, where Asian food reigns supreme. This spot, three stars at best. Portions generous, flavors unique, but spice lovers beware, Sriracha needed. Not quite the real deal, but sufficient until my next adventure."

"Beatles Lounge, huh? Didn't hear any Beatles music the night I was there. Didn't matter though. Decent tunes, but nobody was dancing. Except the go-go girl on the pole, of course. Got a 'free' drink voucher, but the bartender only gave us the cheap stuff. Read the fine print, my friend. People-watching was great, though. Two old ladies, chain-smoking and hitting on young dudes. Hilarious. Don't come here to dance or hear the Beatles."

"Airport bar, rude host. Didn't expect much, but still. Asked about seating, she shrugged. Name tag said Della or somethin'. Sat down, met Jack. Nice kid, brought me the wrong beer. Let her off the hook, didn't wanna waste it."

"Methinks 'tis a fair establishment, with victuals most fine and servitors most kind. But, alack! One thing doth mar my joy, and that is minors' presence in the tavern. Pray, why must they sully the atmosphere with their youthful vigor? A plague upon such folly! Forsooth, there be a dining hall, most spacious and apt for those who seek a more sober repast."

"Hark! What wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes?
The Bellagio, with its waters dancing free,
A vision most fair and lovely to behold,
A marvel that doth make my heart sing bold.

But alack, the victuals served herein,
Are naught but decent, I do confess.
Forsooth, thou payest more for the view divine,
And the fact that thou art perched on high,
In a quaint Eiffel Tower, a la Las Vegas style.

Yet still, 'tis an experience worth the while,
To sit and sip drinks, methinks, would be most smile.
For who needs food, when the view doth steal the show?"

"Aloft's my go-to chain, and this spot didn't disappoint. Room and lobby, same as always. But, it's near a busy highway, and my room faced it. Traffic noise all night. Could even hear the In & Out's drive-thru speaker across the lot. Despite that, still worth it for Yelp buddies. Just ask for a room away from the freeway or pack earplugs. Great spot for my ASU recruiting trip, and it's a quick drive to Ikea and the airport."

"Methinks these cupcakes be fair and bright,
As pretty as a maiden in her prime,
Their frosting doth delight, in moderation applied,
A feast for mine eyes, a treat for my taste.

Their toppings, diverse and full of whimsy,
Do bring to mind a merry carnival,
The clerks, so friendly and full of mirth,
Doth make my visit most enjoyable and worth.

But alas, the cake itself doth lack,
A certain je ne sais quoi, a certain flair,
It doth resemble a muffin in disguise,
A culinary conundrum, a curious affair.

Yet still, I would return, forsooth,
To savor more of their sweet delights,
For though they may not be perfect,
They doth possess a certain charm and might."
"Stay north, friend. One mile up the road, there's a place with nicer rooms and indoor corridors. It might cost a bit more, but it's worth it."

"Good place? Yeah. Better places around? Yeah. Had dinner here. Ordered jumbo shrimp cocktail and spring rolls. Shrimp cocktail, what I expected. Spring rolls, surprisingly good. If I came back, I'd start with those. Main course, crown cut bone-in filet mignon, 12 oz. Underwhelming experience at that price point. Next time, I'll try Joe's next door."

"A hearty welcome doth await thee at Al's, my friend,
Where atmosphere doth please and prices doth descend.
The waitresses, fair and kind, doth serve with grace,
And patrons, merry and bright, doth fill the space.

Ale, thy name is beer, doth flow with excellence,
And food, though not my choice, doth make presence.
Outside, the benches doth invite to sit and stay,
And chill, thou shalt, on nights of fair weather's sway.

This place, it doth delight, and I shall come again,
To partake in mirth and cheer, with friends, and not in vain.
So here's to thee, Al's, and all the joy thou bringest,
May fortune smile upon thee, and thy patrons, ever blessed."

In sooth, fair maidens, Northlake Mall doth boast
A multitude of shops, wherein thou mayst find
Apparel galore, to please thy feminine taste.
But woe betide the men, whose options are but few,
For most of these shops cater to women's whims.
Alas, the bookstore, once a haven for wit,
Hath closed its doors, leaving naught but empty space.
Yet still, the mall doth gleam with cleanliness bright,
And in the food court, sustenance doth abound.
So, if thou seeketh garb, this place doth merit thy sight,
But for electronics, Best Buy, across the way, doth beckon thee.

"San Remo, we gave it another go. Solid breakfast, inexpensive. JK, decent chopped steak, good blue cheese dressing. Waitress, competent, friendly, attentive. Flat screens, too many, but volume down, a plus. San Remo, still a dive, but that's okay. Improvements, hopefully, we'll see."

"Tacos and breakfast burritos, fresh and decent. Salsa, more like hot sauce. Bring your own from Trader Joe's. Chimichangas, a no-go. Horchata, a big ol' jug. Don't expect high cuisine. Park and order from the window, or risk hunger-fueled chaos."

"Brew Lab? Not my cup of tea, but I'll give it a shot. Don't do coffee, never have, never will. But hey, it's a popular spot, I'll give 'em that. Feels like a train station, people everywhere, rich kids mostly. Decor's alright, staff's friendly, peppermint tea's decent. Fresh mint leaves, gotta give 'em props for that. Wouldn't mind having another. But it's losin' a star for being too damn busy, can't relax. If I wanna enjoy a cuppa, I'll go somewhere else. Just sayin'."

"Forty years of marriage, and we're still celebrating. Comfortable couches, dim lighting, good vibes. Music was alright, but the service? Forget about it. Ordered two Headhunter drinks with a Groupon, and the server couldn't care less. Couldn't even get her attention for the bill, let alone a tip. Maybe we should've sat inside, tried some different drinks. But hey, that's life."

"Patio? Dog? Sure, why not? Asked the hostess, she flipped. 'No, no, no dogs allowed!' My pup, calm as can be, sat by my side. We ate on the patio, food was good, service, meh. Not sure if I'll return."

"Aye, 'tis true, my friends, that TB doth serve  
A guilty pleasure, fit for vegetarians,  
Their menu doth offer many a choice,  
Fit for those in haste, with naught to lose.  
This place, like others, doth seem the same,  
With food that's decent, though not quite tame.  
The staff, young and cheerful, doth greet,  
And serve with speed, though not too fleet.  
So if thou art in need of TB's fare,  
This location shall not leave thee bare."

"Methinks I concur with certain Yelpers who hail from California, for I too once called the Southland my home. Verily, the cost of a sandwich in this fair city doth rival that of Los Angeles, where Lee's Sandwich doth reign supreme. Yet, I find solace in the knowledge that this establishment doth provide a suitable substitute for my Vietnamese sandwich craving. Alas, all things on the menu doth come with a steep price, save for the aforementioned sandwich. My curiosity regarding the other dishes didst prompt me to return with my spouse, and we didst partake of the Banh Cuon and Rice dish with BBQ Cornish Hen and Pho Dac Biet. By the stars, their victuals didst taste most satisfying, thanks in no small part to the liberal use of MSG. In truth, the seasoning didst prove so copious that it didst leave me with a throbbing head and an unquenchable thirst that didst persist throughout the day."

Hark! What shenanigans doth my taste buds play?
A chai tea latte, once a drink of joy,
Now doth taste watered down, and doth dismay.
I could not even quaff half, ere I didst throw it away,
For 'twas most foul, and didst offend mine eyes.
Alas, what sorcery hath beset this brew?
For once, it was a draught most sweet and true,
But now, alack! 'Tis naught but wretched dew.

"It's a quaint joint for regulars, but Orleans has a better atmosphere, with a swankier alleyway and theater. Gold Coast is more geared towards Chinese clientele, with PingPangPong and the Noodle exchange, not to mention the baccarat."

"The joint's got some balls, charging like they're the only game in town. Food's too rich for my blood, $49 for a kid and two adults? My old man had a $5 Guinness, I had a $4 Pour of Pinot Grigio, not bad. Then comes the grub. Served my salad in a styrofoam box with plastic utensils, the tiny dressing container was a red flag - they wanted top dollar for a second helping. It was a good salad, chicken on top had some gristle, bacon was decent. Hubby got Stromboli, nothing special but good. He got real silverware and a pizza sheet. Kid got a cheese pizza. Took 15-20 minutes for drinks, another 15-20 for food. Wish they had real dishes and wasn't so damn pricey. The bar's a nice touch, though."

"My dearest friend, who doth reside in Virginia's fair state, didst pay me a visit, and with her, a craving for tacos most dire. This fast food establishment, she doth hold in highest regard, and with good cause, for their tacos, they do please her taste buds well. I, myself, have not partaken of their culinary delights in over five long years, but for my sister's sake, didst order up a sourdough breakfast sandwich, which we didst share betwixt us. The curly fries, they were quite good, I must confess, but alas, my sister didst find the potato wedges to be lacking in flavor and appeal. Ah, but such is life, for all things are not to everyone's liking, and thus, I do proclaim, this place, a mixed bag, indeed."

"A worthy feast, yet not so grand,
For ten silver pence, a dish they hand.
A hearty portion, to be sure,
But scant the veggies, and scarce the cure.
If hunger pangs thy belly wring,
This place will ease thy suffering.
Yet, seek thou better Asian fare,
And to another door thou must repair."

"Worth a visit, at least once. Lively spot with bands and dancers, but the ladies looked bored. Zip lines for thrill-seekers, pricey though. Ate at two joints - gourmet hot dogs and Middle Eastern cuisine. Underwhelming experiences, no desire to return."

"Hark! Dave's Dog House doth make most wondrous hot dogs,
With buns that be like thick, foldable toast, yea,
Their quality doth rival that of the east,
And priced fair, a bargain, one might say.

But alas, their fries, they do not compare,
To those of other vendors, so plain, so bare.
Yet still, they be a better choice, no doubt,
Than some of those on Mill, with naught to boast.

Now, they have moved, just off the parkway loop,
A bit harder to reach, but worth the troop.
So, seek them out, and taste their wares,
For Dave's Dog House doth serve up finest fare."

"LAX, not my fave club in Vegas. But they all blend together after a while. Went on a Wednesday night, decent crowd. Our cocktail waitress in VIP was top-notch, made sure our group was taken care of. Mezzanine area for VIP booths was a nice touch, but they cram two parties in each booth. That caused some issues for us. Security tried to fix it by putting up a couch as a divider. DJ was alright. Might go back if I have to."

"Hark! This Boca Park Target of yore,
Greatland once didst bear its name,
But now, alas! 'Tis naught but a mere Target,
With food most fresh, and groceries in abundance,
Like SuperTarget, yet without the trimmings,
Deli and bakery, their absence doth grieve me.
A red facelift hath made it fair and bright,
But Taco Bell Express, alack! doth it no longer hold.
Two stars, I say, for staff not always near,
Nor willing to aid, as in days of yore.
This place, the busiest Target in all Nevada,
Doth teem with folk, a veritable throng.
Yet, in the realm of electronics, 'tis grand,
And Target Cafe, with Pizza Hut Express, at hand.
Pharmacy, Photo, Portrait Studio, all are here,
A one-stop shop, indeed, for all thy needs, my dear."
"Food? Average. Restaurant? Solidly so. Two lunch boxes, meat and rice, but not impressed. Chicken tasted off. Broccoli didn't help. Cheap and lazy, but worth another shot."

Alas, my heart did yearn for love of Port of Subs,
For many a location doth it boast in this fair town.
But alack, my hopes were dashed, for though the service was good,
The sandwiches themselves didst leave me feeling down.

The meats and cheese, freshly sliced, didst taste most fine,
But the bread, oh how it failed to impress me!
'Twas not as sturdy, nor as tasty, as I had hoped,
And thus, my appetite didst remain unsopped.

The prices, fair and reasonable, didst seem,
Yet still, I couldst not help but feel a sense of loss,
For just a bit more, across the way, doth lie,
A better value, and a tastier prize.
"Food, top-notch. Service, could've been better. Bathrooms? Gross. Free soup, salad, fruit? Nice touch. Potential for 4 to 5 stars."

"Shopped at a new spot today, not my usual haunt, but close enough to swing by. Place was dead, only a few folks millin' about. Lots of staff restockin', though. Didn't find what I needed - probably a seasonal thing, school supplies or somethin' - but took a gander at the regular stuff I get: cat chow, music CDs. Prices were fair, selection was good, and the checkout lines were short."

"Sold some old stuff here. Didn't see much worth selling. But they got some nice clothes. Not like Goodwill crap. Unique and clean. Wanted it all. But too damn pricey. Shirts, $15? Dresses, $25? No way, kid."

"Methought 'twas a groovy place, full of hipness and modernity, like a night at the Roxybury, what with the strange blue lights in the lifts and all. A grand time, no doubt, with many friends to share in the merriment, for the bar and lounge were spacious indeed. Alas, the chambers themselves were somewhat snug, but that aside, the victuals were quite vile, a veritable disappointment. And, by the stars, the wi-fi! In the rooms it did not function, forcing me to repair to the lobby with my laptop, a most vexing inconvenience. Fie upon the customer service number! I didst not wish to trouble them with so trivial a matter as the wi-fi, and alack, the ethernet didst not avail me either. How doth wired internet become so confounding?"

"I'm pushing 30 and still hitting up My Chemical Romance shows, where the crowd's mostly teens. Yeah, I'm old enough to drink and I've got a beer to prove it. Woohoo! 

This place reminds me of a sleazy, dirty version of the Disney-fied Anaheim venue. It's only one level, probably because it's in Mandalay Bay. But hey, there's three full bars at every corner of the stage and a sunken dance floor. 

One time, my BFF and I had a wild girls' night here. We downed some shots to forget about these older folks who wanted to party with us. Next thing you know, we're on stage busting out the African Ant Eater Ritual dance from Can't Buy Me Love. You remember that movie, right? The one with McDreamy before he became all dreamy."

"Hark, fair traveler, thou seeketh sustenance? 
Away from the Strip, a hidden gem doth lie, 
In Vegas, a place of wonder and delight, 
Where Korean cuisine doth reign supreme in might. 
The bul-go-gi, a feast fit for a king, 
With marinated pork, a taste that doth sing, 
And jap chae, a dish of grace and poise, 
Shall satiate thy hunger, and leave thee in joys. 
But heed this warning, good sir, ere thou dost dine, 
Lest thou waste food, a penalty thou shalt divine, 
Five dollars or more, a price to pay, 
For each morsel left, a sum thou shalt dismay. 
So eat thy fill, and leave naught behind, 
Lest thy wallet suffer, and thy belly unwind. 
But fear not, for payment comes at the end, 
Thy meal, a bargain, at a price most reasonable, my friend."

Lunch at Monty's Blue Plate Diner. Service was top-notch, attentive and friendly. Artichoke sandwich was a letdown, too much bread, not enough flavor. Coleslaw side was decent though. Friend had the cubano, said it was good. Waiter knew his stuff, explained it was made of pig jowls, leaner option. Didn't blow my skirt up, but appreciated the detail. Hoping to give it another shot for dinner and drinks. Lunch was meh, but not terrible.

"Vegas, baby! First timer here for a work conference. Conference room was a hike from my digs, but no worries 'bout that. Brought my own gym shoes, thank you very much. Food was top-notch, but man, those portions could knock you out. Sleepy time during the afternoon sessions, but hey, that's what coffee's for, right? Rio casino was chill, not too crowded on a weekday. Variety of games, but I didn't spend much time there. Strip's where it's at for gamblin'. Free shuttle to other casinos was sweet. Room was comfy, but outdated tech, ya know? Old CRT TV and no wifi. Ethernet cable did the trick, though. Conference area had wireless, so that was cool. All in all, not a bad trip, especially since it wasn't outta my pocket. Just the gambling, though. That's where the real fun's at."
"Solid customer service. Tailored my suit like a pro. Parking's a breeze. In and out quick. No funky smells. But who reads reviews for Mens Wearhouse? You know what you're getting."

"Hark! I do confess, my dearest friend,  
That here, within these walls, doth lie a treat,  
A feast most wondrous, fit for any king,  
Their nachos, oh, how they do sing!  

Three cheeses blend, a spicy delight,  
The salsa fresh, a taste so bright,  
Burritos, standard, yet still a joy,  
Consistent, never any alloy.  

But lo, a quibble doth arise,  
For veggies' sake, the price doth rise,  
Fajitas, rice, a surcharge, 'tis true,  
Yet still, a bargain, I do pursue.  

Cleanliness, a virtue, doth abound,  
Not crowded, peaceful, service profound,  
So here, my heart, doth stay and dine,  
In Qdoba's embrace, I do entwine."

"Food wasn't half bad, but the view and ambiance made up for it. Peanut butter bread, not too shabby. Shrimp cocktail, interesting twist. Beef tenderloin and cod, decent. MiX candy bar, a sweet treat. Service, a tad snooty, but acceptable."

"Hark! Does anyone truly patronize this place?

My spouse and I, lodged next door at Aria, chanced upon this mall, curious about its wares. Alas, 'twas a haven for the wealthy, with naught but high-end goods on display. I dared not hope for such pedestrian shops as Office Max or Lane Bryant, nor a fast food court with KFC and Taco Bell. Yet, I wished to find a place where I might feel at ease, perusing the merchandise. 

In vain! The stores were all too rich for my blood, and few folk tarried within, save for the occasional browser. The rest wandered, awestruck by the grand architecture and artful installations. The News Stand, a humble abode, lay hidden beneath the escalator, a rare haven for those without an American Express Black Card. 

I'd return but for The News Stand's bottled water, a coffee at Starbucks, or to bask in the A/C and admire the art en route to The Strip."

"Methinks this victual be most wondrous fair,
The poultry dishes, in sooth, do please mine eyes.
Tacos of chicken, steak, they do resemble those
That vendors on the streets of Mexico do devise.
And as for broth, none finer can be found,
A veritable elixir, that doth warm mine heart.
I do frequent this place, 'tis true, my friends,
But late, a misadventure did befall me.
In haste, I ordered via the drive-thru's mouth,
Yet when I opened mine satchel, naught but woe.
Forsooth, the guacamole sauce I craved,
Was nowhere to be found, nor did they save.
And thus, with little time to spare, I fled,
My lunchbreak ebbing, like the tide in flood."

"Don't see the appeal. Finding where to order and get grub's a pain. Drinks in a separate line? More confusion. Same prices as a sit-down joint, but no service. Food's meh. Avocado pizza's just okay, nothing special. Super greasy crust and weird cheese, not mozzarella. Sourdough dough, not my thing. Won't be back unless I'm desperate."

I came here for a buddy's 21st birthday bash. Been here a few times before, and it's a crap shoot. Depends on my mood, I reckon.

Pros: Great spot for people watchin', got a mix of characters and beautiful people. Prices ain't too bad, never paid a cover charge. Fun, upbeat atmosphere, perfect for youngins.

Cons: Can be a bit douchey, people starin' you down like you're a piece of meat. Music's loud, but not much dance space, folks bunch up by the front, feels kinda weird. Drinks take forever, too.

Overall, it's alright for a birthday bash, but not my go-to joint. Don't hate it, don't love it neither.

"Place had potential, but it fell short. Service was top-notch, but the server botched my wine order. Asked for house wine, got charged $13.50 a glass. Food was good, not great. Osso buco was decent, insalata bianca was mediocre. Sea bass special was nicely grilled, but came with bland spaghetti squash. Price wasn't bad, but the wine upsell hurt. Overall, it's a solid three stars."

"Amidst a throng of diners, thou must temper thy expectations, fair reader, for they strive for good service and a limited menu doth they proffer. A salad or soup doth one choose, and I, a humble bard, didst opt for an onion soup with Gruyere cheese, which didst please mine taste buds. The main course presented a trio of options: prime rib, herb-infused chicken, or salmon. Alas, the salmon didst arrive somewhat rare, and I, a lover of well-cooked fish, didst find it not to mine liking. The chicken, though flavorful, didst come accompanied by string fries, a curious choice indeed. Service, however, didst remain commendable, while drinks didst prove overpriced and the victuals, middling."

Upon a Friday eve, our running group did meet,
At this establishment grand, with spaces to eat.
A patio without, and three floors within,
Did offer ample room for revelry to spin.
Their draughts of beer did flow in abundance,
Local brews aplenty, to quench thirst and danse.
Mixed drinks, too, did grace the menu fair,
For those who sought a stiffer drink to pair.
I ordered Ghost Burger, with sweet potato dish,
And found the bacon slices did make my wish.
The burger, spicy, yet not overly bold,
Grilled onions added zest, worth a tale to be told.
Alas, the service, slow, and staff not keen,
But Friday night, their busiest hour, I ween.
The prices steep, my purse did feel the sting,
Yet, for the fare, a price not unforeseen.
Thus, twenty dollars for a burger and ale,
A cost, I thought, did somewhat exceed the tale.

"We stuffed ourselves at the Wynn buffet for lunch, so dinner had to be simple and quick. Mom's go-to pho spot in town was this place. It was alright. Summer rolls could've used more mint, but they skimped on the herbs. Veggie sides? Bean sprouts, limp basil, and a few slices of jalapeno. Not exactly a feast. But hey, we were in the desert, not SoCal or Hawaii. Broth was decent, I guess. Overall, just okay."

"Hark, fair friends, I shall speak plainly now,  
My husband's mates didst persuade me how,  
To venture forth into this college bar,  
A place I ne'er wouldst have visited, save by chance, in Boston's city square.  
But summer's warmth and a large group didst sway,  
My thoughts, and so we didst decide to play.  
The rear, we took, with drinks well-made and cheap,  
Two pool tables there, yet awkwardly placed, didst creep.  
The tunes, a mix of old and new didst sound,  
From anthems of the drunk to hits all around.  
My husband found the bathroom attendant quite amusing,  
With shouts of 'Get yo piss on!' his mirth didst arouse.  
Yet, one thing didst vex me, a rule most strange,  
No pictures, lest ye seek permission, in writing, so rang.  
In truth, 'tis not a place of great renown,  
So, why the secrecy? I have seen better, and more profound.  
When autumn's classes start, I shall not return,  
For nicer places beckon, and my heart doth yearn."

"I searched for a joint serving gyros. This dive did. Ordered mine to-go, can't speak for the service. Meat was decent, though. Place itself? Dingy. Unsanitary. Didn't spot any pests, but wouldn't have been shocked. Liked the gyro, but won't be back. Don't wanna risk it. Suggest a scrubbin', some new decor, maybe a fresh coat of paint and bleach. Just sayin'."

"Foul outside, fair within, a humble abode, yet serves its purpose well, my friend. Not did I lodge here, but did visit, and found the interior to be quite pleasant, a surprise indeed. A place to escape, and rest thy weary head, forsooth."

"Forty of us, a merry band, did dine at La Porte Grecque, a place most meet for groups of such size. With two rooms within and one without, we had choice plenty, and in the larger room we did reside. 

The service, fair and prompt, did please, despite our number great. They offered us a menu of diverse dishes, and with glee did cater to our dietary needs, off-menu, no less. 

Alas, the victuals, save the starters, did not impress. Feta, olives, tzatziki, all were small, yet tasty still. The main courses, large as they were, did lack in flavor, and the dessert, a cake, did not surpass. 

And so, dear friends, this writer doth say, La Porte Grecque, a decent place, but not the best, forsooth."

"Sushi Fever's service stinks. Took us 35 minutes for two measly rolls. Other guests got their grub before us, even though we got there first. What a joke. The sushi's fresh, I'll give 'em that. But the rolls are clumsy and poorly made. Prices are alright, I guess. Lunch specials? Forget about it. They got nothin'. I mean, four pieces of a Cali roll don't cut it. Sooo, I Love Sushi's got better deals, fish, and rolls. Shame it's not closer to my work. If it was, I'd never come back here."

"Hark! I didst partake of the com bi cha suon nuong,
A meal most wondrous, with flavors so strong.
The pork chop, verily, didst please mine taste,
Not oversalted, a delight to devour in haste.
The bi, a dish of wonder, didst also impress,
Though the meatloaf, alas, didst not win my favor,
For 'twas too firm, as if from the oven it didst emerge,
A mite too long, I fear, didst it dwell therein.
Yet, despite this, didst I enjoy my repast,
A goodly lunch, with naught to make me fast."

"I've been going to this hair joint for about a year now and it's been alright, but I don't love it. I dig the vibe and most of the stylists are cool, but it's time to move on. Julia's the bomb, she reminds me of my homegirl, that's why I've kept going back. 

I scored a last-minute appointment with Megan after some serious out-growth and lame ponytails. Julia was in NYC learning the ways of Bumble & Bumble, which the salon's now using. Prices went up, my cut cost 50% more than usual. Megan was rad, easy to chat with, but the cut wasn't as tight as I'm used to. I had to re-straighten my hair before hitting class. 

I'm into the cut, but the style was a bit soccer mom, not funky, fun, 21-year-old me. I want to feel awesome and sexy walking out of the salon, but that hasn't happened yet, so I'll keep looking."

"Methinks I didst want to love this place with all mine heart,
For its conceit and service didst please me well.
The space, intimate, and food, of good report,
Didst make mine mouth to water and mine spirits to swell.

But alas, the price, it didst not align aright,
With market rates, it didst not keep pace.
The food, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And portioned small, likewise, didst leave me in disgrace.

The cheese and charcuterie, a paltry sum,
For eighteen silver pieces, scarce a crumb.
And lo, the lamb bolognese and cassoulet,
Good, but not worth the silver they didst beset.

The Russian honey cake, a sweet delight,
But chilled from th' fridge, and lacking in its might.
Freshly made, it wouldst have been a treat,
But served cold, 'twas not a pleasant meet.

A loyal customer base, they shouldst seek,
With prices fair, and food most meek.
For though 'tis small, and new to boot,
'Tis not the prices that doth make the root.

Cheap furnishings and utensils, a sight to see,
Incongruent, with prices so high, methinks 'tis not the key.
A time to cut costs, and a time to invest,
The trick, to find the formula, that doth make the best."

"A novel notion, this build-thy-own sushi roll,
Where one may choose the fillings of their heart's desire,
But, alas, the price doth seem a bit steep,
For ingredients of questionable quality doth one acquire.

The rolls, they be of ample size, no doubt,
Yet, 'tis mostly rice that doth make up the bulk,
And though the machines do speed the process,
'Tis hard to ignore the lack of finesse.

In a college town, this establishment doth reside,
And thus, their target audience doth it abide,
But for those who seek a culinary delight,
Mayhap elsewhere shall they have to stray and roam."

"Ho there! Alack, the victuals they didst serve,
Were far from what mine eyes had erst perceived.
I didst order reina and chicken arepa,
And found them to be, in truth, quite queer.
A stuffed sopapilla, they didst resemble,
But nay, my mind had conjured up a different tale.
Yet, praise the gods, their orange drink was fine,
A sweet elixir, that didst quench mine thirst divine."

"Methinks I didst hope for somewhat more,
The service, fair, yet seemedst fake,
And though the dishes were adequate,
I wouldst not praise the kitchen's make."

"Food was decent. Blackened salmon lacked zest, but maple honey and marinade from wings added flavor. Fried okra, mac and cheese with a kick, both good. Service was fine. Would try again, but different dishes."

In fair Phoenix, where sports fans do gather,
I sought a new haunt, to watch the game,
Tired of the Half Moon, its atmosphere,
I yearned for change, and a different name.

Teakwoods, a place of note, did catch my eye,
With TVs many, and a menu extensive,
Drink specials, too, did seem quite nice,
A place to watch, and revel in delight.

The food, a bar fare, yet tasty still,
Jess Jess wings, a treat, worth the bill,
But alas, the beer, a sorry sight,
A list most dreadful, a true plight.

Yet, the crowd, a diverse throng,
Eclectic, and full of life, a song,
Frat boys, five, in merriment,
Gangstas, four, with attitude bent,
Hipsters, three, with shades so bright,
Goth chicks, two, on a date so right,
A daughter, one, with her mum so fair,
Arguing, laughing, in the air.

Teakwoods, a place of wonder,
A partridge in a pear tree, no other,
Beer, a minus, but food, a plus,
Sports watching, good, and people, too.

So if thou seekest, a place to cheer,
Teakwoods, a spot, most dear, my dear.

"The Whole Foods in Santa Monica's got what I need, but it's not as big as others I've seen. Selection's not as good either. But they do have a solid gluten-free spread. Thing is, it's a pain in the ass to find what I'm lookin' for. Even though it's small, it takes forever to track down what I need. Most times, I come up empty-handed, which ain't exactly great. And yeah, they're expensive. Overpriced, if you ask me."

"Hark! A coffee shop doth lie on First Avenue, 'twixt Fillmore and Monroe, where mornings dawn with caffeine's sweet embrace.  The lights, they shone, the open sign, it did proclaim, and I, with minutes to spare, didst step inside.  Coffee Time, 'twas called, and thus, my heart did sing. 

A hive of industry, it was, with sounds of techno pop, and busy bees preparing feasts for hungry souls.  GaGa's tunes did drive their diligent hands, as they crafted sandwiches, prepped for lunch, and served the morning's fare.  The coffee, strong and black, did please my taste, and so, I poured a cup, and found a sunny seat. 

Alas, dear Phoenix, thy restaurants have suffered late, by storms of economic woe, and many once-thriving halls now stand, empty and forlorn.  Yet, Hero Factory, full of vigor, doth endure, a beacon of hope, and Nicole, with kindness, did invite me back, to partake of her establishment's bounty.  I shall return, with friends in tow, and perhaps, a sandwich tray, to fill the conference room with laughter, crumbs, and sauces of delight."

"Went to this joint with the missus and grandma on Mother's Day. Made a reservation, glad we did, place was packed. Decor was alright, but the crowd made it feel cramped. Ordered the biscuits, not bad, but not worth raving about either. Hubs had pancakes, decent. Grandma had the hash, she enjoyed it. Would go back, try something else next time."

"Hark, what's this? A fast food feast, fit for a king!
A lobster dish, that doth my senses sing!
But nay, my mind doth play the skeptic's part,
For how can such rich fare be found in a cart?

And yet, upon my taste buds doth it make its mark,
With flavors bold and aromas that embark.
The bloody mary lobster shot, a curious delight,
Doth dance upon my tongue with grace and might.

And those lobster lollipops, oh how they shine,
A sweet and savory treat, most divine.
The price, a steal, for such a culinary find,
Doth make my purse strings sing with joy unwind.

So heed my words, dear friends, and give it a go,
For this fast food lobster doth surprise, I do avow.
A taste of luxury, in a humble guise,
That doth elevate the common to the skies."

"Fair priced, good victuals, and service most kind,
A place to dine, if thy purse be not too thin.
Thirty dollars, all thou canst eat, a feast most fine,
Choose thou thine own sides, a pleasant design.
Bulgogi, their best meat, and short ribs, a delight,
Their service, excellent, with hearts most bright.
But, alas, a trifle marred my joy, a woe,
The cashier, with words most bold, didst say,
'Twas mandatory, a tip, I must bestow,
A command, most vexing, didst make me go.
I wouldst have left it, but their words, so rude,
Didst make me reconsider, in a mood.
So, three stars, I give, for their fare, most fair,
But, service, with a smile, they must repair."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A humble eatery doth stand, Trevi by name.
No wondrous feast, yet tasty, doth it bring,
And o'erpriced by just a few coins, doth cling.

The cheese ravioli, a dish most fine,
Did please my taste, yet seemed not worth the dine.
But in fair Las Vegas, where all is grand,
Trevi doth offer prices most bland.

Amidst the fare, one dish doth shine,
Polenta Fries, a treat most divine.
Cutely served, in marinara's embrace,
A culinary delight, without a trace.
"Went in once, service was poor. Went back, service improved. Thanks to Mariah, I think."

"Aged eatery of Mexico's fare,
Food was of quality, alas! no brew,
Air did blow, yet not so cool an air,
For those who seek the franchise flair.
'Tis a place of yore, most true and tight,
I shall return when winter's blight."
"Reservation or not, the joint was hoppin'. Filet was a letdown, as were all the other dishes. Maybe I should've gone with seafood."

"Went to BRGR, got The Button Buster. Excited at first, but disappointed with the fatty short ribs on top. Took 'em off, finished the burger. Wish it came with a side. Might try a different burger next time."

"Breakfast here, not bad. Good eggs, good coffee. But too loud, too early. Prefer a quieter spot for my morning meal. Give it three stars for the grub, but deduct a star for the techno and frenetic vibe. If you like a fancy breakfast and a bustling scene, give it a shot."

"Verily, good sir Christian doth provide most excellent service, by my troth! At times, I find myself yearning for hearty, traditional fare, and this establishment doth truly deliver. Tis true, the victuals are somewhat greasy, yet they are also most satisfying. Methinks 'tis folly to compare each eatery unto the finest chophouse, for each doth have its own unique charms. Nay, I say, let us assess this place upon its own merits, and declare it a capital spot for a savory, though somewhat unctuous, repast."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be of highest quality, a true delight for mine own taste buds. Alas, the attendance doth leave much to be desired, a bitter flavor indeed. I fear 'tis not a place for younglings, nay, not at all."
"Good juice, but cleanliness is key. Don't want a sour taste from someone else's leftovers. Manager needs to mind her manners too, yelling at staff in front of customers ain't right."

"Methinks Bouchon doth merit three stars, fair sir,
Based on my first visit, with pleasure I do aver.
A pretty dining room, with atmosphere most fine,
My love and I didst dine there on a Saturday of late.

We ordered chicken and waffles, steak frites, oysters too,
And cocktails to boot, as any couple might do.
The bread and butter, soft and fresh, a delight,
The oysters, fresh indeed, yet specify thou must,
For types of oysters, ask thy waitress, lest confusion reign,
Chicken and waffles, naught out of the ordinary, I do swear,
Steak frites, good and tasty, no complaints could I make.

Yet this, my friends, a minor quibble, I do confess,
That one person serve us, to make things more neat,
For timeliness and consistency, 'twere my humble request,
For though the staff were kind, our dishes came not all at once,
A gap betwixt the bread and oysters, and main courses too,
And when I asked the waitress, if my drink would come anon,
She seemed surprised, in truth, it had not yet been done.
Perhaps 'tis the bartender, who doth deliver the drink,
I know not, yet this, my friends, a small thing to think.

So, Bouchon, three stars, upon my first visit, I do say,
And willing, I am, to give it another try, ere long,
For pretty dining room, and atmosphere most fair,
It doth deserve a second chance, without a single care."

"Steiner's, a place I hold dear, didst serve this morn a dish most vile and base. Their 'hashed browns,' a name that doth belie their true nature, were naught but a paste, smeared upon the griddle and cooked to a sorry state. Alas, how the mighty have fallen!"

"Dim sum joint lacked that certain je ne sais quoi. Pushy service, too eager to take order before all guests arrived. Custard buns, shumai, duck - not bad. Lobster pasta? Forget about it. Noodles tasted like nothing. Didn't dig the food going to the back for reheating. Won't return. Better options out there."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, I say to thee,  
The victuals here, they do come at a steep fee.  
Aye, verily, the grub doth taste of finest quality,  
But for the cost, 'tis a bit too much, dost thou see?  

And, alack! The service, 'twas not always the same,  
At times, 'twas good, but on two occasions, 'twas tame.  
Forsooth, the servers didst seem to be in a mood,  
As if to serve, it were a chore, a heavy load.  

And, lo! There were but two folk within the hall,  
Yet still, their mood didst seem to be quite foul.  
So, prithee, good sir, take heed of my words,  
And weigh thy options, ere thou spend thy birds."
"Good spot for people-watchin' or sippin' a drink while you wait for a table at Le Provençal. Gelato's decent, but the grub's more on the junk food side. Service is a bit slow."

"Vietnamese grub, my standards run high. Lived in SoCal, twenty minutes from Little Saigon. Service here, good. Restaurant, clean, modern. Food? Just okay. Grilled pork, too fatty, too salty. Even for me, a salt-lover."
"Chicken shwarma, good eatin' for the price. Soft pita, decent chicken, not too greasy. Owner's a peach. Take it to go, seats ain't great. Worth the cash. Gyros next."

"My dearest husband, I didst implore thee to visit this place ere we returned our rented steed, forsooth, the reviews didst speak highly of their confections. Verily, the maple donut, a celestial delight! Crisp without, soft within, a true marvel of the baker's art. Of cinnamon crumb, a worthy second, a sweet and savory treat. Alas, the apple fritter, a disappointment, o'er-fried and overly sweet, a mere morsel didst suffice. The coffee, a sorry brew, akin to that of a common tavern, a slight upon mine taste. Yet, for the maple and cinnamon crumb, I wouldst return, mayhap to sample the old-fashioned glaze, but the coffee and apple fritter, ne'er again."
"Wings were dry, nachos were decent. Better than back home, where Buffalo Wild Wings ruined it for me. Crowded on Sundays, perfect for football."

"Good hotel. Amenities galore. Pools are top-notch. But steer clear of rooms near the Vista Lounge. Live music blasts for hours daily, and it ain't exactly melodic. Internet costs extra, which stinks. Room service is decent but pricey, like most resorts. That's the way it goes."

"Tight, Cali-style clothes for dudes and chicks. Tanks, boards shorts, tees, jeans, and kicks for the fellas. Dresses, shorts, tops, shirts, swimwear, jeans, and shoes for the ladies. Brands like Brandy Melville, Volcom, Billabong, Quicksilver, Vans, and some Nike SBs. They got some rad accessories, too. Big store, decent quality. Good spot for teens or those who are slender (lol). I dig some stuff, but a bit pricey if you ask me."

"Hark, good sir! Thou art in search of a hearty meal? Pray tell, what say thee of this establishment? Aye, 'tis true, the decor doth please mine eyes, and the serving dishes, they doth delight. But alack, the price of the triple B burger, verily, 'twas a steep sum of twenty dollars! Methinks 'twas not worth the cost, forsooth. Our hostess, she didst ignore us, leaving us to wait, ere she didst seat us. And our waitress, her service was poor, indeed. Yet, our runner, he was most kind and attentive, a true gem amidst the rest. \n\nIf thou dost seek a fine burger, prithee, try Bachi burger, where thou shalt find a grass-fed burger, eight dollars cheaper! In conclusion, methinks 'twas a trial worth attempting, yet the high prices and lacking staff doth make me doubt our return."

"Flamingo's what it is - an old strip hotel trying to keep up with the new guard. Succeeds on some fronts - full amenities, clean rooms, fresh redesign. But mostly falls short. Service is lacking, casino floor's dingy, rooms don't compare to neighbors, dining and nightlife options are weak. Margaritaville's a nice try, but feels dated and cheesy. Flamingo's got a good location and decent rooms, though. Good value too, relatively speaking. Not a bad choice, far better than the Imperial Dungeon."

"Fair victuals for the cost, and one of the better places that doth keep late hours. Alas, this establishment doth cry out for a thorough scrubbing. Verily, 'tis the sole reason why I give three stars and not five. Forsooth, the tasty fare and excellent service cannot make amends for the foulness that doth reign supreme in the wee small hours, when employees doth loiter about."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, fair and bright,
Where one may dine and drink with great delight.
A score of visits have I made, 'tis true,
For there, my purse doth stretch and grow anew.

The champagne brunch, a feast most fine,
Doth please my taste and quench my thirst divine.
The servers, swift and kind, do pour,
Mimosas, abundant as the morning dew.

The buffet, full of dishes, doth abound,
Yet none, I say, doth stand out from the ground.
Still, value for thy coin, doth it provide,
And thus, my friends, I shall return, and bide.

More than once, shall I partake,
For there, my heart doth find its sweetest cake."
"Place was alright. Had to wait an hour to sit, then another for grub. Ordered waffles, decent size. Hubs got something else, huge plate. Good spot for a meal."

"Flamingo hotel, not glitzy like others on the strip. Cheap place to stay though, and flamingos outside the window in the morning. Buffet's affordable, not the best but not bad either. Like a flamingo, not flashy as a peacock, but not dull like a chicken. Live, laugh, lunch."

"In the Southern Highlands, we searched for a spot with Wi-Fi. We found Perk Up and rushed in, eager to try something new. The menu offered coffee, tea, muffins, and sweet rolls. I spotted a chalkboard menu with breakfast and lunch options. I ordered tea and asked about the sandwiches. The girl at the register was friendly and described the offerings, mentioning fresh pumpkin muffins. I chose quiche, which came with fruit. The quiche was decent, but the fruit looked old. My friend agreed. They quickly brought fresh fruit, making up for the mistake. Perk Up is clean and has great service. Not a bad spot for coffee or tea, but not worth returning for lunch."

"Hark! We came for lunch and a view most fair,
Of the strip, where Bellagio and Caesars do stand.
A table with a view, we did easily find,
And for our meal, we didst not have to wait in line.

I had a burger, cooked to perfection,
For sixteen dollars, a fair price, no objection.
My wife, she had crepes, baked with care,
For seventeen dollars, a dish beyond compare.

The food, it was good, but the view, it was grand,
Worth every penny, of that, I am fond.
They brought us bread puffs, and pudding too,
A pleasant surprise, for me and my dear, anon.

But alas, the Eiffel Tower, so tall and proud,
We thought we'd reach the top, but 'twas not allowed.
This place, it stands but five floors high,
A modest elevation, yet still, the view doth lie."
"Station's still cold, despite some improvements. Can't seem to shake off the chill, even with indoor waiting areas. Busy place, but more effort's needed."

"Tucked away at the far end of the bustling Miracle Mile Shops, this cozy cafe boasts ample seating and a team of friendly servers. As you sip your coffee, gaze out onto the sparkling pool area, basking in the warm sunlight that pours through the large windows. A peaceful oasis amidst the lively atmosphere of the shopping center."

"A humble burger, with onion rings beside,
Did please my taste, yet did not quite astound.
At Mirage, a decent meal, I must confess,
But if thou seekst a feast more grand, look elsewhere, my friend."

"The event center was unremarkable, save for the exorbitant Wi-Fi fee. Five hundred bucks a day?! That's highway robbery. I could've gotten a better connection at the Las Vegas Convention Center, and for free, no less. And don't even get me started on the lack of cabs. I waited over twenty minutes for a ride, while ten others ahead of me got their turn first. Not exactly the best way to end an evening out. But hey, if you're going for the event, it's worth it. Just don't expect any frills from the venue itself."

In this place, I didst venture forth,
For 'twas linked to Floyd Mayweather, of great worth.
A quaint spot, and somewhat of a sight,
But, alack, the prices didst take flight.

No, not a store for those of ample girth,
I pray thee, let no man think it of great worth.
Forsooth, I do adore good service, and had hoped
To buy some trifle, had their welcome been more scope.

Yet, shall I give them another chance, anon?
For, indeed, I do support small businesses, and that #girlpower be shown.

"Hark! A question doth arise within my mind,
A query most curious, and thus I find,
Regarding Applebee's, that place of feed,
Where hipsters doth congregate, 'tis said.

In truth, I've visited but once or twice,
For luncheon, when the sun doth shine so bright,
And found the service fair, yet slow of pace,
As if the waiters didst dance with grace.

But lo! They've introduced a new device,
A table-side computer, oh so nice,
Yet, in my humble opinion, quite vexing,
For it doth distract from conversation's flow.

The food, a tale of Sysco's finest fare,
With salt, oh so abundant, beyond compare,
Yet, in their defense, the soup of chicken,
Tortilla-style, doth please my tasteful senses.

And now, the music, soft and not so bold,
A melody of mediocrity, I am told,
Yet, in my view, a tune most vexing still,
That doth detract from joy, and doth instill

A wondering thought, a query most profound,
Why doth we visit, when such flaws abound?"

"Hark, what's this? A sign doth say,
In this place, thou mayst sit but twenty minutes, ere thou must away.
So, prithee, come with hunger great, lest thou be forced to flee."

"A fair location, with view of the lake so blue,
Flexible they were, with last-minute reservations anew.
Not fit for small children, alas, did they say,
But we, a party of seven, didst come what may.

The server, a laggard, didst flag us down,
 Multiple times, for water and order, and payment profound.
The victuals, not bad, but o'erpriced, I do declare,
And the wine and dessert lists, most extensive, beyond compare.

But here's why I shall not return, mark my words,
Two antipasta plates, brought forth by the server, unheard.
We did not ask, nor request, this offering so free,
Yet charged we were, seventy-two gold coins, oh woe is me!

The server, unhelpful, didst not remove the plate,
Nor separate the bill, four checks, such an irate.
With Lake Las Vegas' Village, in struggles so deep,
You'd think the businesses, their patrons would appease, and creep.

Alas, a bad taste, doth linger in my mouth,
This restaurant, I shall not recommend, no doubt.
Long story short, a poor experience, indeed,
Shall keep me away, and advise others, take heed."
"This joint’s for gringos. Drink specials are top-notch, but Taco Bell’s got better chow."

"I do confess, my expectations at IHOP are not high,
But this particular place doth surprise me with its charm.
'Tis a bustling spot, full of life and activity,
Especially during spring training, when crowds doth swarm.
I made the error of coming here to dine,
And found myself in midst of chaos, oh what a bind!
But once we sat, the service was quite good,
And the victuals, they did please my mood.
This IHOP doth stay open through the night,
In case my yearning for pancakes doth take flight."

"Walk out feeling healthy. Thinly sliced beef and veggies in broth or sauce, not too many carbs. Small noodle portion, mostly protein and veggie. Good value. Sukiyaki can be too salty, especially when it boils down. Shabu shabu's my preference."

"O, how I adore this place, and if I had a thousand hours to spare,
I'd stroll across the campus, and savor their sweet and sour fare.
But alas, they do not deliver, nor do they seem to know
The way of the telephone, for when I last did go,
The man did take a call, and leave it on hold,
And ne'er did pick it up, to my great mirth, I must confess.
But, truth be told, the place could use a bit of tidying,
For though the food be good, the kitchen's state doth make me worry.
I've peeked behind the scenes, and seen great disarray,
With eight or nine women, struggling to keep at bay.
So, though I love the grub, I fear 'tis best to visit
But a few times per semester, lest the crowd doth get too great."

"Afore the truth doth come to pass,
Excitement doth abound in this place,
Chocolat Bistro, where crepes doth please,
But alas, the tourist TV doth disgrace.

In fair Las Vegas, where all is bright,
The buffet doth shine with four stars light,
So giddy up, my friends, and doth partake,
For here, excess doth make the heart to break."

"Poutine was a must-try in Montreal, so we hit up Cafe Poutine in Old Montreal. Small joint, packed tight. Menu looked good - lots of poutine options and sandwiches with a side of poutine. My girl went for the smoked meat poutine, I got the chicken, apple, and brie sandwich. No poutine for me, figuring I could snag some of her fries. Portions were huge - my plate was loaded with fries, even though I asked for none. Poutine was just okay, not as great as I thought it'd be. My sandwich was killer, though - perfectly toasted baguette, brie and apples were a great combo. Service was meh - they blew off my no-cheese request and forgot about the no-fries thing. Prices were steep, too - 35 CA for two waters, smoked meat poutine, and a chicken sandwich. Not worth it. Verdict: if you're in the area and need a poutine fix, sure, stop by. But if you're looking for a life-changing poutine experience, keep walking."

"A woeful plight, my friends, doth lie within the land of electronics. Forsooth, service doth vary, and oft doth leave much to be desired. A sprinkling of kind salesfolk doth grace the halls, yet all too many doth prove inept or overly zealous in their endeavors. 'Tis wise, then, to enter with purpose and foreknowledge of thine desires, lest thou be led astray by confusion and frustration."

"Ay, how strange fate doth play its part!
I, returning home from Iron Maiden's art,
Did find, to mine own dismay,
My flight, oversold, did cause me fray.

In Phoenix, I had paid and checked with speed,
Yet, lo! My seat, they did not heed.
I raged, in ire, with words most bold,
This review, at first, a single star did hold.

But then, the staff, with grace so fine,
Did find me seat, most comfortable and divine.
And swiftly, too, did they provide escape,
Their courtesy, did my anger shape.

So now, three stars, this review doth bear,
For though the start, did cause despair,
The end, did bring me joy and cheer,
Thanks to the crew, so kind and dear."

"This playhouse doth present the latest and most popular pictures of the day. The cost of admission, alas, doth rival that of other establishments such as Regal and AMC. Verily, the state of the facilities doth leave much to be desired. The privies, in particular, doth reek of foul odors and doth suffer from great disarray. I suggest utilizing the facilities located at the rear of the theater, if thou must relieve thyself. The seats within the auditorium doth bear strange stains and a sticky texture, and many of the armrests doth appear to be crumbling. Hark! There is a silver lining to this cloud, for occasionally, this theater doth screen independent films. 'Tis a small consolation, but a welcome one, nonetheless."

"Hark! 'Tis Cracker Barrel, where I have not dined  
For years, nay, eight or more, I do confess.  
Last week, we didst order takeout, and thus,  
Didst receive a visit from the manager, no less.  
He fixed a problem with our order, and so,  
Didst earn four stars, by my reckoning, thou know'st.  
But alas, the chicken fried steak, a dish most vile,  
Didst merit but a single star, in truth, I smile."

"Family eats fish, I don't. Husband and daughter rave about fried catfish. I stick to steak, it's a disappointment. Menu's all fried, nothing healthy. Salad's drenched in cheese and bacon. If you care about your health, you'll feel guilty leaving."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, my aunt and I didst dine at yonder eatery, whereupon she didst revel in the fried soft shell crab, a dish most delectable, I must confess. Yet, in sooth, I must demur, for though 'twas not unpalatable, I have had far better at other Japanese taverns of like quality. Verily, we didst order two great vessels, overflowing with sundry sushi rolls, of spicy tuna, California, eel, soft shell crab, and skewers of chicken teriyaki, besides sashimi. Alack, the victuals were naught but middling, and I wouldst not choose to partake of them again."
"Vegetarians need not apply. Meat-eaters, rejoice. Good grub, stiff drinks, and swift service at the bar. Lawyers love it post-work."

"Tucked away in Planet Hollywood, a hidden gem. Decent grub, prices fair, Strip's heartbeat. 

Sandwich? Meh. Nothing special. Gets the job done. 

But 24/7, a lifesaver after Sin City's darkest hours."

"Thou hast three stars, good sir, for thy staff doth show great kindness indeed. And, verily, the chambers be of fair size. 

But, alas, thy experience doth falter, forsooth. For, lo, thy room didst not await thee until the appointed hour. Fie upon it! Thou hadst time to drop thy bags and venture forth. Aye, thou didst partake of dinner and merriment on the strip, and then, with haste, didst repair unto thy friend's suite. But, alack, thy chamber didst remain unavailable until the wee hours of morn, when, behold, thou didst find thy bedding foul and grimy. 

Yet, praise be to the staff, for they didst respond with haste and cheer, replacing all with fresh linens, pillows, and comforter, as if by magic. 

Now, prithee, good sir, ponder well this tale, and ask thyself, 'Shall I return anon?' Forsooth, only thou canst answer."

"Great joint, fun and hip. Balcony's a nice spot for the pirate show. Prices are steep, though. Shrimp stir-fry was too salty, had to send it back. Kobe sliders were also too salty, but the onion rings were good. Lychee beignets were like doughnuts, too sweet, but the yellowtail sashimi was decent. Edamame was warm and salty, sushi was good, and hubby liked the steak yakitori."

"Went for lunch on 10/26/11. Girl at the counter gave us the stink-eye for comin' in off-peak. Asked about coffee, she tells me there's two joints next door. Real friendly, that one. Almost made me wanna skip the sandwich and go next door for my caffeine fix. Bread was decent, though - warm and toasty. Caprese salad's usually chilly, but on a sandwich, it felt off. Like it was warm and crumbly on the outside, cold on the inside. Not bad, but not worth another visit anytime soon."

"I ordered from 'em often. Liked their pies, but the ravs were always overdone. Liked 'em al dente, ya know? Lasagna was just okay. Had to remind 'em not to burn the bread knots too many times. They were late with my grub thrice, even though I lived just five minutes away. Not exactly peak hours either. Don't reckon I'll be goin' back."

"Hark! What news is this? Mimi's, a place of renown,
Where cakes and scones, gluten-free, abound.
A fellow GF friend and I, didst make our way,
To The Shore, with hopes of a sweet, glorious day.

We had been told, that Mimi's, didst prepare,
Gluten-free treats, beyond compare.
But alas, our hopes were dashed,
For the cakes, were not worth the splash.

The scones, they crumbled, into tiny bits,
And we didst eat them, with jam and cream, in fits.
Our cupcake, a fairy cake, iced with care,
But naught compared to Cuckoo's, beyond compare.

Fellow Yelpers, speak highly of Mimi's,
But for us GF gals, 'twas a disappointment, grievous.
There are better cakes, in town, to be found,
Without the shlep, to The Shore, profound."

"In Arizona, where the sun doth shine bright,
There lies a place that doth serve a feast,
Of Ethiopian cuisine, full of delight,
Though not the most authentic, 'tis a treat.

Their sour injera, a spongy bread, doth please,
With alicha sega wat, a beef stew, if thou dost seize,
A taste so rich, it doth astound,
And in the combos, three stews are found.

A way to sample, and find thy desire,
And in this place, thy taste buds shall fire."

"Our server, a most excellent fellow, didst attend to our needs with great haste and diligence. Our glasses, never empty, didst remain full to the brim, and our orders, in a timely fashion, didst arrive. I, myself, didst partake in the chili cheese fries and twelve wings, honey BBQ style. Alas, the sauce, a tad too potent, didst overpower the taste, and the wings, they didst not remain warm for long, growing cold within five brief minutes. The fries, too, didst suffer the same fate. 

Now, being a man of experience, having once tended bar, I do confess, I am quite particular about the preparation of drinks. My Shirley Temple, alas, was made with the grenadine at the bottom, making it difficult to mix, and, mayhap, a bit too sweet. 

We sat without, in the open air, which was most pleasant, and the televisions, they were ideal for viewing the contest between Carolina and Duke. Methinks, the victual, mayhap, doth not hold the highest place in their regard, yet wouldst I return, anon, to partake in the sporting events."

"Alas, I didst wish to enjoy Tao, my first nightclub venture in fair Las Vegas. The ornamentation and motif didst please mine eyes, with Buddha's visage and maidens within bathtubs, and privies with doors that lock, making them opaque. Alas, the throng didst swell to such a degree that it didst become troublesome, and the assemblage of people was but mediocre. We shall not return, forsooth. Instead, we shall journey unto the clubs at Encore or the Wynn, where revelry doth reign supreme."

"Hark! In this place there be both good and bad, my friend.  

The happy hour, it doth please, with revelers gathered round.  Atmosphere, it doth rival the sun in splendor.  Staff, they doth attend with haste and cheer. 

But alas, the tables, they be packed tight, like a corset on a full-figured lass.  Parking, it doth leave much to be desired, thou must trek afar to find a space.  Fare, it doth pale in comparison to other establishments. 

Yet, if happy hour be thy quest, 'tis not so ill a choice.  But for a meal, seek elsewhere, lest thou be disappointed."

In fair Phoenix, where culture doth abound,
A humble pit stop, with treasures profound.
A gallery, with walls of brick and floor of stone,
Doth house a bookstore and bakery, all alone.
The art, though pricey, doth not disappoint,
A pleasant stop, for mind and taste, 'tis apt.

"Barbecue ain't all the same. Grew up on Chicago's south side, eatin' proper ribs, not that pulled pork nonsense. Rib tips, ya hear me? Saturated in sauce, meat falls off the bone. Smell the char a couple blocks away. That's barbecue, friend. Don't get me wrong, other styles are fine too. Had a pulled pork sandwich, decent. But when it's great, I don't share. Those ribs were just alright. Service was top-notch though. Hostess and waitstaff, real friendly, attentive. Shame more places ain't run like Bobby Q."

"Groupon, sometimes. Like this time, they weren't ready for the crowd. Service was slow, real slow. Stuff came wrong, but we were too hungry to give a damn. Our local sushi spot got overwhelmed, but we'll be back."

In sooth, upon an eve most fair,
With friends I didst venture to a tavern rare,
In Rutland, where prices be a bit steep,
Yet atmosphere and staff didst make us leap.

A classy place, indeed, with views most fine,
Of Princes Street, where folk do stroll and dine.
If thou dost seek a spot to chat and sip,
And bask in elegance, this tavern's a good tip.

"Rudy's, decent joint for BBQ. Pros: sauces galore, creamed corn's top-notch, spacious digs, convenient location. Cons: service can be unprofessional, no fries, general store's lackluster. Verdict: give it a shot, especially for that damn good creamed corn."

"Met at BW3 for a work meetin'. Host and waitress, real friendly. Good grub, decent service. Ordered the Bleu & Black burger, tasty. Fries, a bit soggy from that big ol' pickle, but I ain't complainin', 'cause I was starvin'. Not bad, not great. Wouldn't go outta my way, but I ain't opposed neither. Okay spot."
"Food was two-star quality, at best. But we were hungry, and it was late. So, I give it three stars. It was your typical breakfast diner grub. Didn't blow my mind, but it filled my belly."
"Skillet, more veggie than meat. Sausage, barely a bite. Pancake, fluffy and fine. Decent grub, but nothing to rave about."

"Methinks I've dined here fourfold, and by Jove, the victuals be divine! Of all the Italian fare I've sampled in this fair city, this kitchen doth reign supreme. Alack, the service, though, did leave somewhat to be desired. Pray, good sir, that thou mayst attend to thy patrons with greater frequency and a pleasant countenance, lest they depart in search of a merrier host."

"A fair tavern, fit for a pint ere a match,  
But beware, 'tis oft crowded, and space doth lack.  
No victuals served here, thou must seek sustenance  
In yonder hall, and bear it back with patience.  
The expansive courtyard, a wondrous sight,  
With ample room for revelry and delight."

"Hark! What do mine eyes perceive? A sight most fair and bright,
A sushi bar, with artistry in every detail, doth delight.
My purpose here, to rest and refresh, 'twixt duties great,
Fujo's hospitality, did timely and well-appointed greet.

In Carolina's clime, with fiery craving, I did choose,
The Cajun Roll, with crayfish, shrimp, and crab, in noble voice.
Though not a feast for gods, nor did it leave me cold,
Acceptance, I have learned, in sushi, doth my soul enfold.

But alas! The hot-and-sour soup, did not my taste buds cheer,
With ingredients, not fresh, and broth, but bordering on fear.
Yet still, this place doth hold a certain charm, and grace,
Though perhaps not Charlotte's finest, in culinary embrace."
"Food was passable. Don't expect much from India Palace or Taj Mahal. Private party with rowdy kids. Should've closed to public or asked for respect. Service was fine. Food, meh."

"Verily, the sign doth boast of wondrous fare,
But in truth, 'tis not as good as it declare.
An olden diner, with a feel of days past,
In Glendale, where time doth seem to last.
If thou hast leisure, give it a try,
For the price, 'tis not so bad, thou shalt see."

"Hark! What beer doth flow within these hallowed walls?
A church, yet now a tavern, doth enthrall.
The ale, it doth delight, with flavors so bright,
And yet, methinks 'tis strange to quaff here through the night.

Three or four brews we didst sample, all most fine,
One Belgian style, oh how it didst shine!
But alas, the service, it didst leave much to be sought,
For servers who doth pout, their tips are naught.

Church Brew Works, thy name doth say it all,
Yet, minus one star, for service doth fall.
Perhaps, we shouldst have sat at yonder bar,
To savor beer, in this most curious place, so rare."

"In days of yore, when dwelling near this place,  
'Twas oft our wont to seek its sheltered space,  
For afternoon respite, a merry chat,  
And drain a pint or two, to banish care and that.  
A humble tavern, naught of note within,  
Yet prices fair, a bargain, one might win.  
A glass of wine, a mere nine pence, 'twas said,  
But alas, those days, like youth, are now long dead.  
I, too, would partake of Kopperberg's fine brew,  
For three pounds, eighty-five, a price most true.  
Near Bus Station, it doth stand, a haven,  
For travelers, a pause, ere they take their leave again.  
So, if thou find thyself with time to kill,  
Step in, and let thy cares, in ale, be still'd."

"Last weekend, we chanced upon a novel sushi spot, near our abode, to dine and sample their wares. The rain did pour, and we did crave a feast most fine. Upon entering, we found the place to be quite snug, yet clean and well-appointed. We ordered four rolls of sushi, and Goyza and edamame to start, which did please our palates greatly. The diamondback roll, oh how grand, with its light and crispy tempura bits, a true delight! The fried cali roll, a close second, and the dragon roll, not bad at all. My dear wife, she did enjoy the spicy shrimp roll, but alas, 'twas not to mine own liking. \n\nIn sooth, we would return anon, during happy hour, to save a few coins, and in truth, the only drawbacks to the place, were the decor and space, a bit lacking, I do confess. But fear not, fair maiden or noble sir, for the sushi, verily, doth rock, and a quiet night for two, most pleasant and fine."

"Methinks my sister and I didst venture forth into Chinatown upon a Friday eve, with sushi being our heart's desire. Yet, with a wait of ninety minutes, I didst pose the query, hath thou, my dear sibling, partaken of Korean BBQ? She, with haste, didst reply, "Aye!" And thus, our destination was chosen.

Forsooth, I, a man of little faith in culinary novelties, didst seek guidance from my kin. Once gone, I didst embrace the experience, and, with zeal, didst introduce others to this wondrous feast.
