Upon entry, we didst behold rows of cozy booths, each adorned with a round grill, central to the table. 'Twas BBQ-ing within walls, a veritable carnivore's haven! Beef of diverse sorts, fresh shrimp, and pork, in abundance, didst grace the menu.

Few vegetable options there were, in the form of a salad bar, accompanied by prepared Asian dishes, sweet and sour pork, sushi, tempura vegetables, and varied other salads, akin to macaroni, yet, Asian, their names, I knew not.

Our glasses, ever full, didst remain, and the grill, when messy, didst they diligently cleanse.

In sooth, a unique experience, and one worth attempting, methinks!"

"Ended up here, did we?  Old folks, coupons, oxygen tanks - Sun City's finest.  Dinner at 3:00PM.  Bar's where we sit, appetizers and drinks we enjoy.  Mixed drinks, tasty apps, bartenders who appreciate the young crowd.  Seafood's better elsewhere, but in a pinch, Red Lobster'll do."

"Tis not my fondest haunt, forsooth,  
Where shabby chic and countrified newness doth abound.  
Antiques, a rarity, and prices do vary wildly,  
Leaving me to ponder, with a mind full of doubt.  
The staff, aloof they seem, or perchance I do sense  
A watchful eye upon mine own self and progeny.  
Yet, fortune may smile, and bargains may be found,  
For some new vendors have wrought a space profound.  
So, still I shall venture, with hope in my heart,  
To seek out treasures, and play my part."
"Papa Kelsey's Special Pizza for me, Calzones with extras for the missus. Two Italian salads with blue cheese and ranch. Root beer by the gallon. Food was decent. Support local joints, folks."

"Went to the real deal in DC Ranch. Stopped by with some pals for a late-night bite and drinks. First timer, so one of the fellas got us a couple Tootsie Rolls (three, counting me, since my guy don't like sushi) and a Berry White martini - it's blue, baby. Don't recall what was in those rolls, but they were good. Love sushi, so I wolf it down. This joint's got a smooth, slick vibe."

"Methinks I do adore this place, with its pool tables grand and screens so vast, 
The tunes they play, the ambiance fine, the servers swift and kind at last. 
Their grilled cheese, oh how supreme! A dish most wondrous, doth make my friend beam, 
A vegetarian patty, alas! Not to my liking, yet still, I find this joint quite keen."

"Hark, what bustling scene doth meet mine eyes!
A place of commerce, full of people's cries.
A deal most fair, on Big Mac's had they,
For those who seek quick sustenance, 'twas nigh.
Their children, too, didst crave such fare,
And thus, with haste, their hunger didst bear."

"O, how my heart did sink with woe and sorrow,
For this place, they did call it the best,
But alas, it did not meet my expectations,
The food, it was not up to my imaginations.

The layout, it was fair and beautiful to see,
And the people, they were kind and courteous,
But the food, it did not live up to the hype,
It left me feeling empty and quite vexed.

I would return, but not too soon,
For there are other places to try,
But if it were the only one open,
Then I would give it another chance, ere long.

I do not recall what dish I had,
That in itself, a bad sign it be,
But their bread, it was tasty and good,
A small consolation, but not enough for me."

"A jolly tavern, full of brew and cheer,
With victuals that did please mine eye and ear.
Our server, though a mite slow to begin,
Didst hasten forth with speedy grace therein.
I shall return, but mayhap not for meat,
For this place doth satisfy mine every need, save one,
That is, the craving for a frothy treat.
So here's to thee, good pub, may thy fame increase!"

"Buffet wasn't top-notch. Shrimp had a rubbery taste, Chinese dishes too salty, sushi lacked flavor. Crab legs were puny, not like the king crab in other pics. Desserts, prime rib, and open bar were the only redeeming qualities. Pricey at $30."

"Vegas, baby. Saw four shows: Mystere, Le Reve, O, and Criss Angel-Believe. Not all it's cracked up to be, despite some amazing moments. Way too pricey and plenty of dull stretches. Mystere ruled them all, no question. Most fun, even if not the flashiest."

"Hark, three weeks past, I chanced upon Shoku Ramn,
A place of sustenance, or so said the sign.
I ordered tonkotsu ramen, and potstickers beside,
The latter, crispy and burnt, just as I desired.
But alas, the ramen, oh how it did fail,
Oversalted broth, and noodles, overcooked and frail.
Mushy, they were, and lacking in taste,
Save for the salt, which did my senses assail.
I would not return, save for dire need,
Nor would I journey far, to dine at this steed."

"A pox upon this pharmacy of ill repute,
Whose service doth crawl at snail's pace, doth it not?
And lo, the checkers' queues, they doth stretch far and wide,
As if the patrons' time, it were of little worth.

In this, the city of excess, where doth shine
The glittering lights of vice and sin,
This pharmacy doth stand, a beacon of despair,
A place where patience doth go to die.

And yet, across the way, a Walgreens doth thrive,
A haven of efficiency, where doth time fly.
But nay, not here, where doth the staff, so slow,
Their ExtraCare discount card, didst none bestow."
"Pricey, but worth it. Food's good, especially the ahi tuna. Beautiful decor. Shame about the cocktails, though."

"A most delightful spa pedicure, verily,  
That doth make my day, nay, my week, so merry!  
Clean and friendly, they do be, in truth,  
But alack, their massage chairs, a sorry sight,  
Do crave renewal, else I fear, their plight.  
Yet will I return, again and again,  
For their gentle touch and skilled hands, anon."

"Methinks 'tis strange, the praise that ATS doth receive,
A niche vegan group, perchance, doth give it leave?
I find the place, in truth, to be but so-so,
Despite the name, best carne asada, given by the local press, doth flow.

The menu, limited, doth leave much to be desired,
The prices, high, doth make my purse to feel quite tired.
And though the food, in fairness, doth have its own style,
I find it, in the end, to be but mediocre, at best, awhile.

So when out-of-towners ask, where they might find
The best Mexican fare, I doth steer them away,
For other places, better, doth my mind incline."

"Hark! To meet a friend didst thou arrive,  
Early, to grab a drink and play,  
Draw Something on thy phone, didst thou decide,  
While waiting at a table by the bar, didst thou reside.  
Prompt service, thou art accustomed to,  
But waitedst long, for someone to say, 'Can I get thee?'  
Strange, it was, to wait so long, didst thou find,  
But after, service was good, didst thou bind.  
Happy hour wine, Cabernet, didst thou partake,  
And friend, blackened fish tacos, didst she make.  
Chicken and shrimp lettuce cups, didst thou consume,  
Greasy, they were, and caused lettuce to succumb.  
Food, thou dost enjoy, so not a big deal,  
Tasty, they were, but hard to eat, didst thou feel.  
Flat bread and sushi, thou wouldst order again,  
Aye, this place, thou wouldst visit once more, my friend."

"Fast food ain't my thing, but Five Guys is an exception. This joint's top-notch. Their fries are damn good, you get a ton of 'em, and they're nice 'n' greasy. Can't complain about that. Burgers are decent too, not the best, but hey, it's fast food, not some fancy joint. Appreciate it for what it is. They got some cool pop machines too, all sorts of flavors. Staff's friendly, that's always a plus."

"Noodles serves up good grub, no question. Portions are generous, selection's top-notch. But the service? Not so much. Last time I was in, the joint was dead, save for a few occupied tables. And let me tell you, those tables were a mess - dishes and food scattered all over, just begging to be bussed. Had to ask 'em to clear a table for us before we could even sit down. If they'd been slammed, maybe it'd be excusable. But they weren't. Just poor form, if you ask me."

"Hark, what rating doth this place deserve? Three stars, I say, for food most fair. BB wings, spicy and savory, doth please mine taste. Flavored soju, a delight, in variety we did partake. Alas, the service, poor and rude, doth leave much to be desired. Karaoke, once enjoyed, now marred by owner's impudence. He, with group in tow, doth enter room, mid-song, and asks if tour be permissible. Discourtesy, most foul, doth prompt my nevermore return, alack!"

"Can't complain too much 'bout this joint, got comped for being a Platinum Player. It's an older hotel, not as swanky, but it did the trick for a quick nap. Housekeeping was a bit creepy, though. Chick didn't even knock, just tried to barge in while we were trying to sleep off a hangover. I was like, "No, no, please leave." She was a total creeper, man. 

If you're on the strip side with a view, watch out. They got this crappy band playing from 11 am to 2 am. It's horrible. Last day, I wanted to sleep, but I couldn't. Almost went to the grocery store to buy eggs to toss at 'em. Not exactly classy, but damn, they were annoying. 

Overall, not a terrible experience. Just be aware of their chapel hours. My buddy tried to marry some random chick, but the chapel on the third floor was already closed. Not sure who got lucky on that one. Anyway, enjoy your stay, folks."

"Walked into this joint, looked at the menu, picked my bag, chose my toppings, handed it to the cashier. Simple. Had the turkey with slaw and dressing. It was alright. Bread wasn't great, felt stale. Turkey was too salty. Don't know if I'd go back on my own, but I'd try another sandwich if someone took me there."

"O, fatty food most tasty! Wisheth me that salad hadst not such a large tortilla, that doth make it so filling. 

Alas, the drink station doth never seem well-stocked at noon. 

Verily, the staff doth do a good job in moving folk through line with haste, yet still I find myself in quite a plight, awaiting some twenty minutes ere I may order this delectable fare."

"Hark! What news is this? A new bakery doth rise,
In Mile End, where bread doth meet the skies.
Hof Kelsten, named, doth quickly gain renown,
As city-wide, its fame doth loudly crown.

The baker, Jeffrey, doth supply the best,
To Montreal's eateries, he doth pass the test.
With Central European flair, he doth imbue,
Rye, rugelach, babka, all doth prove true.

French loaves, too, doth Hof Kelsten make,
My favorite baguette, forsooth, doth take.
Meals, they serve, at lunch, at brunch,
But pastries, different, doth my heart bunch.

Yet, alack! Undercooked, some doth find,
So now, I stick to bread, in mind.
For Hof Kelsten, doth rise to fame,
A city-wide contender, in the game."

"Alas, my dear friend, I must confess,
This burger joint didst not impress.
The bacon, oh how sweet it was,
But alas, the rest, a letdown it was.

A Monday, it was, when first I tried,
But lo, they were closed, my heart did die.
I waited patiently, until the morrow,
To taste their wares, and see what they could borrow.

A regular burger, I didst order,
With bacon, eggs, and all the fixin's, in disorder.
The presentation, fair and bright,
But alas, the flavor, lacking in might.

The seating, comfortable, I must say,
The decor, quite pleasant, in a modern way.
The service, good, with nary a frown,
But alas, the food, a letdown, a disappointment profound.

I would return, for an out-of-towner's delight,
But for myself, I fear, not in sight.
The fries, two versions, we didst try,
Truffle, and cilantro, a sorry pie.

Creative, they didst strive, I must confess,
But for my taste, a failure, alas, a mess."

"For this fair price, thou dost receive thy due.
The hour of departure, eleven it was,
And I, with plea for lateness, didst call anon,
To beg a reprieve, until the sun didst pass.
Tired and weary, our bodies didst crave rest,
And thus, a small indulgence, I didst request.
But lo, the answer came, a stern refusal,
A denial of my humble supplication.
In Vegas, city of excess and delight,
Such petty service doth leave a sour taste.
The chamber, modern and well-appointed,
Yet, alack, the hospitality didst lack.
A pox upon their house, for this slight wrong,
I shall remember, and sing a sorrowful song."

In this humble tavern, plain and true,
Drinks flow, pool tables beckon, friends anew.
A place to gather, laugh, and merry make,
With naught but chicken wings and bull to take.

The music thumps, a lively club mix,
That draws a throng of diverse tricks.
Chubby gays, twinks, bears, old-timers too,
Fag hags, all welcome, as they do.

Inclusive, indeed, this watering hole,
Pre-club, a stop, or soul to console.
Specials daily, drinks that wet the whistle,
But smoke, oh smoke, that doth persist and clingle.

Vintage Vegas charm, some may perceive,
Yet options scarce, for gays to retrieve.
So, let us cherish, this modest dive,
Where all are welcome, no need to jive.

"Hark! A tale of Planet Hollywood, I shall recount,
Where meats and seafood, in abundance, they do mount.
A Groupon, it was, that did entice us to dine,
For $79, all-you-can-eat, a feast most divine.

Sirloin, lamb, and shrimp, oh my!
In a separate plate, the surf, did they bring nigh.
Mussels, salmon, and tilapia, a delicious sight,
But alas, some meats, were dry, not quite right.

The salad bar, a decent spread,
Vegetables, hot dishes, all well-prepared, 'twas said.
And drinks, they did include, in this deal,
A chinahuia, with pineapple, lime, and tequila, did steal.

The hunny, a rum runner, did pour,
Much heavier, than mine, it did devour.
Overall, an okay restaurant, I must confess,
But Texas de Brasil, better meat, does possess.

Marcile, our server, did run,
With a split section, his work, was done.
Bad reviews, I had seen, before this night,
But not as bad, as anticipated, the sight."

"The joint stank of puke, like some wild night had spilled over into the morning. But we sat down anyway, 'cause we were hungry. The waiter was a character, dressed like he'd just stepped out of a bad '80s music video. We ordered the pretzel fondue, which was good, but too salty. I had the French Dip, which was a letdown. The roast beef was drowned in some weird mayo-based sauce, and the au jus was way too strong. It was like they were trying too hard to be different, you know? Like they wanted to be the cool spot in town, but ended up falling short. The food was decent, but the atmosphere was lacking. So, I gave 'em a 3 outta 5."

"Hark! A dilemma doth beset mine mind,
Whether to like this place, or leave it behind.
Their happy hour and brunch specials, oh so fine,
But the food, alas, doth puzzle me, in truth.

I've visited thrice, and tried their fare,
But cannot say, with certainty, if 'tis fair.
The initial bites, oh how they doth delight,
But soon, the flavors doth become too bright.

The service, too, doth leave much to be desired,
For though not woeful, 'twas not inspired.
A waiter, once, forgot my iced tea,
And left me parched, to pine for thee.

Yet, there was a time, when happy hour did grace,
Our presence, and a mistake did occur,
They charged my friend but three pence,
For two drinks, a veritable bonanza!

In conclusion, 'tis a place, just passable,
Not one I'd choose, but neither would I flee.
If thou wouldst go, I wouldst not object,
But for myself, I'd seek a different venue."

"Hark! What praise doth In-N-Out Burger receive?
From East Coasters, no less! We had to partake,
On our Vegas trip, to see what all the fuss did make.
And, verily, 'tis a good burger, I do confess.
The fries, as well, did please our tastebuds' delight.
But, lo! The crowd, they did go wild, as if possessed.
An average fast food chain, it seemed to us,
Quick, dirty, and with ketchup, quite a fuss.

A word to the wise, thou drive-thru window lad,
When one declines ketchup, do not gape, aghast.
For, in their stead, a simple 'no, thank thee' would suffice.
Lest thou be deemed a stranger, from a distant land, astray.

So, if thou hast not tried, do give it a whirl,
But, for a hamburger, dost not travel afar.
For, in truth, a burger is a burger, still."

"Upon mine eyes, a place most fair didst Yelp present,
Which I didst visit for my evening's repast.
Chow mein and Thai tea, my order didst comprise,
The latter, a brew most excellent, didst surprise.
Indeed, the best Thai tea that e'er I didst taste,
But, alas! the former dish, didst not so well find grace.
A variant of the noodles, thin and flat, it was,
Not like the full-bodied lo mein, that doth please.
The victuals, save the saltiness, didst delight,
And though the service was not poor, 'twas not quite right.
I shall return, to sample Pad Thai, anon,
And Thai tea, in quantity, shall be mine own."

"First-time Thai? This joint's a good spot to test the waters. They push the buffet hard, like it's a matter of life and death. My waitress was hell-bent on us trying it, and I get why. Bill came, and it added up to 21 quid a head. Buffet was decent, but I didn't eat my money's worth."

"Egg Works. Not great, not terrible. Just your average joe grub at standard prices. Food's not bad, but it ain't the best. But hey, they ain't tryin' to be somethin' they're not. They know their place, and they price accordingly. I'll prob'ly eat here again 'cause eggs are better for me than donuts, but the food's just alright. Three stars, Yelp says. That's what I gotta go with."

Dearest Breadfruit, thou art a place most fair and bright,
With dishes that doth please mine eyes and taste most wondrous.
But alas, thy prices do exceed the means of mortal men,
And thus, I must confess, thy worth doth lie in other things.

A slice of sweet potato pie, oh how it doth delight,
And coffee, if thou insisteth, shall be mine only drink.
For though thy cost doth mount, thy charm doth never fade,
And thus, my heart doth sing with joy, and mine affections stay'd.

Farewell, dear Breadfruit, may our love forever last,
And may thy culinary delights forever be mine own vast.

Yours truly,
Rachel
"Not the greatest, not the worst. No flashy ads, but decent grub. Prime rib used to be top-notch, but they scrapped it. Haven't been back since. Price wasn't worth the flavor. On par with Denny's."
"Food was decent, not great. Selection was solid though."

"Methinks 'tis fair to note, ere I begin,
That this review doth stem from but a single dish.
Our server, kind and courteous, did attend
To our needs with grace, and thus I shall commend.

Now, to the chicken Madeira, my heart's desire,
Which, alas, did fail to stir my soul's fire.
The build-up, great, with atmosphere quite dark,
And modern, too, the restaurant's noble mark.

Yet, when served, my disappointment grew,
For sauce, so bland, and lacking seasoning, too.
No flavors danced upon my palate's delight,
Nay, not even a hint of sweetness took flight.

The chicken pieces, three in total, small,
Did cause me near to laugh, yet kept my mirth within.
French fries, homemade, the only saving grace,
For which, alas, I cannot claim a special place.

In conclusion, dear reader, heed my words,
Avoid this dish, for seventeen dollars, unheard!
For though the atmosphere did please mine eyes,
This dish, alone, doth not justify the prize."

We rolled into the Wynn late, exhausted from the road. Needed something quick to eat, so we hit up The Cafe. They had some solid options - sandwiches, salads, desserts. Ordered the Chicken Portabella. Was a bit disappointed it wasn't freshly made, just reheated and served. For $11, I expected better. But slathered some garlic aioli on it, took a bite, and it was damn tasty. Pair it with a $4 Coke (steep, but what can you do?) and I was set for the night. The Cafe gets packed in the mornings, so rise and shine if you need that caffeine fix. Or just stroll over to Starbucks across the street at Fashion Show Mall. Your call.

"First heard of Krispy Kreme in Canada, around a decade back. People raved about 'em, but I was skeptical. Thought it was just a buncha hype. Then, a buddy brought some to work, fresh from Edinburgh. Had ta admit, they were pretty damn good. Team loved 'em. But I still don't get why folks go nuts over 'em. Just don't see the big deal. Sugar and grease, that's all they are. And we're talkin' the early 90s here, not exactly somethin' new. So, three stars for taste, but that's it."
"Cheap eatery. Fill up or get sloshed on their offerings. Free donuts and coffee for early risers. Old joint, but give it a shot."

"Fair victuals, but slow as the night's darkest hour!
Our reservation, twenty minutes didst pass,
And in the waiting area, we didst find no space,
But stood in pathways, where folk didst come and go.

Our waitress, friendly, and with menu didst explain,
But she, the hostess too, didst bear the weight,
Of duties many, and with slowness didst detain,
Our meal, two hours didst consume, alack!

Mussels, we didst order, first, small and sweet,
In white wine sauce, they didst our taste greet.
Bread, we didst request, but fries didst come instead,
Soggy, they were, our server's words didst belie.

Bouillabaisse, my entrée, hot and steaming,
With seafood plentiful, and saffron sauce gleaming.
A feast, it was, and worth the wait, methought,
But oh, how slow, the service, to behold!

My spouse, his chicken, brie-stuffed didst taste,
And found it fair, but not worth the cost, he didst say.

The food, impressive, but the delay, a bane,
If back I come, 'twill be on a weekday, and alone.
More staff, they need, to speed the meal,
For delicate fare, doth merit greater zeal."

"Wonton soup's my go-to here. No noodles, just the goods. Broth's got a nice sweetness to it, dumplings are on point. Haven't tried anything else, but I keep comin' back for more. Upstairs, Crown Bakery's worth a visit too."
"Dined well, but grub was just fair. Killer cocktails from three to six, though. Should've gone earlier."

"A first-time visitor, I, to this place of revelry,
Sat in the bar, where happy hour did cease to be.
Complimentary hors d'oeuvres, they did proffer,
But I, a humble guest, didst decline the offer.

Cocktails we did imbibe, and ordered fish,
Salmon and yellowtail, fresh and deftly fixed.
The salmon, verily, didst impress my taste,
But yellowtail, alas, was cut too waste.

A gripe, I must confess, didst trouble me,
A scent, most foul and strong, didst assail mine ears.
Disinfectant and cologne, a pungent blend,
Didst make my stomach churn, and near to offend."

"Golden Phoenix, a joint for a decent, cheap lunch. Not too busy during the week, especially if you roll in around 11 am. The staff ain't the friendliest, but they don't bother you none. Food's alright, not too shabby, but nothin' special either. Spicy? Nah, more like a gentle tickle on the tongue. Still, for sixteen bucks, including drinks, it's a damn good deal. And it's close to my work, so I'll be back."

"Been here a few times, not lived in Champaign though. Place is on a main drag, close to campus. Donuts are decent. Service is quick. But they don't always have all the donuts in stock. Was just there, no classic glazed yeast donuts, only glazed cake and minis. Appreciate the early morning Black Friday snack spot."

"Went to this joint for the first time. Wings were decent, service was alright. Catfish? Not so much. But hey, it's a wing place, right? Had the ATL seasoned wings, pretty good, a bit too salty though. Cashier seemed a bit sour, but she kept track of all the orders. Would go back for the wings and fries."

"Tired of the bright lights and loud sounds of the city? Come on down to Treasure Island Hotel and experience a little bit of country charm. Our venue is open late, so even if you've been kicked out of everywhere else, you're always welcome here. We play classic country tunes, perfect for two-stepping and line dancing. And if you're feeling brave, take a spin on our mechanical bull. Just be sure to keep an eye out for our resident hot blonde cowgirl – she'll show you how it's done. Our dance floor is spacious, and the atmosphere is always lively.

Hungry? Sorry, our kitchen had closed by the time you arrived. But don't worry, our friendly bartenders will keep your glass full and your spirits high. Our clientele tends to be a bit older, but that doesn't mean they can't still kick up their heels and have a good time. So saddle up and join us for a night of country fun."

"Hark! A meal most wondrous didst I find,
At this, my latest dining place.
'Twas tasty, and a good value, I didst find,
For seven silver coins, a fair price.

I chose a sandwich of albacore,
A dish of tuna, rich and fine.
And with it, a salad of pecan,
With chicken, veg, and dressing divine.

But lo! My friend, she didst choose,
An omelet of egg whites, pure and true.
And with it, a meal most fitting,
Didst make, to suit her diet, strict and new."

"Took the kids out for ice cream. They picked some joint we hadn't hit before. Decent stuff, but the gals behind the counter could've used a lesson in manners. Chatting up their boyfriend while we tried to order, giggling like a couple of schoolgirls. Kids and I dug the froyo, though. Might go back."

"Decent spot, but not my top pick for Mexican. Service was attentive, but a tad scattered. Asked three different servers for water, got one glass. They were quick with chip and salsa refills, though, and checked in often. Food was alright, a bit too spicy for my taste. But hey, it's Mexican and I'm a wimp. Nobody else seemed to mind. Margaritas were strong, a pitcher was plenty for four of us."
"Clean joint, friendly staff. Good for a quick Asian fix. Not bad, not great either. Fast, cheap, and decent grub."

"Hark! No need for tools or special skill,
Our meal came together without a hitch.
But alas, the value we did not find,
At this fancy cafe, so high and fine.

'Tis not the food stand down below,
But upstairs, where the selection doth grow.
Wraps, salads, soups, and hot trays galore,
Sweetish classics, and more, they do store.

My wife, a veggie wrap did choose,
But found it lacking, in taste and pose.
$4, a fair price, but not divine,
A mediocre meal, at best, we did find.

The smoked fish plate, a better fate,
Creamy horseradish sauce, a delightful treat.
Mixed greens and beans, a pleasant surprise,
Well smoked fish, a feast for our eyes.

But lo, the vegan sweet potato soup,
A kind gesture, for those who dooup.
Flash your IKEA family card, and claim,
A free meal, in this self-service game.

$14, a fair price, for two, we did pay,
In this kid-friendly place, where we did play.
So if thou seek'st mild food, and a view,
Of furniture, then this may be thy cue."

"The joint's alright, ain't perfect though. Service was good, but they didn't seem to get that we wanted grub after studying the menu while our tea was being made. Decor's nice, got some comfy chairs to relax in. Big windows let in plenty of light, nice view of Frederick Street. Food and drinks? Nothing too exciting, but they do it well. Haven't checked the cans or the nosh yet, so I'll give 'em three stars for now. But I reckon they'll easily hit four stars next time I stop by."

"Hark! Today, I ventured forth to this place,
With clients in tow, and their choice it was.
I pondered other venues, more grand,
But alas, 'twas not to be, for they had planned.

Cafe Grande, a bit old-fashioned, true,
Their menu, burgers, paninis, anew.
But lo! My lunch, a fishcake, small yet tasty,
With chips and salad, a pleasant surprise, quite hasty.

The cheese plate, a delight, Scottish cheeses galore,
A banoffee pie, rave reviews, forevermore.
Other dishes, not so grand, a bit dull,
Soup, sandwich, home-cooked, a bit uncouth, pull.

Bean burger, lonely, on a plain bun,
Arrived, forlorn, without any fun.
So, a passable meal, if near,
But not worth seeking, fear not, dear."
"Nello's, gluten-free haven. Ham-pineapple pizza, damn good. Limited GF options, but they do the trick. Friendly service. Not bad, not great. Cheers."

"Eyebrow threading went from eight bucks to ten. Still, she does a swell job, doesn't overdo it, and keeps your brows looking natural. Facials? Good, but watch out for those coupons. They'll give you a raw deal. My ma got a coupon for half off, but they cut the time in half too. Not worth it."

"I glance right, see 'Better than Roscoe's.' No way. But good, no doubt. Problem's the chicken. Roscoe's chicken? Addictive. Like crack. Once you have it, you're done. Can't stop. Back to Lolo's. Nice joint. Better than Roscoe's, place-wise. Colorful, big Kool-Aid jars. Chicken and waffles? Good, if you haven't had Roscoe's. Breading's dry, different. Waffles and syrup? Great. Need to step up the chicken game. I'll be back, though. Definitely better than fast food chicken, but not Roscoe's."

"Just another joint. Good service, cold beer. But no IPA, that's a sin. Food? Meh. Wings were alright, sandwich was stale, fries were soggy. Decor was nice, TVs galore. Maybe try the pizza next time, that's what they do best."

Alas, my dear friend, I didst fall prey  
To the snare of chips and salsa's allure,  
A plight most vexing, I must confess,  
For my belly, now full, doth protest.  
But, save this mishap, the fare was fair,  
As one would expect from a Mexican lair,  
With portions grand and ingredients fresh,  
Though naught extraordinary, the price was neat.  
And so, anon, I shall return, God willing,  
When hunger pangs for Mexican dishes still.

"My mother and I didst venture forth to this establishment, forsooth, upon her sweet tooth's insatiable craving. She didst inquire of the maiden behind the counter, if the coffee-flavored gelato didst contain caffeine. The maiden, with a shrug, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

And thus, we didst laugh at the absurdity of it all, yet, my mother, still curious, didst ask the maiden if there were any dairy-free options available. The maiden, once again, didst reply, 'I know not, for I do not make it.'

In utter disbelief, we didst proceed to order our gelato, and my mother, determined to extract some semblance of usefulness from the girl, didst ask her to recommend a flavor to accompany chocolate. The maiden, with a sheepish grin, didst respond, 'I know not, for I do not eat it.'

Verily, I couldst scarce believe mine ears! Forsooth, the girl mayhap was in high school, and 'twas true, she didst not make nor eat the gelato, but, by the stars, customer service, thou art a dying breed! 

But, lo and behold, the gelato, it didst taste wondrous, and the prices, quite reasonable. Banana Yum, indeed!"
"Food was fair, prices too high. Friend and I played video poker all night, but they only comped us one drink. Disappointed, thought it'd be a decent dive with some gambling fun."

"Hark, what praise doth fill the air?
A buffet, they say, beyond compare!
But lo, my friends, let us not be fooled,
For here, the truth, I shall unfold.

A fourth of all they offer, bread,
A waste, a folly, a misdeed!
And for this, they demand a fee,
Forty dollars, a price too steep!

The California roll, a gem, I confess,
With real crab meat, a rarity, no less.
But all else, a disappointment, a shame,
No special treats, no unique name.

Prime rib, cold shrimp, and crab, they say,
Are reasons why this buffet's the way.
But nay, my friends, those items find,
At every buffet, of a lower kind.

So heed my words, and do not pay,
The price they ask, for it's not worth the fray.
Rio Carnival, Rio Seafood, Wynn,
Buffets superior, for less you'll win."

"People actually eat here? I've been to this joint a few times, and let me tell you, it's not exactly a place for a fine dining experience. I mean, the happy hour menu's got some decent apps, like california rolls and gyoza, but the real draw is the cheap drinks. And let me tell you, they're good. Like, really good. But hey, don't take my word for it. I've had my fair share of memorable nights here, even if they're a little fuzzy towards the end. So, if you're looking for a place to grab a drink and maybe some mediocre grub, this might be your spot."

"Hark! My dearest spouse and I didst venture hither with friends, our bellies growling with hunger. And lo! The menu didst boast a bounty of delectable dishes, making 'twain difficult to choose betwixt them. Fear not, fair reader, for all didst prove most satisfying, a veritable feast for the taste buds, worth five stars, by my troth! \n\nBut alas! The service, a pox upon 't, didst leave much to be desired. A surly waiter, with scant courtesy, didst respond to mine inquiry regarding virgin margaritas with a snappish tone, as if he hadst already uttered the list to another at the table. Pray, good sir, had I but known, I wouldst not have troubled thee. Hubby and I, alone, might have sought sustenance elsewhere, such was the poor quality of service. Alack! A shame indeed for this establishment, methinks."

"Decent spread, not amazing. Shrimp and sweets stole the show. Prime rib? Meh. Watermelon infused with tequila made up for it, though. Rice Krispy treats and candy apples too. Could've used more salad options, but breakfast selection was solid, even at 2 pm. Might return, but Aria and Paris trump Wynn's offerings."

"Hark! Excalibur, a hotel most fair,
In location, prime, and rooms, so rare.
We checked in on a Saturday, with haste,
And found our chamber, freshly renovated, in taste.
The door, alas, would not shut tight,
A curious thing, and quite a sight.
We called, and they did come with speed,
To move us next door, with little need.
The new room, nice, with flat screen, so bright,
And beds, so comfy, a wondrous sight.
But lo! The next day, the door, again,
Would not shut close, and caused much pain.
We called, and they did fix, with grace,
And extended checkout, a gentle embrace.
So stay, dear traveler, at Excalibur,
If budget-friendly, and central, be thy cure."

"Fare was passable, naught that did astound. Rice, a soggy mess, upon the sushi found. Service, middling, withal. We felt pressed, ill-timed the victuals came, and staff, in knowledge of the menu, lacking, alack."

"Abuelos, a chain of Mexican eateries, doth please my taste buds well. Their service, too, is friendly and their fare, passable. In days of yore, a lengthy queue did form outside, a wait of an hour, perchance, did ensue. Yet, on my most recent visit, entry was swift, our party of six, straightway admitted. For guests from afar, I shall return, but, whenever possible, local haunts, I do prefer."

"Hark! Good for a hangover, they say,  
This place doth cure the night's excess,  
But loud it be, in truth, I pray,  
That thou mayst find some peace, and rest.  

The fries, alas, are thin and weak,  
A disappointment, I do confess,  
Yet still, the food doth please, meek,  
In its simplicity, 'tis blessed.  

The drinks, they be strong and bold,  
A plus, indeed, for those who crave,  
A respite from the night's cold,  
And a cure for the morning's wave."

"I stopped by for a trim 'cause I was in the neighborhood and needed a tidy up. Got the usual scissor cut, nothing fancy. Walked right in, no wait. Stylist did a good job, seemed to care about her work. Haircut was better than average, but pricey, 25% more than other joints around here. Still, not a bad deal for a decent haircut."

"Food's good. Bruschetta's top-notch. Service? Shit. Went on a Friday, place was dead, three bartenders yappin' away. Couldn't get a damn thing. Had to grab our own silverware and plates. Took forever to get a drink. But the grub's what keeps us comin' back. Happy hour's decent too, five bucks for a glass of wine. Might give the other spot a shot next time, see if they can do better."

"Hark, my thoughts on this establishment align with the masses. Good tidings, there be:

Food, when it doth arrive, doth please the palate. Lobster and corn, oh how grand! A gin drink, fit for royalty, doth impress. The menu, diverse and full of wondrous choices, doth entice. Drinks, aplenty and creative, doth delight. Weekly specials, a treasure trove of savings, doth abound.

Alas, poor service doth mar the experience. Many a black-shirted server doth stand idly by, while two hostesses doth attend to their duties. A bartender, hardworking and diligent, doth pour forth libations with haste. Alack, management doth need to address this disparity, lest it doth become a grievance most foul.

In conclusion, tasty victuals, potent potables, and questionable service doth sum up this place. Mayhap, a visit shall reveal the truth of these words."

Daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: $3 off specialty margaritas from 7pm-close.
Guys Night Out Tuesday: 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7pm-close.
Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: random beer in a bag for $1 from 7pm-close.
Ladies Night Thursday: $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7pm-close.
Fireball Friday: $2 shots of Fireball from 7pm-close.
$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Get a mimosa carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.
$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Get a bloody mary carafe for $10 from 11am-3pm.

"A haven of delight, this eatery doth serve  
The finest of Italy's culinary fare.  
Its ambiance, warm and inviting, doth imbue  
A sense of comfort, fitting for a king.  
The portions, generous and bountiful, doth fill  
The belly with joy, and prices, fair and square,  
Doth make it a steal, a true rarity.  
In this place, thou shalt find solace and cheer,  
A haven of delight, indeed, my dear."
"Good people, old rooms, but damn good deal. Adjoining rooms a blessing with rugrats."

"A friendly staff doth serve this place,
Where young folk gather, full of grace.
All seem to seek love's sweet embrace,
But alas, the underground space doth lack,
In ambiance, it doth not abound,
No dance floor there, nor lights around.
No mirror ball, no laser beams,
To stir the soul and lift the dreams.
If thou wouldst have folks dance and play,
Spend a few coins and make the day.
Create some ambiance, that doth please,
And all shall revel in joy and ease."

"Hark! Champaign, a city of gastronomic delight, yet lacking in fare from the East, wherefore I do praise Holy Land Grill for its presence. 'Tis not the most exquisite of Middle Eastern cuisine I've had the pleasure to taste, but 'twill suffice. Yesterday, I did partake of their falafel and Greek salad, both of which did please mine palate. The service, too, was most courteous and friendly, a welcome change from previous visits. They did present us with bottles of water, gratis, which did seem somewhat wasteful, alack! Yet, I did find their serving of Mexican Coca-Cola to be a curious, but pleasant, variation. The dessert, baklava, was quite good, but the simple syrup that topped it did naught but detract from its flavor. A drizzle of honey, perchance, would have been a wiser choice. In conclusion, I must confess that, though I oft complain of the cacophony of music in eateries, the silence at Holy Land did strike me as somewhat peculiar. A soft, Middle Eastern melody, methinks, would have been a fitting addition. Despite this, I did enjoy my repast and shall return anon."

"Carson Street Cafe, near the elevators, offered a buy-one-get-one deal for Golden Nugget guests. Not bad. Decent grub, too. Stick to the basics - my BLT was alright, and the chicken in the Caesar salad was good. Service was slow, though."

"A haven of refreshment, where one may quench their thirst and sate their hunger. 'Tis a place of solace, where one may find respite from the heat and the bustle of the city. Yet, beware, good sir or madam, for the service there is not of the most hospitable sort. 'Twere best to pay with cash, lest thou desirest to avoid the awkwardness of a prolonged encounter with the keepers of the establishment. So, if thou art in search of a cool draught and a quick bite, this place may serve thee well, but tarry not, lest thou be vexed by the gruff demeanor of the staff."

"Twice a week, for two months straight, we hit up Big View. Service and grub were top-notch, till the holidays rolled around. Then, they served us stale, old cookies from their bakery. Haven't been back since. \n\nUsed to be, we'd go there once a week. Tried a lot on the menu, and it was all good. Breakfast plates, french toast, pancakes. Shrimp & grits, chicken souvlaki, spinach pastry, greek salad, crab cake. Bakery was great too. Service was friendly, except when we sat at the bar and watched the kitchen get wild. Still, it was a solid spot. Recommend it, but avoid the bar."

"Across from campus theater, we did stray,
Convenient spot, indeed, 'twas our aim.
In we walked, and swiftly seated were we,
Drink orders taken, with haste, did they bring.

But then, a delay, there came to pass,
After drink orders, some fifteen minutes' wait,
Our orders taken, by hostess fair,
Due to waitress's o'erwhelmed plight, we did surmise.

Food came, some fifteen minutes later,
We ate with haste, lest we be late,
Turkey dinner, with small pieces, did come,
Not long cut strips, as menu did proclaim.

Pancakes, with white chocolate raspberry,
His choice, a good pick, did prove to be,
Egg Nog pancakes, a good option, did seem,
But alas, not chosen, by me.

Ticket paid, I did, with speedy hand,
So we could leave, and not be late, in this land.

Overall, a B-, service was good,
Food, just okay, an A-OK visit, as understood."

Last eve, I chanced upon the W, where revelry did reign,
A bachelorette party, full of mirth and glee, did hold its sway.
But, alack, the drinks they served, did cost a pretty penny,
Sixteen dollars, by my count, a sum most reckless and quite funny.

I prayed for water, pure and simple, to quench my thirst,
For such extravagance, my purse could not endure, nor would it burst.
The folk who gathered there, did provide a merry show,
A maiden, scantily clad, did dance, and caused my sides to flow.

The waitresses, fair and bright, did tend to us with grace,
And split the bill, with smiles so wide, into more manageable space.
Indeed, the W, a place of wonder, where wealthy ones do throng,
Yet, not my cup of tea, for I do find it rather wrong.

"A pox upon this tavern, and its rude servitors too!
Two stars I subtract, for poor service I didst receive.
On a Tuesday eve, my friend and I didst sit at the bar,
But the bartenders, they didst pay us no mind, nor care.
Their friends were there, and they didst attend to them alone,
Leaving us to wait, for a menu, forsooth, for long.
And when I asked for ale, the bartender didst throw
The list at me, with scorn and disdain, I do avow.
She came not back, for full fifteen minutes more,
A plague upon her, and her surly demeanor!
Take Midol, woman, and improve thy mood,
For ill-tempered service, doth make a tavern, no good."
"Yard House, good spot for a quick drink. Beer selection top-notch, plenty to choose from. Food specials during happy hour, solid. Entrees just okay, though. Neighborhood's got better options."

Alas, my friends, we found ourselves in woe  
When Big Dogs on Sierra did close its door  
For there we'd go, at least twice, 'twas our rite  
To partake of brew and nachos, oh so bright

But now, alack, we must seek elsewhere  
And so we went to Draft House, with hearts full of cheer  
But lo, the nachos, they did not compare  
To those we loved, oh how our spirits did sink

The ale, it was good, a solace to our woe  
But still, we mourned our favorite nachos, oh so  
For they were gone, and with them, our delight  
In Sierra's Big Dogs, where we'd revel through the night.

"Fare good, but dearly priced, I say,
The wait, long during peak hours, doth come what may.
In Vegas, 'tis the norm, I do suppose,
But, alack, the cost, doth make me choose.

If half the price, the buffet were,
Then four stars, I would confer.
But, alas, the food, doth not make worth,
The price, that doth thy purse unworth.

In brief, thy coin, elsewhere, best spend,
For equal fare, at lower rate, thou shalt find.
And, perchance, fortune shall thy way attend,
At slots, where jackpots may be thine to amend."

"A stone's throw from my humble abode,
This pizzeria doth hold a special place,
Where I do oft repair, to partake
Of their most excellent pies, both veggie and supreme,
With a pitcher of frothy ale, and wings,
To watch the games, on their many screens.

Alas, of late, the prices have risen,
And the fare, once of highest quality,
Hath suffered somewhat, in truth.
But still, the atmosphere doth please,
The service, friendly, and the take-out,
Doth make it worth a visit, I do swear.

For pizza, they do boast a grand array,
A veritable cornucopia, indeed.
And though the other dishes may lack,
In flavor, and in freshness, too,
The pies, they do remain, the main attraction,
A culinary delight, beyond all doubt."
"Grand Lux, love it. Corned beef hash, top-notch. Hair in the fries, a minor hiccup. Waiter and manager, proper apologies. Desserts, fantastic."

"Hark! Good sir, 'tis true, the service at Tea Lite doth shine,
With speedy food and friendly folk, a most divine combine.
Their prices, too, do please, a meal most fair and bright,
Yet, there's a catch, my friends, a lack doth plague their sight.

Alack! Their pho, though tasty, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
No tripe nor tendon doth it boast, a fact most vexing, I do avow.
And though they have a plethora of options to add zest,
No choice doth exist to make the broth more bold, a true quest.

Perhaps, dear friends, 'tis due to their focus on quick repasts,
A streamlined menu, thus, their specialty doth hold fast.
But fear not, for I do urge thee still to visit this place,
And, who knows? Mayhap thou shalt find a newfound grace.

So, go forth, kind sirs, and support this eatery with glee,
And, perchance, ask for more, that they may see,
A change in menu, then, may come to pass,
And I, in turn, shall grant them more stars, alas!"

"Went here on a whim, based on a couple raves. Food was damn good. Four stars easy. But service? Two stars, tops. Took forever for our pitas, and they got the order wrong. Friend had to take his to go while I chowed down. Don't get me wrong, food's great. But c'mon, folks, get it together. Order right, and hustle it up a bit. Maybe someone should give 'em a heads up. Or a Yelp card. We love the grub, but service needs a boost."

"Been here a few times, always packed, always a good time. Had a VIP table, made it easier to get in and enjoy the night. DJ's music was good for dancing, but the dance floor was tight. They got a platform pole, women get up and dance on it, fun to watch. Last time I was here, the big private back room was closed, renovations maybe? The private area's separate from the main room, got private tables and dance areas for bigger groups, own DJ. Not a bad spot for a group, but not the best for just a couple dudes. Vegas got better options."

"Hark! A tale of culinary delights doth unfold,
In Montreal's streets, where taste buds doth unfold.
A humble sandwich, smoke-cured meat doth bear,
And poutine, with onion, mushroom, doth share.

The sandwich, verily, doth please mine taste,
Warm meat, so moist, doth make haste.
But poutine, alas! doth lack a certain zest,
Bacon or meat, to heighten the quest.

Yet, onion and mushroom, doth make amends,
Flavors combined, doth make amends.
But lo! A mistake, doth come to pass,
Tipping, a custom, doth leave me in a glass.

A hurry, I was in, and didn't pay heed,
Under-tipped, my error, indeed.
Waiter, a kind soul, doth ask if all be well,
Service, unexceptional, doth tell.

Saturday morn, early, doth open the door,
Tipping, in Montreal, doth be 15% more.
$1.50, a small sum, doth make me blush,
Embarrassment, doth take its rush.

Cheap, some may say, but generosity doth reign,
Brother and I, doth seek poutine's bane.
Shouting, they did, 'tis not yet open, they cry,
Food, good; service, unsure, doth lie.

Give it a chance, I shall, despite the flaw,
For in Montreal, doth culinary law."
"Room with a view, not too shabby. Right on Miracle Mile, convenient for shopping."

"Methinks 'tis a spacious place, with diverse seating arrangements to accommodate thy needs. A most excellent venue for gatherings, nigh unto the highway, whereupon I have espied men of commerce conferring, and, in truth, I have convened with mine own tutor and study group within these walls. The coffee and tea, I do declare, are of consistent quality. Moreover, they offer free Wi-Fi, though thou must request the password when thou dost acquire thy beverage. Alas, a star doth dwindle, forsooth, by reason of the untidy state of the premises, with littered tables and rubbish upon the ground."

"A fair tavern, with a choice of drinks most fine,
And in the afternoon, it was empty, save for mine own person.
Their victuals, too, didst seem of quality,
But alas, I didst not partake, forsooth, in their consumption."

"3.5 stars. Better than US airline lounges in terms of grub and drinks. Cookies, cheese, veggie platter, cous cous, spring rolls, mini quiche. Full bar with wine, liquor, and soda. Soup too. Sitting area gets packed, but it's better than the hallway. Closed from 10:30 am to 2:30 pm."
"Calamari, fantastic. Tacos, good but not the best. Server, hilarious. Recommended."

"Four of us didst break fast together,  
Two of us didst have steak and eggs, a feast,  
With potatoes, toast, and all the trimmings,  
A bargain at six dollars, nay, a steal!  
Two of us didst opt for the veggie omelet,  
With fresh greens, cheese, and potatoes, a treat.  
Coffee flowed like a river, and service was bright,  
Friendly servers made our day take flight.  
We returned the next eve, our hunger anew,  
Two of us had penne, creamy and true,  
Two had burgers, juicy and just right,  
The best part? Beers, brewed in house, a delight!  
Hefe and Light, both smooth and fine,  
A steal at two twenty-five, we doth decline.  
Five beers and four meals, a total of forty-five,  
A fair price, nay, a bargain, we doth arrive!"

"Bought a Groupon for a cut and color. Stylist did a good job, listened to what I wanted, and nailed the look. Three stars 'cause of a couple things: \nShe mixed the color in a bowl and said if she ran out, I'd have to pay another $15. Felt like I was getting hustled. Should've been told upfront. \nAlso, my shirt got ruined from the color bleeding through the robe. Manager said it'd come out in the wash, but I ain't so sure."

"A humble tavern, this place doth be,
With atmospheric charm, so plain to see.
TVs abound, a wondrous sight,
And service, friendly, withal a delight.

Their beer, cold as winter's snow,
And menu, limited, yet fit to go.
Sandwiches, salads, and more, we did try,
Fair portions, prices, did not make us sigh.

Yet, flaws there be, that doth detract,
No happy hour, a sorrowful fact.
Limited menu, a lack, indeed,
No specials, nor deals, to plant a seed.

Not open all day, a shame,
Drinks, pricey, a burning flame.
UFC, ten dollars, a steep cost,
Wine menu, scant, a sorry loss.

No pitchers, no bottles, to buy,
A drawback, verily, 'tis no lie.
But still, a visit, worth thy while,
For atmosphere, and service, with a smile."

"Methinks this review doth tarry long, my friends! Forsooth, I do frequent Miller's oft, 'tis true,
For 'tis a place most convenient, nigh the office, too.
Their happy hour, with drinks most fair and bright, doth draw me in,
And beer, aplenty, doth flow from tap to tin.
Fare, simple, yet sufficient, doth please mine eyes,
And screens, many, doth show the games of might.
Service, now, doth vary, I do confess,
At times, most kind, at others, quite a mess.
Yet, with friends, merry and bright,
Tis still a place where mirth doth take flight."

"A decent cup of joe, a pleasant place indeed,
Where scholars gather, books and homework at hand,
In the "back space", a haven for study and thought,
Though crowded, 'tis a scene of quiet contemplation.

Bring gold, my friend, for credit cards they do not take,
But fear not, for within, an ATM doth make,
Withdrawal of funds, though with a small fee,
A price to pay for convenience, as thou seest.

And mark this well, fair maiden, the barista,
A vision of beauty, a heart-stealer, no less,
His form, a work of art, his face, a shining sun,
A sight to behold, worth more than any gem or fun."

"Hark! Seeketh thou old-fashioned soul food? Verily, this place doth fit the bill. Fried chicken and cornbread, most delectable fare! A plethora of sides to choose from, thy taste buds shall be sated. Service, good and prompt, maketh this an excellent spot for midday repast, shouldst thou find thyself in town."

"The Mirage. Not a bad joint. Decent rooms, nice gardens. Good eats at Japonais, Kokomo, Samba. Plenty tables in the casino. Shame about the poker payouts, though. Still, a good spot to stay, especially if you're looking for a place close to the action."

"The chambers be dimly lit, my dear,
Alack, they lack sufficient light, 'tis true.
No fridge nor microwave, alas, doth grace
These halls, but, verily, I do confess,
The latter's absence doth not vex me so.
A Philips LCD, of thirty-two inches, doth
Adorn the wall, a modest sight, methinks.
But, lo, the water, hot, doth not abide,
When one doth bathe or doth take council with
The shower's spray. A grievous fault, indeed.
And, prithee, mark this well, a fee doth lie,
A resort tax, hidden, of twenty dollars,
They should include it in the total sum,
And not seek to conceal it, like a trickster.

"I didst watch the pirate show, before the inn,
'Twas passable, yet, my room, the eighth floor,
Didst offer solace, distant from the din.
A blessing, indeed, that noise didst not pour
Into mine ears, a pleasant respite, forsooth.

"Now, listen well, fair sir, the Treasure Isle,
Doth stand within the heart of Las Vegas' smile,
'Twixt Wynn and Paris, Bellagio, nay,
Planet Hollywood, doth form the central way,
All else, beyond, doth pale, and doth not claim
One's attention, save Fremont Street, of old."

Panchos, a buffet of mediocre Mexican food. Enter the colorful building, cafeteria-style. Choose from chili rellenos, enchiladas, tamales, chimichangas, flautas, taquitos, rice, beans, tacos, tostadas. Reasonable price for the amount of food. Non-authentic, greasy, trans fat-filled Mexican food. Flag system for more items. Good service, clean restaurant. Fresh hot sopapillas. Hubby loves the cheese sponges. Reluctantly agree to go.

"Amidst the bustling strip, a Starbucks doth lie,
In name alone, for 'tis not genuine, nay,
They take the gift cards, total rewards, a sign,
Of their true nature, not a part of the vine.

Their prices, too, do tell a tale of deceit,
My passionfruit tea, once two dollars eighty, now doth meet,
Six dollars, a sum most exorbitant, a price so steep,
I paid with my card, and did not dare to question deep.

The space within, quite large, with outlets galore,
A haven for those who seek to charge their device once more,
And mugs, juices, sandwiches, all doth fill the shelves,
A veritable feast, for those who do not fear the pelf.

Yet, for their prices, I must give them but three stars,
For doubling the cost, of a drink so pure and fair,
Is madness, a trick, a scheme, a wicked way,
To part a man from his hard-earned pay."

"Hallway's long, real secret. Few seats, maybe six. Wait's long, twenty minutes easy. Call ahead, that's my advice. Pizza's alright, not great though. Slices in Dublin, CA, now that's good pizza. Won't be back here, but it was an experience."

"Verily, the victuals didst please mine taste,
Afirst, I didst think it but a common feast,
But lo, the flavors didst dance upon mine tongue,
And made me reconsider mine erstwhile boon.

I do confess, I didst feel a mite confused,
Whenas I didst behold the menu, unprosed,
For in mine haste, I didst not see it ere,
And thus, I didst feel a mite discomposed.

Moreover, they didst give me but a box,
To hold mine aliment, and naught but that,
No bag to bear it, nor a straw to sip,
Which didst vex mine spirit, and didst make me rip.

Yet still, the food didst satisfy mine hunger,
And thus, I shall return, to partake of their plunger."

"Solid three. Thick pepperoni's not my thing, prefer the thin slice. Not exactly what I picture when I think NY-style thin crust. More like Villa or Verrazano. Don't dig the black edge crust either, golden brown's my jam. They put some work into it, used to be Atlanta Bread Co. Not from NY, been there, had a few slices. Might go back, not sure if it'll be a regular thing."

"Chicken ain't what it used to be. No more big chunks of white meat, now it's stewed in some broth all day. Not even sure it's all white meat no more. And don't get me started on the burrito lady. She's using her gloved hands to fill that thing up. Fine for rolling, but when she's sticking her hand in all them bins of lettuce, corn, tomatoes, cilantro, it just don't seem right. They should be using spoons on thongs for that job."

"O fond memories, how thou dost play upon my mind! 
In days of yore, at Pitt, where funds were scarce, 
Two eateries vied for our meager purse, 
Lu-Lu's Noodles, Yum Wok, both names entice. 
Their prices low, their proximity a boon, 
But alas, delivery they did not proffer, 
On cold days, through brown slush we had to go, 
With laughter and wet pants, our spirits did glow. 
For us, 'twas worth the perilous journey, 
Up Cardiac Hill, to dorms in haste, 
With food in hand, our bellies full and merry, 
Those memories, forever shall they last."
"Bank's nothing special, but it's there. Drive thru or walk up, whichever suits you. Just keep an eye out, y'know? Smith and Nail place nearby, other businesses too. Convenient spot."

"Saloon's got a corporate feel, overpriced too. Service is good though, beers are cold. Don't like the layout, gotta go through Saloon to get to Comedy Zone. Crowded on Sat nights, bathrooms packed, human traffic jam. Go there to pregame before shows at Fillmore or other Music Factory spots on Fri and Sat nights. Live music and DJ on Sat nights are a plus. Still, it's a standard corporate bar in Charlotte. Would go back."

"Rental shops got me scratchin' my head. New DVDs for five quid? Why bother when you can own 'em for a few more pounds? But hey, they know the score. Their bargain bins hide some gems. Recent flicks, top-notch films, and video games at a steal. Not all bad, I reckon."

"Methought I would give this fair fest five stars, indeed I did,
For last year, my love and I didst attend, and joy didst we find.
The victuals were of finest sort, the music didst delight,
But then, alack, the jousting match didst take a bitter turn.

The host, a knave of foulest sort, didst play the villain's part,
Humiliating a poor maid, and offering her a wretched sum.
He didst espouse his politics, a woeful sight to see,
And thus, didst tarnish the fest's good name, in shame and infamy.

Fests of yore, shouldst be of mirth and glee,
A place where families gather, free from worry and fear.
All cast members, shouldst stay in character, throughout the day,
Lest they sully the fest's good name, and drive the crowd away.

I wouldst love to return, come October's golden light,
But if that knave doth still remain, I shall not partake in the fight."

"Went for the breakfast buffet, twenty bucks. Queue outside, but inside, empty tables. Server kept our OJ flowing. Ambiance, meh. Omelette live counter, good stuff. Crabmeat, shrimp, salads, pizza, soft serve, fruits. Liked the omelettes, Danish, almond croissants, turkey sausage, waffles. Most stuff, good. Pancakes, not great. Guy making 'em, but backlog, cold, stale. Muffins, dry. Not bad overall. Worth a shot."

"Methought this would be grand, a hearty burger, fresh and juicy, at a place they call Fuddruckers, where such fare doth reign supreme. My first visit, and thus my hopes were high. Alas, 'twas naught but a common burger, good, yet not quite great, nor aught to write home about. In n Out, a far better choice, and cheaper too, methinks. If asked again to dine at Fuddruckers, I shall, but for a burger, there be better places, mark my words."

"Hark, good sirs, let us first establish this fact,  
The Mickey Mouse mural, 'twas there ere we did act.  
Now, prithee, let our words of love be spoken,  
For Pho Nhat's #42, my heart doth truly waken.  
Thine barbecued beef, shrimp, and eggroll, so fine,  
Upon a bed of vermicelli noodles, doth combine.  
Thy fish sauce, oh how it doth entice me,  
I shall return, my love for thee shall never flee.  
But alack, my friends, my latest visit didst bring,  
A sense of discontent, among the serving folk, didst cling.  
Perhaps, another pho shall win my heart,  
For change, it seems, doth not come easy to this part."

"Rehab, a place of revelry and delight,
I visited today, with expectations high and bright.
The line, I thought, would be long and winding,
But lo, it moved swiftly, and my wait was finding.

The cost, a mere $60, a sum quite fair,
And the security, not overbearing, I declare.
A car key, credit card, and ID, all they sought,
And in three seconds, my entry was bought.

Inside, a throng of people, fair and bright,
But not so packed, as videos and photos might.
At four o'clock, still room to move and sway,
Not a madhouse, as I had thought, by day.

Few dancers, just two lovebirds, locked in embrace,
Rehab, it seems, is not the wild, crazy place.
Drinks, oh so pricey, $28, a single serving,
But Heineken Light, in buckets, a bargain, worth savoring.

Alas, I would not return, for though it was fun,
Rehab, to me, was not the wild, crazy run."
"Birthday parties? This joint's got 'em. But me? Nah. Smells like a dumpster fire and the staff's about as friendly as a wet cat. Three stars 'cause the kiddos seem to enjoy it, but that's about it."

"Methinks 'twas naught but ale that I didst partake,
Yet found I joy in this fair brewhouse's make.
The tavern itself, a square of finest design,
Didst boast a central bar, where bartenders didst shine.
A tiny aquarium, full of fish so fine,
Didst add a touch of whimsy to the scene divine.
The crowd, though small, didst revel in the night,
And nearby, tables twain didst offer respite.
If thou dost find thyself in Middleton's embrace,
And seek a pint, without the need to pace,
Then hath this place, a worthy stop, indeed,
To quench thy thirst, and banish sorrow's creed."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,  
My breakfast at Perk did not impress.  
The victuals were fair, I must avow,  
But service, alas, did lack somehow.  

My dam and I, we both did dine  
On burritos, mine with bacon, fine.  
And though they were small, as I do reckon,  
The flavor was good, with cilantro sauce anon.  

But, oh, the waitress, how unkind!  
No word, no smile, nor any sign.  
She left us be, like strangers, alone,  
And when we needed her, she was nowhere known.  

The hostess, fair, didst attend to us,  
With water fresh and our bill, what a fuss.  
But when the waitress came, in such haste,  
She slapped the bill down, without a taste.  

No thank you, nor farewell, she did say,  
And so, my friends, I shall not stay.  
For I can make my own burrito,  
And save myself from such disdain and pity."

"Went to this joint with the boyfriend one night. He'd been there before, said it was a good spot for cheap drinks. It was a dive, but that's what we were looking for. Ordered a Tokyo tea, asked the bartender for the trivia game thingy. Also got the honey hot wings, they were real good. Place was dead that night, but we still had a good time. Checked out the karaoke room on the way out, people were having fun."

"Oh, how I adore all things phyllo and spinach! Greek restaurants beckon me, dear friend, with promises of delectable treats. A taste of Spanikopita, a morsel of Baklava, my heart doth sing with joy!

Aye, the Spanikopita, a dish most fine, didst please my palate with its creamy feta cheese. I added a sprinkle from my salad, a trick I learned at home, to heighten the flavor, 'twas a delight!

The portion, generous and fair, the price, most reasonable, the atmosphere, warm and inviting, a cozy haven for luncheon or dinner. I returned anon, a testament to its charm, forsooth, a place I shall revisit, whenever fate doth bring me to Madison's shores!"

"Hark! A Beerarita doth please mine eyes!
And lo, the quesadilla, full of chicken, doth lie.
Alack, a little more flavor it did need, I do confess.
But soft, the chips and salsa, a wondrous treat, did bless.
The salsa, too, did make up for the quesadilla's lack, I do declare."

"Methought this eating place was but so-so, my rating doth depend on victuals weighed against cost. One thing I didst not fancy, all dishes served à la carte, I pray thee! A Caesar salad I didst order, 'twas passable, yet o'erly large, and I didst not devour all of it. My spouse, a humble burger he didst choose, alack! naught special for the price, no sides to boot. Here again I wouldst dine, anon, should other taverns be too full."

"A cup of coffee, a cup of tea,
With noise of radios, blenders do be,
But wifi, good and strong, doth make it so,
That now I know the way, I shall go."

"Good service, fair sir, yet hard to find,
In strip mall, rural north of Guadalupe, 'twas hidden.
Food portions, large, but flavor, just so-so,
I had omelet, with all, and hubby, Scottish eggs Benedict, didst savor.
Benedict sauce, good, but bread, a mite tough,
Omelet, just fair, with home fries, English muffin, enough."

"Methinks we chanced upon this eatery, my friends and I,  
After a merry jaunt through yonder shops so nigh.  
'Tis but an ordinary place, yet suited to our needs,  
With jalapeño bread, a curious treat, our hunger to feed.  
  
A turkey sandwich was my choice, with stuffing and cranberry  
Sauce, a feast for the taste buds, verily, a Thanksgiving delight.  
But alas, 'twas dry, my friends, and left me somewhat unsatisfied,  
Yet still, a decent meal, and worth the price, I doth decide.  
  
My comrades, too, didst find their victuals to their liking,  
Save one, who lamented the lack of PBR, her heart's desire.  
The waitress, kind and fair, didst attend to our each whim,  
And when a burger lacked heat, didst swiftly make amends, with a grin.  
  
So, though the fare may be but common, the atmosphere doth please,  
And after a tiring day, their food doth bring us ease.  
Thus, shall we come again? Mayhap, anon, my friends,  
For despite its flaws, this place doth hold a certain charm, and gentle ends."

Alas, my friends, I must confess,
The Juan Turkey Wrap did not impress.
Despite my usual disdain for healthy fare,
I thought to give this place a chance, with nary a care.

But lo, the wrap did taste like mush,
A flavorless concoction, without a single hush.
No distinguishing features, just a bland mix,
Leaving me to douse it in hot sauce, with a heavy fix.

Yet still, I shall give this place another go,
Perhaps the "happy" menu holds a better show.
"Sipped coffee, ate eggs. Not bad, not great. Prices okay, but not gourmet. Plastic utensils, good. One napkin, lame. Service, meh. Nice spot, though. One bathroom, annoying. Won't be back soon."
"Location-wise, it ain't half bad. Food-wise, it's a mixed bag. Somewhere between Panda and the real deal, but leanin' towards the latter."

"Juicy Pho, off the strip. Not bad for Vegas. Ordered pork chop rice, small portion, not great. Friend's Korean BBQ ribs, decent. Their Pho, just okay. But the egg roll wrapped in lettuce? Damn good. A bit of a haul from the strip, 10-15 minutes by car."

"Fie upon these paltry patties, dear!
A sorry sight, indeed, they do present.
Forsooth, their scanty size doth mock my stomach's need,
And their dear price doth make my purse lament.

In days of yore, when schooldays' joys were mine,
I didst partake of burgers, plastic, vile,
And lo, their taste and texture, then, didst seem divine.
But now, alas! These burgers, cheap and mean,
Do bring to mind those wretched, rubbery things,
And thus, my gorge doth rise in disdain.

Ten silver pieces, gone! Oh, cruel fate!
For such a sum, a hearty meal I might have had,
But nay, 'twas spent on this, a sorry bite,
Which doth but taunt my hunger, leaving me irate.
No more, I say! This place shall see me not again,
For worthier fare, my taste doth now demand."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

The original text describes a negative dining experience at a Chinese restaurant. The food was of poor quality, and while the service and ambiance were acceptable, they did not make up for the subpar cuisine. The writer expresses their disappointment and lack of enthusiasm for returning to the establishment.

In the revised version, the language is more concise and direct, reflecting Hemingway's distinctive writing style. Instead of stating that the food was "kind of low-end Chinese," the revised text simply describes it as "low-end Chinese." Additionally, the phrase "not really bad, just not good either" is condensed into "underwhelming experience with too much repetition." Overall, the revised text maintains the same meaning as the original while incorporating Hemingway's signature concision and clarity.

"I hit this joint for some poker and maybe catch a flick. You'll be drenched in smoke, worse than that Korean BBQ stink. Gotta wash my clothes right away, smell like an ashtray otherwise. Lots of tables, plenty of action, mostly old-timers. Youngest guy at the table, usually in my 30s. Food's alright - Fuddruckers, Subway, oyster bar's decent, not as good as Palace Station though."

In fair Madison, where the Capitol doth stand,
A new-ish coffee shop doth please the land.
Colectivo, by name, doth boast a charm,
With rustic, hipster feel, and no alarm.

The tunes, they play, are cool and fine,
The decor, a sight to see and divine.
Seats abound, both within and without,
E'en on the porch, where one may pout.

A variety of brews, both hot and cold,
Teas, too, for those who dare be bold.
And should thou hunger, fear not, dear guest,
For food and ale, they have at their behest.

But, alack! No wi-fi on the weekends,
Lest ye be forced to converse, or read a book that ends.

"Stayed at the Westin, heard noise up in my room. Thought nothing of it, dropped my gear and headed to work. Toilet wouldn't stop running, went downstairs to report it. Came back, still running. Went to grab grub, came back, still not fixed. Reminded 'em again, finally got fixed. But then, found a pool of water behind the toilet. Called 'em up, they fixed it quick. One good thing, check-ins usually around 3 pm. Switched from Hilton Garden to this place early one morning, they let me check in at 8 am."

"Hark, my dear friend! 'Tis my first visit to this place,
And, verily, the victuals didst leave me in a daze.
Fresh, they were, but choices few, alack!
For luncheon, I didst find their spread to be quite lacking.
But lo, their breakfast spread and salad bar didst please,
A feast for mine eyes, and a treat for my taste buds, 'twas.
Alas, no fish, save fried and feathered fowl, didst they proffer,
A bitter disappointment, indeed, and cause for dismay.
Nor didst their sweet treats delight, alack and alas!
I shall not spend six-and-fifty pieces of silver there,
Forsooth, their customer service didst shine, full fair."

"Hark, what store is this? A Whole Foods, by the look,  
But smaller than the one I know, at Ray Rd. and the 101,  
My favorite, where I oft do shop and dine.  
The scent within, I must confess, doth not impress,  
Like Asian markets, with their rice and meat,  
It doth assault mine nostrils, and doth make me retreat.  
But still, I venture in, to see what they do have,  
And find the olive bar, with but eight small containers,  
A paltry sight, indeed, and not worth the cost,  
But still, the meats, they doth look fresh, I must boast.  
The cheese, too, doth seem of good quality,  
And all the store, well-lit and clean, doth be.  
But alas, my favorite bacon, nowhere to be found,  
And but one loaf of bread, that doth my taste astound.  
I glimpsed their bulk section, full of sweet delights,  
But, full and satisfied, I did not tarry long in flight.  
In case of need, I'd stop, but not for pleasure's sake,  
For other stores, I'll seek, my Whole Foods experience to make."

"Meh. Not bad, but not great either. Older room, though. Staff? Not exactly friendly. Checked in, girl barely said a word. Told me the wrong floor too. Lugging my bags all over, couldn't find my room. Finally called the front desk, different floor altogether. Construction going on, bunch of workers and trucks. Sat in my car for 12 minutes while some guy tried to back a trailer in. Nope, I'm a paying guest. They should work around me. Wouldn't stay here again. But the actual hotel? Nice. Staff? Fantastic."
"Never been to the cronut joint. Lines too damn long. But some Italian bakery gave me a taste. Not bad."

"I needed redemption after that disaster of a burger from Carl's Jr. Two cheeseburgers at BK would do the trick. How hard could it be? I waited, watching others get their food while my order lingered. Five minutes passed and my order still wasn't ready. Two plain cheeseburgers, for crying out loud! Finally, I got my food and it made up for the earlier fiasco."

"I called ahead, they said come on in. Thirty minute wait for a table, I was steamed. They don't take reservations, that's their policy. Vegas, Saturday night, they should know better. Menu's limited, food's alright, not great. Truffle fries, incredible. Good company, made the meal enjoyable. It's an okay spot, I'd go back, but not in a hurry."

"Brunch was good, patio atmosphere nice. But a key mistake that keeps it from being great. Asked for no onions, got onions. Told the cook tried but failed. What if it was an allergy? Just serve it up anyway? Waiter showed little care. Some other service issues too. Not enough to make us come back."

"Hark, my dear friends, listen well,
For I have news of a wondrous spell,
A place they call E-Z Buffet, ye see,
Where food doth flow like a bountiful sea.

Two days had passed since last I didst partake,
In Asian delights, my heart didst ache,
So in I went, with hunger as my guide,
To find sustenance and quell my inside.

The place was large, with food galore,
Seventy-five dishes, and more,
Chinese fare, with Clam Chowder, beef,
Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, relief.

And pink marshmallows, who knew?
I laughed with glee, my spirits anew.
The staff was friendly, the place was neat,
With Sushi, Kim Chee, Egg Foo Young, a treat.

Fried chicken, spare ribs, mushrooms too,
Fish, shrimp, and more, a feast for you,
Desserts, including ice cream, sweet delight,
A high three stars, this restaurant bright.

Lunch buffet, six seventy-five,
Sunday, eight seventy-five, a fair price,
Regular menu, for those who wish,
To dine, and savor each delicious dish."

"Sushi's good here. Creative, too. Decor's nice, good spot for a casual date. But service? Not so much. Last time, we had a group of six and got ignored after they took our orders. Waited 45 minutes for our food. Friendly, sure, but inefficient. And they tacked on a 20% tip without asking. Couldn't split the bill more than three ways. Not worth the hassle."

"Went to the Fremont Street Experience with my kid and some friends. Had a good time, but the place shut down early. They said it was for families, but they kicked us out at 9 pm. That's not very family-friendly. If they want to attract families, they should stay open later on weekends."
"Been here thrice. Once for dinner, twice for brunch. Three stars, tops. Food's not great, even when I'm famished. Presentation's on point, though."

"Hark, what news is this? A Groupon, I didst find,
For lodgings fair, upon a holiday most kind.
With haste, I didst make my way, o'er Labor Day,
To this resort, wherein I didst hope to play.

The grounds, they were a sight to behold,
Well-manicured lawns, and trees of old.
But alack, the rooms, they didst require
A bit of updating, to make them more desire.

The tiles in the bathroom, worn and old,
Didst need replacement, ere they grew cold.
And in the cabinet, beneath the screen,
A space there was, where once a fridge had been.

The staff, they were polite, and courteous too,
At check-in, and checkout, they didst see me through.
But other than that, I didst not converse,
For I was busy, enjoying all the verse.

Oh, the activities, they were many and grand,
Pools, movies, smores, music, mini golf at hand.
One could rent paddleboards, or kayaks too,
To paddle round the lake, of Las Vegas, anew.

Dogs, they were allowed, I didst espy,
So, perchance, my furry friend, shall come nigh.
In conclusion, the price I paid, was fair,
For the quality, of the hotel, beyond compare."

"Red Ridge Park, a quick 10-minute walk from my place. I'll miss it when I move. Run the exterior loop, about a mile, when I'm feeling fierce. Two sides are a bit uphill, two are flat - good for a casual jog. Well-lit at night, always felt safe alone. Kids' water park, play areas, basketball courts, baseball diamond. Busy, but not crowded. People walk, play with their dogs, or picnic. New homes across the street, starting at 200K. Not bad. Wet n Wild nearby. Wish they had an enclosed dog park, like some other places I've been."

"Hark! The victuals were passable, a tavern, 'twain't bad for ale imbibers, woe is me, a non-ale drinker. A black bean burger, perchance from Morningstar Farms, did grace my plate, yet an extra fee of nineteen pence, methinks, doth raise my ire. \n\nThe attendance, sporadic, our draughts refilled, alack, when the bill didst arrive."

"Methinks the reviews didst speak of wondrous feasts,
But alas, mine own dish didst not meet expectations.
Chicken pasta, with linguini, basil, and cream sauce,
Didst weigh heavy on my stomach, like a leaden anchor.
The service, though, didst shine like the brightest star,
Five stars, I say, for their courteousness and care.
And gladly, they didst serve my favorite brew,
Dos Equis amber, a drink most fair and true."

Hark! I've visited Osteria twice, my friends,
To partake in their delectable fare,
A sandwich first, then pizza later,
To sate my hunger and quench my thirst.

My hopes were high, for I do reside
Across the street, a mere stone's throw,
And thus, I wished this place to excel,
But alas, my experience hath been mixed, I do confess.

The sandwich, an Italian delight,
Was truly tasty, a masterful blend,
But the pizza, oh, how it did fall short,
Leaving me underwhelmed, my friends, I do declare.

It reminded me of pies consumed in days of yore,
When I did dwell in New York's city's heart,
But that, my friends, doth not bode well,
For quality, it doth leave much to be desired, I do aver.

Yet still, I hold out hope for Osteria's fate,
That they may flourish and prosper,
Perhaps a weekend brunch shall be their saving grace,
Or pizzas made with love, a culinary embrace.

"Verily, I say unto thee, my dearest friend,  
That ne'er have I felt such foulness descend  
Upon my person, as on that day we didst  
Take to the river, and with joy, didst glide.  

Aye, 'twas a merry time, with laughter free,  
We tied ourselves together, a jolly spree,  
And with a cooler of ale, our spirits didst rise,  
As we didst bask in the sunshine, and the water's surprise.  

And, prithee, good sir, do thou wear a hat,  
A broad brim, to shield thy visage from the heat,  
For in such garb, we mayst brave the elements,  
And with mirth, didst conquer the day's events."

"Tis well, my friend, 'tis well indeed,
No need to fret or make a fuss,
For all is fine, and doth proceed
As it should, with naught amiss.

Verily, I speak the truth, my word
Is bond, and thus it shall be heard,
No sarcasm doth my voice convey,
But rather, all is well, come what may.

And so, my dear, let us partake
In this most noble of breakfasts, fair and bright,
For here, within this hallowed hall,
Doth lie a feast most wondrous and grand, fit for a king's delight."

"Good grub, this place has. Crepes, savory ones, mind you, they're top-notch. Coffee's decent too. But, a hostess, they could use. First timer, I was, and confused, I was.
