No clear sign of counter or table service. Had to chase down a worker, I did. Service, spotty it was. Two waitresses, there were, and full tables, every one. Fifteen minutes, we waited, to order. Wait times, too long, they were. Twenty-five minutes, for two crepes? Way too much. Didn't mind, I didn't, but don't come here, if you're in a rush. Good eatery, still, it is."

"Hark! What value doth this hotel bring,
A mere $109 per night, and that's not all, my friend!
For on the weekends, 'tis a bargain indeed,
Compared to $400 for a tiny room, cramped and in need.

And throw in breakfast, free of charge,
And drinks in the eve, a bonny largesse.
The hotel, once upgraded, now doth shine,
The rooms, nice enough, yet the lobby, a bit divine.

But alas, service doth leave much to be desired,
Our food, delayed, and the wait, quite tiresome and long.
The check-in, a slow affair, and the front desk,
Doth stop and answer phones, a most vexing quirk.

Yet, one kind soul, did call me "cute",
I know not if to be flattered, or to be mute.
The shuttle, a mystery, no consistent word,
We used taxis, $10 a trip, to the Strip, oh so absurd.

In conclusion, this Embassy Suites, not the best,
I prefer the other, on Paradise, at a higher cost.
But still, a good stay, and value, doth abide,
For those who seek, a cheaper place to reside."

I've wanted to check this place out for years, but always ended up sticking to the Strip. Finally made it out here on my last trip. It's an outdoor party, and the screens are pretty impressive. This is old Vegas, where everything is dirt cheap - drinks, food, you name it. But, let me tell you, it's pretty damn ghetto here, especially at night. Saw a lot of street people, and some suspicious-looking bags. But hey, that's part of the charm, right? You can just walk around with an open container, no worries. Had to keep an eye on my wallet, though. Maybe the earlier shows aren't as seedy. Came for the last show of the night, so maybe I was asking for it.

"Upon a night most fair, my love and I didst venture forth,
In search of ale and merriment, to banish all our woe.
And lo, we found this place, most fitting for our quest,
Where folk in costumes doth gather, and make merry with the rest.

Two cups of brew we didst have, of Sin City's finest ale,
And Sam Adams' cherry wheat, which doth our thirst assuage.
A fine selection they doth boast, of microbrews and more,
From Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, and Stone, and others of renown.

But alack, the service doth lack, in speed and in cheer,
Despite the bustling crowd, and our free drink coupons dear.
Yet still, we shall return anon, to taste their brews once more,
For 'tis a place most meet, to gather with friends on the Strip's floor."

"Methinks I did expect a greater show,
A vista most fair and grand,
But alack, the view did please me well,
As day gave way to night's sweet spell.
The victuals and the decor, methought,
Were but average, nay, not quite right,
Yet still, the view, that wondrous sight,
Doth make this eatery special, by my troth,
For though I dwell in this fair town,
This view doth never cease to amaze me now."

"Methinks I've seen 'Viva Elvis' a fair few times,
From its grand opening to a few months past.
The show, though improved, doth not progress much,
And seems not to fit with Cirque's other vast.

Now, mark you well, the music, scenes, and garb,
Are quite delightful, and worth the price of admission.
The performers, dressed in Elvis' era, do greet thee,
And 'Jail House Rock' and 'Return to Sender' be my favorite treat.

But, alas, the choreography doth lack the wow,
And the singing women, though talented, doth not feel quite right,
For Elvis' voice, methinks, doth make the songs more bright.
And the transitions between scenes, clumsy and slow.

Yet, despite these flaws, I did enjoy the show,
And recommend it, for it shall soon depart, thou know."

Alas, fair maiden, with sorrow I say,  
This business, once mine, now doth belong  
To new masters, who with haste did take  
The reins, and all my hopes did break.  
My eyebrows, once a work of art,  
Now doth resemble a sorry state.  
One brow, uneven and thin, doth mar  
The other, full and lush, a sorry sight.  
I fear, fair maiden, I shall not return,  
For quality, alas, doth no longer burn.

"Tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll, oh my!
How delectable they did taste, upon my word!
Trendy, indeed, the vibe doth seem, yet somewhat cramped,
I do confess, the low rise sushi bar, doth not appeal.
AYCE dinner, priced not too steep, a bargain, one might say,
Parking, plentiful, a convenience, beyond a doubt.
Music, pleasant, and ventilation, most fair,
Food, satisfactory, and experience, generally, quite pleasant."

"First tats, with Jessy. Sister had some work done, liked her. Got matching dragonflies on our hips. Fast, friendly, comfortable. Went back two weeks later for another, inverted colors, matched but different. Clean shop, important to me. Excellent first experience."

"Bang's the spot for you if you're into Billy Joel, Elton John, and some good ol' fashioned people watchin'. Don't mind standin' 'cause tables are scarce, and you might just find yourself beltin' out Journey tunes with the rowdy crowd. But if you're lookin' for a more low-key night, this ain't the place for you. There's a cover at the door, and it's a fun spot, but livin' here? Nah, that's a hard pass."
"Not bad spot for a game. Bartenders kept an eye on things, but food took its sweet time. Thirty minutes passed and still no grub. Cancelled the order, asked for the bill."

"Alack, my hopes were high for this sandwichery,
But found instead a humble lunching place,
With ingredients of questionable worth,
And portion sizes that did not suffice.

The steak melt, with too little meat,
Didst leave me feeling incomplete,
And though the sandos sounded fair,
Their execution did not meet my glare.

For such a price, I did expect
A sandwich of true excellence,
But alas, 'twas not to be,
And thus my disappointment doth ensue."

"Squirrel Hill impressed me more than Bangkok Balcony. Found it on a vegan website, open late, easy street parking. Disappointed the clothing stores were closed, great mix of vintage and new. Liked BB's layout, modern without being sterile. Flatware was great, good selection of tofu, asked how spicy I wanted it. Food was cheaper than expected, packed place, nice decor. Good, but I'm biased, love Thai food. Three stars because we both felt sick later."

"Table by the window, view of the strip. Not too shabby. Eiffel Tower in the distance, adds a touch of romance. Drinks, top-notch. Live music, on the other side of the bar. Choose wisely, my friend. Crowd, mature, date-night types. We had one drink, laughed, and left. Worth a visit."

"A frozen hot chocolate, I didst procure,  
To sate my thirst and warm my soul.  
The wait, it was a lengthy one, I must confess,  
Yet, the drink itself, didst make amends.  
'Twas rich and creamy, with a flavor so divine,  
That I wouldst have it once again, in a heartbeat, 'twine.  
For though the price, didst seem a bit steep,  
I found it worth it, in the end, to sleep.  
And thus, I shall return, to try their fare,  
And see if their dishes, be as fair and rare."

"Breakfast: eggs, spuds, bacon, joe and OJ. Twenty-two bones. Ten for the entree, three for the coffee, six for the OJ. Side of hash browns, plate-sized. Good, not great. Overpriced by a quarter. I'll stick with Waffle House. Twice the grub for half the price, and better coffee to boot."

"Methinks 'twas but a mediocre feast,
This place they call Price's, where wings be quest.
From Maryland, I came to Charlotte's land,
In May of 2012, with eager hand.
Their wings, alack, were small, O woe is me!
But tater tots, a delight, didst set me free.
A memory of youth, a taste so sweet,
Yet, wings from home, more satisfying eat.
Price's, farewell, thy name doth leave my lips,
For better wings, my heart doth now equip."
"Food's decent. Only joint around for a fast bite. Stayed at Mandala Bay, next door."

"Not my scene, Old Town Scottsdale nightlife. Went to The Mint with 12 girlfriends for Happy Hour on a Friday. Had a good time. Food's great! Drinks are good, especially at half price. Interior's cool. Bathroom's weird, didn't like it. Staff's friendly, but seemed new. Server had trouble with our big group. Told us one group bill would be easier, then it wasn't. Waited 30 minutes for my bill. Would come back for Happy Hour again, but insist on separate checks."

"The burger joint got decent reviews, but I wasn't blown away. Good, not great. Overpriced too - sixty bucks for a burger, fish sandwich, fries, and two sodas? Not worth it. My girl agreed. Three stars, tops."
"Canyon Ranch, not as advertised. Overpriced, small, unoriginal. Energy massage? What's the point of that? Not impressed."

"Methinks all Apple stores, by Jove, do boast
Of ample space, good lighting, and fine display.
Their wares, so neatly arranged, do catch the eye,
And friendly service doth abound, by day.

But, alas, their prices, oh how steep!
For what they offer, 'tis a king's ransom, yeep!
So, dear Apple enthusiasts, take heed,
And know that better deals may be found, with speed.

And thus, I pray, if thou hast coin to spare,
Do consider donating, without a care.
For those who lavish wealth, 'tis a noble deed,
To share thy riches, and spread joy, indeed.

Eat, drink, and make merry, friends, 'tis the season,
To revel in mirth, and let good times roll, with reason."

In sooth, the victuals were of fair quality,
With choice enough to sate thy appetite.
But, alack, the ambiance didst lack,
That je ne sais quoi, that doth make night bright.
'Twas not a lively place, I do confess,
Especially for Vegas, where mirth doth reign supreme.
Yet, praise the gods, a Groupon didst aid,
And made the cost, a goodly sum indeed.
For otherwise, o'er-priced, 'twould have been deemed.

"Airpark did a good job, not great, but good. For a fair price, too. Better than Danny's, that's for sure. I've seen better details in the area, but they cost more, around $250. So, considering the quality and price, Airpark was a good value."

"Hark! This Panda Express, a drive-thru doth possess,
A boon indeed, when sun doth beat with fierce oppression.
I stepped within, and swiftly didst they serve,
My craving for a meal, without the need to swerve.

Alas! The orange chicken, Beijing beef, a woe,
Dried up and lacking sauce, a sorry state, I do declare.
Yet still, 'twas Panda Express, no surprise,
Average fare, without the need to open eyes."

"Methinks, fair sir, thou art oft found In this, the city of sin and sound, Where gambling and revelry do reign supreme. But mark thee well, forsooth, If thy skin doth bear the hue of snow, Thou mayst find that certain dishes be Tainted with a heavy hand, to suit thy taste, Without a word, or so much as a trace Of query, ere they do present the feast. A case in point, my friend, doth lie In yonder pho, a dish most divine, Which, on a recent visit, did arrive With naught but scraps of meat, and nary a slice Of tripe or tendon, to make up the lack. No, they did not proffer more of the rest, To fill the void, and make the dish complete."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy for Galaxy Luxury's splendor! Yet, alas, at times, my chariot doth not convey me thither, nor doth the theater provide sufficient seats for the cinematic spectacle I wish to behold. \n\nBut fear not, dear friends, for Brenden doth offer solace in its cozy embrace. The staff, with manners most courteous, doth ensure a pleasant experience, and prices, fair and reasonable, doth not break the bank."

"Alas, my dear friend, how fares Mamma Mia's reach? A mere 0.7 miles, a distance too great, alack! Their online system doth declare, 'Tis not enough, thou art too far away, East of 20th or West of 64th, North of Washington or South of Lincoln, nay, 'tis a journey too long, a drive most foul. Yet fear not, fair sir, for their pizza, though distant, doth remain most delectable, a treat worth the toil, a slice most divine."
"Mexican joint. Decent. Salsa bar, top-notch. Generous servings. Four stars, minus one for the outdated dcor."

"3.5 stars. Flamebroiler fan seeks teriyaki joint near me. Rice bowls, the sandwiches of Asia. This place fits. Cayman combo: Fiji, slow-cooked chuck in teriyaki sauce, a bit tough. Singapore curry, chicken and carrots in Japanese curry, slightly sour. Chicken, stringy, not my thing. Enjoyed the meal, good portion size, cheap, five bucks! Unique menu, not your average teriyaki. Close to Midwestern, will return. Update after trying apps, crab puffs, egg rolls. 10% off for Midwestern students."

"Trader Vic's threw a pre-opening bash at Planet Hollywood last week. Tikipug said they ate like kings - lobster, shrimp, duck. They were taken to a banquet room with hula dancers, mai tais, and free mugs. Met Eve, Trader Vic's granddaughter, and saw the unfinished restaurant. Executive Chef Rick Giffen, formerly of Mon Ami Gabi, cooked up a storm. Not your average Pu Pu platter. Three stars for food and drinks, one for decor. Maybe they should offer VR helmets. Love Trader Vic's, including the one in Havana (that's another story). This is a Trader Vic's Lounge, like the new one in Beverly Hills."

"A fine hotel chamber, yet pricy, alack!
I visited thither on Memorial Day eve,
With friends, and found the room quite fair,
Yet, for each small luxury, they did charge.

For a bed, a mere $20 per night, they'd say,
And the fridge, a fee, lest ye wish to play.
But, 'twas in a prime location, near the Strip,
Where Rehab, a concert, doth take its grip.

Drake and Wayne, they did perform, I heard,
But, alas, the line, long, and tickets scarce,
Doubled in price, and sold out fast,
A two-hour wait, at least, to pass the test.

The casino, restaurants, and nightclub, too,
Did offer diversions, for me and you.
Yet, on my next visit, I may choose to stray,
To other hotels, or a less busy day."

"Methought we started with Waffle Fry Nachos,
Doused in gooey white cheddar and sloppy joe,
And topped with salsa and jalapenos, no less.
'Twas delicious, yet next time, I'd ask thee,
Kitchen, to hold the sloppy joe, I pray.
For I wouldst not miss the meat, verily.

I hadst the Crispy Four Cheese Burger,
With cheese fried crisp onto the patty,
A cheesy concoction, crisp and creamy.
Aside from the brioche bun, 'twas tasty,
Well seasoned, I didst think. But, alack,
The bun, too much bread for the burger, made it dry.
An onion roll, a better choice, methinks.

My husband, his BYOB, didst select,
Beef patty with pepper jack cheese, jalapenos,
Caramelized onions, all on the onion roll.
'Twas well prepared, flavorful, and juicy,
Indeed, a tasty dish, methought.

But, alas, the service, slow it was,
The place, but newly opened, we didst see.
Most places, need a little time, to work out kinks,
I do hope, service doth improve, with time, anon."

Steve's Greenhouse Grill, a place most wondrous,
With A-OK fare, and atmosphere quite sportive,
Like Cracker Barrel, but without the backing,
And with a design scheme that's quite kitsch and tacky.

Loud colors, loud TVs, and ads for strong drink,
A menu vast and varied, with something for everyone to think,
Bar menu, overpriced, but servers full of cheer,
Singing praises of each dish, with nary a speck of fear.

Chicken fried steak, with fries, my meal did make,
Kristen G., her choice, fish and chips, with clam chowder to partake.
All was well, some salt, some just right, some bland,
But still, a place most worthy, of thy hard-earned pound.

So, take Cracker Barrel, cut budget by three,
And tell the manager, all patrons to please, thee,
In Phoenix, this place, doth fit the bill,
Steve's Greenhouse Grill, doth stand, most fulfilling still.

"We watched Central Bistro take shape, curious about what it'd become. Inside, it's lively, almost too loud. Windows open, Phoenix's mild weather made it perfect. Wonder how it'll be when they close 'em. 

Food? Delicious. Service? Good. But, two visits, we saw bartenders prepping garnishes with bare hands. Juice running down their arms, slicing oranges for drinks. Another time, a bartender reached into the olive jar, grabbed a handful, and put 'em in the garnish tray. I promptly removed the olives from my martini. 

Central Bistro, get your act together before Maricopa County pays a visit."

"Hark! In fair downtown Phoenix, I didst seek
A place to dine where old homes didst speak.
And lo, I found Coronado Cafe, a spot
Wherein I couldst indulge in victuals hot.

A workday it was, and thus, I didst order
But one dish, lest I appear a glutton.
The roasted chicken sandwich, oh how grand,
With potato salad, a tasty second hand.

The bar, though small, didst seat us comfortably,
And spirits, wine, didst tempt me sorely.
Alas, I couldst not partake, for duty called,
But shall, anon, when next I visit this hall.

The chicken, moist and flavorful, didst please,
And potato salad, a satisfying tease.
A simple, hearty meal, fit for a king,
I shall return, when busy-ness doth cease.

For now, I bid thee farewell, dear cafe,
Until we meet again, in cooler clime,
When cozy seats outside, shaded from sun's rays,
Shall beckon me, and thou shalt be mine."

"Methinks I must concur with Pierre and Donald, fair gents,
Two dishes on the menu, worth the order, I do reckon.
Lettuce wedge, a tasty treat, and Willy burger, oh so fine,
But steaks, alas, are not worth thy time, my friend,
For seasoning, overpowering, doth make it hard to dine.
And cook, dear sir, dost thou know the difference 'twixt
Med rare and well? A vast disparity, I do declare,
For when I asked for rib-eye, med rare, lo and behold,
A hockey puck, most unappetizing, didst appear.
Yet, bread, when hot, doth please, and wrap-up burgers, too,
Lettuce wedge, a delight, doth make my day anew."

"Good grub at fair prices. Got there mid-week, post-breakfast, based on rave reviews. Lookin' forward to their famous bread bowls. No wait, place was half-full. Server was top-notch, friendly, attentive, and quick. Menu had plenty of options, but everything sounded too good. Went with Jamm's French Toast, wife got an omelette. Food was alright, maybe didn't order the best dishes. Wouldn't come back, too many other breakfast spots to try in Vegas."

"The new entrance's a helluva lot better than the old one. Used to be, you'd have to climb five flights of stairs, then another two to get to the dance floor. Now, they got a random guest elevator that takes you to a random floor, then you gotta navigate through some pool-side concert and up another flight to get to the good stuff. Not too shabby. 

Still ain't a fan of the tiny dance floor they got, and how it's always closed off. And when it gets crowded, forget about it. You gotta go outside if you wanna breathe, but that's not exactly ideal in the winter. 

It's clear that the same folks who designed TAO did this place too. No flow, no ambiance, no way to party comfortably. Guess I'll stick with XS."

"Upon a Sunday eve, with friends I didst stroll,
Into a place of victuals, where we didst dine.
A smallish room, yet cozy, with heat outdoors,
A menu vast, with choices manifold.
Each of us chose a dish, but lo, the portions great,
Didst fill our table, making meal-time quite a feat.
Beware, dear friends, lest ye be overcome,
By sauces rich, and servings most generous.
Tea, in a metal dish, didst come to us,
And though the fare was heavy, I didst find it tasty.
Alas, the service, left a bit to be desired,
Yet still, a night of joy, with friends, I didst acquire."
"Pizza good, service bad. Girl at register ignored me, then rude. Guy with red hair greeted me, but girl yelled at him. Place dirty, tables filthy. Pizza good, but fix service."

"Stopped by for a sweet treat since the missus loves red velvet cupcakes. Sunday afternoon visit, selection was limited. Each cupcake costs three bucks, not bad for a fancy place. Frosting's the real deal, but the caramel flavor fell short for me. Red velvet didn't have that creamy tang. Not bad overall, still satisfied my sweet tooth."

"A fair eatery within Phoenix's aerial hub,
Where kind service, pleasant ambiance, and tasty victuals are nigh.
I, a traveler weary from my journey's length,
Didst partake of their grilled fowl-filled pita, rich in garnish and sauce.
Their plugs, too, didst provide a convenient charge,
For devices that require an electrical discharge.
Verily, a fine dining experience, indeed,
In this airport oasis, all needs are heeded."

"Fair club, indeed, with beauty to behold,
Where men doth gather, and women doth unfold.
A night it was, when trade show came to town,
And men, they doth outnumber women, by a count of renown.
Fifty to one, the ratio didst seem,
A sight to behold, a scene most queer.
But still, the drinks didst flow, and merriment didst reign,
With friends, colleagues, and models, a joyous refrain.
The club, it doth have flaws, with drinks watered down,
And prices, they doth climb, like a mountebank's crown.
Yet, would I return? Aye, I wouldst say,
If entry doth not require, a secret way."

"Blossom, the joint serving up the best Peking duck in town, according to our server, takes two days to prep. Seventy-nine bucks a pop, so my expectations were high. I've had the real deal in Beijing, and this place didn't quite measure up. Duck came wrapped in skin and meat, sauce and all. Shoulda been just skin, if you ask me. Sauce was alright, but the skin wasn't crispy enough. They chopped the duck up after that, meat was juicy, but had a weird duck smell. Better than other SoCal spots like Duck House, but not worth the price tag."

"Ever fair, my dear. Pasta dish, pass thou by. Disappointment doth reign. 

A Pizzookie, half-cooked, they do proclaim. Alas, 'twas raw, scarce twenty percent tamed. 

I spoke to our waiter, Thomas, a poor soul, of this faux pas. He shrugged and walked away, his duty fled. Ill service, indeed. 

My rating, once four or five stars bright, doth now descend. Mayhap, another time, the service shall be worth the fight."

Thursday night, no wait for dinner. Fancy menu, but we went light - sandwiches, pastas, pizzas. Chicken buffalo wings, easy to eat. Pasta a la bolognaise, a mistake. Penne-like pasta, tomato and meat sauce, mediocre taste and presentation. Big portions, good service. Pizzas looked good. Maybe next time.

"A fair enough tavern, good for a merry meet,  
Or swinging by for supper, should thou so incline.  
But, alas! The drinks, they do come at a steep cost,  
And the victuals, they leave much to be desired, I find.  
The sandwiches, o'er salted, and the meat, not so fresh,  
Yet, if thou art but seeking ale or sport, 'tis a pleasant place to bide.  
And on karaoke nights, mirth doth reign supreme,  
So gather thy friends, and join in the jolly scheme."

"Hark, what news is this? A haven for the youth,
Where tea, once dull, now doth excite and unite.
In this, their HQ, all things are bright and gay,
Contrasting the dank, somber tea houses of old.
My thoughts on this place do change with each visit,
As does the tide, and fortune's whimsical bent.
At first, a youngling didst tell me to seek
Online, the answers to my queries, perchance to flee.
But later, kind employees didst lavish me
With the "DavidsTea experience", in all its glee.

A choice of teas, for home or to carry,
Doth await, with prices, some might deem too dear.
Yet, I chose a chocolate-orange blend,
With whisked soy milk and agave, to make amends.
Alas, the cost, four dollars and a half,
Didst make my heart sink, like tea leaves in a draught.
And alack, the brew that didn't fit the cup,
Didst meet its fate, in a sink, with nary a frown.

Was it good? Aye, 'twas epic, beyond compare,
But expensive, too, as some might declare.
This shop, for a quick caffeine fix, doth serve,
Yet, cramped it doth become, and a glass kettle, hard to preserve."

"Hark! What news is this? A thrifty rental car,
With service swift and sure, doth now avail.
A nail, most wicked, did attach itself
Unto my tire, rear and right, with stealth.
But fear not, for the roadside aid did come,
In five short minutes, swift as summer's wind.
And lo, the customer service, so bright,
Didst shine with excellence, in corporate light.
The car, exchanged in haste, did take but thirty minutes,
And I, the chooser, didst pick the new conveyance.
Methinks they heeded my words, with diligence,
For service now, doth seem, in fair improvement."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth come from mine own lips,
Of a hotel stay that did my patience test.
'Twas earlier this year, on business I did stray,
And found myself within these walls, a guest.

The check-in, oh how slow it did proceed,
As if the procedure were of ancient creed.
And when a delivery I didst require,
It came not swiftly, but with much delay and blunder.

I didst not partake in the restaurants' fare,
But chose instead a cafe, with pastries so fair and rare.
Yet, after a pair of days, the Frenchness didst wear,
And I didst find myself in search of something more to share.

The room, it was a bit above the rest,
But still, the hotel left me feeling quite depressed.
I would not choose to stay here again,
For pleasure's sake, my friends, I do declare."
"Antenna balls? Out. New ones coming, but no word on when. Picture didn't help much. Grabbed a Jumbo Jack instead. Tasted good, but not worth the trip from Canada."

"Underwhelmed, that's what I was at this joint in Scottsdale Quarter. Trendy, yeah, but too much like a Fox restaurant. Menu's small, unimpressive. Food? Meh. Interesting, sure, but not worth writing home about. Chicken? More like a sad thigh and drumstick. Soggy polenta. Spinach? Drowning in salt. Creative? Maybe. Tasty? Nah. Waitstaff confused. Extra apps we didn't order. Skimpy portions. Profit margins? Not my problem. Won't be back."
"Chinese take-out. Decent. Lo Mein, good. Shrimp, beef, good too. Shrimp and lobster sauce, no thanks. Ribs, hit or miss. Fatty, you know? Won ton, egg drop soup, nope. Fried rice, good. Rarely bad."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past, I didst venture to the first establishment in Fort Lauderdale, and by the stars, 'twas a wondrous experience! The victuals, they didst astound, and the atmosphere, it didst enchant. Alas, this place, it doth not compare, in sooth, 'twas a disappointment. A busy Wednesday eve in Florida, 'twas a quiet Monday night in Vegas, and we, but five tables occupied the tranquil space at eight o'clock. Forgive me, fair reader, for I do confess, methought the meatballs, dry they were, and pasta, undercooked, alack! The chicken parmesan, good, but naught more than passable, the sauce, still, most excellent. 

Marry, I find it passing strange, that near all praiseworthy reviews of this place do speak of Steve's presence. Mayhap his absence did affect the fare? Our server, kind and diligent, the grub, alas, did not meet expectations, set by...his own hand. Thus, three stars, I shall bestow, and though my hunger be sated, my heart doth yearn for the Florida site, where Steve doth reign, and all doth prosper."

"Hark! Gave Chang's another chance, and lo,
The service was improved, I must avow.
Friendly and efficient, they did strive,
And thus, my heart doth now forgive.

The Salt and Pepper Prawns we did share,
And Shrimp Fried Rice, a dish most fair.
Their food, though not the greatest, doth please,
And thus, my taste buds doth appease.

But alas, the service, once a woe,
Now doth shine, and all my doubts doth go.
A fortunate turn, indeed, doth bring,
And thus, my visits shall now cling.

Aye, even the fortune cookie, once bare,
Now doth contain a message, though quite rare.
A saying on a little piece of paper,
A small delight, yet still a treasure to capture."

"Decor clinches it for me—Mid Century modern, restaurant done well. Top spot for me and a mate to chow down and chat. Booths feel private, like our own little world. Chopped salad, love it. Green goddess dressing, incredible. Real-deal rolls and butter, soft and warm. Maybe I'm hooked on iced tea (still deciding), but they serve it right—big glass, mint, simple syrup, iced tea spoon. Simple things make the experience. Cake and shake for dessert, to die for. Tiny chocolate shake, tiny chocolate cake. Perfect little treat."

"A family restaurant, dull and uninspired,
The food, mediocre, the service, tired.
My pad, once crispy, now burnt to a crisp,
I'll not be eating there, no need to grip."

In this place, thou shalt find treasures both fair and foul,
A haven for thy purse, yet beware of the toll.
I purchased a trinket for my mother, a token of love,
A keychain of worth, for the price of twelve dollars above.
But alas, 'twas a curse, for it broke in her hand,
And twice it did fail, like a fleeting dream in the land.
I returned it with haste, and didst receive a card in exchange,
For cash was the payment, and no receipt could I arrange.
This shop, a gamble it be, with goods of varying worth,
Yet park thy steed with ease, within Tivoli's girth.

"Thai Rama, a small joint near the light rail, easy to miss. Big fan of Thai food, a little picky, wasn't sure what to expect. Menu was extensive, lots of options. Ordered F.B.I., friend bananas and coconut ice cream, didn't know what to expect. Food came quick, ice cream first, then shrimp pineapple curry. Ice cream was a bit too frozen, but still good. Curry was spot on, flavorful, but pineapple was canned, lacked freshness. Staff was friendly, wouldn't go out of my way to return, but if in the area, might stop by."
"Crew's what makes this joint tick. They're why I keep comin' back. Always doin' more than what's asked. That kinda service, it's rare."

"Dairy Queen, closest one to me. Brother and I, we hit it up regular. Shakes, blizzards, ice cream cakes when it's someone's b-day. Stuff's pretty good, I gotta say. But the staff? Mostly garbage. Rude, every time we come in. Don't matter though, I'm in it for the grub, not the service."

"Friday nights at Uncle Sal's, no reservation needed. Those days are history. Dinner was on me, and I blew it. Next door, Blind Pig saved the day. We shared plates, nibbled entrees. Steak salad, a winner. Short rib, well done. Tacos, fresh but unremarkable. If suggested, I wouldn't object. No wow factor, but nothing wrong either."

"We rolled in past midnight, the place still lit up, serving up grub. Service was slow, but hell, it was late. I don't recall what I had, maybe a steak, but that watermelon juice was damn good. Friendly service, prices a bit high, but that's Aria for you. We found better deals elsewhere."

"A plate of breakfast potatoes, au gratin potatoes, and veggie chow mein. Cover it all in melted butter. That's what the terrorists hate about America. Place was clean, service was decent. Food choices were standard for a downtown LV casino buffet - ordinary and plentiful. But that big vat of melted butter? You can put that stuff on anything."

"This joint's where you wanna end up after a night of tossin 'em back. Typical Mex food, not bad. Drive-thru was quick, no complaints there. But, man, they skimped on the Carne Asada fries. I mean, I've seen better portions at other spots. It was like they were tryin' to save a buck or somethin'. That was a bummer, for sure. Might give 'em another shot in a couple weeks, see if they step up their game."

"Aye, naught too wondrous didst I find,
In this place they call a 'fast food joint'.
Burgers, fair and juicy, yet not divine,
Onion rings, crispy and tasty, didst shine.
Price, alack, didst sting like a bee,
For what it was, in Vegas' glee."

"Food and service, both did please,
No qualms, nor grievances to seize,
In Vegas, burgers of better breed,
At prices more fair, thou shalt find indeed."

"I stop by here often, 'twixt my place and the folks'. Orders can be a crap shoot, me and the kids, ya know? Staff's always changin', but I reckon it's worth it for the convenience. Lines can get long, mornings especially, but they hustle folks through quick enough. Had to send drinks back once or twice, they were real sorry 'bout it, fixed it up pronto."

"Upon a Friday eve, I chanced to stray
Into this place, where people doth play
Their revelry, with mirth and glee
Amidst the din, a merry spree

The drinks, they did flow freely
And bartender, he did ply me
With concoctions of his art
Yet, alas, one drink did depart
From expectation, a trifle strange
The three wise men, he did not arrange

But fear not, for the music did play
A lively tune, to banish dismay
The DJ, he did spin his wheel
With skill and grace, did he reveal
His craft, a wondrous delight
To stir the crowd, in joyful sight

Yet, tacos, I did not partake
For those, my taste did not awake
But still, this place, I shall not shun
For drinks and music, it hath won"

"Into the OFM, we didst stroll, without a wait, part of the Westin Hotel's domain. The decor, quite pleasant to behold, yet the patrons, elsewhere they didst roam. Our server, most helpful and kind, suggestions didst give, for sushi rolls, a fine place to begin. Two tuna-based rolls, mild and spicy, didst satisfy. The cioppino, a dish of note, with mahi, cooked well, yet presentation, a stew it didst not make. Caesar salad, with anchovies on high, didst please. Waluu, a Hawaiian delight, didst earn praise. Crab cakes, tasty, didst they say. The experience, relaxed and friendly, service, quite fine. But food, besides sushi, a revival doth require, to compete with newcomers, in this culinary strife."

"Methinks 'tis an improvement, this new regime,
That doth bring back the old chefs, and serveth with glee.
A visit, perchance? Aye, verily, worth thy time,
But pray, good sir, cease thy hovering, lest thou doth impede
The sushi bar's bounty, and causeth the chefs to frown.
Forsooth, 'tis a sight most curious, to behold
Thy vigilance, as if thou dost fear o'er-generosity.
Alas, dear sir, have faith in those who doth prepare
The feast, that they shall not be overly lavish, nor spare.
So, let us raise our glasses, and give thanks for this change,
And mayhap, in time, thy trust shall be restored, and all shall range."

"Hark, good sir! I pray thee, tell me what thou didst order from yonder menu, that I may partake in this feast with thee."

"Marry, kind sir, I didst request two eggs, scrambled, if thou must know, and a dish of potatoes, all for a mere $3.85, a veritable steal! And, prithee, didst they not come with a slice of toast, and a side of home fries, to boot?"

"Indeed, they didst, my good fellow. The eggs, though scrambled, were quite plain, and the toast, a trifle burnt, I must confess. But, alack! The home fries, devoid of flavor, didst leave much to be desired. A sprinkle of salt and pepper, I didst add, yet still, they didst lack zest. A few bites, I didst take, then, with a sigh, didst push them aside."

"Twas early morn, when first I didst enter this establishment, and lo, 'twas empty, save for a scattering of regulars. Low key, indeed, the atmosphere didst seem. Aye, I couldst envision, how, after a night of revelry, one might seek refuge here, within these walls, open, as they are, throughout the night."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that, save for such nocturnal adventures, I wouldst not make it a point to visit Ritters, for, alas! They do accept naught but cash, and that, a pitfall, methinks, forsooth."

"Sunset Grille? Nah, not my cup of tea. Sure, it's got a swell atmosphere and the service is top-notch, but the grub's just alright. Had a salt-cured Canadian bacon that'll make your taste buds quiver, and the eggs benedict's ain't half bad either. But let's be real, there's better places to chow down in this town."

"Methinks 'tis better than Chipukele, but not by much, fair friends. The tortillas, hand-made before thine eyes, be indeed the crowning glory of this place. Sweet corn tortillas, fit for a king! Alas, the pork, too sweet it doth taste, and the shredded beef, but mediocre, I do declare. Rice and pinto beans, a feast for the gods! Verily, if Chipotle be thy only choice, choose this place, but else, 'twill soon be forgot, I fear."

"Airport food ain't always great, but this place wasn't half bad. Chicken sandwich was decent, not too greasy. Fried pickles, though - they were damn good. Crisp, warm, just the right amount of batter. Worth going back for, that's for sure. Price wasn't too steep either, considering it's an airport joint. And hey, free Wi-Fi and power outlets? That's a bonus. Charlotte Airport ain't so bad after all."

"Fare fit for a king, yet served in disarray,
With clamor and din that doth assault mine ears,
No place to rest mine eyes, for tables lay unclean,
And half the cost of PF Chang's, but dearth of cheer."

Hark! Methinks the luster of In-n-Out doth fade,
As I didst find this place to be no different made,
Than those I chanced upon in fair Califia's shade,
When youthful taste didst rule my gastronomic sway.
But now, alas! My palate doth crave more refined fare,
And though 'tis true, their burgers be decent, rare,
The hype and fame that doth surround this joint doth seem,
In truth, but empty words, a tempest in a teapot's scheme.

"Alas, my woeful state, with hangover's pall,
Did mar my visit to this famed eatery,
Where cramped seating did impede my joy,
Yet views of kitchen's bustle did assuage my sorrow.
Fare was good, but dear, thou must confess,
And early booking, else thou shalt be pressed.
Forsooth, a night ere mine own reservation,
A stranger offered me five hundred pieces,
A testament to this place's renown,
In popularity, it doth stand alone."

"Methinks 'tis a fair hotel, with virtues many and few vices.  Firstly, the breakfast, made-to-order, doth please mine eyes and stomach.  A ticket doth grant us access to the dining hall, where eggs, French toast, or pancakes, with potatoes and sausage or bacon, doth await our choosing.  And lo, a selection of cereals, oatmeal, bread, muffin, and fruit, with juice, milk, and coffee, doth round out the repast.

"The location, too, doth boast its charms.  'Tis situated close by the mall and eateries diverse, and the interstate, with ease of access, doth lie nearby.

"The chamber, spacious and well-appointed, doth provide a comfortable abode.  A kingly bed, with sleeper sofa, doth offer restful slumber, and a full refrigerator, stove, and microwave, doth make us feel at home.  Cleanliness, too, doth reign supreme within these walls.

"Alas, some drawbacks there be.  The room, upon entry, doth feel oppressively warm, and the air conditioning, though welcome, doth bring a chill too fierce.  Pillows, alas, doth lack the plumpness we desire, and two, alas, doth not suffice.  And, oh, the stairs, so steep and winding, doth pose a challenge to those with troublesome knees or burdens heavy.  An elevator, alas, doth not exist.

"Yet still, this inn doth earn our praise.  Not overly costly, nor too grand, it doth provide a pleasant sojourn for travelers weary."

"Hark! This eatery, grand and vast,
In Arizona, a place of renown,
A steakhouse, where meat doth reign supreme,
And patrons dine in luxury, it seemeth.

My friend, a server here, didst work,
His final shift, a bittersweet quirk,
For I, not fond of steakhouses, didst come,
To share this moment, and bear him company.

The atmosphere, a blast from the past,
A 70s vibe, that doth evoke the vast,
Retro feel, like an Arizona mobster's lair,
Dark, cozy, and inviting, without a care.

I ordered a shrimp salad, oh so fine,
With crunchy, juicy shrimps, a treat divine,
Saved them for last, a delightful surprise,
A culinary joy, that doth open eyes.

My roommate's sirloin, a tale of woe,
Twice sent back, a disappointment, no doubt,
But the bread basket, a saving grace,
Rosemary-topped, light, fluffy, a delightful pace.

And the best part of the night, a treat,
A beer for.5 cents, a Foursquare feat,
Our waiter, kind, a generous soul,
Didst hook us up, at the table, our goal."

"Methinks 'twas a fair day at Mandalay Bay,
Where prices for lunch were quite reasonable, I say.
And lo, the wait time for our party of ten,
Was less than ten minutes, a feat most wondrous, my friend.

The burgers, they were good, I must confess,
But after thirteen miles, all food wouldst be blessed.
Yet, alack, they were out of sweet potato fries,
A disappointment, indeed, that caused many sighs.

The service, too, was slow, I must avow,
Despite the lack of patrons, a curious thing, now.
We had to seek out servers to bring us drink,
And wait for orders, a tedious, lingering link.

Some dishes, too, were not prepared aright,
Onions added when they should not have been in sight.
Salads came after entrees, a strange, confusing course,
And some meals arrived five to eight minutes in advance,
A disarray, a chaos, a state most unfortunate,
Leaving us unsure if we'd return, in truth, anon."

Hark! Steak and Eggs, a meal most fine,
After a night of mirth and revelry, doth shine.
A place to rest thy weary head, and fill thy belly too,
Before thou dost retire to thy hotel room anew.

The food, though cheap, doth satisfy,
And though the quality may not be the highest, 'tis nigh.
But fear not, for the wait, it doth decrease,
As those ahead of thee, do leave their place, in search of ease.

Their patience doth wear thin, as they do wait,
And nearby slot machines, do call their fate.
So put thy name on the list, and wait with glee,
For soon, thy turn shall come, and thou shalt eat with glee.
"Almond taro milk tea, not bad. Popcorn chicken, not what I expected. Breaded pieces, leftover."
"Chicken good. Service bad. Cashiers snooty. Drive-thru messy. Girl gross."

Sunday afternoon, football and grub on the mind. Got a seat at the bar, quick and painless. Portions, big. Classics and specials, interesting. Food, just okay. Did the job, but not worth coming for. Service, terrible. Our server, Randi, nice but confused. Bill issues, long wait. Manager, MIA. Finally comped, thanks to gambling. Good for sports, bad for food.
"Pizza's alright, some's better'n others. But let's be real, none're that great. Place used ta be cleaner, but now? Service's slippin'. Cinnamon rolls though? Can't get enough. Keeps me comin' back."

"'Tis a tiny, cramped space, full of folk,
Serving dishes cheap, yet mediocre, at best.
A place of little note, save for the throngs
That gather there, their pennies to expend.

But, alas! The praise it doth receive,
Doth far exceed its worth, in my opinion.
For though the fare be fair, 'tis naught but grease,
And the atmosphere, most uninviting.

So, if thou seekest sustenance of quality,
Best look elsewhere, lest thou be sorely vexed.
For this place, though full of life and bustle,
Doth fall short of true culinary delight."

"Summer nights got you down? Head to a Hounds game. Cheap prices, good people, and a chill vibe. Lacrosse may not be the most exciting sport to watch, but the Hounds play hard. Bring a friend, grab a drink, and enjoy the summer evening. Props to the Hounds for using Memorial Stadium too. Keeping the old girl alive and kicking."

"Methinks 'tis a passable tavern, good victuals they serve. Naught but the ordinary at the bar, naught that doth astound. A place of gathering for the locals, oft full of mirth and cheer. Some patrons, mayhap, do partake in ale a bit too freely, yet harmless they be."
"Pizza prices too steep. Twenty-six bucks for a large? Ridiculous. Athens pizza, down the road, better and cheaper. Tastes better too."
"Chinese food, good to have after a few buffets. Came for lunch, prices steep for Chinese and dim sum, but comped, so didn't matter. Salmon cold noodle, superb. Rest, slightly above average."

"A hearty tavern, full of cheer and glee,
Where honest folk do gather, 'tis plain to see.
No fancy trimmings, nor high-falutin' fare,
Just stiff drinks and victuals, fit for a king's share.

The barkeep, a jolly soul, with wit so bright,
Doth serve the patrons with a smile so light.
No airs or graces, but a friendly demeanor,
Maketh one feel welcome, like a neighbor.

'Tis a place to watch a game, or share a tale,
With comrades old, or new friends met by chance.
After a long day's toil, 'tis a haven, a respite,
To quaff a pint, and let the world slide out of sight."

"Methinks the raves for this eatery did pour forth like a river in springtime. Service, it did excel, and with our meal, a medley of veggies didst accompany. Fried dumplings, we didst begin with, and though delectable, the filling, I didst wish for more. Bibimbap, a sizzling stone pot didst bring, with beef, alas, in scant supply. Rice, the dish didst mostly compose, leaving the beef and veggies in scarcity. A change, I do suggest, to augment the beef and veggies, and reduce the rice, that all may partake in a feast most bounteous."
"Beans and cheese, decent. Cheese, cold and unmelted. Oil instead of lard, a plus. Green salsa, good. Chips, a small side, would be nice. Hard tacos, good. Lettuce, too much, filled half the shell."

"3 Stars. Big joint, nice decor. Cold outside, but upstairs balcony looked sweet. Two rooms, two DJs - one hip hop, one top 40. Main room DJ, terrible. Beat matching? Forget it. New Year's Day in Vegas, expected better. Staff, nice though. Cover charge, steep - $40 weekends, $20 ladies. Bouncer, cool. Let girl in free, I paid $40. Normal Vegas club pricing, I guess. Wouldn't go back, too many other clubs to try."

"Hark, I dined at this eatery (take out) and savored their pad tai and PH\u00d2. The establishment was radiant, newly-built, and charming. The service was exceedingly cordial and punctual. The pad tai met my expectations, and I sampled my comrade's beef, which was equally delectable. Alas, I had been craving PH\u00d2, as it is scarce on the NW side, and my health required it. Oh, how my anticipation was deflated! Upon opening the container, the broth lacked its characteristic scent, and upon sipping, it tasted overly sweet and viscous, revolting! Moreover, the color was an unsettling shade of brown, despite my request for chicken PH\u00d2. I attempted to salvage the dish by adding noodles and seasonings, but alas, the odor and flavor were too much to bear. I drained the liquid and consumed the noodles instead. Verily, I would have bestowed five stars upon this venue, had it not been for the wretched PH\u00d2. Methinks perhaps I visited on an unfavorable day."

"Hark! A place for cheap drinks during happy hour, my dear? A tiny bar, indeed, with patrons who do imbibe. 'Tis a smoky, noisy den, full of those who take their drinks quite seriously. Locals gather here, and 'tis a sight to behold. Entertainment may be hit or miss, but the crowd itself doth provide mirth. I've had some tasty dishes herein, and free popcorn doth await within the indoor bar. Pray, bring thine own plastic darts, for the dartboard doth not always cooperate. The staff, kind and friendly, doth ensure a pleasant visit."

"Hark! What eatery doth reign supreme?
In this fair land of T-Bird and 59th Ave,
A question doth arise, and thus it seems,
Why doth Del-Taco trouble itself to be?

Chipotle, a name of quality and renown,
Doth serve the masses with its tasty fare,
Bean or veggie burritos, a choice most sound,
Yet, alas! They doth upcharge with such glee,
For chips and salsa, a price most steep,
Eight dollars, a sum most dear, doth be,
For a meal most simple, coke, chips, and salsa,
A cost most high, a price most rude, doth be.

This place, a tidy keep, a duty doth impose,
To keep the dining space, in order, doth dispose."

"Went to Daisho sushi twice. First time it opened, second time tonight. Nigiri was fresh, green tea ice cream was good. Service was alright. Rolls lacked flavor. Maybe we ordered wrong. Live across the street, thought I'd give it a shot. Still prefer my regular sushi spot for the same price."

"Drove past this joint plenty of times, curiosity got the better of me. Walked in, wasn't hungry, just wanted a loaf of sourdough. Few days before Christmas, place was busier than usual, no big deal. Waited 10 minutes to pay, that's pushing it. Workers were slow, I've been in retail, you don't keep customers waiting. Bread was damn good though, might go back."

"Hark! My kin and I, we do adore
The victuals served at this establishment.
We oft pass through the drive-thru gate,
And our repasts are fresh, hot, and savory, by fate.
But of late, the elder woman, with brows so dark,
Who tends the window, doth wear a scowl, most stark.
She doth act as though each request, a burden be,
With haughty mien, and words of disdain, doth she speak.
A new Mexican eatery, further down Greenway,
Hath opened its doors, to chase away
The foul mood that doth plague this place, alack!
Three stars, Rivas! Attend to thy demeanor, ere thou dost lose all thy clientele!"

"Place was big inside, got seated quick despite the crowd. Ordered drinks fast, menu came soon after. Got the AYCE for $20, good deal since most rolls were $10+ each. Quality was average, presentation was meh. Had to ask multiple times for refills and bill. Food was good for the price, service was slow. Will give 'em another shot in a bit, maybe they were having an off night."

"In fair Las Vegas, where revelry doth reign,
Amidst the splendor, doth this eatery remain.
No fine dining here, nor cause for delight,
Tis but a humble abode, for hunger's plight.

I chanced upon the prosciutto sandwich,
And found it met my hopes, no more, no less.
A crusty baguette, prosciutto di parma,
Mozzarella, arugula, and balsamic, all in harmony.
A simple meal, swiftly served, and thus it ends.

The cheese pizza, alas, did suffer fate,
For lack of time in oven, made it soggy, quite.
Yet still, 'twas devoured, with nary a complaint,
For hunger's pangs, do make the taste buds faint."

"Hark! A fortnight past, a friend and I didst step within these walls, On a Tuesday eve, when all the world didst doth its business. And lo! The place was ours, save for a maid, Heidi, kind and fair. We didst converse with ease, and she didst join in our cheer. I didst order thus: an Oggie, mushy peas, and chips of potato. The victuals were not wondrous, but neither didst they dismay. The pasty, dry; the wine gravy, strange; the beef, lean but tough. Yet ciders, Strongbow and Hoegaarden, didst please mine taste. And when the night didst wear on, we didst essay the dartboard, a sport most pleasant. In conclusion, 'tis a place to share a drink and merriment with friends, and on a busier night, the crowd doth make a lively scene."
"Vegas, not bad. But, let's be real, the bread's off. Fix that and we're talking a damn good sandwich."
"Needed grub before MJ show. Bar seemed quicker. Bartender took her time, but service was good once she showed. Had kobe beef fries with chili and cheese. Satisfying. Decent spot for sports too."

"Avalon, hit or miss. Prices, sometimes hard to grasp. T-shirt, holes, $14. Thrifty, not exactly. Lower prices, yes, sometimes. Buying process, mysterious. In-style clothes, rejected. Grandma's clothes, accepted. Mixed bag, always. Worth a visit, yes."

"Hark! What store is this? A veritable treasure trove of beauty supplies, it doth seem. Twice the size of others, with products galore, it doth astound. 

Upon my recent visit, after work, three employees didst attend to customers' needs. One didst greet me, though her mien didst not bespeak great enthusiasm, she didst show courtesy. 

My purpose, swift and simple, to procure nail polish, using the $5 coupon gained from joining their club, didst not require aid. The cashier, kind and cheerful, didst tally my purchase, and I shall return anon."

"Gilley's. Cheap Jameson, decent grub, fun patio. Been there a few times now. First with Dana S - you know, Some Hot Bitch. We laughed at karaoke, drank cheap whiskey. Went back for more drinks and food recently. Nachos were alright, like Taco John's. Chicken strips were frozen and fried, but the vinegary sauce was good. Had some jalapeno grits too, they were the best part. Not a bad spot, but not the best either. The Strip has better options, but in a pinch, Gilley's isn't terrible."

"Hark, fair readers, listen well to my tale,
Of a club visited, where celebrities did prevail.
The dance floor, small as it may be,
Did not deter us, for the music, a delight to me.

A place to chill, with champagne flowing free,
Girls entered without cost, a sweet ecstasy.
On Valentine's weekend, we did prepare to leave,
But LMFAO appeared, our spirits did retrieve.

We stayed the night, their performance, a treat,
A memory to cherish, forever to keep.
My friends, too, have visited, in days past,
Far East Movement, their sight, did truly last.

So, choose your weekends wisely, dear friends,
For celebrities abound, till the very end."

"Jimmy John's subs, perfect for lunch. Get 'em delivered or grab 'em quick at the shop. Secret tip: opt for the tasty nine-grain bread instead of the standard white roll. I always go for the beach club - turkey, provolone, tomato, lettuce, and guac. Love the guac option. Veggie sub's a winner too - sprouts, cheese, tomato, cucumber, and more guac. And don't forget the cookies, especially the chocolate chip. They're huge and delicious."

"A fair and pleasant place, where one may find solace in a steaming bowl of corn chowder, 'tis true, the service doth lag, yet the fare doth make amends. A varied menu, with choices most fair, and staff, who doth strive to please. Their breads and muffins, too, are worth the try. For breakfas', lunch, or e'en dinner, 'tis a goodly spot, I do declare."

"Went to Enso for lunch with a buddy. Ginger salad, standard fare. Sushi, pretty but unremarkable. Spider roll, damn good. Atmosphere, too dark, trying too hard to be upscale. Run by Yanks, zero authenticity. Spent a hundred bucks, no booze. Good, but not worth it. Hit up New Zealand Cafe for better sushi at half the price."

"I dig their sandwiches, man. Turkey, ranch, and bacon - that's my jam. But, you know what sucks? Those new Coke machines they got. Every time, it's like lime juice in my drink. No bueno. Can't even let it run for a bit, still tastes nasty. That's a bummer, 'cause the sandwiches and staff are top-notch. Guess I'll have to stick to takeout."

"We hit up this joint hoping to score some prime rooftop real estate, but they told us we could only order takeout and sit up there if we cleaned up after ourselves. What a bummer. The service was alright, our waitress was nice but a bit scatterbrained. She brought us two beers when we only ordered one. The grub was meh, not terrible but nothing special. Had the pork queso dip, which was solid, but not as spicy as I like. I'd order it again, though. I went for the Cuban, but the lettuce and tomato killed the flavor of the BBQ. Once I ditched the veggies, the BBQ was decent. Hubby got the straight BBQ sandwich and liked the meat, but it wasn't anything to rave about. This place isn't worth regular visits, but I won't complain if someone else suggests it."

"My crew and I hit up this WH spot after a night of ragin'. It's not much to write home about, just your typical greasy spoon fare. But the service is top-notch and it's got this vibe that makes my hangover feel a little better."
"This place, it's like Mars. Red rocks, jagged, rough. But it's in Arizona. That's the problem."

"Methinks 'tis hard to render judgment on this place,
For though our server was most excellent and bright,
And we didst enjoy the victuals and drink, alack,
Two of our number didst fall ill, in truth quite wight.

A plague upon the mussels, say I, forsooth,
That dish didst bring us naught but woe and blight.
We hadst crab cakes, short ribs, arancinis too,
Gnocchi with lobster, and potato, all in view.

In sooth, I didst enjoy each dish, save the arancinis,
Which didst taste of port wine, a bit too keen.
The drinks we hadst, from Braddock's smash to moscow mule,
Were pleasant, and the manhattan, make thine own, a rule.

This hotel restaurant, within The Renaissance,
Didst boast an eclectic, upscale ambiance, in sooth.
But, alas, the food poisoning doth mar the score,
And thus, this review doth merit but three stars, no more."

"Tucked away on Howe Street, this unassuming watering hole is a local favorite. Inside, it's cozy and well-appointed, perfect for sipping a pint or two. The menu offers hearty pub grub, ideal for soaking up the previous night's indulgences. Though I'm not one for sports bars, The Standard's atmosphere makes it a great spot for catching a game. It gets packed during rugby season, so plan accordingly."

"Chili's, a place I visit with family and friends, about twice a month. Bell and 7th St., or 27th Ave and 101, are the spots we hit up. Food's decent, chips and salsa, a good deal. Green chile and enchilada soups, top-notch. But, service at North Valley Parkway, a kink. Orders messed up, waitresses friendly, but clueless about the menu. Food takes forever, no apologies. Try again, a few months later, same issues. Wait time for food, ridiculous. Drink refills, a pipe dream. Last Saturday, nice waitress, friendly greeters, food as expected. 90 minutes for soup and salad, water to drink. Four times, same problem, not a coincidence. Chili's on 7th St., great service, normal wait time. Hope it changes, a decent spot."

"A fair spread of victuals, fit for a king,
The sashimi, fresh as spring's sweet blossoms sing.
Chinese delights, cooked to perfection, swift,
Crab legs, a feast, and plentiful, no need to rift.
Spring rolls, alas, did not impress, nor dumplings too,
But still, this buffet, worth a visit, 'twill do.

Heed the sign, ere thou dost fill thy plate,
Lest thou be charged, and cursed be thy fate.
For taking more than thou canst eat, a sin,
An extra fee, eight dollars, thou shalt win.

Yet still, this place, a recommendation, I give,
For Chinese buffets, 'tis one that doth live."

"Pied Au Corchon full up? Fear not, fair friends! Here lies a worthy substitute, indeed. 

A feast for senses, this eatery doth provide, with dishes fresh and well-prepared, in portions moderate, and ambiance rustic, yet refined. But, alas, slow service doth plague, and noise doth fill the hall. 

My own repast, a veritable delight! Veal heart tartar, fresh and full of flavor, did please my taste, though lacking somewhat, I knew not what. Thin fries, crispy and well-salted, accompanied, and raw vegetables, finely sliced, beneath a vinaigrette. For sweet conclusion, shared apple tarte, nicely presented, with apples vinegared, and sorbet, a tiny scoop, yet pleasant, upon its top. Not extraordinary, but pleasant, hot, and flaky of crust. 

In conclusion, worth the cost, this place doth stand, a noble alternative to renowned eateries in Le Plateau."

"A cup of coffee, brewed in French press style, did taste like water, alas, with dregs of grounds within. A breakfast place, where mornings start afresh, should serve a brew most fine, nay, excellent. Alas, the coffee I didst receive, was far from meetin' expectations. \n\nAnd, by the name, a place called Morning Squeeze, one would suppose, did offer freshly squeezed or blended juices, but nay, 'twas not the case. Mayhap, they shall make adjustments, and raise their standards, ere long. The place, indeed, doth possess a pleasant atmosphere."

This joint's got real potential. TVs are set up nice, even in the can. I'd give it five stars easy if they stepped up the grub and had a better selection of brews and hard stuff. I've asked for Crown Royal Cask 16, Jack Daniel's Honey, Kraken, Captain Morgan Private Stock, Jack Daniel's Single Barrel, but they don't have any of 'em. Half Moon, hello! Not everyone's looking for bottom-shelf swill. Fix these two problems, and I'll give it another look. Five stars, easy.
"Settled in, ordered a Caesar. Snack between meals, nice dressing but a bit too much seasoning. Casual spot."

In fair Champaign, where culinary delights do abound,
A Korean eatery did catch my eye, 'twas a new foundling.
Their menu, laminated and neat, didst display their fare,
But alas, no pictures, only words, didst leave me in despair.

I chose the combo platter, bulgogi, priced at nine ninety-nine,
And waited patiently, as the minutes didst slowly combine.
The dish arrived, with rice aplenty, and two ban chae beside,
A bean soup too, all for my pleasure, didst my senses decide.

The bulgogi, well-seasoned, yet the meat, in small slices lay,
Detracting from its worth, I must say, in dismay.
Prices, my wife doth claim, have risen since her college days,
Alas, a slight above average, in my culinary ways.

Pros: Average price, large portions, a Korean feast,
Cons: Long cook time, prices higher, than other eateries at least.
A hidden gem: Your meal, with rice, soup, and two ban chae doth come,
A pleasant surprise, indeed, for those who do arrive.

"Grub's a crapshoot. Afternoons, it's a miss - salty fries, flavorless meat. But nighttime, it's a hit - sandwiches are solid. Ribs, when they got 'em, are a joke. Don't drink, so can't speak to the bar. Just the grill."

In fair Arizona, where I didst roam,
I sought to savor local dishes, home.
The Fry Bread House didst beckon me,
To taste the native cuisine, I couldst see.

Their fried bread, freshly made, didst delight,
With spices that didst ignite my sight.
I found it good, though fiery hot,
A flavor that didst make my senses trot.

Alas, I cannot recommend a dish,
For I didst only sample one, in truth's fish.
But if thou seekst a tasty treat,
The flatbread, there, doth can't be beat.

"This Bruegger's joint, it's top-notch. Better than the one down the street, that's for sure. Friendly staff, quick service, and a damn fine cup of coffee. They got all the usual suspects on the menu - bagels, sandwiches, soup, you name it. And some nice booths by the window, perfect for watching the world go by."

"Methinks the air is full of cheer,
And prices, fair and not too dear.
Wine-a-ritas, diverse and tasty,
Yet, alack, not quite up to par.
Local vintages, light and crisp,
But, prithee, not my cup of tea.
I do confess, I hold CA wines
In higher esteem, and thus,
Their price doth seem a mite steep.
Aye, the pinot grigio, a gem,
Yet, at $25, a trifle dear.
I shall return, and next time,
The flight, for $6, I shall espie."
"Average sushi joint. Nice bar, limited seats. Good sushi, nothing special. On par with Ra, but not as great as Sakana. Struggled with giving it four stars, but it's just too average."
"Wings great. Sadly, closed. Slow service killed 'em."
"Pizza was decent. Wings were dry, but I'll give 'em a pass. Sauce was good. Still searchin' for a taste of New York in this town."
"Food, great as always. New digs, nice. Chairs, uncomfortable as hell. Music, too damn loud. Can't hear a thing. Get some decent seats and turn down the noise, or I'm taking my grub to go."

Sally's is where we go when the night's still young. It's the only joint in town that's still cookin' after midnight. The grub's not bad either - burgers, fries, and some killer onion rings. But let's be real, we don't come here for the food. We come for the atmosphere. It's like steppin' into a time machine, with all the old motorcycles and 50s knick-knacks on the walls. And the staff? They're always friendly, like they're glad to see us. The booths are comfy, and the ice? Man, that stuff's like crack. I know, I know, it's a strange thing to get excited about, but damn, it's good. All in all, Sally's is a solid spot to kill some time and have a good time. If they'd just let us smoke inside, I'd give 'em five stars, but I guess that's not their call to make.

"Place ain't bad. Music's a mix. Oldies, hip hop, rap, rock. Went on a Friday night. Half the crowd's a bit rough. Dance floor's small. But they give away free stuff to them that wait in line early. Clothes, but not much. Maybe 15 total. One per person. Good spot for local ladies. Free, you know?"

"Hark! I say, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For I have tale to tell, of culinary spell,
In Phoenix, city of the sun, where heat doth dwell,
I've lived for thirty years, and know it well.

To Old Town, we didst venture, with friends in tow,
For Restaurant Week, a night of gastronomic vow,
But alas, fair readers, we shall not return,
For though the service was attentive, ambiance did burn.

The tables, cramped and close, didst make us feel,
As if in marketplace, amidst the din and deal,
And noise, it didst ascend, to levels high,
Not quite the intimate dining, we didst espy.

The food, it was good, but not of home run fame,
My venison, raw within, a surprise came,
Not cooked, as I had thought, my preference being,
Medium-well, yet raw, it didst my taste buds sting.

My dining partner, her meat, didst send back,
For cooking, medium rare, her desire, didst attack,
A dessert of foie gras and donuts, strange, it was,
None of us, didst enjoy, such sweet, surpass.

Cocktails, we didst not partake, but tempting, they didst seem,
Yet, regular menu, prices high, for servings small, didst deem.
Once, it was worth, our trial, thus, we didst conclude,
In Phoenix, other eats, our taste buds, may yet, induce."

"Methinks we dined at Vogue but late, my dear,
And found the victuals to be of great cheer.
I had the meatloaf, juicy and sweet,
My spouse, the lasagna, rich and neat.
We shared the calamari, alas, a woeful sight,
Fried tempura, drowned in grease, a sorry plight.
The ginger'mongst the carrots, a delight,
But little calamari, a sorrow to behold,
Our waiter, courteous, yet his manner cold.
We felt unwelcome, as if to say,
'Depart, good sirs, and tarry not, I pray.'
But nay, the entrees, worth each penny,
A verity, a truth, a certainty."

"After one visit, I must confess,  
The ambiance was quite pleasant, I must profess.  
The decor was lovely, but the lighting, alas,  
Was dark, and made it hard to see, I do surmise.  

The service, oh how it did excel,  
With Pin Kaow, I must give them a bell.  
Their table touches, though, did border on the extreme,  
Five people checked on us within five minutes, it did seem.  

The food, it was a mixed bag, I do declare,  
The chicken satay, grilled perfectly, beyond compare.  
The peanut sauce, authentic, yet lacked a certain flair,  
A flat taste, that left me not entirely aware.  

Tom Ka Koong, a rich and sour broth,  
With coconut milk, lemongrass, mushrooms, and shrimp, in truth.  
A delicate balance, that not all may enjoy,  
For some, it may be too sour, and thus destroy.  

Roasted rice beef, a new concept, indeed,  
With cabbage, Thai basil, and spices, it did proceed.  
Crushed rice, roasted, and scattered on the beef,  
An interesting texture, a unique experience, in belief.  

Chicken yellow curry, delicious, I must say,  
A dish that pleased my palate, in a major way.  

Overall, a B+, I must aver,  
Hoping to return, and try more dishes, I do endeavor."

"Monroe Hardware's alright, but it ain't no old-time general store like Mast Drug or Renfrow's. And it sure ain't no Home Depot or Lowe's neither. It's stuck in between, like a fish outta water. I ain't been to the Monroe location, just the one in Mint Hill. But let me tell ya, it's a mighty big space, used to be a Winn Dixie. Feels like they're tryin' to fill a hole with a thimble. Staff's friendly, but they got too much ground to cover. It's like they're stretched thin, ya know? On the bright side, it's just a stone's throw from my place. But if I'm lookin' for a real project, I'll probaby hit up Home Depot or Lowe's while I'm out and about."

"Hark! This Dillard's doth now serve but one purpose,
A place where last season's finery doth find its haven.
The lower floor, once bustling with life and cheer,
Now lies dormant, empty, and devoid of light.

Upstairs, the racks doth brim with garb of renown,
Designers' names doth grace each hanger and gown.
Fourty percent, the least of discounts doth show,
Fifty and seventy-five, the larger sums doth flow.

By size, the clothes doth hang, a sight to see,
In Michael Kors, a top of quality doth be.
Eighteen, the price doth drop, from fifty's height,
A steal, indeed, a bargain of great might.

Bedding, accessories, and shoes doth fill the space,
But alas, the footwear doth leave much to trace.
For those with small or large feet, choices doth lack,
Or gaudy styles, which doth not appeal to all, alack."

"I ain't no Vegas gal, that's for sure. Went with a friend who knew the ropes, so we skipped the line and cover. Wasn't wearin' heels, neither, on account of a pinched nerve in my back. Bouncer almost didn't let me in, but I had on some cute flats. View from the club was decent, but not worth the price of admission. Dance floor was packed, drinks were expensive. You gotta shell out for a table if you don't want strangers touchin' you all night. If you're gonna go, grab a few bottles of liquor from the CVS across the street and get a good buzz goin' before you show up."

"Hark! Bravo, a chain of renown, doth provide
A salad decent, upon which I do rely.
Their reservations, a blessing, doth save me time,
From lines long, and waits of forty-five.

I do confess, their Romano crusted chicken,
And balsamic chicken, doth please my taste.
Their Parmesan dressing, a delight, doth make me keen
To try and recreate it, in my own place.

Alas, their entrees, too salty, doth not appeal,
But still, I stop by, to grab a salad, and revel.
The parking, abundant, doth ease my mind,
A boon, indeed, when shopping, or movies to find."

"Tasty black bean tacos, two bucks. Better than any burrito in Manhattan, but not as good as some spots in Phoenix. Went before First Fridays, patio was cute all lit up at night. Server chatted with us about Shark Week, good times."

"Jamie C. and I agree. Gotta come back for my final decision. Server was top-notch, wish I'd gotten his name. Sangria was good, two glasses worth. Michael wasn't sold on his mojito, switched to Stella. Shared calamari and blue corn chicken enchilada, both tasty. Sauces were great, ate it all. Enchiladas were good too. Want to try more shared plates, will be back."

"Alas, poor Kamakura, why doth thou bear such malice? 

Verily, 'tis a place of fond memories, a family fave, 
For years, my sire didst take us there, when sushi was new, 
And we didst return, for special days, with joy anew. 
The teppan, we didst savor, with delight and glee, 
But now, alack, the charm doth seem to flee. 
The chefs, perchance, do lack their former zeal, 
Or mayhap, 'tis but my own perspective doth reveal. 
Yet still, they thrive, despite the negative word, 
For in LA, a 3.5-star rating, they wouldst have heard. 
And so, I say, give Kamakura a chance, 
For 'tis a place of wonder, in this fair land of Japan."

"A shop most fair and full of wondrous things,
Where gifts of wit and whimsy take flight.
But alas, dear friend, beware the cost,
For prices here do mount, and quickly lost.

Yet still, in times of need, this place doth save,
When gifts of old seem dull and stale.
The staff, so kind and full of grace,
Do make the visit worth thy time and space.

And though the room was bare, 'twas fate,
Not lack of shoppers, nor a sign of hate.
For in this place, a card didst I find,
To celebrate a friend's grand milestone, divine."

"Got the Gold Standard, he got the Longhorn. Pricey dogs, minimal toppings. No Buldogis, look it up. Won't regret it. Edible, satisfied hunger, but that's it. Las Vegas Pinks, below them. Helpful staff, pleasant. High prices, the strip. Skip it, unless you're a hot dog fiend."

"TIP: Free Wi-Fi here, but it's spotty. Only fly Southwest at McCarran - disjointed layout. Two gates for Southwest, so you might have to hustle to the other side of the airport. Rental car center requires a shuttle, waste of time. Fox Rental Car is separate from the center, avoid them. Cheap rentals in Vegas anyway."
"Dinner here last week. Good reviews brought us in. Food was good, not great. Duck stood out, steak was just okay. Cheese plate, excellent. Service, top-notch. Give 'em another shot before judging."

"Fare priced high, yet nourishment doth please. Duck, roasted, lacked moisture, skin not crisp. Pork, sweet and sour, did delight. Rice of coconut, delectable dish, worth every penny. Thirty pieces of silver, steep price to pay. Will return, for coconut rice, a dish divine. Next time, satay shall be mine."

"Brisket with nacho fries and an outlaw burger, that's what I ordered. My cousin got the same burger, but without the fries. He ordered after me, but his food came first. Someone else, who ordered after me too, got their burger before mine. I asked the waiter why, and he just shrugged it off, saying mine was on its way. Ten minutes passed, still no burger. Finally, after another ten minutes, I got my food. The fries were good, the burger was great. But the service? Not so much. They messed up my order and tried to cover it up. Would I come back? Sure, but I hope the service improves."

"I come here with big groups or when I can't decide what I want. They got a little bit of everything. I've had a few things on the menu, all pretty good. Not amazing, but not bad either. Chicken Madeira and Farfalle with chicken and roasted garlic are my go-to's. Tell 'em to ease up on the garlic though. And their cheesecake? Always good. Different flavors, but I ain't never met a piece I didn't finish."

"Davio's dinner didst leave me unimpressed,
Service, a vital part of any feast,
Didst falter, like a play with too much repetition,
Leaving me to feel as though at Eat 'N Park I didst dine.
Fare, just passable, yet not of high quality,
Akin to others of its ilk, in taste and presentation lacking.
Server, unskilled and ignorant of menu's contents,
A poor substitute for one who knows his duties and can present.
Time, a precious commodity, best spent elsewhere,
At Arlecchino or Alla Familia, a better choice, I do declare."

In fair Paris, I didst tarry three nights,
And asked for a chamber with kingly bed,
But they didst give me a room with twain queens instead,
Which brought me discomfort, and my rest didst mar.

The next day, they didst move me to a room with a king,
Whose bed was not so bad, and I didst find solace within.
The rooms were clean, and the bathrooms, too,
With showers closed, and a tub, wherein I couldst renew.

The TV hadst some good channels, and the sound was clear,
But alas, the elevators didst work with great speed,
My view was of the airport, not so grand, I fear,
But the location of the hotel was most excellent, indeed.

I didst use their spa services, and wrote a review apart,
And found the restaurants in Paris to be a work of art.
I recommend climbing the Eiffel Tower high,
For the view from the top is most wondrous to the eye.

The monorail metro is nearby, a convenience, indeed,
But my only sorrow was that they wouldst not let me use the spa on the day I didst depart, which didst cause me great need.
Yet, in conclusion, 'tis a good place to stay,
In the heart of Paris, where one can find delight in every way.

"Came back to this joint a few days after my first visit. Place still looked swell, but the drinks were weak. Beer and wine glasses were modern, but the pours were stingy. Ordered the Louisiana Chicken pasta and Bibimbap. The chicken pasta was rich, maybe 2,000-3,000 calories, but damn good. Felt like I was at Applebee's though. The Bibimbap was a letdown. Missing the hot stone bowl, it was just a mediocre salad. Will give it another shot, but need some time to rethink the menu."

"Distrito, a place of some renown, doth fail to impress, its energy lacking, akin to a still pond. The decor, too, doth leave much to be desired, with darkness and lounge-like atmosphere that doth border on tedium.

We began our feast with guacamole and chips, the latter oversalted, nigh inedible. Yet, I did consume them, brushing off the excess salt with mine own fingers. The former two, however, did please our taste buds.

Next, we ventured onto vegetable tacos, a pleasant delight, and a Mexican flatbread, adorned with mushrooms and a sauce of huitlacoche. Both dishes did satisfy our hunger. Alas, the rice, with corn, cream, and habaneros, a Mexican risotto of sorts, did fall short of our expectations, owing to an overabundance of salt.

Distrito doth offer a diverse array of margaritas, and we did sample the watermelon-cucumber and cilantro varieties, finding them both agreeable.

The service, we had heard, could be a trial, yet we did receive fair, if unremarkable, attention from the staff.

In conclusion, Distrito did not prove a memorable experience for us, and we do not yearn to return."
"Good grub, but no credit cards and stingy coffee refills means I won't be back too often."

In days of yore, when I didst dwell in fair Arizona,
I chanced upon Aunt Chilada's, a place of gastronomic wonder.
With friend in tow, I didst venture forth, and dined with glee,
But first, we didst don plastic forks, and combed our locks with glee.
A jest, a quip, a merry prank, we thought it to be,
But alas, our visages were marred, in such a state of disarray.
I know not why, but we didst deem it wise,
To groom our tresses with a fork, in such an unwise guise.
The victuals, neither here nor there, didst fail to impress,
A mediocre fare, yet palatable, and thus I shall express.
A "meh" experience, it was indeed, but not so vile,
That I wouldst advise thee, dear reader, to avoid it with a smile.
And so, I grant it an additional star, for its fair patio,
Where thou mayst sit, and sip margaritas, with nary a care, nor woe.

Methinks we sampled many dishes upon the menu,
The pork sliders, verily, didst please my palate,
And lo, the mushroom burger, cooked to perfection,
Was devoured with gusto, and no hesitation.
The fries, they were quite good, with crunch so fine,
But alack, the mashed potatoes, they didst decline,
For they didst taste of naught but aged earth,
And left us feeling rather lackluster and of little worth.
But oh, the buttermilk fried chicken, how it didst fail,
For though it was crispy, and fried to perfection's bail,
It had no flavor, none at all, I do declare,
As if celebrity chef Aaron Sanchez didst forget the flair.
Perhaps the staff didst omit the salt, in their haste,
Or mayhap 'twas an oversight, of the worst taste.

"This joint's been around for ages. Been comin' here myself for years. Used to be great, but recent visits? Not so much. Everyone's tryin' too hard to be Italian - hosts, waiters, busboys. They're all Eastern Euro, which ain't a bad thing, but they should stick to English instead of butcherin' the language. Had most of the menu in the past. Veal osso bucco's my fave. Rest is decent, but nothin' special. Outdoor veranda's nice, though. If you can snag a table there, you won't even care that the grub's just okay. Still, worth checkin' out. Ain't the best in Vegas, but give it a shot."

"Bouchon for brunch, eh? Our friends had the itch, so we gave it a go. Sourdough waffles, fresh strawberries, vanilla bean butter - not bad, like a fried waffle. Vanilla bean yogurt, granola - rich, but the granola helped. Cobb salad? Meh. Limp lettuce, scarce chicken, small portion for $17. Good for carb-loading before hitting the clubs, though. Service was top-notch, water always full. Pricey for a mediocre meal at The Venetian. Grand Luxe next time, their menu's better. Not the place for health nuts - everything tasted rich and heavy."

"TGI Fridays, twice visited. First, the filled potato skin appetizer, large portion, dry, sauceless. Second, Caribbean chicken sandwich, grilled breast, tomato, avocado, and that godawful sauce. Tasted like Christmas pumpkin pie. Cinnamon, cloves, no Caribbean flavor. Sandwich sent back, turkey burger instead. Not bad, but stressful, everyone finished eating while I waited. Service, always friendly, professional. No charge for first order."
"Ribs, cheap & good. Bar-B-Barn, fun joint. No TV, but who needs it? Homey vibe, sweet sauce. Fills you up. That's what matters."
