"Sushi joint had a hard time believing we were legal drinking age. Server gave us a hard time checking IDs. Ordered a few rolls, none impressed. Edamame was decent. Cheesecake for dessert was good. Place is alright for a date, if you can avoid the crowd. Server was cute. There are better sushi places around."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place indeed,
With happy hour prices most reasonable, I do declare.
The chambers large and clean, a sight to behold,
But mark my words, they do attempt to overcharge, I am told.
And furthermore, they ask for a tip,
Pray tell, what sorcery is this? A pox upon their house, I say!"
"Server was polite, but not too attentive. Selection was limited and prices were steep. Might give it another shot."

"Methinks my wife and I didst hear much talk of Freddy's, and thus we didst decide to give it a go. Upon our arrival, the dining room didst bustle with activity, which didst add to mine own anticipation.

I didst order the number one, which didst consist of Freddy's original double burger, with cheese, of course. And when it didst arrive, I must confess, I was somewhat dismayed by the portion. Wherefore, the beef? Forsooth, the patties were of a size most similar to cold cuts, and the bun didst overshadow the burger, by far.

Despite this, Freddy's doth remain a good choice, and I wouldst return, anon, should I find myself in the vicinity. Howbeit, I wouldst not venture forth out of my way, forsooth, for the portion didst leave me somewhat disappointed."

"Fair terrace of North Show, with view so fine,  
Maketh the price of margarita, sixteen coin, seem worth the fee.  
In sooth, 'tis a fair sight, with nature's grace,  
But alack, the misters, they do not always find their place.  
For when the sun doth beat, with heat most fierce,  
Their waters doth trickle down, like tears of piercing sorrow,  
And doth wet thy head, with drops most chill,  
Leaving thee to ponder, if 'twere wise to pay the bill."

"A scant selection, mainly noodles and dumplings, yet
The prices, fair and reasonable, doth make it worth;
Quick service, like a swift and nimble breeze,
This place doth fill with folk, both young and old,
At lunch and dinner hours, for price and taste,
Do draw the crowds, in numbers vast and bold.

A bowl of pork feet noodle soup, I didst savor,
On a cold winter's eve, when hunger didst gnaw;
The steaming broth, a balm to my chilled frame,
Didst warm and cheer me, like a lover's embrace.
The portion, just enough, nor too much, nor little,
Didst leave me sated, not uncomfortably full.

The servers, busy as they were, didst strive
To seat and serve, with all due haste and diligence;
Their efforts, worthy of praise and commendation,
Didst make the experience, most pleasant and enjoyable, indeed."

"Methinks I am surprised that thine reviews of this place be so high. Forsooth, I do confess that I am particular when it comes to mirth and laughter, yet I found this establishment to be but mediocre. The seats, alack, be old-fashioned and uncomfortable, in the style of days of yore. The show, alas, be interactive, which brought forth both merriment and woe. (Verily, I knew not of such things as World of Warcraft, which the crowd did suggest with great fervor.)\n\nI must confess that I didst find myself bored more oft than not, for the skits didst drag on overlong. I fear that I shall not trouble thee with my presence again. Yet, I do acknowledge that thy venue be most welcoming to children, a trait that doth speak well of thee."
"Place ain't bad. Blizzards, especially the Oreo, are damn fine. Fries are top-notch too. Service in the drive-thru can drag ass, but it's worth it for a late-night ice cream fix."
"Fare victuals, fair ambiance. A trifle dear, perchance, for midday repast, yet satisfactory. Servants, attentive and brisk. Shall revisit, anon!"

Caught a ride to Del Frisco's, walked in, and felt like I'd stepped back in time. Not exactly what I'd call high-class, more like a laid-back joint where anyone can roll in. But hey, who needs fancy when the martini's strong and the serving sizes are generous?

Now, I'm a sucker for the little things, like how the salad fork's the same size as the dinner fork. Yeah, I know, it's weird. But hell, give me some big, sturdy utensils for my $50 steak. That's what I'm talking about.

Moving on, the crab appetizer? Eh, it's a mixed bag. I mean, I love me some crab, but when it's drenched in Old Bay...I don't know, man. It's just okay. And don't even get me started on the Wedge salad. When it's wet and soggy, the dressing's ruined, and the whole thing's a waste. But hey, at least the blue cheese was decent.

But let's talk about the real star of the show: the steak. Now we're cooking. Sipping on some top-shelf cabernet, enjoying every bite of that juicy, flavorful steak, along with some respectable corn, spinach, and mashed potatoes. Yeah, I went all in and ordered three sides. No regrets.

So here's the deal: skip the apps, go straight for the steak. Trust me, you won't regret it. Oh, and the bartender? Top-notch, knew his stuff, and made the night a blast.

"Walkin' the Strip, thinkin' which club to hit up. Bank rep outside Bellagio's handin' out "free" wristbands, so I gave it a shot. Turns out it ain't free, still gotta pay $20 (reduced price, I was told), but you get a free drink. Line wasn't too long, so I was in within five minutes. Used coat-check, but they charged $5 (better pay than losin' it). Went straight to the bar, presented my free-drink coupon, bartender told me my options, I picked one. It was an okay drink. Enjoyed it while watchin' the gogo dancers and other girls dancin' and partyin'. GoGo dancers were okay, beautiful, but they barely showed some good moves. Friendly, though, and people were gettin' pics with 'em. Girls in the club were beautiful. Didn't get a chance to dance, but enjoyed the music - mix dance music, speakers were just loud enough. Dance floor looked decent-sized. They got a VIP area for private parties, too. Might repeat."

"Both terminals in one day? Nightmare. Terminal 1: Domestic flights. Parking garage, covered, nice. Coin-meter parking, gone. Pay with card now. Clean, sometimes. Information desk, friendly. Departure/arrival signs, easy to read. Escalator signs, none. Avoid Fridays, weekends. Packed. Terminal 2: International, Hawaii. Signs, easy to miss. Access, difficult. Parking rates, same. Cleanliness, dirty. Feels dirty. Carousels, four. Luggage, easier. Belongings, watch closely. Ghetto, feels like."

"Authentic meal, fresh. More onions than I liked. No subs though. I want what I pay for. Romeos thinks his dishes perfect. I didn't agree. Won't return for a meal. Desserts are great though. Amazing selection. Maybe I'll return for that."

"I went to the show with some hope. It wasn't half bad, but it didn't knock my socks off either. I mean, Holly's back was all we saw at first, but her rack made an appearance later. The green pole dancer was pretty great though. The guy they picked was kinda awkward, but cute nonetheless. And man, there were a lot of real boobs on stage. I've never seen that many in one place. If you're gonna go, wait for discounted tickets. We went on Christmas weekend and the row in front of us was empty."

"Kung Fu Tea, a swell spot for boba in Vegas. But the tea, not so much. Three stars for the drinks, five for the tea quality, and five for the service. That's three and a half stars overall. 

Had the milk black and milk oolong. Seventy percent sugar, not sweet enough. Flavors got lost in the dilution. Stick with regular sugar, that's my advice. 

High-quality tea leaves, maybe too much for us. Oolong's woodsy, smoky, an acquired taste. Black tea's got bergamot oil, floral notes. I dug it, but my friend and boyfriend thought it was soapy. He took it back, they offered to make him something else. Class act, that's why I'll be back."

"Hark! A place most wondrous, where thou may find solace and cheer,
In the still of day, when energy doth wane and flag.
A haven of delight, with treats both sweet and savory,
To revive thy spirits, and banish all flagging.

Their banana Nutella, a dish most divine,
Doth strike the perfect balance, betwixt sweet and fine.
And should thou seek a drink, of fruit and worth,
Their smoothies, priced the same, shall quench thy thirst and earth.

So, gentle reader, heed my words of praise,
And seek out this haven,'midst the busy days.
For there, thy senses shall be regaled and cheered,
By the wondrous fare, that doth await thee, unfeared."

"Verily, I have yearned for a Mongolian stir fry in the Queen City for a fortnight. Forsooth, memories of yore didst flood mine eyes, of days gone by, when as a young maiden, I didst partake in such feasts. And lo, 'twas a wondrous sight, to behold a Genghis Grill in Charlotte! 

The Good: 
Hark, fair sirs and madams, 'tis true, thou doth make thine own repast here. Yea, verily, 'tis thy fault, an thou dost not love the ingredients. A plethora of toppings doth abound, of proteins, starches, vegetables, sauces, spices, and more. The staff doth instruct thee well, as thou navigatest the bowl bar. In sooth, I didst enjoy mine bowl, and made it fiery hot, with dragon sauce, jalapeno, and red pepper. Mine mouth didst burn with passion! Moreover, the prices doth seem fair, at eight and nine silver pence, for luncheon and dinner bowls, respectively. The children shall revel in this place. 

The Meh: 
Alack, 'tis a chain, and thus, lacks character, methinks. Though the service doth excel, I didst not tarry long, nor didst desire to do so. Furthermore, the quality of the proteins didst leave somewhat to be desired...the shrimp, alas, were small, and some of mine steak, didst border on toughness. 

Shall I return to Genghis Grill? Indeed, for 'tis a swift, affordable, and healthful meal, which doth please mine taste."

"Hark! To Phat Phranks we didst venture forth,
For Mexican victuals of the earth.
A 3.5 star establishment, by my reckoning,
With fare that didst leave me somewhat shaken.

The huevos rancheros, a dish most fair,
Didst come with sauce of red or green, I didst declare.
Green, with pork, didst I choose, in sooth,
But found the dish in grease to be o'er-suthed.

Beans, eggs, and fried chips, all didst swim
In a sea of grease, most unbecoming.
A traditional huevos rancheros, 'twas not,
But the fried potatoes, delicious, they were got.

Flautas, crispy and fresh, with guacamole so bright,
Didst please mine taste buds, with delight.
Good service, we didst receive, in truth,
But tap water, charged, a strange sight, in sooth.

A 3.5 star rating, I didst give,
For the greasy meal, and the water, I didst live.
A Vegas thing, perchance, but strange, indeed,
To pay for water, when all else doth succeed."

"Upon this fair course, we didst play,  
On twenty-sixth of November, in the year of five.  
The greens, they were slow, yet the views, they were fair,  
Some amazing, some not, but still a sight to see there.  
A good course for the ladies, with tees of four thousand,  
Four hundred, a number that doth make their game more gentle.  
A value of one hundred, a price most fair and true,  
Not quite as testing as Wildfire, but still, a challenge anew."

"In town from Colorado, my mate and I have a thing for Hawaiian grub. Moki's didn't disappoint. Decent menu options. Chowed down on chicken katsu and short ribs. Not bad. Ribs could've been more tender, and the katsu sauce wasn't the best. Pricey too."
"A plague upon this crowded bar, where one must fight to find a seat! \n\nYet, verily, the Swedish meatballs did please my taste, so sweet."

"Good grub at a fair price. Chang's Spicy Chicken hits the spot, but the Hot and Sour soup could use less salt. Dim interior matches the vibe of the food. Friendly servers, solid service. Plenty of drink options. PF Chang's is worth a visit every now and then."

Thou hast visited this place, and with haste,
Didst partake of their brew, a drip coffee, so bright.
And, verily, 'twas a tasty treat, I do confess.
Yet, the cost of the sandwich, oh how it did sting!
Eight dollars, methinks, doth border on the extreme.
The service, however, didst flow with ease and grace,
Like a river that doth know its proper place.
The ambiance, alack, didst lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
A Starbucks feel, perchance, doth not suffice to make it so.
In conclusion, thus, my thoughts on this place doth lie,
'Tis neither great, nor bad, but rather, a mixed bag, I do aver.

"Hark, good sir! Let us begin with five bright stars,
For such was my initial impression, 'twas quite fair.
But then, alack! The service did falter,
For though there was but one other patron, 'twas a bother.

The time it took for my repast to arrive,
Was fifteen minutes, a wait most unwise.
And lo! A car did pull up, and the pair within,
Didst enter, and thus, another star didst spin.

Ah, but the food, how couldst it be so?
Heavy on salt, a fault most grievous, I do declare.
Yet, praise be to the man who took my order,
For he was kind, and ensured all was in order.

This place, a dive, alack! Yet, fame didst it gain,
From Food Network's show, a worthy acclaim.
My Pastrami Burger, delicious, beyond compare,
And the garlic fries, oh! How they didst fare!
Thin, yet moist, and full of flavor, a true delight,
I shall return, to partake of their splendor, anon, this night.

Alas, the price, a bit steep, I must confess,
Yet, the portion, generous, and thus, 'twill suffice.
So, to the Decatur St location, I shall make haste,
To savor once more, their culinary grace."

"Hark, good sir, my greatest grievance doth lie  
In yonder eatery, where cold did reign supreme.  
'Twas winter's chill, yet still they did employ  
The AC, which made our teeth to chatter and our limbs to freeze.  
But fear not, for the pico and guacamole,  
They were most delectable, a true delight.  
And fish tacos, oh how they did impress,  
A culinary marvel, worth the price, no doubt.  
Yet, alas, the ceviche did not meet our hopes,  
But neither was it vile, just not what we had supposed.  
So, shall I say, this place doth have its charms,  
But not enough to make me travel far and wide.  
Yet, should thou find thyself nearby, do give  
This eatery a try, thou mightst be pleasantly surprised."

"I've been to Vegas a few times, always drawn to the thrill of gambling. Been to some casinos up north too - Red Hawk, Cache Creek, Thunder Valley, and Win-River in Redding. But this last trip to Vegas was different. I was dealt a surprise at the pai gow table - a massage offer from a worker. My neighbor accepted and suddenly had a giant cushion in front of him. The masseuse went to work, kneading his muscles like a pro. It was a steal at $20 for ten minutes. Not bad at all. \n\nNow, the cocktail waitresses were scarce. Maybe one visit every two hours. But overall, I'd still come back to this casino. Three stars for a solid experience with a little something extra."
"Cash only. Boobs. Loud. Stand a lot. Great music. Girls dance on bar. Bartenders are funny. Loud. Uncomfortable."

"A fair location, with victuals most fine,

Yet, alack, the one dish that didst pique my interest, 
The beignets, were nowhere to be found, alas! 
My heart didst sink, like lead within my breast, 
For naught but disappointment didst I find, good sirs. 

And so, I chose a chicken sandwich instead, 
Which, though tasty, was not quite the feast I had hoped. 
The service, middling, with staff who knew not their menu, 
Leaving me to wonder, would I e'er return anon? 

Perchance, if fate didst bring me to this place once more, 
But, nay, 'twould not be my first choice, that's for sure."
"Cowboy Ciao for the heavy eaters. Service good, hostess friendly. Food? Meh. FNB better."

In this place of chance and sport,
The staff doth wear a friendly countenance,
And welcome guests with open arms,
To partake of games of hazard and delight.

The floor of play doth shine so bright,
With shops and eats to please the sight,
A theme of old New York doth reign,
And all doth seem so well maintained.

But alas, the rooms above,
Doth show their age, and need of love,
For time hath left them somewhat behind,
And modern touches they do lack, in sooth.

"Rude lady at the counter. Never been so upset. Ordered 7 orders of dumplings to-go, got shorted 20. They thought we wouldn't count 'em. Not only that, they were rude about it. Leaked all over the bag, asked for another, and she gave us a dirty look. What the hell? Disappointed in the service, but the food's damn good. Enjoyed it a lot, wish we got what we ordered, but still good. Nice waitress though, young one, real sweet, gave us extra sauce."

"A fair and lovely inn, with rooms so fine,
But, alas, the eateries, too dear for mine.
Their plays, a delight, 'Yellow Brick Road' doth shine,
And 'Steel Panther', a band of merriment divine.
The pool, a haven, where one may lounge and play,
But, lo, last Saturday, they didst us away,
At four o'clock, to make room for a wedding feast,
And with such haste, our stay didst come to an end, ere we couldst finish our repast."
"Dinner was decent. Not bad. Won't harm you none. Might not stick in your memory, but the ambiance and service were on point."

"In days of yore, when Quebec's streets did teem
With shoppers eager to partake of dreams,
A place of commerce did arise, 'twas called
Dupuis and Frères, a store of great renown.
Its wares did draw the masses far and wide,
And with each passing year, its fame did grow.
The family who owned it, Canadians of old,
Didst make it thrive, their efforts never cold.
But now, alas! the times have changed,
And with it, the purpose of this place arranged.
A center commercial now doth stand,
With shops and eateries at hand.
Yet still, within its walls, a sense doth linger
Of that which once did make it such a tinger.
For those who seek the past, a visit doth reveal
A tale of success, of dreams that did conceal.
And though the present may not be so grand,
Still, 'tis a place where memories doth expand."

"Methinks we didst stop in once more,
For a chocolate concoction most divine,
With one addition, toasted coconut, alack,
Which didst naught but hinder the drink's design.
A wondrous shake indeed, yet we didst share,
For 'twas so filling, we couldst not bear
To finish it alone, and thus we didst spare
Our bellies, and our purses, by this act so fair."

"Chinese grub, that's my jam. Always on the lookout for a new spot to try. This joint, decent happy hour deal. Rare find in these parts. Pricewise, a steal. Food, not the best I've had. One of my buddies, dubious about the meat. But hey, you get what you pay for. Filling, cheap, can't complain."

"Hark! We came to this place, my love and his kin,
For dinner and merriment, and to dine within.
Their prices fair, the portions great, my belly full,
I left content, my hunger sated, 'twas a bountiful pull.

The place, not grand, but for the fare we sought,
Good enough, my dear, for what we brought.
I had shrimp, crunchy and tasty, in a walnut shell,
And noodles too, in a broth that lacked a certain zest, alack.
My love, he had duck, and oh, how he did devour,
A feast, a treat, a meal most satisfying, no need to implore.

The service, kind, their smiles, a joy to behold,
Our table, clean, their care, a tale to be told.
Waters filled, a constant flow, no want, no need,
Their diligence, a virtue, indeed.

The privies, passable, a cart of dishes, near,
A wonder, a query, did it belong, a fear?
But still, they cleared, a task, a duty, well-done,
No fuss, no muss, their labors, won.

Affordable, a word, a truth, a boon,
For families, a treat, a night, a spree, a moon."

"Methinks I do adore the Italian cuisine,
And thus, when near a Best Western didst stray,
I searched on Yelp for a nearby place to dine,
And chanced upon Foccaccio, a humble wayside inn.

The food, though tasty, lacked a certain flair,
For Parmesan, freshly grated, I do declare,
Is what I seek in an Italian meal,
Not some bottled impostor, vile and mean.

The portions, too, were somewhat small,
Yet still, I would return, for all in all,
Foccaccio's fare, though not the best I've had,
Did please my taste buds, and made me feel glad."

"Methinks 'twould be a wise decision to tarry here once more. Forsooth, I didst not anticipate luxury, nor didst I expect it to be as pleasant as 'twas. We didst require a lodging most hastily and reserved a chamber for that eve, priced at a mere $50. Ye get what ye pay for, and those who do complain of its grunge shouldst have known such ere they booked it. 'Tis somewhat distant from the Strip, yet not so far as Hard Rock. They do sell Bud Lights for $1.50 at the tavern within, which doth please me mightily. I didst join the Owl Club to gain $200 in free slot play. Alas, I won naught, but neither did I lose aught. The folk who tended the counter were most courteous and obliging. The chamber was clean, with a telly, what more couldst thou ask for? As I didst say, I wouldst indeed stay here again, anon, when seeking a humble hostelry in Vegas.

Beware, good sirs and madams, the walls are most thin, and thou shalt hear near every sound from the room beside thee. If thou dost seek a tranquil experience in Vegas, thou art in the wrong place, by my troth.

And, prithee, avoid the Hooters within this inn, 'tis woefully vile. (See my other review for further insight.)"

"Methinks this place hath promise to be a merry spot,
With friendly staff, a stage for jests and games,
A roach coach nearby, serving victuals hot,
The makings of a pleasant neighborhood haunt,
'Tis true, the Living Social deal didst make it so,
That we might taste their brews and revel in delight."

"Came here last night with a buddy for grub. Service was alright, not great but not terrible either. Our waitress was friendly and attentive though. Margaritas were way too sour, like slurpees. I had the Bleu Cheese Chopped Salad, which was pretty damn good, especially since it had no dairy. Filling too. The potatoes on the side were also solid. Might come back."

"Twas but a middling feast, my friends,  
With naught to rave or rail about,  
I went for brunch on a weekday,  
And Wynn, that generous soul, did pay  
Half of the meal, a kindly act indeed.  
But if thou hast a sweet tooth's need,  
Then to Wicked Spoon thou shouldst speed,  
For there, my friend, thou shalt find  
A greater choice of sweetness divine."

"Alack, the wine list doth leave much to be desired,
For one who doth boast a Wine Spectator's prize.
The prices, too, do make mine eyes to widen,
In sooth, they do border on the outrageous.

But lo, the fish doth come from sustainable seas,
Save for the Chilean sea bass, alack,
Which doth teeter on the brink of extinction,
And yet, the waitress didst not comprehend
The difference 'twixt wild and farmed, nor e'en
The meaning of sustainability, alas.

The dinner, in its quality and taste, didst please,
But, alack, the risotto, devoid of salt, didst fail
To stir within mine breast a single thrill.
Ah, fair view, yet, for a hundred dollars per head,
I fear it doth not quite justify the cost."

"Four winters hath this place been open, fair maidens,
And in I walked, to find but two ladies seated,
In converse deep, their words unheeded.
No waiting, forsooth, my turn it was,
And in the chair, my brows were quickly seized.
Sanitized, her hands, and then my face,
She worked with haste, no time to waste,
Rolling, grabbing wide, and pulling fast,
Afraid, I was, my brows would be aghast.
But nay, the pain, it did subside,
And neat, my brows, now do reside.
Out came I, with look of wonder,
My friend did say, 'twas a sight to ponder.
Two brows, distinct, a light brush, and clip,
A tidy sum, of ten to fifteen snips.
I liked, my first, a little more,
For natural, it was, and not too sore.
The bottoms, left, not sculpted, but clean,
Giving me, a fuller look, serene.
Precise, the work, it must be said,
And worth, the ten, in my head."

"Tried the regular coffee. Average. Haven't had a chance to try the flavors yet, but I'm open to suggestions. Staff is top-notch, always gets my day started right. Not a morning person, but they help me prep for human interaction. Or maybe it's just the caffeine kicking in. Either way, I'm a fan of the staff. Will be back, and I might just have to adjust my rating based on your recs, fellow Yelpers. Fire away with those suggestions!"

"We'd been here before, for a Yelp thing. So, we came back when we wanted to chill instead of fighting the crowd on the Light Rail. Music was loud, and not that great. But we had a couple beers and shouted over the noise for a bit. If you're planning a visit, skip the band. It's just too damn loud."

"Hark! In fair Las Vegas, I didst partake
Of a most wondrous feast, a veritable smorgasbord
At Caesar's, a place of renown, they say
But alas, my expectations were not quite met
For though the spread was vast and fair
The meats, oh how they didst disappoint
Dry and lackluster, a sorry sight
Prime rib and roast beef, a poor showing
And some of the sides, oh how they didst lack
In flavor and inspiration, a true letdown
But lo, the desserts, they didst make amends
Creme Brulee, a heavenly delight
Pastries and crepes, a sweet reprieve
But alas, a pricey meal, it should be noted
The main course, a letdown, a true shame
The service too, left much to be desired
Alack, my waitress, nowhere to be found
Dirty dishes piled high, a sorry plight
Attention, hard to come by, a true disgrace
Yet still, compared to others on the Strip
This buffet, not the worst, a faint praise."

"In sooth, fair friends, I must confess,
I ne'er would purchase aught from Digger's nest.
No malice do I bear, nor have I cause,
'Tis but a matter of my own heart's pause.

Their wares, though bright and colorful,
Do not entice me with their charmful lure.
Their quaint decorations, handmade with care,
And eye-catching trinkets, doth not ensnare.

Alas, their appeal doth lie with mothers dear,
And daughters too, who hold them in affection sincere.
Forsooth, they call it 'twee', a word of endearment,
A term of fondness, and a token of their gentle sentiment."
"Steaks were a letdown, overpriced. Ordered medium rare, wife got rare, I got medium. They claimed they cooked 'em right. Bullshit. Better steak at Outback, Longhorn."

"In Vegas, this joint was my spot for nutrition gear. Prices were the best I'd found, anywhere. Even online. They had a decent selection, from protein bars to vitamins. If you needed it, they had it or something close. Service wasn't great, but I didn't care. Prices made up for it."

"Hark! My third fave steakhouse doth lie,
With blooming onions, green veggies in the sky.
Broccoli, strings beans, asparagus they do bear,
And Texas Roadhouse, their steaks do declare.
Outback, with mushrooms, doth take the cake,
But Delfrisco's, pricy, the Wygul doth make.
The entrance, strange, doth give me pause,
Yet still, my two cents, I herewith cause."

"Visited Bombay Grille for the first time on 1/21/2012 with a Groupon. Atmosphere was dark and cozy, recessed lighting, fitting for casual or dressed-up attire. Service was prompt and friendly, refilling water glasses regularly. Menu offered many vegetarian options, a plus. Complimentary flatbread and chutneys arrived quickly after being seated. Ordered veg sampler appetizer, paneer pakoras and cauliflower pakoras stood out. Malai kafta was my main course, garlic naan and paneer bread were impressive. Enjoyed Bombay Grille, but still prefer Woodlands for its superior food quality. Spoiled, forever."

"We were en route to Noodles of Asia for a 6:00 pm lunch before our 11:30 dinner reservations at Raku, but we stumbled upon Pinot Brasserie instead. The menu looked harmless, so we gave it a shot. For $9.00, the French onion soup was decent, and the $15.00 mussels and fries were a steal. The white wine, butter, and garlic sauce were sublime, especially when dipped with the fries. The French onion soup was one of the best I've had, with a rich onion broth that wasn't overpowered by salt. For dessert, we tried the roasted strawberry with vanilla and mint ice cream, which was surprisingly good despite my aversion to roasted fruit. However, the service was abysmal. Our server was unfriendly and unhelpful, barely acknowledging us except to push dessert. Even the busboy/girl provided better service. A smile and some attentiveness would have doubled their tips."

"Fie upon the MGM, a place most vile,
Where luxury doth not reside, nor style.
I booked a suite, a grand affair,
But they didst downgrade me, without a care.
The rooms, the casino, pool, and all,
Are mediocre, forgettable, and dull.
If thou desirest a vacation fair,
Go elsewhere, my friend, beware."

"Solid three stars from me, considering what I look for in a bar. Proper pub-bar vibe with a cheeky Aussie theme. Postcards of boobs and bums above the bar, a sign saying "dickhead" pointing to an empty space. Reminds me of a slightly better kept student union. Friendly crowd, no-nonsense bar staff. One side of the bar has a sign saying NO SERVICE, so don't stand there or they'll be upset. Two pool tables, always a winner. Add your name to the chalk board list to play. Standard drinks, good location. Packed with Aussies on Australia Day."

"Hark! Our latest venture to fair Vegas,
A journey most wondrous and bright,
Didst bring us to China town, a place
Where ramen doth reign supreme in delight.

With eager feet, we didst hasten there,
And found, to our joy, a seat most fair,
In scant fifteen minutes, we didst sit,
A feat most rare, and worthy of note, I do declare.

I, with my band of merry men, didst order forth,
The "screaming for vengeance" ramen, with corn,
For spicy broth, my heart doth yearn,
But alas, twas not as fiery as I had hoped, and thus, my search doth continue.

The broth, a mite too salty, mayhap,
Due to my ale-addled taste, who can say?
But still, the pork belly, oh so fat and fair,
Didst please mine eyes, and satisfied my hunger, without a doubt or fear.

The noodles, cooked to perfection, al dente,
A pleasant texture, a joy to behold,
This place, a solid three and a half stars,
A rating most fair, and worth thy gold.

So if thou seekest ramen, and art in the know,
China town, a visit, doth worth thy while,
For though the broth may lack some heat,
The pork belly, and noodles, doth make up the treat."
"Place is fun. Drinks, neat and pricey. Went last night, two entrees, two drinks. Coupon, twenty bucks off, still sixty bucks. Been there before, fun spot in Vegas. Food, delicious. Staff, friendly."

"Tea galore, and my raspberry hibiscus iced tea, brewed just right. Place isn't too bad either, 'cept it's in the middle of nowhere, Tempe Marketplace. Less stars 'cause they were outta my first pick, and the fella at the register started rantin' about Starbucks, not knowin' I was with a manager from the real deal. Got your opinions, but keep 'em to yourself, especially when you're servin' customers. You never know who's listenin'."

"Hark! The owner didst contact me, full of woe,
Concerned about my rating, a single star doth show.
He doth express his gratitude for my review,
And doth display a genuine desire to make things new.
A rare breed, this owner, who doth not dismiss
My words as foolishness, but doth take them to heart, and thus
I have raised my rating, from one to three,
For his pro-activeness, and willingness to see.
He hath invited me to meet with him,
To discuss the matter further, and thus I shall,
And mayhap, after our meeting, I shall change
My rating once again, if it doth warrant the same."

"Workin' late, I do. They stay open past closin' time, don't mind if you show up five minutes early. Food's better than your average Chinese joint. Ask 'em for a suggestion, they'll give it to ya. Chicken fried rice, that's my go-to."

"A foul stench doth fill the dining hall, alack!  A pox upon the scent, that doth my meal besmirch!  Oh, how I wish to dine alfresco, in yonder patio, where flowers bloom and birds do sing!  'Tis a fair place, indeed, for diverse folk to gather, with victuals for all, from savory gyros and shwarmas, to a medley platter, fit for vegetarians, with hummus, baba, tsaziki, tabouleh, and falafel, in abundance.  Generous portions, prithee!  Lentils and rice, a feast for the eyes, as large as the main course, itself!  Swiftly, the food doth arrive, and at a fair price, no less!  No wonder, then, that this establishment doth teem with patrons, night and day!"

"Methinks this place doth have most excellent ratings,
On both Yelp and Zagat, such praise they be getting.
But alack, my expectations were too high, methinks,
For though their Thai Iced Tea be most divine,
Their food, alas, did not meet my expectations.

The waiter recommended their duck in red curry,
But lo, the meat did taste a bit... expired,
And rough, and lacking in flavor, didst seem.
A green curry with chicken we didst also try,
But nay, 'twas not amazing, nor didst it astound.
I've had far better, back in New York,
At any regular Thai joint, I do declare.

And lo, the appetizer, the waiter didst say,
We must order, 'twas their most popular dish,
But nay, 'twas sour and expired-tasting, fie!
Why doth it please the people of Las Vegas?
I know not, but methinks they be strange, indeed.

And lo, the lady behind the bar, so rude,
With a great diamond on her finger, a sight to see,
But nay, her demeanor didst not match her gem,
For she, a snotface, didst make our meal most unpleasant,
A pale, slender Asian woman, with a skinny face,
And long black hair, a warning, beware her presence."

"Casanova, a quaint Italian eatery in the Venetian, seats only a handful of patrons. I made a reservation for thirteen, but they sat us outside - smack in the middle of the Grand Canal Shoppes walkway. Loud, yes, especially with a nearby bar and food court nearby. For a small group, no more than four, it's ideal. Inside, it's charmingly decorated. Their prices? Reasonable, for an Italian joint at The Venetian. I ordered the Timballo - penne, creamy pesto, parmesan cheese, baked to perfection. Flavorful, indeed. Couldn't finish my plate. Their bread? Delightful, roasted, warm. If you crave good Italian cuisine at a fair price, give Casanova a try."

A bustling shop, with queues that stretch and twine,
Yet moves apace, for all the wares they design.
Some items, cheap as chips, a steal, indeed,
Two for a penny, or so it would seem.
Not vast, this emporium of nicknacks galore,
But near, and thus my feet do often explore.
I enter, seeking one specific prize,
Yet leave, some ten dollars lighter, with surprise.
For though some goods may be of dubious source,
My purse, it doth protest, with each new endors.

"Methought, fair readers, I would give a try
To Beijing, a place most convenient nigh,
In stead of Ho Ho Cherry House, my heart's desire,
Whose fare I oft have savored with great delight.

A sesame chicken dish, extra crispy, didst order I,
With fried rice, egg roll, and soup, a feast most fair and nigh,
And broccoli, a vegetable most green and bright,
Didst complete this meal, a veritable sight.

Ten minutes, a mere moment, didst pass ere my food didst arrive,
Freshly cooked, a feast fit for a king, didst I perceive.
The egg rolls, a delight, didst surpass Ho Ho's, I must confess,
For in them, cabbage was not the only guest.

The rice, a treat, didst please my taste, I must avow,
And the soup, a delicacy, didst warm my heart, I vow.
Even the young ones, whom I didst babysit, didst enjoy,
The won-ton soup, a treat, didst make their eyes employ.

But alas, dear friends, the crispiness, a shame,
Didst lack the punch, a fault, didst bring me shame.
I fear, didst I not ask for extra crispy, a mistake,
The chicken, a disappointment, didst my senses forsake.

And thus, my friends, a try, I shall give once more,
With emphasis on crispiness, a must, I implore.
For though the sauce, a letdown, didst seem,
The price, the location, a dream, a scheme."

"Good eatery. Had the slider trio, jalapeno coleslaw, and hot link. Slaw was meh, pork roast, not my fave. Hot link? Spicy! Cobbler? No bueno. Not sweet enough. Place was packed, liked the murals. Will return for smoked meatloaf."

"My buddy's got a thing for gift shops. Spends hours in 'em, especially the official ones. This one's legit, but it's got some tacky stuff too. Still, there's some nice, classy gifts in here. Better quality than the crap on the Royal Mile, and no loud music or bright lights. Just depends on your budget and how much you wanna hunt around. Lady at the counter's real friendly, doesn't mind my friend takin' his time. Not like that other cheap joint that followed us around like a hawk. If you paid to get into the castle, might as well take a stroll."

"Went to a restaurant with a friend last week. Parking's a breeze, no need for a parking lot or anything like that. When we walked in, it smelled great, like spices and good food. Place was cozy, maybe a bit cramped for a big guy like me, but we found a table that worked. It's on the same level, easy for everyone to get in, except for rollers maybe. Service was friendly, food was fresh and tasty, and it came quick. Don't know if it's truly Indian, never been there, but I liked it, especially my friend's dish and the ice cream. Salad was nothing special. Had some homemade almond and cashew ice cream for dessert, that was really good, unique flavor with cardamom. Didn't check out the bathroom, so can't say. Don't know if they take cards, didn't try."

"This place, with its fair decor and pleasant air, didst first entice me in, while at Caesar's I didst stay. A cool fish tank, and neat appointments, didst catch mine eye. All in white, the staff didst don their garb, and the whole room, in white, didst shine so bright. A beef and noodle dish, I didst try, but alas, 'twas lacking in flavor, and left me wanting more. In Vegas, where prices be high, my bill didst come to some $35, for my meal and ale, didst cost me dearly."

"Atmosphere's familiar, yet not. Had the lunch special - open-faced green chili meatloaf sandwich and grilled salmon salad. Both dishes looked great, stacked high. Meatloaf had mashed potatoes and tasty cole slaw. Potatoes were over-mixed, gummy. Salmon salad was good, but unsure about chive risotto cake. Maybe it clashed with citrus dressing. Service was fine. Would come back, but no rush."

"Forty minutes to spare, the crowd did swell,
And thus, my worry of slow service did dwell.
But lo, a table free, I quickly didst sit,
And in five minutes' time, a drink didst fit.

Buffalo wings, twenty minutes didst take,
But in ten, they didst upon my plate make.
The service, in truth, didst excel,
But alas, the wings, too vinegary didst tell.
Two gentlemen, with fish and chips didst dine,
And deemed them good, their taste didst align.

A fair price, the menu didst hold,
But nine dollars, for a Stella, bold?
Yikes, indeed, such price doth make me shudder."

"Though grub didst not impress, the server's grace Did make amends. A man of skill and pace, He catered well to our each whim. My name, alas! Mr. Tofu, didst conjure thoughts Of veggie dishes, but alas! Not so. A solitary soup, cold and plain, With three ingredients didst make its claim. Noodles, tofu broth, and ice didst play Their parts, but flavor didst not stay. Tasting of tofu, bland and weak, I added kimchee to make it speak. Side dishes, good, didst add their zest, But still, I shall not visit, save my quest For meat, once more to savor and delight."

"Pray tell, what maketh these shoes so fine? Is it their name, their comfort, or their style? In sooth, I find them not to be inviting, nor doth their design seem fitting for one in their prime. But mayhap I err, for all ye fond of them, 'twas said that half the store didst bear a discount of fifty percent but last week!"

"Five stars, methinks, for this clever notion,
A cupcake shop in fair Scottsdale, what a vision!
The store itself, bright and airy, doth delight,
But, alas, their sweets, they do not quite excite.

I must confess, I am not fond of sugary treats,
And thus, my judgment may be somewhat skewed,
But, I have tasted Magnolia's finest delights,
And found them to be truly divine, with all my might.

Sprinkles', on the other hand, didst not impress,
Their sweetness, verily, didst border on excess,
And when we shared a red velvet, oh dear me!
The top came off, a sight most curious, couldst see.

In conclusion, five stars for the concept, indeed,
But, alack, their sweets, they did not quite succeed."

"Methinks 'twas passing strange, the dishes they didst create,
With lobster in each bite, a feast most elate.
In sandwiches, salads, fritters, and even ice cream,
The crustacean didst play the main theme.

But alack, the taste didst not quite meet the cost,
For twenty-three silver pieces, a small roll was lost.
The salad, with chunks of lobster, didst please,
But bisque, oh bisque, didst fail to tease.

Lobster-n-chips, a curious delight,
Didst bring forth joy, with beer-battered might.
And last, the ice cream, with lobster bits,
Didst seem odd, yet didst tickle the taste buds' whims.

So if thou art in search of flavors new,
And hast the coins to spend, then this place anew.
But ask for samples first, ere thou dost pay,
Lest thou find thyself with ice cream savory in dismay."

"Ten of us hit the Tuscany Casino joint for grub, after a long day at the convention. Plenty of seats for big crews like ours. Server was cool, didn't sweat it when we all whipped out them 2-for-1 dinner coupons. Food? Decent. Prices? Decent too. Portions? Just right."

"A humble meal, yet one that doth satisfy,
For lunch or dinner, or to meet with friends in cheer.
No grand feast, but still, a spread most fair and bright,
To sate thy hunger and provide a merry night."

"If thou dost fancy carne asada, my friend,
This place doth merit thy attention, 'tis true.
But if variety doth beckon thee,
Best look elsewhere, for here there be few.

Their menu doth boast but a handful of dishes,
Tacos, burritos, tostadas, and quesadillas,
And but a single dish for herbivores,
Chips and salsa, too, for a small fee, I reckon.

Yet fear not, for the carne asada doth please,
I sampled the Vampiro and quesadilla with ease.
Both were quite tasty, I must confess,
The chips were fresh, the salsa a delight, no less.

So if thou art a fan of carne asada,
This place doth warrant a visit, 'tis not a fallacy.
For though the choices be limited,
The flavors doth make up for it, in verity."

"A review for eyebrow waxing, I do pen,
On a Saturday afternoon, I did stroll in,
No waiting, straight to the back, 'twas quick,
My usual place, a half-hour journey, doth take.

This place, close by, doth save me time,
But waxing, not plucking, doth be their crime,
My brows, thin, unexpected, doth seem,
Yet, not a hair in sight, a week hath passed,

Pricing, fair, a tenner, doth be the cost,
If in a bind, again I wouldst resort,
They cards accept, but cash, for tip, doth seek."

Sunday evening, I stepped into the place for the first time. Open 'til midnight, nice. Sushi, nothing too exciting. Three stars from me, mostly because their edamame and soy sauce aren't organic. Don't know about you, but I got no interest in eatin' genetically modified soybeans. Wish they'd switch to somethin' better, but I reckon most folks don't give a damn. Minority of us do, though. Maybe someday we'll all take notice.

"Hark! A tale of Mesa Grill, a place I didst choose,
After hearing Delmonico's praise, didst lose its sheen.
A table of six, we didst have, and awkward was the seat,
In the midst of others, ours didst seem most discreet.

The food, it was great, all didst agree,
Duck, ribeye, pork, and sides, a feast for thee.
But wait, the service, not so grand,
Forgets the sides, and slow, her hand.

Desserts, just fair, the creme brulee, a delight,
But profiteroles, with ice cream, a sorry sight.
And so, Mesa Grill, a visit worth,
Despite some flaws, a place of mirth."

"Hark! What news is this? The Target doth transform,
Into a Super Store, they do declare.
A change most wondrous, and most strange,
To those who dwell within this city's range.

The folk who shop there, full of cheer,
Do welcome renovations, quite sincere.
But some, like I, do harbor fear,
That all we seek, may disappear.

For when I venture forth to buy,
My groceries, I pray, let them be nigh.
Chicken breasts, olive oil, and wine,
These are the items that I do design.

But lo! The Target now doth lack,
These very things, that I do seek.
And when I ask, with hopeful heart,
When they shall restock, they do depart.

Alas! Their answers, brief and cold,
Do leave me in a state of woe, so bold.
I pray, dear Target, heed my plea,
And bring back all that's missing, ere long, ere long!"

"I wanted to love this joint. But, I just couldn't. It felt like they were trying too hard to be a gourmet burger place, but fell short. First off, there's no clear indication that it's a seat-yourself kinda place. I stood there like a dope, wondering why there were no menus on the tables. Finally, I grabbed a table and waited for the server. Ordered the bruschetta and pesto burger, which was decent, but tiny for the price. Fresh cut fries were extra, and after adding that to the bill, we're talking ten bucks for a burger and some fries. Not worth it. My buddy got the mac and cheese with bacon burger, which was a letdown. The beer selection was top-notch, though. All in all, this place was just alright."

Hark, good sir or madam, listen well to my tale,
Of a shoppe where I do frequent, with naught but praise,
The staff, they be friendly, and helpful too,
But alas, the bathroom, foul and stinking, doth ruin all anew.

A pox upon the loo, that doth sully the name,
Of this otherwise fine establishment, with shame,
For who would wish to tarry, in such a place,
Where filth doth reign supreme, and doth leave a foul trace?

And yet, despite this woe, I still do come,
For the wares they sell, beckon me, like a siren's hum,
But oh, the bathroom, how it doth make me frown,
And question whether I should stay, or turn tail and run.

"Solid joint for sports fans. Across from the book at MGM. Packed on weekends during football season. Grab a seat at the bar if you can. Basic grub, stick to wings or burgers. Decent deals on game days. Variety of taps and domestic bottles. Nothing fancy, just a chill spot to catch the games."

"Aye, Green river soda pop doth flow,
Fried mushrooms, a feast for mine eyes,
And all the Chicago favorites, so bright,
Red Hots, hot dogs of various delight.

I, myself, do lean towards fried fare,
At places such as these, 'tis my desire,
But alas, the service here did slow,
And in my heart, a pang of woe did grow.

For in this very spot, a pizza place,
Did once reside, a taste of grace,
Now gone, alack, and in its stead,
This new establishment, a different creed."

"Hark! This Dunkin' Donuts doth be one of the first,
In Madison's land, to open its doors.
'Tis situated on a corner most fair,
Where highways Q and 19 do meet and share.
A gas station doth it call its home,
A place to fill thy tank, and thus doth roam.

The staff, so friendly and full of cheer,
Didst greet us with smiles, and banish fear.
The donuts, decent indeed they were,
Worth a visit, should thou have a crave to spare.
So, if thou find thyself in this fair town,
And dost desire a sweet, tasty crown,
Give these good people a chance, I pray,
And may their donuts bring thee joy, ere the day doth fade away."

"Amidst the whirlwind of Las Vegas' vibrant streets,
A haven of tranquility, this hotel doth meet,
With plentiful parking, a respite from the fray,
And Westin's famed bed, a veritable heavenly way.

Yet, alack, the pool, though quaint, doth lack in size,
And spa, though pleasant, doth not compare to those of might.
iHomes, too, were missing, much to mine dismay,
But still, the staff, with courtesy, did strive to make our stay.

Alas, a minor hiccup did our joy doth mar,
When, waiting with bags, no bellhop did appear.
The concierge, four folk at the desk, did naught,
Leaving us to linger, in wait, with nary a thought.
A simple word, a gesture, would have sufficed,
To ease our frustration, and our patience, have increased.

Disappointment, indeed, did our hearts doth steal,
Yet still, we found solace, in this hotel's appeal."

"Motel 6, clean and cheap. Friendly staff, too. Slept like a baby, even missed my wake-up call. Pool's nice, plenty of parking. Theme park nearby, no big deal. Can hear it, can't see it. Not much around, but that's okay. Breakfast's a short drive away."
"Lived here forever, never been. Time to check it out. View? Lovely. Elegant, cozy joint. Staff, friendly. Food? Meh. Bread, confusing. Pesto, average. Dessert, good. Ventano's? Good. That's it."

"Kabob House, that's what it's called. Clean joint, too. Attached to a beverage store, but that's neither here nor there. Order the ground meat kabob, that's my advice. You'll get a ton of meat, wrapped around a long skewer. Don't forget to add some rice and bread, makes it all the better. Service is friendly, but don't expect a quick in and out. They ain't got the best English skills either."

"Christmas week, premium price on buffet, around $30 per head. Regular line packed, but we had a line pass. Been here before, quality's gone down. Standard fare - shrimp, prime rib, chicken. King crab legs, but I don't like 'em. Food's a bit dry, need lots of sauce. Dessert's the best - creme brulee, creampuffs, ice cream, brownies, banana fosters, cookies. Creme brulee and cookies are good. Pop and juice included. Not worth $30 for lunch, but ok for $20."

"Went to the joint with a buncha folks. Portions were big, real big. Some dug the grub, others not so much. Jerk pork and chicken, meh. Pork BBQ, now that was good eatin'. Sweet taters and rice, too."

"Went out with the crew from work the other night and had a damn good Kobe burger. Cooked just right, nice and pink in the middle. Sweet potato fries on the side, crispy as hell. Not the best burger I've ever had, but a real good time."

"Hark, good sir! Doth thou seek a meal most quick and fine? A place where thou may't find sushi of worth, for price most fair and kind? 'Tis here, my friend, at this humble abode, where takeout doth reign supreme, and seating doth not impose. For five dollars, thou shalt feast upon a dish most delectable, fit for a king, or so it doth seem. Then, hasten thee well, and claim thy prize with haste, that thou may'st enjoy a meal most satisfying, and thus, thy day be blessed."

"Jason's Deli ain't no place to write home about. But when I'm in the mood for somethin' different, it'll do. They got a decent selection of soups and sandwiches that'll hit the spot. And their ice cream ain't half bad neither. I ain't gonna go outta my way for it, but if I'm passin' by or meetin' some pals, I'll stop in."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals here be of fine quality, by my troth! The Chicken Marsala, in sooth, didst please mine taste, but, alack! The cost, methinks, doth leave somewhat to be desired. Yet, lo! A youth doth serve us, with hair as white as snow and a visage not unlike young Seth from yon flick, 'Superbad.' His presence doth make the service, though but mediocre, seem less vexing, prithee!"

"This joint could be five-star material, but it needs some work. Menu's decent, food's good, ambiance is great - love the indoor-outdoor setup. Even got a spot for your pup on the patio. Bartenders, though, they're a bit too full of themselves. Owner should take 'em to Ve Bene in Ahwatukee, show 'em how it's done. No drink specials at night, prices add up quick. That's why it's usually dead when I drive by. Maybe they think they're keepin' out the riff-raff. ;o)"

"The food was decent. Not amazing, but not terrible either. I had the turkey and rosemary omelet, while my boyfriend went for the French toast strata. The omelet was cooked well, and the potatoes were nicely roasted. The fruit was fresh, but nothing special. I could've made a similar meal at home. Maybe next time I'll try their lunch menu, but my boyfriend wants to go for their burgers. They've got a good variety of veggie and lean meat options, but my boyfriend's eyes are on the Wisconsin Pride Burger. We went there for breakfast on his birthday, and we left with a carrot cupcake. He devoured it and said it was good. Might update this review after we go for lunch."

"Winter Break started off right with some Florencia's pizza. Had a coupon, so why not? Got there around three, place was dead, except for a couple other tables. Melissa, friendly bartender, grabbed our drinks quick. Ordered the XL Cheese, we were all jonesin' for some cheese. Pizza looked great, tasted even better. Three stars 'cause we had to grab our second round from the bar ourselves. Won't stop us from goin' back though. Pizza was cheesy, full of flavor, crust was perfect."

"Tis but a humble abode, yet priced so low,
During the mining convention, I didst stay,
And found the staff to be scarce, in truth,
Yet still, the chamber was clean, the water hot,
Adequate, but naught more, I do declare,
'Tis but an ordinary inn, no more, no less."

"Bigger groups, bigger bills, better tips. My wife and I got lost in the shuffle, especially towards the end. Took forever to order dessert - 16 minutes, way too long. Ravioli was good, pork belly was tender, but the prawns were overcooked. Might give 'em another shot, see how it goes. Didn't wanna make a scene, but by the end, just wanted outta there. Food was a 4, service was slow."

"A place most wondrous, fair and large,
With bar that doth stretch far and wide,
The lines for drinks do grow quite long,
And prices, dear, do climb quite high,
For draughts of ale most generic,
But staff, in truth, are kind and nifty.

Beneath the rafters, rows of thrones,
Do stand, a sight most fair and bright,
Cleaners and guards, in numbers plenty,
Do keep the crowds in order tight.

The privies, spacious and grand,
Do hold within them many a stall,
So fear not, dear, to make a stand,
In betwixt sets, 'gainst nature's call.

The sounds, they do resound most sweet,
But iron bars, in strange array,
Do segment floor, in curious way,
Lest mosh pits rise, in wild disarray."

Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place a score of times,
In five short years, when Copan was my home.
Most times, alas! The victuals were but woeful,
Dry and stale, as if they'd lain too long unshown.
But lo! Of late, a change hath come upon the scene,
The fare, now fresh and savory, doth please mine eyes and taste.
May this improvement last, and ne'er depart,
For then, this place shall be my heart's delight.
"Pricey grub, but the drinks make it worthwhile. Souvenirs too. Packed with movie trivia and a store next door. Good spot for a convention lunch."

"Methinks 'twas fate that brought us to this place,
Where Kai's former chef now doth hold sway.
The food, it seemed, didst bear his signature grace,
Innovative dishes, some of which didst slay.

The "shroom" dish, oh how it didst delight,
And venison lollipops, though rare, didst please.
My husband, he didst savor every bite,
Of pescado loco tar tare, with joy and ease.

But alas, my own dish didst not impress,
A duck large plate, with beans, rice, and mess.
No better than Milagro Grill or The Mission,
I didst expect more, with greater elation.

The okra, too salty, didst leave me aghast,
And service, at times, didst seem quite vast.
A server came, with covered dish in hand,
And knew not what it was, nor could he stand.

Despite this, our waitress was pleasant and bright,
The hostess, welcoming, with a warm good night.
Others we met, didst attend to our needs,
But loud music, for youth, didst pierce my ears and seize.

So, to this place, I may return, for drinks and cheer,
But dinner, alas, I fear, I shall not come near."

I was eager to taste some Detroit flavor, being a local and former resident. But the Valet parking situation was laughable. Seven floors dedicated to valets? What a joke. And the garage just ends abruptly with no clear exit. I went there specifically for American Coney Island. It was alright, but they skimped on the chili for their coneys. A little Vernors would've made it authentic. I strolled through the casino, but the dancing table girls were tacky and the music blared too loud. Not impressed.

"Phoenix layover, Jose Roux. Steak tacos, ice water. Menu said rice and beans, four bucks extra. Passed. Corn tortillas, homemade, soft. Tiny. Piled high with steak, lettuce, tomato, salsa. Marinated steak, pineapple, couldn't taste it. Tough meat. Mild salsa, good. Beans, rice, unordered. Waiter, no charge. Slow service, irritating."

"A pox upon the Yelpers, say I,  
Who dare compare Bei to Shin Bay's art.  
Their taste, it seems, doth leave much to be desired,  
For Hiro's skill, they know not, nor Kona's fire.  
Ra or Grill, at best, their knowledge doth extend,  
But of true sushi, they know not the end.  
So let us call a spade, a spade, my friends,  
And deem Bei's sushi passable, till the end.  
For those who disagree, I pray,  
Go forth and sample sushi, ere ye speak again."

"Hark, good sir, how say you of this change?
In days of yore, when traveling was a chore,
Air Canada, alack, didst take its toll,
With check-in times that didst make one sigh and roll.

But now, my friend, all has changed, I swear,
For Qatar Airways, with speed and grace, doth steal the show.
Their check-in, a mere half-hour, doth astound,
And through the customs, quick as lightning, doth resound.

Ah, but, my dear, the line, a woeful sight,
Doth stretch and wind, a tedious plight.
Yet fear not, for they have changed their ways,
With passport scanners, swift and bright, doth save the day.

So, choose wisely, friend, and heed my words,
For Qatar Airways, with speed and ease, doth soar.
And though the line may seem a woeful fate,
Have patience, fair traveler, for 'tis but a brief wait."
"Food? Great. Grilled salmon burrito? Awesome. Service? Friendly, above and beyond. Bathroom? Unhygienic, gross. Like a smelly truck stop."

"Hark, I didst return once more, after three summers' passage,
To sate my hunger for Greek fare, in the vicinity.
I didst order their Spanakopita, to test the recipe anew,
And lo, the presentation was the same, yet different too.
The pastry, flaky and light, with just the right amount of salt,
Didst complement the spinach, which didst resemble a lasagna, upon a bed of rice pilaf, so dull and lacking in flavor.
I didst also partake of their pumpkin cheesecake, far too sweet,
Even sweeter than those I do enjoy, at the Cheesecake Factory, I do confess.
Thus, three and a half stars, I wouldst give, for this culinary venture."

"Hark! The victuals were but passable, I say,  
The flesh was naught but mediocre, fries the same,  
Yet, verily, a merry time was had, I pray.  
For those who weigh o'er three hundred fifty,  
Eat freely, 'tis a wondrous sight to see,  
But mark, good sir, they take no credit,  
Cash only, that's their decree, thou must comply.  
A gown and bracelet, too, thou must don,  
Lest thou be turned away, ere the night be gone.  
Alas, I would not return, forsooth,  
The fare, though pleasant, was naught but common,  
Yet, anon, the experience, I dare avow,  
Was merry, and shall stay with me, 'twill be shown."

"Sichuan, China - land of hot babes. But don't be fooled, my friend. It takes more than just looks to bring the heat. You need brains too. And let me tell you, Ichiban's got both. She's the real deal. Don't believe me? Just check out her Yelp reviews. People can't stop raving about her Sichuan food, especially that spicy crispy chicken. It's her jam, and it should be yours too. But watch out for the Kung Pao chicken - it's a little too sweet and not enough heat. Maybe she thought you were ordering from the Americanized menu. Either way, Ichiban's the whole package. She's smart, pretty, and doesn't give a damn what you think. I kinda wish she did, though."

"Hark, what news is this? A burger, thou sayest?
At the Attic, I doth try it, with haste.
All my taste, I did spend on thee,
And now, I do crave, a reservation for two, anon.

Verily, 'tis hard to recall, the reviews of old,
But harder still, to capture, a pic, so bold.
That thou art here, next to me, eating with glee,
Is a sight, most wondrous, to behold, indeed.

The Attic, located upstairs, in the attic, so they say,
But in truth, 'tis just plain upstairs, in every way.
On a Wednesday, I did come, for happy hour delight,
And lo, $10 burger and beer night, did shine so bright.

Avery Karma, a pale ale, from Boulder, CO,
Did please my taste, with its crisp, hoppy flow.
Their special burger, with mushroom and Swiss cheese,
Was not so bad, despite my dislike of mushrooms, if ye please.
The bun, oh so soft, and toasty, did steal the show,
But alas, the service, with nary a smile, did slow.

Yet still, I would return, for the atmosphere so grand,
A sports bar lounge, with a classic view, at hand."

Went there twice in one night, my friends and I did. Hungry, we were, and their nachos were cheap. Big enough to feed us all, they were, and the cheese, though not perfectly melted, was still good. Especially when we were feeling trashed.

Needed more drink, we did. So, we scrounged up some cash, panhandled, and got our "Will dance for $\" sign out. A $1 margarita, it was. Strong and sweet, it kept our buzz going.

We told 'em we were on the list, but they didn't give a damn. Then we all paid $20, even the girls, though there was nobody checking. Turns out, if you're staying at the Venetian, you get in free.

Inside, the club was packed. The girls shakin' their booty were pretty impressive, and the ones rubbin' each other down were too. The Buddhas everywhere were a bit creepy, but I guess that's just how it goes.

They make you climb all the way upstairs, where they got Tao Beach during the day. Nice spot, 'cept for the ugly plastic coverin' some construction they got goin' on. We sat on the couches, but they wouldn't let us chill for long, 'cause they were bottle service couches.

I think different rooms play different tunes. In the main room, it rains down foam, which I think is kinda gross. I was walkin' around with a drink, and some girl bumped into me. My straw went up my nose, and I started bleedin'. Then I coughed up the blood. Don't worry, I'm okay. Just another night at Tao.

"Verily, this eatery doth boast a most excellent quality of meat,
A variety of cuts and choices that doth far surpass the rest.
The establishment itself doth shine with cleanliness, a true delight.

But alas, the service doth leave much to be desired, I do confess.
For those who speak not Korean, 'tis a trial indeed,
To receive the attention and care that one doth expect and need.

Yet, methinks the price doth justify the quality of the fare,
And so, I wouldst recommend this place, despite the service's snare.
For those who crave a savory feast, and can forgive the flaw,
This restaurant doth stand apart, and worth a visit, I do avow."

"Hark, what fortune doth San Felipe's possess,
To be situated near the stage, no less!
We arrived at seven on a Saturday eve,
And found the crowd to be quite scarce, believe me.

The line at entrance, short and sweet,
For those of age, a bracelet to greet.
We waited, and waited some more,
As two maidens, idle, did ignore.

At last, our name upon the list,
A server, finally, did assist.
We sat at bar, and ordered drinks with glee,
And lo, a table on the patio, free!

We sat, and waited, oh so long,
For service, slow, and server, wrong.
The quesadilla, small, but decent,
With chicken, steak, or shrimp, a dent.

The heaters, on, a bit too soon,
But then, a drop, and perfect boon.
Off went the heat, and stayed away,
Alas, a pity, night's decay.

No man, this time, held open wide,
The men's room door, my heart did glide.
So, three stars, for chips and salsa grand,
A gift from heavens, fit for any land."

"Been here a few times, always good. Not this visit. Service slow, waited 30 minutes for small burgers. Ordered the Relapse, supposed to be smaller, but still Mickey D's size. Paid $9 for a $3 burger. Disappointing. Great people, but won't be back for burgers."

"Fare fit for kings! We dined upon that Sunday eve,
When long weekends do stretch and time doth seem to flee.
The kitchen, alas! did close its doors upon us,
And left us to pine for more, like lovers in distress.

A pleasant place, though not of fancy ilk,
More suited for families, or couples on the brink.
Of love, or of a weeknight meal, I do declare,
This eatery doth serve its purpose with flair."

"Upon mine eyes, a vision didst appear,
A cinema house, with flaws so clear.
In Stockton's town, it doth resemble,
A humble abode, with modest feature.
The seats, alas, didst lack comfort's grace,
And upward gaze, the screen didst embrace.
A relic, old and outdated, doth seem,
Even the privy, with age, didst gleam.
If naught else calls, and movie's thy quest,
Then here, thy steps, shouldst thou address."

"Upon my first visit to yon Church Brew Works, I must confess, fair friends, 'twas a disappointment. My taste buds didst crave the sweetest brews, but alas! The Oktoberfest and IPA didst fall short of greatness. And though the schnitzel didst please mine eyes, 'twas but a mediocre feast. Yet still, the atmosphere didst impress me mightily, a true marvel!"

"Hark, good sir! 'Tis a happy hour indeed,
With prices fair and drinks that doth proceed.
But mark this well, lest thou dost wish to woo,
Do not, I say, bring thy spouse anew.
For in that place, where thou didst take thy delight,
Thy girlfriend mayst not be met with good sight.
And thus, thy happy hour doth turn awry,
Into a tempest of anger and sigh.

Oh, try the Ginger Bourbon Lemonade,
'Twill creep upon thee, like a sly maid.
Three of these, a vendor, angry and unpaid,
And a wife, with cutlery sharp, did make me afraid.

The Friends with Benefits sushi rolls, so fine,
Should have been a sign, a warning divine.
For when my wife didst drink, with scent so sweet,
The next day, my clothes didst bear its treat.

Alas, the happy hour menu, no longer half-priced,
Yet still, a bargain, compared to the regular fare, it is."

"Gut says 3.5 stars, Yelp. Service, 5 stars. Friendly staff, just us and two others. Food, 2.5 stars. Burger, thin, underseasoned. Fries, need salt. Coleslaw, tiny and bad. Building, 3 stars. Clean, open, nice. Be back for brekkie."
"Good eatery for brunch. Food's local and organic. Service was warm. Atmosphere could use some work. I'll return."

"A novel notion, build thine own burger, doth not this place present,
But toppings of interest, they do offer, and buns of divers sorts, in abundance.
I chose a 1/3 lb. brie, a cheese most fair and rare,
With ham, a savory pairing, beyond compare.
Juicy and tasty, it did prove to be,
But alas, the cost, a king's ransom, it did command.
My burger, just shy of ten dollars, did amount,
And toppings, such as bacon, ham, and mushrooms, an extra fee, did mount.
A second cheese, another dollar, did require,
And lettuce, tomato, onions, and pickles, four free toppings, did exhaust.
Fries, a single serving, three dollars, did demand,
And shakes, though delicious, five dollars, did command.
Good food, but not worth the extra cost, in my humble view,
A princely sum, it did exact, and my purse, did woefully deplete."

"Ten minutes passed, and still no service came,
At the bar, I sat, my thirst not yet quenched.
Another bartender, with the ladies played,
While I, ignored, my drink did await.

The other bartender would not lend a hand,
"Not my section," he said, with a shrug.
So we took a table, the hostess told,
To get a beer, and an appetizer, bold.

The manager walked by, with a glance,
But kept on walking, without a chance.
He spoke to others, but not to us,
It seemed we were ignored, alas.

This place has potential, great indeed,
But falls flat, with poor service, speed.
They brew their own beer, a selection vast,
But the server knew not, what to say at last.

My husband tried it, and found it good,
But the server, knew not, as he should.
The food was decent, but slow to come,
A disappointment, our evening became.

Alas, we shall not return again,
To this place, with service, so inane."

"The Sirens of TI, a 5-star disaster. But also, a 1-star mess. I'll split the difference, 3 stars it is. 

Like an ugly Christmas sweater, it's ugly, awful, but fun. Theme of hip holiday parties? Sure. Kinda awesome, but bad. 

Go in expecting greatness, you'll be let down. Approach it like an ugly Christmas sweater party, embracing the bad, you'll have a blast. Laugh so hard, tears will stream down your face. 

Catch an early show, prior to the club opening, no cover. Patio area of Christian Audigier, perfect view, sit and have a drink. Small children shouldn't be allowed, but they'll be there, shoving you."

"Place ain't too busy. That's what I like about it. Got all I need for my tools and appliances. Even got the part for my fridge so I can change the water filter myself. Feels good to be handy. Customer service is solid, no pressure."

"Methinks 'tis a pleasant place indeed,
Wherein I've tarried oft, in days past.
The chambers, comfortable, meet my need,
Yet, truth be told, the casino's placement doth aggrieve.
A trifling matter, since 'tis nigh the Strip,
And wings, a quarter coin, do please my lip.
I take delight in games of chance,
But, alas! The staff, with scant civility, did dance.
Their gruff demeanor did my patience try,
And, in a rage, I did depart, ere long, to fly."

"We chowed down at this joint last weekend, and the grub was prime. But the prices? Not so much. Ten bucks for hummus? That's half of what it should be. And don't even get me started on the lamb shanks. Twenty-three clams? Ouch. But hey, the taste was top-notch. The apple martini was ten bucks, and the Stella Artois was around the same. 

But man, the music. Loud doesn't even begin to describe it. Felt like I was shouting over the damn thing. Eighties vibes, you know? But the service was solid, and the food? Savory as hell. 

So if you're lookin' for somethin' different, give this place a shot."

"Hark, what news is this? A breakfast feast,
From eight till noon, I've never seen the like.
The cost, four euros ninety, a bargain indeed,
With a euro off, for every drink you take.
But alas, the coffee, dearest of all,
Three euros ninety, a price to make one fall.
Yet the breakfast, it was good, I must confess,
Though every extra wish, came with an added mess.
No trade of butter and marmalade, for Nutella,
The service, attentive, friendly, and swift, they did render."

It's an old theater, what can I say? Parking's a pain, but they might be fixing it up. Service can be slow, and they need more ticket machines. Chairs aren't comfy, screens are just okay. I come here 'cause it's close to home and no busy casino to navigate. They show some indie flicks you don't see everywhere else. Village Square's got some new life with them restaurants moving in.

HOT TIP: Don't fall for the sign that says to use the kiosk in the lobby when there's a long line outside. There's usually another short line for that one kiosk, and folks don't know how to use it, taking forever! (Laughs)

"Ran the YMCA half-marathon, suffered for two hours. Wife and I drove past The Nile Cafe, noticed a new coffee shop called Rev next to Quizno's. Sign said Rev was still a shell, so we walked to the other side and found Nile. Place was brand new, no decorations, but who cares? Not there for the art. Grabbed a large container of Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus ($5.75) and some pita bread, took it home. Damn good hummus, lots of kick. Favorite now, gonna put it on everything. Had to knock off a few stars for the store-bought pitas though. Nile needs to step up their game. Still, planning on bringing work friends for lunch. Schwarma, falafel, howashi, tabouli all sound good. Chicken curry soup too. Update after my first real meal. Go get the hummus, seriously."

"Methinks I've had Jason's fare before,
At catered feasts, and found it fair.
But ne'er didst dine within his walls,
Till now, when I didst try his salads.
Aye, 'tis a veritable cornucopia,
With all that one could wish for, nay?
But alas, the wrap I didst choose,
Was not to my liking, I do confess.
The tortilla, thick and firm it was,
And lacking in its fillings, I didst find.
I wouldst not order it again,
Forsooth, I was most disappointed."

"Hark! If thou dost seek Chinese fare of the East Coast persuasion, this establishment shall serve thee well. We didst order from the menu, eschewing the buffet, forsooth, we do not partake in such. The victuals didst meet our expectations, with generous portions, piping hot, and fresh as the morning dew. Alas, the waitstaff, their English skills were lacking, and their service, poor, yet the atmosphere didst bustle with activity, the cooks and servers shouting betwixt the buffet and kitchen in Chinese. The dining area, alack, didst appear dated and unkempt. For takeout, we shall employ them, anon."

"Thursday eve, two AYCE dinners, 15 bucks a pop. Boarding pass, y'all. 

- Sign up fresh, get two fer one buffet, ya hear me? Don't tell 'em I sent ya. Wink-wink, nudge-nudge. 
- Cash only, no exceptions. Don't be that guy, got it? 
- Thirty-five minute wait at eight o'clock. Hunger pangs, yo. 
- Four bucks to access your own dough. What a gyp! 
- Nigiri sushi, bust. Come early, or it's a bust. 
- Chinese fried chicken, small wings, better than the rest. Word. 
- Tofu stir fry, yum. Hot and sour soup, too. Chicken noodle, yeah. 
- Tacos, always. Not as soggy as Sunset Station. 
- BBQ ribs, bonus! Summer special, you feel me? 
- Chopped sweet potatoes, Sunset gives you the whole shebang."

"Fare thee well, fair sir! How doth thy taste buds fare? Doth thou find delight in fried seafood, prepared with skill and care? Verily, 'tis good, yet somewhat dear. Methinks, at Long John Silvers, thou mayst find a similar feast, at a lower cost, and perchance, with greater haste. In sooth, 'twas naught but mediocre, not worth a verse or prose."
"Decent spread. Seen better, but not bad. Pharmacy folks, friendly and eager to assist. I'll be back for more."

"A hearty selection, full of comforts dear,
No haughty dishes here, nor aught to fear.
For those who shun the fancy, this place doth suit,
With prime rib, a feast fit for a king, no doubt.
And should thou bring thy young ones, fear not,
For they shall find delight in every bite and thought.
But alas, the coffee, poor and weak, doth fail,
To please the palate or to lift the veil."
"Good eatery. Biscuit, top-notch. Lunch, decent. Soup, amazing. Catfish, thin. Fried okra, good. Returning."
"No burger joint. Can't customize, too pricey, basic menu. Five Guys is better."

"Food was decent, ambiance lacking. Employees seemed taken aback by our presence. Paper menus, no music or TV. Felt like we were intruding. Booth had an awkward outdoor sign. Strange seating layout. Food was good, though. Might order delivery, but won't be back for more."

"Saturday nights, Noches Caliente brings the heat. Live band, lively crowd, locals and visitors alike, all eager to dance. Cover's $10, includes a drink, but don't get too fancy. Seating's on three sides of the dance floor, good views of the stage and the dancers. Wear shoes with some grip, that wooden floor's slicker than you think."

"Methinks I oft delight in humble haunts,
Where service tends to be of finest sorts.
But on this day, 'twas not the case, alack!
For slow and disarrayed the service was, in sooth.

Aye, I did order garlic bread, a staple dish,
And found it to be quite tasty, naught amiss.
The bolognese, too, did please mine taste,
Yet naught exceptional, in my honest thought.

In conclusion, methinks 'twas but an average feast,
With naught that did excel, nor aught that did impress."
"Amsterdam, love it. Went there years back for cheap drinks and ladies' night. Show's great, always a good time."

"Ah, Kohl's, thou art a wily store indeed,
Where savings doth await, but only for the keen.
Thou must shop sales and use coupons with great heed,
Lest thou pay too much, and thy budget doth bleed.

But fear not, dear shopper, for I have found
That toys, books, and decor, at Kohl's are profound.
Their selection doth change, like the wind doth blow,
So thou art sure to find the latest, don't ye know.

Kitchen tools, bathroom decor, and frames,
Doth Kohl's possess, in abundance, it claims.
But wait for sales, and use those coupons wise,
For adult clothing, alas, doth come at a prize.

Children's garb, though pricey, doth go on sale,
So bide thy time, and wait for the tale.
Use coupons, stack them high, and watch the cost,
For at Kohl's, savings doth come at any cost."

"Gave 'em a 3, service was lackin', bread crumbs everywhere. First impressions, girls up front were snotty, talked shit about our group. Restaurant's nice, but sat downstairs 'cause some joker rented the top spot. Waiter passed us off to an Asian dude, weird. Food was good, filets, ribeye, sebass, expected. Sides, though, disappointin'. Creamed spinach, mac and cheese, panko all over, gross. Mashed potatoes, no panko, thankful. Boxin' up leftovers, specify, 'cause they only gave us ribeye and one filet, lots left on plates."

"Husband got a call from Pep Boys' manager after my post. He appreciated the apology, but I still think the company and others should know about the poor service we got. Updating the review, adding stars 'cause the manager tried to fix things. Thanks."

"Good Thai grub, but pricey for the Third World digs. Been here a few times, and the food's always on point, but the portions are a bit small. Place smells like a mixture of pine and Lysol, gives me a headache. Sketchy location, in a rundown strip mall with some shady businesses. Saw a guy getting a blowjob from an Oriental woman outside once. Not exactly the kind of place you want to bring out-of-town visitors. Friendly male servers, but the women at the front desk can be a bit testy."
"Pack cash, small bills. Change machine dispenses coins. Gift shop exchanges, but skip the fuss."

"Two chambers booked I did procure,
For mother dear and aunt most sure,
The rooms themselves were fair and bright,
But staff, alas, did leave much to plight.
A problem great did we encounter,
With reservation, causing discontent,
Yet call recorded, did save the day,
And sixty-seven dollars went away.
Alas, I cannot speak too fond,
Of hotel, needing upgrade beyond,
Buffet, promised, did not appear,
And pool, in filth, did leave us queer.
RIO pool, far better, doth seem,
Luxor, in need of work, doth gleam."
"Thursdays, we got trivia. Stick around, fights break out at the bar. Cheap Great Lakes draft, too."

"Feelin' like a punk today. But hey, could ya put down yer drink? I need mine served, pronto. You know, after all that nonsense you spouted 'bout orderin'. Beans ain't bad, but service? Shoddy, kiddo. Shoddy everywhere."

"A fair location, yet too vast, alas,
All seemed a bit lost, in such a space.
A shame, indeed, that at a certain hour,
The club and its folk did change their power.
But elsewise, 'twas a place most fine."

"Pure's alright. It's a bit old-school, but still fun. Nice Grecian vibe with all the flowing curtains. Last time I was there, the bartender was preggers. That was something. My favorite spot's the rooftop bar upstairs. Nice view of the Strip."

"I hit up Metro SB outta convenience, not 'cause I love the joint. It's a weird spot, full a weirdos. Never been there at night, but I reckon it gets real wild. Place is havin' an identity crisis, can't tell if it's a dive, club, restaurant, or pool hall. Don't matter though, I'll still swing by. Just remember, they only take cash, so bring your benjamins or use the ATM - but watch out for them service fees, they'll rip you off."
