"Hark! I must confess, fair friends, I am not yet prepared to don the mantle of a fan, full-fledged and true. For to be such, I would have to journey far and wide, through bustling streets and crowded highways, to wait in line and brave the metal door's mighty slam, all for the sake of savoring their delectable fare. And alas, 'tis not an option for the evening meal, for they close their doors at four, ere the sun doth set. 

But fear not, dear friends, for I didst heed the words of Robert M., and ordered thus: a green chile burrito, enchilada-style, with beans upon the side. The beans, though runny, served their purpose well, as I didst dip my burrito bits within them, and found them good. The sauce, that made it enchilada-style, didst bring a pleasant heat, and I didst find myself well-pleased. 

And so, I say, 'twas A-OK, and I shall return, though mayhap not with such haste and reckless abandon, on a work day, when duties call."
"Biscotti, that's all I got. Flavors were good, but the consistency? Meh. I expected more from PIT's Italian grub. Maybe it was the humidity, but the damn thing just crumbled apart like dust."

"July, went to Koi. No review, till now. Sushi bar, inaccessible. Main dining, it was. Server, nice, apologetic. Salmon, eel, small. Sunset roll, eel, cucumber, avocado, special sauce. Sake flight, enjoyed. Not wheelchair friendly. Food, good. Going back, soon. Three and a half stars."

"I met a friend at TT Roadhouse. She said it had a cool jukebox. It was punk rock, but I found some Jawbreaker tracks. Drinks were decent, and the crowd wasn't the usual Old Scottsdale bunch. Nothing special, but worth a visit if you're nearby."
"Service top-notch. Friendly staff. Food decent, not exceptional. Chicken makhani, best dish. Tikka masala, meh. Naan and paratha, good."

"Family joint, good eats. Pastries, bread, top-notch. Expand the spice rack, sauces, traditional fare. Word of caution: shelves bare, supply and demand? Don't be late, miss out. Apple strudel, get a slice."

"Food at Wynn's place, top-notch as expected. Lobsters, perfectly roasted. Filet, cooked just right. Facility, wonderful. Service though, that's where they dropped the ball. Host staff, friendly, welcoming. Showed us to the bar, then to our table. Personal touch, using names instead of shouting them out. Table service started strong too. Rolled out the lobster cart, ordered right away. Good energy, sense of humor. Then, things went south. Waiter and table staff, not so great. No follow-up on food quality. Had to flag them down for drink refills, multiple times. Price point, Vegas reasonable. Menus online, plan ahead. Service issues, that's what'll keep me from bringing guests back."

"Hark! How fortunate I am to come at a time when all are busy,  
So my thoughts on crowds, I cannot truly divine.  
But one of the check-in staff, a rude knave indeed,  
Doth never greet me, nor doth he show any good cheer.  
He doth ignore my requests, and doth make me ask thrice,  
For a towel, a humble thing, yet he doth not comply.  
And though the rest of the staff, do make me feel welcome,  
This grumpy soul, doth mar my stay, with his scowl and ill temper.  
But still, I find this place, to be clean and swift,  
And folk here, do not pester, nor do they persist."

"Methinks I am most pleased with larger menu choices now.  Two employees, I didst ask, when this change didst occur, and neither knew the answer.  A guess, I do make, 'twas very recent.  My burger, verily, was quite good.  Next time, I shall order it medium rare, for 'twas too well done, to mine own taste.  Hot fries, I didst request, and they were brought forth.  My daughter, alack, didst find the pretzels and beer cheese to be lacking.  A tale, we didst tell, to the waitperson, of the faulty cheese.  Beer cheese, by rights, should be orange and creamy.  Alas, 'twas naught but pretzel bites, with a whitish, watery cheese, that didst taste of naught but salad dressing.  Ranch, it didst resemble, sans the garlic.  My daughter, she didst declare, 'twas awful.  And, upon tasting it, I knew somethings amiss.  Flavorless and watery, it didst lack all taste of cheese or beer.  The waitress, she didst not believe, nor didst she offer to replace it.  Strange, methought, for such a thing, she shouldst have done.  My daughter, she didst order appetizers, instead of a meal, and thus, I didst feel a pang of guilt.  Glad, I am, to see appetizers and other sandwiches, now on the menu.  Goldies, I hadst always thought, didst serve but burgers, wings, and pizzas.  I shall return, and try a sandwich, anon."

"Thou asketh why three stars didst I give, and not five?
'Tis due to ambiance, dear friend, which didst falter. A winery visit shouldst be a pleasing sight, yet naught but dim silence didst greet mine eyes. No music didst fill the air, nor crowds to enliven the space. The servers, too, didst dress in humble garb, a stark contrast to the finery I hadst hoped to behold. 
But fear not, for the food didst make amends, in part. Bruschetta, alas, didst disappoint, being naught but plain toast, small and lacking in flavor. Yet, mushroom risotto, twisted burger, and mac and cheese didst delight, each dish a culinary triumph. Thy taste buds shall be pleased, I do confess. 
The service, too, didst impress, with swift and friendly attendance. 
In conclusion, my dear spouse and I didst enjoy our repast, yet the evening's memories mayst fade, shouldst we ponder future dates."

"Hark! What news is this? Sephora doth stock Korres,
In Fairview, Pointe Claire, a store most fair.
But alas, in Quebec, their shelves doth lack,
Due to packaging laws, a most vexing snare.

A pox upon such rules, that doth impede,
The flow of commerce, and doth cause such need.
For why must we, in search of creams so dear,
Go forth and find them elsewhere, far and near?

But fear not, friends, for Sephora doth provide,
A selection grand, of brands most tried.
And staff, so helpful, doth guide thee well,
To creams of worth, that doth thy soul sell.

Yet, research thou must, before thou doth buy,
For some brands, doth merely meet the eye.
And prices, similar, doth thou find,
As Dr. Hauschka's, with Olgivy's, intertwined.

But woe is me! For Sephora's website doth charge,
A premium, for products, so hard to discharge.
And shipping, free, doth come with a catch,
In Canada, a hundred fifty, the sum to scratch.

So, seek thou out, SkinStore.com, a site most fair,
Where shipping, free, doth come without a snare."

"Methinks 'tis a fair outdoor mall, more suited for those of advanced years, my dear. On a day of warmth, 'tis a pleasant place to stroll, with mist sprays all about, and eateries aplenty to sate thy hunger."

"Hark! A tale of haste and prudence I shall tell,
Of a journey to Vegas, on the Fourth of July,
A last-minute trip, with naught but fate to guide,
We flew in swiftly, and with speed did arrive.

A cab we hailed, and in ten minutes' time,
Didst reach our destination, with nary a dime.
The fare was fair, and with a gratuity,
We paid the sum, and with ease didst enter in.

Six of us, in a suite of two bedrooms, didst abide,
With kitchen full, our needs didst satisfy.
Away from glamour and glitz, we didst choose,
This humble hotel, with shuttle service, didst cruise.

MGM, Mandalay, and airport, didst they take,
And though 'twas not the best, our stay didst make.
An OK rating, we didst give, I pray,
For other hotels, along the strip, didst sway.

A word of wisdom, let this be a sign,
To heed the call, when thy cab doth arrive.
Be prompt, my friends, and tarry not,
Lest thou be left, with naught but regret.

So heed this counsel, and with haste,
Make thy way, to thy appointed place.
For in this city, where lights doth gleam,
Punctuality, doth reign supreme."

"Eastern's got some decent bakeries, but Freed's ain't what it used to be. My family's been gettin' birthday cakes there for years, but the quality's taken a hit. 

I came back from Korea, and Freed's was the first place I went. Their strawberry shortcake, black forest, and fruit tarts were top-notch. But after a few visits, I noticed the cakes were too sweet and a bit dry. Maybe my taste buds changed, or maybe their prices just went up for no good reason. 

People say the service is lackin', but it's more like it's hit or miss. Sometimes they're on top of things, offerin' samples and chattin' with customers. Other times, it's like they don't care."

"Methought, fair readers, we would dine here,
Forsooth, a coupon didst entice mine eyes,
And 'twas the all-natural conceit that didst cheer,
In this place, cleanliness didst reign supreme, by'r lady!

But lo, what disappointment didst we find,
When kiddies' menu, none couldst we espie?
Alack, the staff didst say, 'Tis plain, my friends,
Yon burgers, hot dogs, sans toppings, ye may purchase.

Fries, a separate matter, large, yet scant,
Didst feed us all, but waters, oh so meagre,
In shot glasses, five, they didst present,
In Arizona's heat, a sorry plight, I do declare!

Yet, methinks the victuals, goodly they didst taste,
Burgers, small, but flavourful, in sooth,
And cheese, American, in this place, didst seem out of place.

Mayhap we shall return, but special trip, I doubt,
For here, in this land, of all-natural thought,
We found not what we sought."

"Hark! Our merry band didst take up residence here,
In this, the city of sin and mirth,
For our revels and sport, we didst choose well,
But alas, our lodgings didst leave much to be desired.

A burlap sack, I swear, wouldst have been preferable,
For the rooms, they didst lack in comfort and in cheer,
Especially in the "old building", where my friend didst reside,
With naught but two beds and a television to abide.

The service at the front desk, it didst seem,
Was nonexistent, and the bellhop, he didst appear,
Angry at us, as if we hadst done him wrong,
And the World Fare Buffet, oh how it didst go wrong!

A food court within the casino, full of woe,
With eateries most foul, that didst make us say,
"Alas, this place doth need a transformation,
To rival other hotels and casinos in this town."

"Methinks DH and I didst venture forth to Upper Crust,
For happy hour, with pizza and wings, we didst trust.
The pizza, verily, didst taste of Grimaldi's flair,
But alas, the wings, a single star didst bear.
The atmosphere, with shadows dark and deep,
Didst lack the colors that our spirits doth keep.
Yet, numerous televisions, for sporting games, didst abound,
A curious sight, indeed, in this place around."

"Torn between three and four stars, I was. Standard cocktails, but nothing special. Atmosphere, bare and empty. Service, average. Bartender, unenthusiastic. Ice, too small. Agnatha, crisp and tart. August 21st, smoky. Convenient, yes. Parking, plenty. Location, close. Solid drinks, yes. Table, no worry. Back, I will come."
"Sushi, great. Spicy tuna, must-try. Steak, fillet mignon, decent. Chicken, dry, but saved by teriyaki sauce. Impressed, overall. Back in town, will return."
"Avoid this joint if you got kids over eight. Place is tailored for youngins below that age. Laser tag's fun, but watch out for the little tykes."

"Food's alright here. Nothin' special, but nothin' terrible neither. Just your standard fare, ya know? Been here a few times, decent service, but the grub's just sorta...meh. Like it's all been pre-packaged or somethin'. Frozen, maybe."

"Ritz bar and restaurant, Bistro 24. Friday night delight. Grill Night buffet, worth every penny. Appetizers, oysters, lobster, tuna, filet mignon, shrimp, duck, cheese. Sushi stand, enough said. Grill, filet mignon, lamb chops, salmon, shrimp, mashed potatoes, grilled greens. Dessert stand, decadent. Wine list, va bene."

"Good eats can be found in unexpected places. Take this joint, for instance - it's tucked away in a dingy strip mall, but don't let that deter you. Inside, it's cozy, clean, and serving up some top-notch grub. My buddy and I stumbled upon it, and we were mighty glad we did. Their chips were crispy, the dip was delish, and the rice was on point. Portions were generous too. My friend, a chile relleno aficionado, gave it high praise - said it was one of the best she'd had. We'll be back, no doubt about it."

"Ere I purchased the Groupon, I perused each review,
So well prepared, I knew what lay in store.
A master of delay, I waited till the last,
And fortunate was I, for they found a way to accommodate me.

Jennifer and Kelly, a pair of skilled lasses,
Tended to my nails, their touch, a gentle caress.
Their work, a hour and a half, did take,
Friendly, they were, and their skill, did make.

Two gripes, I had, a minor quibble,
Awkward, the chair, for my pedi, did feel.
Couches, they had, for the ladies, fair,
More comfortable, it did seem, I did declare.

Nude shades, my preference, they lacked,
Explained, they did, their policy, quite attacked.
One more visit, discounted, I shall have,
Then full price, a pretty penny, I shall crave."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Verily, the victuals and attendance upon them were most excellent, a true feast for mine eyes and belly. Howbeit, there was this one odd fellow, with his cur at his side, within the establishment. Trow, 'twas a breach of hygiene standards, and didst stir within me a sense of unease. Fie upon him, say I!"

"Upon a time, a friend and I didst make reservations at this place,
During Restaurant Week, our hunger to satiate.
The atmosphere, though welcoming, didst feel a bit too neat,
But drinks, they were, and potent, didst our spirits greet.

I started with a plate of pickles, varied and fine,
Which didst prepare my taste buds for the feast divine.
For entree, I chose the trout, pan-seared to perfection,
With barley risotto, a dish of pure elation.

And for dessert, key lime pie, my heart didst sing,
For I cannot resist its sweet and tangy zing.
In conclusion, 'twas a pleasant experience, indeed,
And I do look forward to return, and more to read."

"Upon the eve of love, I chanced upon this place,
Vintage, where romance doth fill the air,
A patio, by the fire, didst provide a space,
For me to sit, and savor wine so fair.

Their Sangria, oh how sweet and fine,
Didst quench my thirst, and made me feel divine,
And on most Saturdays, a singer, Sarah,
Doth grace the stage, with voice so rare.

A place for lovers, or for friends to meet,
Vintage doth provide, a setting so discreet,
So if thou art in search of charm and grace,
Come hither, and let Vintage be thy place."

"Hark! A Bricktop's update doth come anon,
And with it, news of their most excellent brunch.
Forsooth, my friend did sing a sweet melody
Of Bricktop's feast, and thus, we did converge
Upon this SouthPark haven, with haste and glee.

Their brunch menu, diverse and grand,
Doth rival their lunch and dinner fare,
In style, New American eclectic, 'tis true.
A bloody mary bar, thou mayst create thy own,
Or choose from special drinks, like blood orange mimosas,
Bellinis by the carafe, a wondrous sight, indeed.

My taste buds, they did dance with joy,
At the French Toast, a dish most divine,
Brioche slices, big and fluffy, with caramelized bananas,
Warm maple syrup, fresh whipped cream, and crispy bacon,
A feast fit for a king, or queen, for that matter,
All for the sum of eleven silver pieces.

If thou art feeling quite indulgent, fair sir,
Do try the bite-sized homemade doughnut starter,
Thirteen sugary doughnuts, with dipping sauces three,
Raspberry, chocolate, and vanilla cream, a delightful treat.

The brunch bill, it may rise high and steep,
But fear not, for 'tis worth each penny, mark my word.
So, give Bricktop's a visit, and revel in their cheer,
For their brunch, it doth rival any other, I do aver."

"Hark! Cantina doth rock indeed,
A place of gustatory wonders, 'tis decreed.
Though exterior doth not suggest such delight,
Within its walls, a feast doth take flight.

On weekends, young and loud doth throng,
But fear not, 'tis no fraternity strong.
Reserve a table, wait thou shalt,
Yet, trust me, 'tis worth it all.

Cantina boasts all that's good and fine,
Margaritas top-shelf, a taste divine.
Kiwi/Strawberry Special, try thou must,
A refreshing twist, a flavor just.

Good Mexican brews, on tap they flow,
Drink up, my friend, for all do so.
Food, oh food, how to describe,
Chopped tostada salad, a dream come alive.
Refried beans, pulled chicken, all doth please,
But Kobe beef fajitas, my heart doth seize.

Back I shall go, but plan not I,
A big night, for full and tired doth lie.
Scene is fun, loud, yet a gentle warning,
Eat, drink, enjoy, but pace thyself, my morning."

"Hark, good sir! The victuals here be of the finest sort,
A feast for thine eyes and thy belly, no doubt.
But, alas, 'tis a popular place, I do declare,
And at noon, the crowd doth swell, with nary a chair.
So, prithee, come early, or tarry till late,
That thou mayst find a seat, and partake of this feast with ease."
"Cheap beer, decent grub. That's what you're here for. Place can get rowdy, but that's part of the charm. Blue collar joint, through and through."

In fair Montreal, we chanced upon a tavern old,
With prices reasonable, our spirits bold.
The open air did grant us fine views of folk,
And staff, most kind, did our hearts beset.
But lo, dear friends, the victuals they did lack,
Save grilled cheese, hot plate-cooked, a sorry snack.

"Borealis, my go-to spot in Cambridge. They live by the motto 'think globally, act locally.' Menu's full of local flavors, drinks too. Consistent quality, occasional changes based on what's fresh. Decent selection of Ontario brews and vinos. Service is solid, not exceptional. Cozy converted schoolhouse, nice patio out front. Check the specials, good drink deals. Worth 4 stars, pricey though."

"Verily, 'tis a wondrous shoppe, where treasures lie hid,
A chance discovery, fortune's whim, doth provide.
For though the wares be varied, and fortune's hand doth play,
I've found, each time I entered, riches beyond compare.

BabyGap jeans, a prize most fair and bright,
Janie and Jack, The Children's Place, in abundance doth shine.
My heart doth sing with joy, for this shoppe doth hold,
A trove of gems, fit for a queen, or so it doth seem.

And now, with child once more, the maternity sect,
Doth call to me, with promise of comfort and ease.
So shall I venture forth, and see what wonders lie,
In this, my favorite shoppe, where bargains doth abound."

"Fear not, dear friends, if wine doth not tickle thy fancy; for there be plenty of other potions to please thy palate. I chanced upon this establishment at noon, and by the stars, what an excellent experience didst I have! The servants were quick and kind, the victuals most delectable. Verily, 'twas a feast fit for a king!"

"Sauce runs the show at Canes. It's the real MVP. Chicken's alright, fries are meh. But that sauce, damn. I need four extra every visit. Dip my chicken, dip my fries. Slaw? Meh. Substitute more toast, please."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy and mirth,
For this place, it doth be my utmost dearth!
Both locations, they do please mine eyes,
But the west side, it doth take the prize.

A score of vegetarian dishes, they do proffer,
And I, a creature of habit, do devour them with great zest.
The Bruschette Salad, it doth delight,
And the Athens Fries, they doth make my senses take flight.

Verily, I say, this place doth hold a special place,
In mine heart, it doth find its dwelling space.
For those who seek good food and cheer,
Come hither, friends, and cast away fear!"

"Driving through Henderson, searching for a decent spot to grab some grub. Strip malls everywhere, chains galore. Almost gave in to Taco Bell when I spotted a gem - Trader Joe's! Newly opened, it shined like a beacon in the desert. Clean, spacious aisles, stocked with all sorts of goodies. Best part? Not mobbed like the city locations. 

Hit up their pre-made sandwiches, few veggie choices, but scored a PB&J lunch bag for $3.49. First time seeing such a treat, and it hit the spot. Half a PB&J, crisp apple slices, 100 calorie cookies, string cheese, mini water bottle. Bread was a bit dry, PB&J filling a tad stiff, but the rest kept me satisfied. 

Solid deal for under four bucks. Hoping to find it again when I return to SF."

"In this locality, there be few eateries to choose from, thus Squid Ink doth quench mine appetite for sushi. More oft than not, I do opt for takeaway o'er dining within its walls, and service hath been prompt with victuals of passable quality. Their happy hour, methinks, doth offer fair value, provided thou art content with simpler rolls. Worthy of mention, 'tis a tad dear in price for its worth."

"Hark! What news is this? Do people truly rate
Airports with such fervor and debate?
As if they had a choice, a say in the matter,
And their words held sway o'er the city's fate.

But nay, fair friends, forsooth, 'tis but a dream,
A fleeting thought that doth deceive the mind.
For who, in truth, doth choose a city based
On its airport's merits, or lack thereof?

And yet, methinks, this wondrous sight doth prove
The power of words, the might of human voice.
For though we may not choose, we still can speak,
And share our thoughts, our feelings, our joys.

So let us raise our voices, friends, and shout
Our praise or censure, loud and clear,
For though we may not choose the airport's form,
Our words, at least, shall echo far and near."

"Trypt isn't the hotspot in Vegas anymore, but it's still a sweet club. XS's sister joint with the outdoor waterfall and chill vibes. Girls get wild on the poles while dudes snap pics like paparazzi. Music's solid too. Bars were slammed, but we only hit up the one near the dance floor. \n\nRolled in around 1 am with my crew - two gals and two dudes - after catching a lackluster show (KA, peep my review) and getting our drink on at the tables. I had put my name down for guestlist earlier, but they let us in free and easy, no hassle. That's how you make a club experience smooth."

"Hark! This humble abode may seem plain, yet its flavors do delight.  In truth, most Triple D joints we've tried have fallen short, leaving us to ponder the cost of their fame.  But Flavors of Louisiana doth bring forth a culinary dream!  Their dishes, a symphony of taste, smell, and appearance, do please.  Aye, a liquor license, that we might quench our thirst with a frothy brew, would make them truly great.  Our hunger, sated by the 'go' box, did crave their fish anew.  Reheated, it proved the flavors came from within, not from excessive grease without.  Methinks the Gumbo, loved by Mother dear, didst lack not slimy okra chunks.  Oysters, chicken, and catfish, all worthy dishes, didst please our men.  Alas, the tater salad, though enjoyable, didst lack meat in sufficient quantity and size.  Dirty rice, too, didst suffer from this same defect.  Yet, despite these flaws, our time at Flavors of Louisiana didst bring us joy."
"Sandwiches, great. Fill me up, two, maybe three. Pricey, sure. Taste, good. Friends, go. Lines, long."

"Went there for our 10th anniversary. Knew what to expect since we'd been before. Menu's more a la carte now, which is good. You can skip courses to save money or go all out with the endless fondue. Came with a Groupon and they were cool about it. Didn't love the Swiss cheese fondue, but hubby did, so maybe it was just me. Other courses were great. Serving sizes were decent. Split a dessert and it was enough. Service was a bit slow, but it's not the place for a quick meal anyway. I like to take my time and enjoy myself."

"Went to Caffe Boa after seeing Payton slaughter a pig at Devoured. Had to check it out. Ordered fries in a big paper cone as an appetizer. Damn good. Sauces were great too. Calzone was decent, but not what I expected. Flatbread was strange, but the fillings were good. Service was fine, patio was nice, but the strip mall vibe wasn't my thing. Hope the rent is worth it."

"Hark! If thou hast perused my ramblings, thou wouldst know
That franchise eateries hold little sway with me.
But lo! Texas Roadhouse, an exception doth make,
A place where service, steak, and value do abound.
I've visited eight of their establishments wide,
In five states diverse, and found naught to deride.
This location, too, doth meet my lofty standards,
Our server, skilled; the victuals, savory and neat;
The call ahead seating, a minute's brief delay,
A trifling inconvenience, soon forgot, I ween."

"Smooth, rich, flavorful...vegan?  I didst harbor doubts about attempting soy gelato, but after sampling the spicy chocolate, I was ensnared.  A medley of chocolate soy and regular mixed berry didst grace my palate, and though both were delectable, the mixed berry was somewhat icy in texture, lacking the velvety smoothness of its counterpart.  The spicy chocolate didst boast a wealth of rich, spicy flavor, with nary a hint of soy's tangible essence.  Verily, a most excellent establishment for indulging one's sweet tooth!"

"A capital breakfast place, 'tis but a short drive from the bustling strip, yet worth the journey, prithee! We arrived ere break of noon, and lo, the house was full, a Wednesday, mind thee. So, later in the day, and on the weekends, prepare thyself for a wait, an it please thee.

"We were straightway seated, and our order taken, with all due haste. Mama's French toast, with eggs and choice of meat, did we select, and sausage, I did choose. Anthony, the ham steak plate, with toast, potatoes, and eggs, did he select, and Texas toast, he did choose. And verily, the victuals were cooked aright, and did please our taste, in sooth.

"I do confess, a hearty breakfast doth make my day, and this, it did fulfill. And Mr. Mama, the master of the house, didst himself attend to us, a kind and dedicated host, with a family's love, did he show. A pleasant sight, indeed, to see him offer coffee to his guests, with a smile, and a cheerful word, did he bestow."

"Hark, 'twas many moons since last I graced these halls,
But today, a play didst entice me to return,
'Takin over the Asylum', a grand production indeed,
Within this theatre, classic beauty doth abound,
A chandelier, grand and majestic, doth hang,
And students, on Wednesdays, may purchase tickets for a song."

"Hark! What words of wisdom doth Nicole W. speak?
'Tis true, my friends, Alexander Michael's doth provide
A haven for those seeking sustenance and cheer,
In the 4th ward, a place most quaint and dear.

For those who dwell nearby, 'tis a spot most prime,
Where simple fare and fine ale doth abound,
And chicken pita, oh so tender and divine,
Doth satisfy thy hunger, sans a doubt.

But lo! A beam doth grace the ladies' room,
A curious sight, indeed, yet no cause for alarm,
For in its presence, one doth feel quite at home,
In this cozy space, where food and drink doth flow.

Alas, a small complaint doth trouble mine ear,
The telly in the dining hall, a strange affair,
Yet still, the atmosphere doth make amends,
With low ceilings, a snug and cosy den.

So, gather 'round, my friends, and heed my word,
For Alexander Michael's doth stand, unheard,
A gem in the 4th ward, worth a visit, thou shalt see,
A place of solace, food, and merriment, for thee."

"Verily, this place doth please mine eyes,
I do beseech thee, give it a try.
Upon entrance, gaze downward, friend,
For thou dost stand upon a fishy fiend.
The decor, most trendy, doth impress,
And atmosphere, most chill, doth bless.
A drink we did imbibe at bar,
Upon a Wednesday eve, most fair.
Then forth we went, to patio's embrace,
Where dinner did await, with nary a trace.
Sushi, most delectable, doth delight,
Freshness, in every morsel, doth take flight.
Alas, one quibble, I must confess,
The bathroom sink, a wondrous mess.
Faucets, they do not work, I do declare,
Unless with force, the handle thou dost slam,
And then, the water doth spray, most queer,
In errant bursts, a sight most strange, I fear.
Yet, all else, most excellent, doth be,
This place, a gem, doth shine, for thee to see."

"Furr's Restaurant, a blast from the past. Grand and Sun City, just off the 101 Highway. Been around since the 50s, but still looking sharp. Had a swell time with some Yelp buddies - Rand, Mike, and Scott. Cafeteria-style, but you can go back for more, all for the same price. No digging through leftovers, just straight up service. Classic American grub, try a bit of everything. Tasty and fresh, can't wait to go back."

Hark, my friends, I've oft visited Culver's abode,
Where my son doth revel in their tasty fare,
And the cheese curds, oh how they do astound!
But, alas, I thought it overpriced, I swear,
Until I chanced upon Five Guys, good sirs,
Their burgers beckoned me with savory cheer,
And thus, I saw the light, and all my fears
Did vanish like mist at dawn's early beam.
Now, Culver's, thou art better than the rest,
In Surprise, thy burgers do surpass the best,
And Five Guys, though dear, doth not compare,
For thou art cheaper, and thy fare more fair.
So, here's to thee, Culver's, may thy reign
Endure, and may thy customers remain
Forever satisfied, and in blissful thrall,
To thy delectable shakes, burgers, and fries,
And, of course, those heavenly cheese curds, that doth enthrall!

"Fair priced, delicious plant-based dishes, served with grace and care. Tunes play softly in the background, as I sip my tea and ponder life's mysteries. Though the menu be small, 'tis more than made up for by the sweet, sweet pies that lay within. A cozy space, where one can work and dine, free from distractions and worldly cares."

"O, how I adore Grand Lux Cafe, a place most fair and bright!
Though not as grand as the Venetian site, 'tis still a wondrous sight.
The servers, friendly and attentive, make our dining experience delightful.
The atmosphere, spacious and clean, doth please mine eyes and senses.
Aye, verily, a joy 'tis to partake of victuals herein.

Methinks, dear friends, thou shouldst try the Molten Chocolate Cake,
A sweet indulgence that doth live up to its name, by the lake!
So, order it forthwith, lest ye wait overlong,
For 'tis prepared with care, and taketh some twenty minutes to arrive, ere ye can savor its rich, chocolatey delight."

"Amidst the throngs of travelers, I did find
A haven in this hotel, clean and fair.
The chamber, spacious, modern, and divine,
Did boast a bed most comfortable, with pillows rare.

The shower, too, did please mine eyes,
With shelf and lighting, pressure that doth rise.
A mirror, lit and swiveling, did allow
Me, shaving in the shower, a gentle repose.

The halls were quiet, ventilation fine,
A testament to comfort, all divine.
The staff, though pleasant, cooperative,
Did falter somewhat, with room service unpredictive.

Yet still, the site, most fortunate,
Not on the Strip, a blessing, most elate."

"This joint? Love it. Found it through LocalDines. Been our go-to spot for date nights ever since. Only tried the dinner menu, but what they got, they got right. Variety keeps us comin' back for more. \n\nBlue Corn Enchiladas, Chimi with that sour cream green chile sauce? Don't miss 'em. And the Guacammus and Waffle Fries? Appetizers done right. You won't regret it."

"Methinks 'twas a most pleasant sojourn we had at this place, my friends! Arriving betimes on a Thursday eve, we didst partake of their libations, and lo! The bartender didst inform us that all well drinks were gratis for the first hour. A most fortuitous circumstance, indeed! Alas, poor wight, the one amongst us who didst order a drink of higher price didst pay dearly for his folly. The ambiance was most tranquil, with seats aplenty and music that didst stir our spirits. Mark me, good sirs, this place doth merit a visit, despite its location from the Strip. 'Tis worth the small fee for a hackney coach, arrive betimes, and take advantage of their generosity in offering well drinks without cost."

"This place gets a bum rap. Sure, it ain't Wrigley, but the seats are comfy, the weather don't ruin the game, they got real grass, and the layout's way better. You never gotta walk far for a dog or a john. \n\nAnd let's be real 'bout the Suns. In the last decade, the D-Backs been the local team with the best shot at a title."

Mystery Castle's got a strange allure. Guy who built it used recycled materials, like burned bricks. They were neat. Tour guides were friendly, too. Cash only, but worth it. Creator? Not so much. He abandoned his kid, then built a castle for her. Had a fancy bar, too. Wished I could've met Mary Lou. She's the interesting one. Experience was cool, but dad's actions were messed up. That's what my husband and I talked about after.

"Verily, fair friends, the service here doth please,
But lo, the prices now do cause dismay.
Forsooth, the cost of dining here hath grown,
And withal, the victuals' taste doth wane.
Thus, I do say, my visits now are fewer,
For 'tis a pity to pay more for less, anon."

"Aye, fair Parc Jean Drapeau, thou bring'st back fond memories of days past, when first I courted my love, my heart's desire. Each eve, we'd stroll an hour long, amidst thy verdant paths and shaded nooks, our spirits lifted by thy beauty and grace. Thy winding trails, thy tranquil spaces, and all the merry festivals that bloom within thy borders, make thee a jewel of Montreal, a treasure to behold. When seek'st a pleasant day beneath the sun, and wish not to depart the isle, then hie thee hence, and revel in thy charms."

"Methinks 'twould be a 5, save for one thing, which shall be told anon. First off, they gave us far too much victual for our coin. Not that I do complain, but verily, a plethora of grub. The carnitas, by Jove, were most excellent, crispy in some parts, spiced to perfection, and of a texture most divine. The last time I didst taste such carnitas, 'twas some eight years past, in fair Mexico. The tortilla, hot and fresh, didst complement the dish most well. The service, swift and friendly, didst round out the experience most satisfactorily. And lo, they be open at all hours, a boon indeed, forsooth. My sole gripe, a minor quibble, methinks, the taco shell of mine own taco, o'ercooked and somewhat hard. But, all else, perfection itself!"

Minecci's, my dearest husband and I have oft frequented,
Their pasta dishes, alas, we have not tried,
But what we have, hath been most delectable,
A lightly battered cod, with marinara sauce, and a few olives nigh.

The breading, mayhap, could be dispensed with,
But verily, 'tis a dish most wondrous still,
Soups, have always been of good quality,
Salads, plain, yet servicable, no need to fulminate.

Yet, one dish, doth leave me in dismay,
Their veal parmigiana, so cheap, they say,
For 'tis ground meat, not a filet, I fear,
And thus, my friends, doth leave me in despair.

Atmosphere, of yore, doth seem,
A bit dim, yet cozy, doth it gleam,
Decor, in fair condition, doth appear,
A place for love, or family cheer.

Not for urbanites, a night so bright,
But for those who seek a peaceful sight,
Minecci's, shall be, a place most meet,
For a low-key date, or family treat.

"Hark! What treasures lie within this space!
A veritable cornucopia of finery and grace.
The wares for women, oh so fair and bright,
Do dazzle mine eyes with their splendor and light.
But alas, my purse doth protest loud and clear,
For I, a humble traveler, have spent too dear.
At outlet stores, my coin did freely flow,
And now, my heart doth ache with woe.
This place, so full of life and energy,
Doth pulsate with a noise that doth assail me.
A cashier, with modern ways, doth vex me sore,
For he, with cards alone, doth make us wait once more.
In San Francisco, carts we used to bear,
But here, small baskets pull our purchases fair.
I pity him who doth the mess behold,
When day doth end and night doth take its hold."

"I've had my fair share of meals at this joint, and let me tell you, it's top-notch. Family-owned, through and through. You can taste it in the food, the way they take pride in their recipes. It's a mix of Italian and American cuisine, but don't let that fool you. Their prime rib, pork, seafood, and caesar salad are all top-shelf. I stick to the Italian dishes, can't help myself. That linguine with king crab and crispy leeks in lemon butter sauce? Divine. My husband's a fan of the old-school spaghetti and Kobe meatballs. Service is impeccable, and the decor? Spectacular. Wine list is endless, cocktails galore. This place oozes sex appeal."

"Hark! A culinary find, my dearest friend,
In KJ kitchen, where doth Yelp doth wend.
A first-time visit, and oh, what joy didst bring,
For food most wondrous, doth our taste buds sing!

Pork belly, oxtail, red wine, pork chop too,
Cantonese style, all dishes didst shine anew.
Complimentary soup and dessert, a sweet delight,
Our hunger sated, with nary a single bite.

The crowd, it swelled, as evening drew near,
We waited patiently, without a speck of fear.
Yet, verily, the wait, it was worth the while,
For flavors such as these, doth make us smile.

Aye, we shall return, at an earlier hour,
To savor more, of KJ kitchen's power.
Great victuals, that didst not disappoint,
A gem found, in this culinary quest."

"As I strolled through yonder airport, bound for my gate,
My thoughts did turn to victuals, and the sorry state
Of fare that oft doth plague the traveler, left to choose
Betwixt the bland and bitter, or the sweet but crude.

But lo! A beacon of hope, a shining light,
Did break upon my sight, in form of Blanco bright.
The angels sang their praise, in chorus sweet and clear,
For in this place, I found a culinary cheer.

In Tucson's hills, I had beheld its peer,
A feast for taste buds, and a wonder to hear.
What joy! What bliss! In this dire food domain,
A haven, a reprieve, a fish taco, so plain.

Well done, fair Phoenix airport, thy name doth stand
For offering succor, in a land of gastric woe.
Thy fish tacos, a wise choice, a veritable find,
A gem amidst the dross, a treasure to behold, a true delight."

"People in there were top-notch. RN in cardiac unit, Morgan, was a real sport. Cheerful, helpful, took the edge off. Facility's a bit worn, but that's understandable. Hinges on my bathroom door screamed all night, water faucet shook the room. Easy fixes, but they detract from the overall experience. My wife and I have been admitted to John C. Lincoln before, and we trust 'em to take care of us."

"A company most fair and true,
Their prices, quite affordable, I do declare.
Inventory aplenty, a feast for the eyes,
A challenge, indeed, to make a choice so wise.

We chose wood laminate, a fine selection,
For our downstairs, a transformation, a new dimension.
Baseboards, new, a perfect complement,
A finish, most elegant, a true event.

Honest folk, these people, a joy to work with,
Their integrity, a beacon, a shining light.
We'll use them again, when upstairs we renovate,
For their expertise, a treasure, a true delight."

"In fair Las Vegas, a city of delight,
I chanced upon a noodle house, a sight most bright.
Their spicy tonkotsu ramen, a dish divine,
Did please my taste buds, and left me in a shrine.

Their fried rice, a savory treat, did satisfy,
And gyoza, crispy and flavorful, did catch my eye.
The prices, too, did seem most fair and cheap,
Compared to those in the Bay Area, where I oft do sleep.

So, should my ramen cravings return,
To this place I shall again turn,
And try their Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen, a dish most dear,
For in its depths, I sense a culinary cheer."
"Mesa exceeded expectations. Flavors popped. Ribeye, jalapeno cornbread, both A+. Great for groups. Scored a sweet 3-course deal during restaurant week for $56."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place, wherein I've dwelt since youthful days. Thai victuals, oh so delectable! Alas, a quibble doth arise, forsooth, in form of rice surcharge, two dollars fifty, when four or more partake. Yet, barring this, 'tis most excellent fare, and I, withal, would urge all seekers of novel culinary delights, to partake of this establishment's bounty."

"Methinks 'twas passing fair, with choices many to select.
In a prime site, 'twas simple to detect.
Yet, alack, my mind didst not receive a wondrous impact,
For all that 'twas, didst seem but commonplace, I reckon."

"O, what a wondrous bartender, skilled in his craft!
And entrees, they do please mine taste, so fine and fair.
But lo, the sashimi, priced so high, doth vex me sore,
For half the quality, twice the cost, I do declare.
Alack, the finest fish, I did not find, alas!
Yet, lamb belly, oh so tender, doth make my heart sing.
I didst have the rabbit dish, but, alack, not first,
For naught can compare to lamb, so sweet and fair."

Monday night, took the kids out for an early dinner. They were hungry, and the joint offered free grub for the little ones on Mondays. Hostesses looked like they were just hangin' out, but the reviews said the service was gonna be rough. Turns out, we got sat down quick and the waitress was on top of things. She wasn't all up in our business every ten seconds, but she made sure we had everything we needed. Some dude in plain clothes came by, asked if everything was cool. We said yeah, and a few minutes later, he snuck up behind me and grabbed my empty cup. Asked if my waitress was gettin' me another beer. Told him no, and that was that. Guy must've been a manager, but he coulda introduced himself. Good chow, good service. Oh, and happy hour's from 11 to 7, Monday through Friday.

"Hate this joint? Can't blame 'em. Line's a bitch, wraps 'round the block like a snake. Reminds me of that damn Indy ride at Disneyland. But hey, got my Fast Pass, skipped the whole shebang. People waitin' since 10 pm? Shit, that's crazy. 

Inside, the devil in me comes out. Not literal, of course. Place is a madhouse, makes you lose your mind. Don't usually listen to house music, but somethin' 'bout this joint gets me movin'. Jumpin' up and down like a fool. 

It's a big-ass club, plenty of room for everyone. Folks here just wanna have a good time. Night ends early mornin', my dogs barkin' for mercy. XS, you've been good to me."
"Mac Shack, great place. Pasta, fresh veggies, friendly folks. Ordered carryout, still tasted great at home. Veggie options, yep."

"Methinks 'tis FroYo place most fair,
Which doth my heart's desire ensnare.
In truth, 'tis nigh to CenPho's bounds,
Where "Twitter Tuesday" doth abound.
Their flavors, consistent, ne'er do fade,
Nor toppings, which my taste doth sway.
A creature of habit, I do confess,
Cookie Monster, my choice, doth impress.
Tiny PB cups, so small, yet sweet,
Do make my frozen treat complete.
Alas, the price, a tad higher, doth seem,
Than other shops, where frozen dreams do gleam.
But Twitter, I do follow, 'tis true,
And Tuesdays, there, my visits do accrue.
A "secret" word, whispered with glee,
Doth grant half-off, a bargain, 'tis to see.
Two frogurt treats, for me and mine own,
For five dollars, a price most unknown."

"Methinks 'tis a fair establishment, where one may partake of a delectable sandwich at a most reasonable cost, especially given its proximity to the city center. I didst sample their All-American offering, which, alack, didst contain cranberries, a fruit that doth not oft please mine taste. My love, however, didst enjoy his Cannonball, a dish that didst earn his hearty approval."

"Matt Goss, Palms hotel and casino. Saw him perform, same power, same passion. Caesar's Palace, next stop. Phenomenal show, guaranteed. Strong stage presence, svelte voice, dancing, loves the audience. Great band, sexy dancers. Singing, moving, grooving. Next chance, Caesar's Palace, definitely. Sexy show, pure sex."

In sooth, I knew not what to make of this place,
Being within the Plaza hotel's embrace.
But lo, the victuals didst please mine eyes,
A poke bowl, my belly didst surprise.
My spouse, she didst try the seared ahi dish,
And found it to be most wondrous and delish.
Yet, if thou art in search of poke,
Poke Express, up Craig road, doth brook.

"Hark! I knew not what to expect from this play,
But feared it might be cheesy in some way.
Yet, to my delight, it was not so,
For it was witty, humorous, and had a bit of show.

Afore the curtain rose, two men did play,
One on the piano, and one on bass, I pray.
The bassist, Penn, didst blend in with the crowd,
As if he were a part of it, and not proud.

Throughout the play, the actors didst engage,
With those who watched, in merry dialogue and page.
And when it ended, Penn and Teller didst wait,
To meet and greet each person, ere they didst depart,
Which showed their love and care for those who came,
To see their play, and share in their good name."

"Methinks 'tis a grand fete, where joy doth reign supreme! Huzzah!

Verily, if thou dost cherish the radiant sun and merry folk, then hast thou found thy haven.

Aye, the entrance fee may seem a mite steep, yet for a full day's mirth and merriment, 'tis a fair price to pay. I do recommend this festal gathering, with all its delightful trappings."

"Hark! My friend, a local of this fair city,
Didst introduce me to this place, so pretty.
She bade me ride the shuttle, free of charge,
From the strip, where driving is most large.

Sam's Town, the name of this wondrous site,
With interior grand, a western delight.
Two floors of gaming, and a cinema vast,
A buffet, with food most tasteful and vast.

Prime Rib, the theme of the day, so fine,
I did not know of the bowling alley divine.
I shall return, to gamble once more,
For luck didst smile upon me, evermore.

The cocktail waitresses, with drinks so fine,
Came round oft, to make my heart sing.
A great experience, indeed, it was,
I shall take the shuttle, to Sam's Town, anon."

"Methinks I've been a member of Massage Heights for nigh on nine months now, and verily, I fear I shall not renew it again. Forsooth, I do enjoy their establishment, but alas, my workplace, a resort upon the strip, doth offer additional perks which make the experience all the more pleasant. Trow, 'tis the small touches that doth make the difference, such as water and healthy victuals before and after the massage. Yea, though my work doth not provide a membership, I do believe 'tis worth the coin now and again. Thus, I shall fulfill my one-year contract with Massage Heights, but shall not renew it, forsooth, for I believe I may find better service elsewhere."

"Tram's, a place of some renown,
I've visited oft, with varied crown.
Their Pho, a dish of no small fame,
Hath pleased me well, save for the game.
Of basil and mint, a plentiful share,
Doth make the broth most fair and rare.
Other dishes, too, they do prepare,
With skill and art, beyond compare.
A short menu, but one of great might,
And service, swift and full of delight.
This place, so busy, night and day,
A wonder, given its humble way.
Better than Minh, up the street,
Spice Island still, doth hold the seat."

"Methinks I do approach Thai establishments with caution, my dear,
For oft have I encountered Massaman most queer.
Salty as the sea, or raw as the day it was caught,
Or flavorless, like a dish without any thought.

But fear not, fair reader, for this tale doth change,
For I didst find a Massaman of rare range.
The potatoes, cooked through, a delight to chew,
And shrimp, with tails intact, a sight anew.

The sauce, akin to bisque, a taste most fine,
Didst bring joy to my senses, and made me decline
All other dishes, save the rice, a gummy mess,
And coconut ice cream, a sweetness I must confess.

So, if thou art in search of Massaman true,
And a meal that doth please, as well as renew,
Then seek out this place, with wooden decor so bright,
And enjoy a feast, fit for a king, this night."

"Hark! This place doth please mine taste, I say,
In group of many, diverse dishes did play.
Foie gras, spicy crab, and tuna tartare,
For appetites, did make their entrance fair.

And for main course, 'twas surf and turf, they call,
With fois, a huge chunk, and butterfish, standing tall.
On bed of shredded sprouts, black truffle sauce did flow,
Decadence, indeed, doth this dish bestow.

Other dishes, too, didst taste, with glee,
Creamed spinach, gnocchi, lobster au curry, for thee.
Spinach, oh so fine, didst make my heart sing,
Amidst these flavors, my senses did take wing.

Desserts, a trio, didst delight mine eyes,
Chocolate souffle, mix candy bar, and chocolate surprise.
Pistachio ice cream, a worthy mate, didst accompany,
Souffle, the best, a sweet symphony."

"This joint's always been a go-to of mine. Their gyros? Top-notch, kid. Tender lamb, zesty sauce. Eight bucks, but worth it. You can also score a combo with fries and a drink for a couple bucks more. Give it a shot. Feels like a mom-and-pop spot, don't know if it's corporate."

"Hark, what cheerful spot doth lie before mine eyes!
A place where friends may gather, laugh and love,
And partake in sweet libations, savory bites.
The atmosphere, it doth delight,
As doth the drinks, with prices most fair and bright.
Sushi, nigiri, martinis of diverse kind,
All served with mirth and joy, to make our minds inclined.
And should we sit at yonder sushi bar,
We may behold the chefs, their skills to show,
Preparing our repast, with speed and care,
A feast for eyes and belly, beyond compare."

"Hark! If thou seeketh a burger most fair,
In Las Vegas, this place doth hold a rare gem.
Crisp fries, both sweet and savory, doth abound,
And burgers, oh so juicy, doth astound.

Bahn Mi and Kalbi, twain favorites of mine,
With flavors rich, and spices most divine.
Yet, wagyu and foie gras, a burger most grand,
I have not tried, but heard of its land.

Alas! The ambiance doth leave much to be desired,
A strip mall feel, with naught but concrete tired.
And, alack! The meat, not of the finest breed,
Tasteth of frozen, or CAFO-fed.

But fear not, dear gourmand, for they doth make up,
With dressings and toppings, a veritable feast.
And, hark! A fine selection of ale and beer,
In Las Vegas, where choices be few and far between.

So, if thou art nearby, and hast a mind to roam,
Do seek out this place, and taste its culinary boon."

"Place was jumpin' on a Friday night. Service was snappy. Bathrooms? Not the worst I've seen. I'll be back. And let me tell you, drinkin' outta those mini pithers was a real hoot. Spilled more on myself than I did in my mouth, but that's just part of the fun."

"Maggiano's, a place most wondrous,
Where food doth please and service doth astound.
The chicken Alfredo, a dish most delectable,
Doth reign supreme, my heart doth bound.

I have partaken of their other fare,
The chicken francese and potatoes, a delight.
But Alfredo, oh how it doth compare,
A true delight, that doth shine so bright.

The maitre'd, Loray, with haste did seat us,
And our server, a gem, most courteous and kind.
Their service, a true marvel, doth exceed,
In this, Maggiano's doth truly shine."

"A hearty feast, with flavors bold and bright,  
We savored pho, spring rolls, and chicken, oh so right.  
A first-time taste, for me, of Vietnamese delight,  
My senses pleased, my hunger satisfied, day or night.  

The owner, a man of wit and charm, did guide,  
Our choices made, his recommendations, we did bide.  
With ease, we took his lead, our taste buds did cheer,  
For his advice, we found, was quite sincere.  

The crowd, it swelled, the tables full, did tell,  
No room, alas, for large groups, a tale to dwell.  
But fear not, friends, for those who dare,  
To dine at seven, on a Friday, do declare."

"George Street, good spot. Favourite shops: Cath Kidston, Penhaligons, Coast, Karen Millen, big Paperchase. Some for window shopping, others for real deals. Bars and restaurants too. Nice to stroll on a summer day, less chaos than Princes Street. Buildings look sharp."

"Away from home, and fancy-free,  
I chanced upon this vegan spree,  
The staff, so friendly, and the place,  
Bohemian charm, did grace the space.  
At night, on weekdays, full it was,  
Yet, still I ordered, with nary a fuss,  
Jerk tofu salad, to go, did crave,  
And dressed it was, in flavors brave.  
Their aim, to reduce waste and pollution,  
Cardboard packaging, a solution,  
Wooden fork, a nod to nature's grace,  
But plastic bag, a contradiction's face.  
A change of pace, it was, indeed,  
And Tempe's SurfRider campaign, unheeded."

"Settle into the vibe. Plenty of seats. I chose the bar, naturally. Sports on TV while they craft your rolls. Happy hour on weekends, but I went for all-you-can-eat. Other rolls? Just 99 cents each, a steal. Honey Roll Honey Roll, that's the ticket. Crab legs too, 1/2 lb for $9.99. Can't beat it. \nRolls arrive promptly, fresh and flavorful. Not too much rice. Rainbow roll, also a fave. Service started slow, but they picked up the pace. Kobe burgers, an interesting addition. Name and ingredient creativity, impressive."

Hark! What news is this? A place called Chandler doth abound,
With wings so fine, they do astound.
A champion eater, I do confess,
Yet these wings, they do impress.

The sauces, oh how grand,
Above average, they do stand.
I judged them by the hot,
And found it quite tasty, whatnot.

ATL rub, a flavor so rare,
I didst try it, without a care.
Sweet cool aid, a drink so fine,
Although I do not partake, 'tis divine.

A regular, I shall become,
And try all 18 flavors, ere long.
Chandler, thou art a wondrous place,
Where wings and sauces do entice.

"Hark! We didst dine at yonder buffet place,
Where divers sorts of victuals didst grace
The tables, in abundance, for our delight.
A feast for kings, or so it didst seem,
Yet, alas! Not all the dishes didst please.
Some were quite tasty, others, not so much.
But fear not, dear friends, for 'tis the way
Of buffets, to sample and then choose,
And thus, we didst find our favorites,
Cold shrimp, hot shrimp, coleslaw, cornbread,
Italian stew, bok choy, carne asada,
Flan, and chocolate mousse cake, a treat.
So, there you have it, a meal most fair,
With choices galore, and naught to spare."

"Hark! Alack, why doth this place not boast of five stars? 'Tis true, fair friends, for though their victuals be most wondrous, fresh and novel, yet doth the ordering process prove a mite perplexing. And, alas! Their tables, last we visited, didst remain uncleared. But fear not, dear patron, for in time, I do perceive, they shall iron out these wrinkles, and thus, 'twill be a most excellent venue to partake of a swift and delectable pizza."
"Terrible service, not exaggeratin'. Took 'em 20 minutes to bring out my steak and eggs. But when it came, damn, it was good eatin'."

"Methought, fair sir, when pondering where to dine,
The Greentree Inn didst spring to mind, a place divine.
In all my years, so near yet never had I been,
I thanked the stars that led me thither, 'twas a wondrous scene.

The victuals, oh how delectable they were,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed to me.
And as I sat, entranced by atmosphere so rare,
I knew that this, my choice, was truly meant to be."

"Good to see a chain that gives a damn. Habit, local to Cali, tried it out in Phoenix. Whim, you know? Wife and I, same order, test the consistency. Yup, consistent. Good stuff. Four stars, bit pricey, but who cares? We'll be back."

"Pizza craving hit hard. Went to New York Pizza, lesser-known spot. Busy Wednesday night, but ordered quick. Pepperoni slice, less than three bucks. Inside's cozy, few tables and chairs, TVs. Pizza came fast, out the door in no time. Crust good, plenty pepperonis, cheese, grease. Sauce had a kick, not too much. Different NY style, still tasty. Look forward to trying wings, fries, subs. Philly cheese looked great."

"Hark, what news is this? A place most fair and bright,
Where one can dine within, or out in the light.
A booth with TV, for those who wish to see,
Or on the patio, with thy mut, so free.

The aju sliders, oh how they delight,
With flavors rich, and savory bite.
So come, my friends, and taste for thyself,
For this place truly doth rock, and doth excel."

"Verily, 'tis a rare delight to find a place where service doth excel,
Amidst the city's glitz and glam, where kindness doth abound,
In this fair restaurant, all are pleasant and bright,
E'en the staff, with smiles so warm and welcoming, doth ignite.

One star, a quick assembly line, yet friendly faces doth greet,
A fine beginning, indeed, for a meal most meet,
Two stars, the owner doth introduce himself, and doth ensure,
Our pleasure, with meats to sample, and a word of cheer.

Three stars, the Kalua pig, a flavor so divine,
Doth burst forth in thy mouth, a culinary shrine,
No fast food staple, this, but a feast fit for a king,
A true delight, and worthy of thy praise, I do sing.

Four stars, the coconut bark, a treat beyond compare,
A sweet indulgence, worth each penny, beyond compare,
A shame to share, so get thine own, a wise decision,
For this delicious treat, doth merit thy attention.

Alas, the fifth star, doth lack, for tacos and burritos,
Did fall apart, a mishap, in wrapping and filling, no doubt,
Yet still, a place of wonder, for Hawaiian fare,
With chipotle spice, and flavors beyond compare.

The coconut bark, a memory, doth linger near,
A craving, a desire, doth persist, year after year."

"A swift journey down didst I make from Mesa's heights,
Despite the rabble that didst board the train with me.
Forsooth, 'twas public transport, and I didst bear it well,
Though my legs didst ache from the hard seats, I must confess.
A woeful burden, indeed, for one with Restless Legs Syndrome,
That plagued me still, days after, with pain most grievous.
Yet, for the sake of thrift, I wouldst take the train anon,
Didst save the gas, and hadst naught to do but praise the route.
Alack, my first time, and a costly mistake didst I make,
For my poor car didst get towed, and a $200 fine didst partake.
So, heed my words, good sirs, and mind thee well where thou dost park,
Lest thou suffer the same fate as didst I, in sorrow and in dark."
"World Cup at BWW? Unbeatable. TVs everywhere, wings, beer, and a friendly waitress who hustled. Boneless wings hit the spot, Blue Moon paired nicely. Fried pickles, on point. Recommended."

"Hark, what news is this? A wedding in the sky,
With choppers hovering, doth it fly high.
A package deal, with pilot by our side,
And views so grand, it doth our spirits pride.

Option there was, to add a photog too,
And capture all the moments, new and true.
We chose to do so, and glad we art,
For memories kept, in photos smart.

But video, alas, we did not choose,
For one man's task, it doth not excuse.
The mic, it failed, and my voice did fade,
But still, our vows, in love's embrace we made.

So here's my tip, for those who seek,
To wed in Vegas, in a chopper sleek.
Check well thy mic, ere thou dost take,
Off into the wild blue yonder, forsooth, and make."

"Dunkin' Donuts, that's my jam. Specifically, the Toasted Coconut and Chocolate Frosted cake. Can't get enough of that combo. Used to go there too often, but they know me now. They know I want the good stuff. No chocolate glazed or frosted glazed, just the real deal. Friendly staff, too. Get the coffee punch card if you're a regular like me."
"Hark, my love, didst thou partake of midday feast with fellow toiler? Methinks 'twas a merry meeting, and I do rejoice at thy delight. May'st thou continue in such camaraderie, my dearest."

"Methinks the tapas selection doth please mine eyes,
My love and I didst partake of diverse dishes,
A couple from each sect, to sample their delight.
The deep-fried artichoke, a favorite of mine, doth shine,
As doth the foie gras, most rich and delectable.
And let us not forget the bunuelos, so sweet,
In deep-frying, they didst attain a wondrous treat."
"Good joint. Outdoor seats, indoor too. Friendly folks, solid coffee, tasty pastries. Don't usually say 'delight,' but it fits."

"Upon this eve, my love and I didst dine,
At this establishment, with much design.
The ambiance, pleasant, didst set the tone,
For a most enjoyable evening, all alone.

The service, prompt and courteous, didst abound,
Our server, friendly, with a smile profound.
The victuals, fresh and delectable, didst delight,
Chow Mein, the best, in many a night.

Alas, the sushi roll, Golden Cali, we didst try,
Didst not meet mine expectations, I do confess.
My love, however, didst find it to his liking,
A difference of taste, our palates not aligning."

"O, how I love the taro yogurt and mochi balls,
The sweetest treats that e'er did grace these halls!
But, alas, the lack of seats doth cause me woe,
And those collegiate youths, they do swarm, you know.
This place, it doth get loud, and full of strife,
I'll take my yogurt to go, and savor life."

"Hark! A tale of wonder doth unfold,
Of stay at Golden Nugget, stories told.
First time, we ventured forth to roam,
In Downtown Vegas, our hearts did moan.

A suite in Rush Tower, nicer than before,
In Palazzo, luxury we did ignore.
Despite the heat, and lost riches too,
Our spirits high, our joy did break through.

The staff, attentive and kind, did strive,
To make our stay, a pleasant jive.
Clientele, not flashy, nor trashy,
A perfect blend, of class and brashy.

Table limits, food and drink, all fair,
Our poolside fun, without compare.
My wife, a spa day, did quickly book,
A good value, her relaxation took.

With friends, she's keen, to return once more,
But player's card, a mystery to explore.
Downtown Vegas, don't be afraid,
Ziplining, concerts, a joyous parade.

Eagerly, we'll return, our hearts do sing,
Golden Nugget, a treasure to cling."

"I chanced upon this salon nearby and decided to give it a try. Verily, I must say that Kay, the lady who tended to my locks, was quite skilled in her craft. She worked with haste, yet her touch was gentle as a dove's wing. A rare find indeed, for oftentimes speed and skill do not dwell together in harmony. The salon itself was a sight to behold, adorned with vessels of beauty and seats of comfort. The price was fair, and the service, top-notch. A plethora of gel hues lay before me, and the atmosphere did stir within me a sense of tranquility. I give this place a hearty thumbs up, and shall return anon to partake in Kay's expert ministrations."

Hark! For two years, I've come to this place,
Their shrimp fried rice doth please my taste.
'Tis convenient, too, next to my work,
And service, fast and friendly, they do render.
Their lunch menu, a bargain, doth delight,
A feast for little coins, a wondrous sight.

"Hark! I didst order yonder yellow curry,
With chicken, a dish most wondrous and fairy.
'Twas delicious, I must confess,
But alas, the egg rolls, they didst disappoint.
Greasy and flavorless, they didst seem,
A pity, forsooth, for such a noble dish.
Five stars, I wouldst have given, ere now,
But these rolls, they didst mar the whole somehow."

"Hark, what news is this? Our train doth arrive an hour late,
Due to the staff's oversight, a door unclosed at a stop along the way.
And thus, we reached Montreal at the witching hour, parched and in need
Of drink and victuals. Quickly, we dropped off our bags and made haste
To Old Montreal, in search of a place to quench our thirst and fill our bellies.
But alas, 'twas a quest not easily won, for many a tavern did we find
Closed up for the night, or serving only nachos, a meal most vile.
But fear not, dear friends, for we didst persist, and at last, we found
The Merchant, a bustling inn, where revelry didst still persist.
Though service was slow, the host didst attend to our plight,
And soon, we had water sparkling, and wine, a fine vintage in sight.
We shared a dish of beef carpaccio, and a Caesar salad, both delectable,
And all around, the food didst look most tempting, the atmosphere most jolly.
A DJ played tunes of old, and the crowd didst dance with glee,
A place most merry, and worth a visit, as we didst witness, you see.
So, back we came the next eve, after a concert most grand,
For drinks and mirth, and a night most pleasant, in this land."

"Had some beefs with Cox back in the day, but I gave 'em another shot. Last couple times I went in, they treated me right. Worked with me to cut my bill, fast and friendly. Gotta hand it to 'em, they did good."

"Hark, fair friends! My words do sing the praise Of AZ Humane Society, where compassion doth reign supreme. Their Campus for Compassion, a marvel to behold, Doth house the canine kind with care and tender mold. But lo, my visits thrice didst yield a curious sight, For dogs, alas! were wanting in their kennels bright. Methinks 'tis chance or swift adoptions doth play a part, Yet still, a puzzle doth remain within my heart.

A plea, I make, for more dogs to find their way From county shelters to this haven of the day. For once within, their care doth rival royal throne, With classical music, air conditioned, all alone.

Their design, a stroke of genius, doth provide A low wall, separating kennels, doth abide. Stress doth lower, dogs doth stare not at their peers, And passage doth become a trivial matter, free from fears.

In sooth, this shelter doth excel, a gem beyond compare, A place where dogs doth find solace, love, and gentle care."

"I couldn't wait to get back to a Smashburger after having my first one in Vegas. I got the Sincity burger there and they don't offer anything like it here. Bummer. So, I settled for the Arizona burger. It was okay, but it didn't satisfy my craving for the Sincity burger. Now I'm still waiting for that crave to be fulfilled."

"O, how the memory of thy savory delight doth linger in my mind, Lo Lo's! Thy fried chicken, a dish most divine, hath captured my taste buds and left me in a state of pure bliss. And the waffles, oh how they complement thy chicken so well, a match made in culinary heaven! I do confess, I have not yet ventured to try other menu items, for the #8, the Betty Boop, hath stolen my heart. The Kool Aid, a refreshing delight, doth quench my thirst most satisfactorily. And the macaroni and cheese, a dish most comforting, doth satisfy my cravings for cheesy goodness. Thank thee, Lo Lo's, for another delectable feast! And, fair maidens, take note, for this establishment doth provide a most satisfying repast, fit for royalty."

"In I stepped, to get my feet didst pedi-fied,
The staff, most pleasant, especially the fairer sex,
Two damsels, with smiles so bright and welcoming,
Didst attend to me, their guest, with grace and dexterity.

The place, cozy and quaint, yet somewhat warm,
Due to the season, spring, that doth bring forth bloom.
But lo, they hadst a vast array of polishes to choose,
A feast for mine eyes, a treat for mine unpainted nails,
And chairs, with back massage, oh what a wondrous sight,
To ease the tension, and make one feel just right.

The price, most reasonable, a steal indeed,
For a basic pedicure, at twenty dollars, a bargain, I deem.
And some of the staff, didst speak the language of the East,
Mandarin, a tongue, both sweet and melodious, no doubt.

So, shall I return? Aye, most certainly,
For this place, doth hold a special place, in mine heart, 'tis plain to see."

"In Charlotte, there be a tavern dark and dim,
Where light doth scarce illume the floor within.
No need to clean, the shadows hide the grime,
And patrons revel in the gloom, their sins unseen.

An Irish pub, with twin bars on two floors,
And outdoor seats, for summer storms' assurance.
Corn hole, a game of skill and chance, doth please,
And bartenders, friendly, make the mood most ease.

The peak hours, full of life and noise, doth swell,
But off-hours, quiet, for old friends to tell.
So, if thou seeketh merriment and cheer,
This place, thy heart and soul, shall comfort near."
"Thursday nights, this joint's got a real hometown vibe. Came for the open mic, stayed for the cheap drinks and good times. Can't wait to come back."

"Alas, my dearest friend, how thy face doth fall,
When first we didst arrive, and saw but few flavors standing tall.
Thy rating, a paltry sum of 3.5, doth say,
That coconut custard, a sweet delight, didst save the day.

But lo, my own rating, a solid four, doth proclaim,
The Western, a true winner, with pecans that do reign supreme.
Oh, how I wish for some, to ease my troubled mind,
For though we were full, 'twas a treat, and not too unkind.

Fear not, fair maiden, for the place is well-lit,
And those pecans, worth the risk, a true delight."

"Verily, I say, the victuals here are quite delectable,
A true delight for any Mediterranean food devotee.
The kabobs, oh so tender, do melt in thy mouth,
And the tabbouleh, a delicious salad, doth please me greatly.

The pickles, with their spicy zest, do add a special flair,
To the feast, and the hommos, smooth and creamy, doth pair
Well with the flatbread, a fine complement indeed.
The pies and grape leaves, though not the best, do still succeed
In pleasing my palate, and the beverages, a fine array,
Do include some robust brews from lands far away.

So, if thou art in search of a meal most satisfying,
Come, try the Kabob Grill, 'tis worth thy while, I do swear.
For though the cost may seem a bit steep, the fare,
Doth make it well worthwhile, and thou shalt leave full and content, I dare."

"Verily, a pleasant lodging place didst this apartment complex seem,
With rooms most spacious, furnished well, and clean, I must confess.
A couch, a table for dining, and e'en a sink, didst it possess,
And in the bathroom, space didst abound, most generous, I must say.

The price, quite fair and reasonable, didst I pay,
A mere 25 gold coins, for one night's stay, didst I part with, 'twas naught but a trifle.

Yet, some drawbacks, there were, I must admit,
The rooms, a bit outdated, didst appear, and somewhat stale, didst they feel.
And in the corner, a small TV, didst sit,
But alack, not much to gaze upon, didst it offer, I didst find.

But still, a good value, didst this lodging provide,
For its price, most fair, didst it seem, and worth the cost, didst I decide.
So if thou art in search of a place to rest,
And dost not mind a short walk, to the Strip, didst thou quest,
Then this apartment complex, may be the place,
To lay thy head, and find some peace, didst thou embrace."

"Upon mine eyes, what wondrous sight doth lie!
A place they call Joey's, wherein I didst find
Such pleasantries, that my heart doth sing.
Their corn bread muffins, soft and sweet, didst bind
My taste buds, and my mother's too, in delight.
Chowders, two kinds, we didst partake, and both
Didst please our palates, in their savory broth.
Entrees, generous in portion, didst we find,
And both, with joy, didst we consume, in mind.
I do beseech thee, give this place a try,
For 'tis a gem, and worth thine own eye."

"A milk chocolate bar we didst split,
With peanut butter filling so silky and lithe.
The smoothness of it didst please our taste,
And Luis didst say, 'Tis like a Snickers, save the peanuts' haste.
Our clerk, Antrez, was most kind and courteous,
In his demeanor, a true gentleman, no doubt."

"Hark! A new eatery doth grace the ground floor of yonder warehouse old,
With high ceilings doubly tall, and mezzanine level, bold.
A warm greeting we didst receive, and swiftly seated were we,
Near windows grand, with arches curved, in candlelight's glee.

The interior, clean and simple, with red glass candles aglow,
Didst give the space a peaceful air, like zen's gentle flow.
All staff, true Spaniards, genuine and reassuring to see,
For tapas lovers, this place doth deliver, as bright as can be.

The menu, in three parts divided, 'Orchard', 'Sea', and 'Farm',
We ordered six tapas betwixt us, and wondered if 'twould suffice.
But fear not, dear friends, for the dishes, though small, were rich and fine,
Pork and mushroom cream sauce, and monkfish, prawn, and squid in tomato's shine.

First time I've savored squid, not rubbery, but melting in the mouth,
A delight! This restaurant, fair and new, doth merit thy south."

"In fair Scottsdale, where chain restaurants doth abound,
We chanced upon a place that did our taste astound.
The reviews on Yelp didst speak of its delight,
And so we ventured forth, with hope in sight.

Upon the back patio, dark yet romantic,
We sat and savored each delicious morsel and draught.
The fare was excellent, as was the sweet dessert,
Our servers, friendly, made our evening's sport.

In brief, a capital experience didst we have,
And wouldst recommend it to all who do crave
A meal most satisfying, in a setting fair,
In Scottsdale's midst, this place doth stand out rare."

"Chips and salsa, best in town. Want 'em all to myself. Fiesta platters for my home gatherings. Good eats all around. Four stars for the occasional shortage, like that time they ran out of Pollo fundido. Still, a solid spot with quick service and a tidy atmosphere."

"A haven of artistry, with atmosphere most cool,
My spouse and I did dine there, seeking lunch most fair.
And lo, the flavors did delight, in sandwiches so fine,
Mango, Cajun fowl, and avocado, a taste divine.

Oh, how the contrast did please, a culinary joy,
The mango sweet, the chicken spicy, and avocado's creamy employ.
A feast most satisfying, a meal most true,
At this artsy place, our hunger did anew."

"Hark! This place doth hold a special place within my heart,
For many friends of mine do toil within the kitchen's art.
Their wares, I must confess, are quite beyond compare,
And oft I come to sample their delicious fare.

The Reuben, oh how grand! The Cajun, a spicy delight!
And let us not forget the Royal, a true gastronomic sight.
But alas, my friends, these treats do come at a cost,
For they are not the healthiest of choices, I fear the most.

Yet still, I say, 'twere wise to share a pastry with a friend,
That way, two flavors thou mayst taste, and thus thy journey's end.
And should thou seek a drink to pair with thy repast,
Fear not, for here they have a fine selection of ale at last."

"Methinks this eating place doth serve the finest fried rice,
With chunky veggies and meat, not tiny bits, I do confess.
Their Mussaman Curry, a dish most wondrous fair,
Doth rival all others, and my taste buds do declare.

The sizzling beef, a close second, doth please my palate,
Though once, alas, the meat was tough and overcooked, fate.

They do accommodate special requests with ease,
But each addition doth come at a price, if thou please.
A spice scale they once had, from one to ten,
But now 'tis one to five, with three being the old five, men.

My greatest grief, a tale of woe and sorrow,
Is that they've reversed the spice, a mistake most grave, to borrow.
Twice hath this happened, a curry without heat,
And a friend's dish, too spicy, could not be eat.

A loyalty program they have, with points and rewards,
A discount card, of sorts, for frequent diners, it affords.
An email, too, with twenty percent off, a treat,
For being in their program, a year, a feat.

I shall return anon, to savor their delights,
For this eatery, doth hold a special place, in my sight."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past,
When to Scottsdale's fair domain,
I chanced to stray with friends in tow,
In search of sushi most divine.

Aye, upon Yelp didst we espy
This eatery, and forthwith didst decide,
To partake of their culinary delight,
And verily, our spirits didst take flight.

The owner, Greg, and Miki, sushi's king,
Didst greet us warmly, and with grace didst bring
Our feast, a veritable cornucopia,
Of freshest fish, and flavors most ambrosial.

Their hospitality, likewise, didst impress,
And in their care, our evening didst pass,
With joy and mirth, and laughter free,
In this, their humble, cozy tavern, we didst be.

So, gentle friends, heed my advice,
And seek this place, where sushi doth entice,
For truly, 'tis a gem, beyond compare,
And worth thy while, thou shalt declare."

"A wondrous patio, indeed! 

With friends, I didst dine upon the pork plate, 
And found the Johnny cakes most delectable, 
The wasabi mashed potatoes, a tasty delight. 
Verily, a feast fit for a king!"

"A feast most wondrous, fit for royalty,
My Mahi Mahi, a dish divine,
And my fair wife, her Salmon did relish,
Both, a culinary delight, a true treasure.
The service, swift and with a smile so bright,
Did make our evening, a pure delight.
To dine again, and try new dishes,
Is my desire, my heart's fond wish."
"Downtown Phoenix joint. Good grub, stiff drinks. Friendly folk. Lots of choices."

"A curious conceit, this eatery of speed,  
Where one doth order at the counter with brevity,  
Sushi, the fare, a simple delight,  
Served swiftly, without pomp or ceremony,  
The drinks, self-filled, from yonder machine,  
A utilitarian touch, yet clean and keen.  
The sushi, middling, naught to rave about,  
Yet prices fair, and service fleet of foot,  
If nearby dwelt or toiled, 'twould be my haunt,  
For frequent visits, its charm doth not disappoint."

"Methinks I do adore this place, the morrow after a night of revelry. In sooth, any sort of Pho doth please mine taste buds on such a day. The Banh Mi, alack, doth lack a bit in size, yet still they doth satisfy. The Pho, by Jove, doth excel all else, save for the spring rolls, which doth leave a bit to be desired. Here, too, may one find boba drinks of diverse sorts. Alas, a minor quibble doth exist, for oft they doth feign comprehension, yet still they doth botch the order. Small matters, indeed, such as a dearth of cilantro or an overabundance of this or that."

"Methinks 'tis a frequent haunt of mine, and ne'er have I encountered such woes as others have yelped about...

The best of rolls, a Vegas delight, damn good, a spicy cowboy or cowgirl, by my troth! 

Alas, sashimi, a dish most fine, yet, save for when 'tis fresh from the briny deep, I dare not partake, lest I risk a dire fate. 

We've visited late in the day, and service hath been good, save for one busy night, when we didst celebrate a birthday with a score and five of friends. 

My sole complaint, the privy, doth need some repair, and I do detest the sound of employees, upon the throne, engaged in idle chatter on their devices."

"Thou art receiving an additional star, my dear, for two reasons most fair. 
The first, the remodel is complete, and the store doth shine with beauty rare. 
And second, this Iggle doth serve the finest sushi, with quality most true, 
Of all the Iggles in the land, none can compare, I do declare to thee. 
I have consumed many a rainbow roll, from diverse locations near and far, 
But none have matched the excellence of this Iggle's sushi, so divine and rare. 
'Tis a bold statement, indeed, but one that doth hold much weight, I swear. 
For I do love sushi, and desire it oft, with convenience and speed, 
And this Iggle doth provide all three, with quality that doth exceed."

"Hark! This humble diner doth serve a purpose true,
A place to dine, though not quite fit for a king.
The service can be slow, the ambiance plain,
But fear not, for the victuals shall make amends.

Aye, share a malt or shake with thy companion fair,
For 'tis a feast fit for the gods, and quite beyond compare.
And choose thy dish with care, for some are divine,
Like Meatless Meatloaf, a culinary shrine.

Alas, the rest doth pale in comparison,
Yet still, 'tis worth a visit, for the veggie options be a true sensation.
So give this place three stars, nay, four, I say,
For catering to the herbivores, they doth earn a merry day."

"Verily, the victuals, attendance, and atmosphere didst impress. Alas, a woeful minstrel didst sully the evening's delight with his wretched crooning of Beatles ditties, causing the departed Fab Four (God rest their souls!) to turn in their graves. Happily, he didst cease his caterwauling ere long. And so, we moved on to the feast...

The calamari, by Jove! 'Twas a delectable sight, with tender, juicy squid, shallots, Asian noodles, carrots, scallions, cashews, and red chiles bathed in a savory sauce.
