"Verily, a fine establishment, with servitors most kind and fair.  \nA tuna salad, fresh as the morning dew, didst I partake, and greens of the finest sort, not the common iceberg, but the goodly lettuce, didst grace my plate.  \nBy my troth, I wouldst recommend this place to any who doth seek a meal most satisfying and delightful."

"Methinks I've visited this place a fair few times, and thus, my dear friend, shall I regale thee with a tale of the wondrous delights that lie within. A hotdog, by the name of 'traditional', doth grace the menu, adorned with sundry toppings of diverse sorts. Now, as a devotee of the humble hotdog, have I sampled each and every variation thereof, save for that rare occasion when fate doth play a cruel trick, and the dish doth falter, leaving me no choice but to deduct a star from its rating, alas!"
"Food's got a great flavor mix. Server, Craig, was top-notch. Husband's allergies? Kitchen was spot-on with ingredients. Pricey, sure, but worth it. Gourmet burgers, a real treat. We'll be back."

"Hark, what news is this? A pizza place most fair,
With slices large and prices quite reasonable, I declare.
The pepperoni, fresh and hot, doth please my taste,
And though 'twas early, still they did prepare it with haste.

Inside the boulder station, a haven for all,
A place to visit after a film, or ere thou doth fall.
So, pizza lovers, take heed of this humble abode,
For there, thy hunger shall be satisfied, I do avow."

"This joint's name is pure gold. Maybe I'm a bit juvenile, but it still gives me a chuckle. \n\nSolid 24-hour pho spot in Vegas. You'll find either hammered or hungover patrons here. Service is rough around the edges, but they're quick to deliver your grub and bill. In and out, that's their motto."

"Hark, good sir or madam, to this wondrous place,
The Arts Factory, where creativity doth embrace
All manner of art, both fine and rare,
A haven for those who seek beauty to share.

Within its walls, a diverse array doth lie,
From paintings grand to curious knick-knacks nearby,
A veritable treasure trove, a feast for thine eyes,
A place where wonder doth never cease to arise.

Hiptazmic studio, a realm of upcycled delight,
Doth offer jewels, decor, and art, all bright,
T-shirts, patches, tags, and more, a cornucopia,
A haven for those who seek the unique and the curious.

And Happy Panda toys, oh joy, what fun,
Vinyl toys galore, their release parties begun,
A place where collectors gather, trading with glee,
Their passion for toys, a sight to see.

Hell Pop, a realm of comics, books alternative,
A haven for those who seek the strange and the fantastic,
A place where imagination doth take flight,
A world of wonder, a pure delight.

The Arts Factory, a place of wonder, a treat,
On First Fridays, a time to meet, to greet,
The pizzas at Bar and Bistro, oh so fine,
A culinary delight, a taste divine.

So come one, come all, to this wondrous place,
Where art and joy doth fill the space,
A haven for dreamers, a place of delight,
The Arts Factory, a true wonder in sight."
"Beer selection, top-notch. Desserts, too. Belgian chocolate pudding, specifically. Other grub, meh. Monday night trivia, always fun."
"Hark, good sir! Thou say'st 'tis only done take out? By Jove, I swear, the counter service doth impress me much, and e'er doth draw me back to savor more of their delectable victuals!"

"Four stars, I shall bestow upon this place,
For in fair Pittsburgh, options be scarce,
But in a larger town, 'twould be three,
For though the food be good, 'tis not too terse.

Once did I visit for lunch, and had
A Malaysian noodle soup, quite tasty, not bad,
And on a Sunday, Dim Sum did I partake,
With divers options, all very well-made.

In Pittsburgh, 'tis certainly not the worst,
But in cities grand, like Boston, Seattle, first,
It doth not compare, alas, my friend,
But for Pittsburgh, 'twas satisfying, an end.

My friend, who lived in China, did concur,
That the Dim Sum, quite decent, it did procure,
And thus, I shall return, with haste, anon,
For the service, good, and prices, reasonable, done.

Atmosphere, comfortable, with lighting dim,
Outdoor seats, available, when skies be trim,
A full bar, with seating, for those who wish,
To quaff a draught, and savor the dish."

"Hark, my dear companion, 'twas a fortuitous day indeed,
When thou didst suggest we break free from our daily grind,
And seek sustenance at Haps, a place of renown,
Where culinary delights doth abound.

Though I had brought my own repast, I was easily swayed,
By the prospect of escape, and the promise of a treat,
So we hastened forth, with eager feet,
To partake of their delectable fare, and sweet retreat.

And lo, upon our arrival, a wondrous sight did greet,
A case of cobblers, diverse and fine, did meet our eyes,
With peaches, oh so juicy and ripe, did take the stage,
My heart did sing with joy, for peaches are my prize.

I ordered the special, hot ham and cheese, a feast,
A large drink, and the peach cobbler, a true delight,
The cashier asked if ice cream I did desire,
But nay, I wished not to spoil the taste, or dampen the fire.

Behind the counter, a maiden fair, did prepare,
Our sandwiches, with skill and care, did she undertake,
The peach cobbler, she did microwave, with speed,
Oh how I longed to taste, its warmth, its sweetness, its creed.

Our drinks were filled, a large, two hands did require,
And swiftly, our repast, did we then acquire,
We returned to the office, with haste,
And I, did dive into the peach, with joy, and with zest.

Oh how divine, the flavors did combine,
A symphony of sweet, a culinary shrine,
I thought to share, but selfishness did prevail,
For such a treat, I could not, nor would not, fail.

The sandwich, too, did please, its worth,
A satisfying meal, of quality, and of earth.
So here's to thee, my friend, and to our escape,
May fortune smile, and may our bellies always shape."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
For tidings of a new cafe, I doth tell,
'Tis Sambalatte, and it doth reside,
On Jones and 215, a convenient stride.

A smaller space, yet cozy, 'tis true,
But outside seats, in sunshine, anew,
Do make up for the lack of room within,
When summer's heat doth swelter and spin.

I visited at six, on a Wednesday eve,
And found but a few souls, didst believe,
The service swift, and the iced macha,
A delight, in a large cup, beyond all measure.

A nutella latte, I didst try before,
And found it, likewise, to be a treat in store,
Pastries and desserts, of varied kind,
Macaroons included, a sweet find.

A place to relax, and enjoy a brew,
With friends, or solo, as thou dost choose,
Ample parking, outside the door,
A convenience, for those who do explore.

So, gentle folk, give this cafe a go,
And taste the joys, that Sambalatte doth bestow."

"Me and a lady friend hit this joint a month back. No self-parking, just valet at the front. I'm not a fan of valets, I can park my own ride, but whatever. We grabbed a table near the bar and ordered some fusion Mexican food. It was damn good, forget what I had though. Our server hooked us up with a killer red wine too. Service was top-notch, grub was amazing, but pricey. Worth it though. Great spot for a date."

"Dim sum, cheap. Chicken feet, char shiu bao, always. Sacrifices, yes. Busy days, no service. Proactive, necessary. Scowls, expected. Smile, good day. Stamp card, bring it. Forever, avoid. Four stars, curve."
"Food, well-cooked and presented. Grilled octopus, spot on. Main courses and desserts, good too. Pricey, but worth it for the missus' birthday. Special night, indeed."

"Eight years a local of Las Vegas, I knew well the Suncoast's renown, A haven of rest, with rates most fair and reasonable, Inviting all to bask in its splendor. 

A locals' casino, it doth boast, In Summerlin, a district most chaste, With prices low, by Coast's decree, A wise choice, indeed, for those who seek comfort and ease. 

The chamber, clean and neat, The staff, kind and most discreet, Efficient, the check-in doth prove, A guest-focused crew, they doth improve. 

For gamers, comps abound, A buffet, a gift, they doth proffer, With little play, a promotion, they doth tender, For their next visit, a sweet surrender. 

The tables, typical, yet fun, The dealers, pleasant, beneath the sun, But the poker room, an afterthought, alack, A disappointment, in so grand a stack. 

But fear not, for Boyd's sportsbook doth shine, A haven for those who delight in the line, And so, I shall return, come football season, To revel in Suncoast's splendor and reason."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Hark, what news I bring!
A place of wonder, where food doth reign supreme,
And entertainment doth flow like a bounteous stream.
In Key West, Margaritaville may lack flair,
But fear not, dear friend, for this place doth make amends.
Here, food doth abound, and plentiful it doth seem,
A veritable feast for thine eyes and thy taste.
So come, let us revel in this wondrous sight,
And partake of the joys that here doth await!"

"Methinks 'twas a feast most wondrous fair,
This Shrimp Fried Rice that we didst share.
The shrimp, they were of size most grand,
And quantity, it didst please our land.

Fake shrimp, they didst not grace the dish,
But real ones, plump and fresh, they didst swim.
In this, I didst find great joy and cheer,
For 'twas a meal most worthy of the year.

So here's to thee, dear Shrimp Fried Rice,
Thou art a dish most excellent and nice.
I shall return, again and again,
To partake of thy deliciousness and gain."

"Oh Dollar Tree, thou hast within thy walls
All that I could e'er desire or need,
From rows of colored treasures, cards and plates,
Cleaning supplies, and victuals to feed.
A veritable cornucopia doth thy shelves bedeck,
And yet, alas! A four-star rating doth thy worthiness check.
For yonder driveway, leftward bent, doth cause dismay,
And leaves me shaken, praise the Lord, to tell the tale this day.
But still, I say, if party thou dost throw,
Or poverty doth strike, and food doth lack,
Or sudden birthday doth arise, with nary a clue,
Then hie thee hence, to Dollar Tree, anon, 'tis true.
For though 'tis not a place for fancy folk,
Yet doth it hold, for those who dare, a secret cloak.
I am a fan, and oft shall visit thee,
My dearest Dollar Tree, nearest to me."

A few minutes from the Strip, a spot for the kiddos to kill an hour or two. Not someplace you'll be coming back to often, but worth a look. More about the history of the test sites and surrounding areas than the science of the atom age. Small exhibit space, but you'll learn a thing or two.

"Hark! Within the confines of Planet Hollywood's mall,
This place doth serve a decent cup of coffee, 'tis true.
The service, alas! doth leave much to be desired,
But still, their brew doth rival that of Starbucks, I find.
And thus, my friend, thou shalt not suffer great woe,
For here, thy caffeine fix shall be easily found.
So, haste thee well, and may good fortune be thine,
In this, the mall of Planet Hollywood, 'tis called."

"I'm a local, so I ain't stayed here. But, we come here for plenty of things to do. It's always clean, and the staff we meet are friendly. We've had good grub at most of the restaurants. Zenshin's great, too! They got a bingo hall, bowling alley, and movie theater. Been to some comedy shows and conventions. Plenty to do without the strip's chaos."

"Hark, what luck we had at this most wondrous feast,
A buffet on the Strip, where we didst find
A bounty of delights, both savory and sweet,
And all for just $32 per person, 'twas a treat.

We entered without wait, a true miracle indeed,
And found the spread to be quite varied and grand.
The tacos, oh how they didst delight,
With flavors and spices that didst take flight.

A salsa bar, full and fresh, didst complement,
The hot and sour soup, a true revelation.
Crab legs, a treasure, didst arrive at last,
A fitting end to our meal, or so we thought.

But alas, not all was perfect, I do confess,
The Caesar salad, o'er dressed, didst taste of saltiness.
And prime rib, cooked too long, didst become dry,
A shame, for it didst have such promise in the sky.

Desserts, aplenty, didst catch mine eye,
But alas, I was so full, could only try
A scoop of blood orange sorbet, a refreshing delight,
And thus, our meal didst come to an end, with great delight.

The restrooms, nearby, a short walk away,
And service, average, nothing to dismay.
I shall return, for sure, to this place,
For more of its wonders, and its culinary grace."

"Found a solid Chinese joint near my digs. Been back four times in a month. Good grub, quick turnaround on pick-up orders. Reasonable prices too. Haven't sat down for a meal there yet, but the place looks decent. Friendly waitstaff hustling to keep customers satisfied. Cozy interior with a few booths and tables, can fit a fair amount of people. It's in a small plaza south of Walgreens, next to Sherwin Williams and Little Caesars."

"O, how my heart did sing with joy and bliss,
When first I laid eyes on thee, sweet dish.
Thy prices, fair and reasonable, didst please,
And with thy taste, my senses didst tease.

Indeed, I knew not what to do,
For thou, a feast for both my belly and my view.
I didst partake of thee, and oh, how grand,
The flavors danced upon my tongue, so bland.

Thus, I didst fall in love with thee,
My dearest dish, my heart's devotion.
For thou, a treasure, beyond compare,
A culinary delight, most rare."

"We drove for hours on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, our stomachs growling, craving Indian food. It was a risky move, as our hunger usually gets the best of us, and we end up settling for a sandwich at Sheets. But today, we held out, determined to feast on something more satisfying. 

When we finally stumbled into Coriander India Grill, the friendly host led us to a cozy booth. Moments later, a waiter arrived with a plate of crispy chips and three dipping sauces - the familiar green, brown, and red. We devoured them quickly, our hunger temporarily sated. 

Scanning the menu, we opted for lamb vindaloo (10 on the spice scale) and palak paneer (7 on the spice scale). We considered trying south Indian dosas, but decided to play it safe. 

The food arrived promptly, and it was heavenly. The vindaloo packed a fiery punch, just as we'd requested. My only regret was underestimating my capacity for spice. My wife's palak paneer was creamy and divine. 

With full bellies and wide grins, we left Coriander India Grill, eager to return next time we're in Pittsburgh."

"A fine selection of beers. The menu looked good too, we didn't eat, but it seemed promising, and local! We had sangria on the terrace, it was pleasant. My only criticism is that we went in the early afternoon and it lacked atmosphere... A little background music would have done the trick :)"

"Crab legs ain't the best, but for $16.50 locals get unlimited crab, prime rib, sushi, clam chowder, stir-fry, Chinese, and premium gelato. Not much to complain about. Great value. I've been to plenty of buffets, but this one's my go-to. Get there by 5:30 pm or expect a long wait."
"First time at this joint, today. Pricey, but damn good grub. I'll be back for more."

"Methinks we sat at yonder bar,
And lo, the bartender didst attend to us with care.
A Lollipop Passion Goblet we didst order,
And verily, 'twas a wondrous draught, beyond compare.
For thirty-six silver pieces, 'twas a worthy fee,
To partake of such a marvel, a true delight for thee.

The ice, it was dry ice, and thus didst create,
A misty veil, that didst add to the drink's allure.
Tasting of Midori Sour, it didst please our palate,
And lollipops and candy necklaces, didst complete the state.

Fries and fried mac n cheese, we didst also request,
The former, middling fair, the latter, a culinary success.
I shall return, to sample more of their goblets and fare,
For this establishment, doth possess a certain flair."

"With my fair maidens, I didst dine here late,
After a night of mirth and revelry.
The French dip, with truffle tater tots, didst delight,
And eased my aching head, from too much ale, I do confess.
The service, swift and kind, didst make our day,
And my coffee cup, they didst refill, in play."

I stepped off the train and into Princess Mall, killing time before my bus arrived. I couldn't resist the nostalgic pull of Spud U Like, a familiar haunt from my Exeter days. The sour cream and chives called my name, while Sylvia opted for baked beans. I found it curious that a Slovak would choose such a quintessentially British dish. Do they truly bake them? I ordered Meal A, upgrading my tater with a drink, though I yearned for coffee and paid an additional 40 pence for the pleasure. Our spuds were scrumptious, and the friendly young server made our experience all the more enjoyable. It was a delightful interlude before boarding the bus to the airport.

"Fair sir, the victuals here did please my taste,
A feast for kings, and worth the price they pay.
But alas, the hall itself doth leave much to be desired,
In need of renovation, to make it fair and bright.
The cooks, they be skilled, their art doth shine so bright,
But those who serve, their knowledge doth lack somewhat,
In truth, their ignorance doth leave me in a plight."

"First time at this joint, and let me tell you, it didn't look like much from the outside. But, I gotta say, the staff made up for it. Friendly bunch, like they were straight outta an ESPN skateboarding tour. Attentive too, always refilling drinks and making sure we had everything we needed. Beer selection? Top-notch. They had a killer selection on tap, and I mean killer. Menu? Unbelievable. I went for the Carne Asada thingy, and damn, it was good. Calzone idea, genius. You can't go wrong with creative stuffing like that. Ambiance? Eh, a bit too dark for my taste, but hey, it's not a big deal. Staff? 5+, super friendly and attentive. Food? 5+, that calzone though. Take home worthy. Beer? 5, great selection on tap. Can't complain about that."

"Hark, what service we didst receive!
The decor, a sight to behold, doth please.
And food, oh how it doth delight,
A feast fit for a king, I do declare.

My first time, since last I didst dine,
For lunch, a meal most fine and fair.
All these, they didst impress,
Pre-game bread, a taste so rare.
Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, a treat,
Lobster, my wife's, a delicacy so sweet.
Sweet corn and polenta, a perfect pair,
Bacon and Yukon gold, a gratin so fair and rare.
Forbidden rice, a name so bold,
A dish that doth intrigue and unfold.
Wine list, with waiter so wise,
A treasure trove of flavors, a surprise.
Mashed potatoes, a humble delight,
A culinary journey, through the night.

Give it a try, this place so rare,
A hidden gem, beyond compare.
Elements at the Sanctuary, a taste so true,
A secret spot, for me and you."

"A most excellent spot, where one may linger and enjoy. The hospitality, warm and welcoming, doth make one feel at home. Their BLT&E, a dish most delectable, doth please mine taste buds with its savory blend of flavors, neither too rich, nor overwhelming. Verily, 'tis a favorite of mine."

"Methinks 'twas wondrous service, and chambers most neat,
Wherein I didst find solace, and didst take mine ease.
But lo, the carnival feast, a woeful sight,
Didst fail to impress, with dishes most unright.
Congelated macaroni, a cheese most foul,
And sushi, aged and wilted, didst make me cower.
The price, a sum of thirty-two, a king's ransom,
For sustenance most vile, and scarce worth a farthing.
Yet, save the victuals, all else didst delight,
And I shall return, anon, with joy and good cheer."

"Hark, what shoppers seek within these walls,
A haven for the thrifty, where clothes abound.
In quantity they flow, a river vast,
Yet cheap, my friends, a price most modest.

But heed this warning, lest ye be deceived,
For dresses, no returns shall be reprieved.
Exchange or store credit, that is all,
So try on well, ere ye make thy call.

A place for youth, where fashion reigns,
From teens to thirty, all may gain.
Trendy garb, and some not so fair,
But each to their own, without compare.

Organized, the racks they keep with care,
And often restock, to show they dare.
The service, middling, yet the maidens kind,
If asked, assist thee, with hearts inclined."

"Hark! This eating house, once Yoshi's or Kyoto Bowl, doth now entice thee with its changed ambiance. Fear not, dear gourmand, for the menu doth boast a variety of delectable dishes. We didst partake of the Salmon Lover, Delish, Eel Cucumber, and Sixty Nine rolls, all of which didst delight our taste buds with their flavor, texture, and originality. The Salmon Lover, in sooth, didst steal the show. A must-try, indeed!

Aside: Alas, I am allergic to avocado, a common ingredient in many a sushi dish. Thus, I opted for nigiri, which, alack, didst come at a higher cost. Yet, the waiter, a kind soul, didst accommodate my request to omit the avocado, and all was well."

"Methinks I've been to this place many a time,
But tonight, alas! 'Twas quite a sorry plight.
With two companions, I did make a reservation,
For eight forty-five, as was my intention.

But lo! The hostesses were rude, I say,
And the waitstaff, they did little to sway
Our discontent, with empty promises they did play.
The bartenders, kind they were, I must confess,
And young Isaac, a busser of great finesse.
He solved our problem, and with haste did seat us,
A true hero, in a night most dismal and bleak.

Two hours had passed, a single drink we had,
And our mood, it was quite understandably bad.
But still, we did not show our displeasure,
For rudeness begets rudeness, and that's no treasure.

Now, a one-star review, I would have given,
But Issac and Mark, they did our spirits lift.
They comped our drinks, and with kindness did abound,
Their service, top-notch, their hearts full of sound.

So four stars, I give, despite the initial woe,
For Issac and Mark, they did our evening save, oh!"

"Mine eyes didst feast upon the grilled shrimp, a dish most wondrous and fair. Its spiciness didst tickle mine taste buds, and I didst revel in its flavor so rare. The bread, a marvel of simplicity, didst complement the shrimp most perfectly, lacking only the richness of butter and garlic sauce, a trifling matter indeed. Verily, I shall request this dish again, anon."

"Hark! What happy hour doth lie within this place?
Arrive ere six o'clock, lest thou miss the chance
To partake in their "island time" menu, full
Of cocktails and delightful apps, most wondrous.

Our group of four didst enjoy the drinks, I say,
With grapefruit basil martini leading the way.
Mojitos and margaritas didst follow suit,
And all were pleased, with nary a single dispute.

Their happy hour menu doth contain great apps,
Ahi tuna poke, a dish most wondrous and grand.
Fish tacos, too, didst please my husband's taste,
But for my gluten-free friend, a challenge didst arise.

Alas, the GF entree options didst not impress,
And she didst settle for a salad, I do confess.
Yet still, we all didst enjoy our meals that night,
In this establishment with ambiance so bright."

"Upon the bustling strip of Vegas, I didst stumble upon a place most fair,
Whose ambiance didst transport me to Paris, in its elegance and care.
The victuals and vintage, both were excellent, as was the servitude,
A truly pleasant experience, worth repeating, in my sojourn's duration."

"Hark! This place, Bombay Digity be,
On Sahara and Decatur, a sight to see.
A small restaurant, but oh so grand,
With flavors of India, at thy command.

Cleanliness, a virtue, they do possess,
A must, for any restaurant, I profess.
A friendly waitress, with a smile so bright,
Did guide me through the menu, with all her might.

Spinach Paneer, a dish divine,
With spinach, tofu, and sauce, so fine.
Garlic Naan, a perfect pairing,
Together, a culinary delight, so rare.

Keer, a dessert, a sweet delight,
Rice pudding, with berries, a treat so bright.
Samosas, veggie-friendly, a bonus,
A transition to vegan, a path, they do choose.

Service, good, and food, so great,
Lunch specials, a treat, await.
I shall return, with haste,
To savor more, of this Indian feast."

"Hark, my friends, I shall regale thee with tales of yore,
Of poker rooms and shifts galore.
'Tis the Bellagio, where I doth play,
Six times a year, by the light of day.

Now, listen well, for I have observed,
The morning shift, 'tis truly deserving.
Calvin, the manager, doth rule with grace,
And all the staff, they doth embrace,
Their duties with glee, and a smile so bright,
They doth make the game, a pure delight.

But alas, my friends, the evening shift,
Doth falter, and doth not lift.
The young ones, at the front, they doth seem,
So full of themselves, and their dreams.
They doth take their time, to start the game,
And doth show little care, for those who came.

But fear not, for there be some, who doth shine,
Old Timmy, he doth stand out, so divine.
And the 2 to 10 crew, they doth bring,
Joy to the table, with their pleasant ring.

The problem lies, within the staff,
Who doth instruct, the customers, so gruff.
For naught but woe, can come from such ways,
And doth leave a sour taste, in the end of days."

"Fair maidens, with colors bold and bright,
Topmost unique, to make thee stand in sight.
Prices fair, and jewels of funky delight,
Classic pieces too, like black Fall's jacket so fine,
A worthy addition to thy wardrobe, under $100 doth shine.

Friendly lasses tend the shop with cheer,
A sale section in the back, for thrifty gleaners to appear.
Summer finds of note, for ladies to acquire,
Go forth and fetch them, ere they do expire."

"Hark! We've dined at LaVecchia's oft,
And found it to be quite the spot.
Parking's easy, and free, by the way,
In the Hearst tower, a convenient stay.
The walk down's pleasant, the atmosphere grand,
With businessfolk and upscale patrons at hand.
RiRa, Luce, and a courtyard so fair,
Make the location quite elegant, beyond compare.
Reservations? They're easy to keep,
For we've been seated, while others did sleep.
The wait staff's prompt, and attentive,
Our drinks arrive swiftly, without a fuss or a fret.
Appetizers, a tad too salty, I confess,
But main courses, oh! They're truly divine, no less.
We've returned often, despite other choices galore,
For LaVecchia's charm, we can't help but adore."

"Alas, I didst miss the special of two ninety-nine, yet my craving for their breakfast burritos doth persist. Methinks 'tis time to give them another chance, forsooth. Mayhap now shall be the hour when I do partake of their culinary delights once more. Verily, I do wish their salsa were thicker and had a greater fiery essence, with less of that tangy vinegar flavor."

"Rainy day, clouds thick as fog. No use cravin' frozen yogurt, but we stopped by anyways. Got the snickerdoodle and peanut butter, Andes mints on top. Yogurt was good, not too thick or watery. Place had a cheesy vibe, but plenty of seats. Liked that they posted calories on the wall, even if it was a bit tacky. Friendly service, clean joint. Be back next time I'm around."

"Methinks my love and I didst partake of Chili Cheese Dogs most fair,
A culinary delight that doth please our taste buds beyond compare.
The hot dog, cooked to perfection, didst snap most satisfyingly,
When bitten into, its juices didst flow forth like a bounteous spring.
The chili, rich and savory, didst complement the dog most finely,
In perfect proportion, so one might devour it with ease,
And yet, methinks, a change I wouldst make, anon,
To shredded cheese, more fitting, than Kraft singles, alone.
But still, most delectable, this snack, upon the strip, didst shine."

"No car, so I'm stuck with County Market. Decent selection, but sometimes they're out of stuff. Like at the start of the school year, you know? People must've been stocking up on essentials. But the other day, they only had one kind of tofu. My friend said it wasn't the best. Not a big deal, really. Just a minor gripe. \n\nThing I don't love about County Market is their produce. It's often close to rotting or already there. Or I'll get bananas that are way too green. Can't eat 'em for a week. Don't mind sifting through the fruit and veggies, but when there's nothing good...that's a bummer. Generally, I like the place. I'll keep going back."

In sooth, I chanced upon this coffeehouse,
To taste their brew, and see if 'twere a prize.
The flavor was familiar, and I did ask,
If they roasted their own beans, or didst task
Somewhere in Canada, for such fine fare.
The barista replied, with a smile so fair,
That the beans were from 49th Parallel, in Van.
Ah, Vancourites, if ye seek coffee divine,
This place doth serve it well, and worth thy time.

I also ordered a scone, of which I did partake,
And found it most delicious, with nary a mistake.
The shop itself, though small, doth have its charm,
But the people-watching, alas, doth leave much to disarm.
Unless, perchance, some event doth take place,
At the convention center, with folk in abundance.

The staff, I must say, were most courteous and kind,
A pleasant experience, for all mankind.

"Fresh catch, daily. Shucked oysters, watering hole, cold brews, and fine wines. Fresh meat, seafood, salads - all delicious. Hang out, watch people, enjoy a drink. Friendly staff, top-notch market, and a damn bar too."

"Six of us hit the Monte Carlo for a Saturday night steak dinner. Two-for-one drinks and a prime table made up for the lackluster atmosphere - too bad it's in plain sight of the casino floor. But hey, it's Vegas, right?\n\nThe steak? Top-notch. A 120-oz monster for six, cooked to perfection. Sides and sauces were top-notch too. Friendly, attentive staff made the experience even better. They even hooked us up with free entry into the Brand's "after hours" lounge. Not exactly a hotspot, but hey, it's Vegas, baby! Bottom line: Great steakhouse, subpar nightclub. Only in Vegas."

"In truth, the visit was not so bad, my friend. For just $35, I did receive a standard manicure and pedicure, a most excellent deal indeed. They did offer an upgrade to gel, but nary did they pressure me to accept it, praise the heavens! The staff were quite efficient, though some might say their manner was brusque, perhaps due to a language barrier, alack! But lo, the entrance doth present a problem, for the fumes that doth emanate from within are quite strong, and may offend those of delicate sensibilities or certain... conditions. Moreover, a dedicated cashier would be most welcome, methinks. Yet still, this place doth provide a decent service at a reasonable price, and that is no small thing."

"Arena built like a champ. Steep stands, luxury boxes, club areas - prime spot for hockey. Loud, intimidating, perfect for noise. Music hall conversion? Impressive. Too bad about the location though. Glendale? More like Snoozeville. Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, this eatery doth serve most wondrous victuals, by my troth! Alas, the seating space, alack, doth suffer from dearth, should the outdoor patio remain unopened. Fear not, fair patron, for 'tis a brief delay, and worth the wait, anon! For within, they do prepare most delectable comestibles, both vegan and vegetarian, with flavors so divine! Their pho, a brothy delight, doth warm the cockles of mine heart, and their fresh rolls, crunchy and savory, doth leave me in raptures! By my honor, I shall return anon, to partake in their culinary delights once more!"

"Trump hotel delivered. Friendly staff from the get-go. Room was spotless, plenty of space. Shower, huge. 

Minus one star for too-firm pillows and early morning train horns, but neither ruined the stay. 

Pool, nice, but grab a lounger early. 

Skipped the restaurants, but coffee stand muffins and fruit, top-notch. 

No casino, no problem. Lobby stayed quiet, smoke-free. Would go back."

"In this fair spot, a branch of yonder famed pancake house doth lie,
Less thronged with people, tucked away from prying eyes.
The staff, kind, swift and skilled in their art, doth serve with grace,
And parking, plentiful, a boon to those who seek a space.
Their victuals, of high quality, doth please the taste,
As witnessed by the many fans who sing their praise.
Try what thou wilt, for naught but joy doth come from such a feast.
A crimson sign, aglow, doth mark the entrance, midway down the row."

"Methinks 'tis a fair and lovely inn,
Where travelers may find rest and solace within.
But lo, a bakery doth reside here also,
Owned by none other than Carlos, he of the culinary show.
Ay, 'tis true, good sirs and madams,
That his sweet delights do draw a crowd,
And thou must prepare thyself to wait,
For nigh an hour or more, ere thou dost partake.
But fear not, for 'tis worth the while,
To taste his confections, so divine and worthwhile."

"Till 9:30, this joint stays open. In a town that never sleeps, that's saying something. And let me tell you, the grub is top-notch. For 7.95, you get a full meal, including a drink and an egg roll. If they delivered to UNLV, it'd be a five-star affair."

"Hark, good sir! What doth mine eyes perceive? A meal most fair and worthy of my purse! 'Tis not the dos gringos of yore, but now, 'tis called Rocky Point Cantina, a name most fitting for this fine establishment. Verily, I didst enjoy the fare, with tacos and coronas at a price most reasonable, a mere $2! The interior, a sight to behold, didst impress me with its grandeur and finesse. In sooth, a place most excellent for a repast most satisfying!"

"Hark! What eatery is this, that doth arouse
My taste buds thus? 'Tis Spinelli's, by the name,
A place of wonder, where culinary joys abound.
The cheese steak, oh so fine, doth make me swoon,
With peppers, onions, ratioed to perfection,
And bread, soft as a cloud, with crunchy outer layer.
The pizza, fresh and hand-tossed, doth fill me up,
A satisfying meal, with nary a drop of ale,
For now, alas! But soon, 'twill be available,
To quench my thirst and complement the feast.
Beyond the main course, there's more to explore,
Appetizers, salads, desserts, and Stromboli galore.
So, gentle friends, let us give thanks for this find,
Authentic, relaxing, and free from pretenses,
A true delight, that doth warm the cockles of mine heart,
And maketh me exclaim, in loudest voice, 'Enjoy, my friends, enjoy!'"
"Marry, what a wondrous place! Neat, fair-priced, good service, delectable victuals - by my troth, 'tis a feast fit for a king!"

"By fortune's grace, I chanced upon Linda's door,
In search of a nail technician, as I did adore.
Her skills, I soon discovered, were quite divine,
And her warmth, a welcome solace, like a sweet shrine.

With ease, we conversed, our spirits did entwine,
As she worked her magic, my nails did shine.
Her touch, a gentle caress, left me feeling fine,
And her passion for beauty, did my heart enshrine.

Since March, I've returned, her talents to employ,
For gel, acrylic, manis, pedis, and more, enjoy.
A massage, too, she gives, with such grace,
Leaving me in bliss, within her peaceful space."

"Outside Inn, just another joint in the hood, but the name got my attention. Wooden decor, exposed beams, rustic feel. Bar area dark, TVs too small. Dining area small, vinyl seats, needed more wood. Food though, nice surprise. Sweet potato fries, prime rib, better than most. Prices fair, draft beer selection vast, but a bit steep. Service quick, friendly. A good spot for a cold one and some prime rib. I'll be back."

"Methought I didst partake of a delectable confection,
A slice of red velvet cake, most fair and fine.
The frosting, rich and creamy, doth delight,
With a buttery finish, and a tang of cream cheese divine.

The cake, alas, didst lack a certain moisture,
But fear not, for the frosting didst make amends,
In copious quantity, it didst allure,
And saved the day, with its sweet, sweet essence.

The establishment, a trendy spot, indeed,
With prices that didst rival those of New York's finest.
Yet, the staff, most friendly and obliging,
Didst make our visit a pleasant, enjoyable experience."

"Moscow mule, thou art the drink most divine,
In this establishment, all else doth pale.
A jukebox with issues, beer selection fine,
But naught compared to thy refreshing gale.

Food, decent, yet not worth a second glance,
But thee, oh moscow mule, my heart doth dance.
Cucumber vodka, mint-infused, a treat,
Bartenders, kind and skilled, a joy to meet.

So here's to thee, dear moscow mule, my friend,
May our acquaintance never end.
For in this place, thou art the star that shines,
And in my heart, forever thou shalt be divine."

"Methinks 'tis wise to steer clear of the first reviewer's wares, my friend, 
When seeking lodging, pass them by, and thus it ends. 
For though they proffer transport from the aerodrome, 
The cost, I fear, may be quite beyond your means, my lord. 
Prepayment, they demand, ere you set foot inside, 
And should the driver ask for more, thou art denied. 
Look for signs that say "Airport Shuttles" or such, 
And choose the one that doth accept thy payment, by Jove! 
Two companies there be, my good sir, take heed, 
One taketh cash alone, the other, credit doth need. 
I chose the latter, for I had not a coin, 
And thus, my friend, I couldst pay with ease, and no strain. 
Use these shuttles, good sir, for they are cheap, 
But six silver pieces, per person, doth it keep. 
A cab, it doth cost more, so heed my words, my friend, 
And save thy pence, by choosing thus, an end."

"Maryland, my home of twenty winters,
Where steamed crab legs doth beckon,
A feast most wondrous, and my heart doth sing,
Of joys and delights, naught but wonder bring.

This place, so fair, doth hold my heart,
Despite some reviews, which doth depart,
From truth, for here, all doth excel,
In service, speed, and portion, all doth tell.

Elyse, our waitress, kind and fair,
Doth guide us well, with recommendations rare,
The Bloody Mary, a drink divine,
With crab leg garnish, doth make it shine.

The service, swift, doth please mine eyes,
And though the crowd, doth thinly disguise,
The quality, which doth never fade,
In quantity, and taste, all doth persuade.

My family, in joy, doth feast and cheer,
And here, we shall return, year after year."

"Chicken ain't fried? You sure? Yeah, that's what I asked the cashier 'cause it was crispy, juicy, and looked and tasted like fried chicken. But it was broasted, whatever that means. To me, it means secretly fried chicken that's better for you than the real deal. And they got malts, shakes, a self-serve yogurt bar, sandwiches, and the famous Dole whip. If you're into that sorta thing. Personally, I like takin' a day trip to Boulder City, enjoyin' the scenery. But if that ain't your thing, this place is on the outskirts, no need to go into town. They got a drive-thru too, but be patient, they cook everythin' fresh to order. Worth the wait, trust me. It's a small hole in the wall, used to be a shack across the street, now it's a full buildin'. They must be doin' somethin' right. BC's got a lot of hidden gems, don't skip this one, you'll regret it."

"Hark! 'Tis a Chipotle, my dear friend,
Where thou shalt find what thou dost expect, anon.
The younglings love it, and wifie too,
For she can eat healthy, as she doth choose.

I do confess, I hold not Chipotle high,
As Mexican fare, it doth not satisfy.
But for what they serve, 'tis quite tasty, indeed,
Their chips and guacamole, most excellent, I swear.
And their pork, oh so juicy and fine,
A feast fit for a king, or so it doth seem.

Beware, my friend, when they dole out the meat,
For oftentimes, they may be stingy, indeed.
Especially when the line doth stretch and grow,
Then may their portions be scant, I do foresee.
So watch closely, lest thou be left unsatisfied,
And may thy meal at Chipotle be truly divine."

"Disneyland got nothing on this joint. Walked in, saw fish tanks, waterfalls, and fake animals that looked real as hell. Spent two hours gawking. Lady at the fudge stand, though, she wasn't having a good day. Fudge was still damn good, though. Place is too rich for my blood, but I'll be back for more trinkets."

"Troon North doth boast a Pinnacle course most fair,
A true delight for golfers of great skill and care.
The Monument course, though pleasant, doth not compare,
Inspiration lacking, yet still a round most rare.

The greens and fairways, in good condition they be,
But not so perfect, as one might hope to see.
Pro shop's wares, a fine selection, doth abound,
For those who seek to purchase golf's finest gear, profound."

"Verily, once found, I doth cleave unto it fast,
This place, in sooth, hath won my heart at last.
A year, or more, hath passed since first I came,
And still, my nails, they doth proclaim their fame.
The staff, so kind, doth know me by my name,
And asketh of my life, with interest, trow?
Their gentle touch, doth make me feel so fine,
A true delight, their ministrations divine.
My next visit, I do eagerly await,
For their expertise, doth make my spirit bright."

"By fortune's grace, I chanced upon a dwelling near to all my heart's desire, including a ski and ride shop of renown, Ski Pro, whose wares rival those of Colorado's finest. Sales abound, with prices fair and low, as if the fates themselves didst conspire to bring me joy. A ski suit for my young one, once priced at $175, now cost but $59, a veritable steal! Their stock of skis and boards doth impress, though for me, 'tis but a rare purchase. The staff, while not overly friendly, doth serve with adequate care, unburdened by excessive cheer or expectation. So, visit Ski Pro, and let not the service deter thee, good sir."

"Never had a bad meal here. Ground beef hummus, best I've had. Coconut shrimp, outstanding. Only issue, they closed at 9:30, we got there at 8:30. Staff sat down to eat in front of customers. Waitress was nice, but felt a bit unprofessional. Despite that, service was good, food was excellent. Definitely recommend."

"Hark! If fortune didst grant me but one chance,
To savour either coffee or chocolate in a dance,
I'd choose the latter, from Courier Cafe,
A place of yore, with aged charm, so quaint and gay.
The carpet, old; the waitresses, older still,
Yet their smiles, though wrinkled, warmth doth instil.
And silverware, tarnished, yet doth shine,
In this, a haven for a hearty milkshake divine.
Thick, creamy, and in a metal cup o'erflowing,
On winter's coldest days, my steps doth it draw.
For any true devotee of milkshakes, 'twould be so,
To seek out Courier Cafe, where memories grow."

"This joint's alright. Not some fancy 5-star spot, but it's got its charm. They use quality meat, and you can customize your burger how you like. It's not too pricey either. Atmosphere's decent, good tunes playing most of the time. Had a minor setback with a Morrissey song, but I ignored it. Not a bad option for a casual dinner. I'd go for the 2/3 burger and add my own toppings."

"Methought the name of this eatery didst seem gimmick-like, yet now I do confess, 'tis one of the finest places in all Phoenix to partake of Pho. My doubts were laid to rest, for the broth and noodles didst please mine taste. The bustling crowd within didst make the service swift, yet I didst not mind, for I didst crave but a quick repast. I shall return anon, to sample more of their delectable dishes."

"Tuscany, one of Vegas' newer courses, offers a unique experience. The clubhouse, once a quonset hut, now boasts a beautiful building and restaurant. Rhodes Ranch, the "sister" course, often offers package deals. The layout features sand traps and water hazards, challenging my drives. The course winds past a stone clocktower, with spacious fairways. The theme, centered around wine and vineyards, adds to its charm. For the price, it's an excellent choice. A bit of a drive from Summerlin, but worth it."

"Trifecta's been good to me. Been there a few times, always found something worth looking at. Staff's friendly, too. They got stuff for sale that's not too pricey, you know? Not like some galleries where it's all outta my league. 

Saw some Nevada photography last time I was there. Guy named Anthony M., he's a friend of mine, had some of his work displayed. Support my buddies, that's what I do. 

Place might be small, but they know how to throw a party. Food and drinks, they got it covered. 

Take a stroll down to the Arts Factory, check out Trifecta. Don't be a culture snob, just look around and see what catches your eye. Something's always cookin'."

"Tis a bustling terrace, full to the brim,
Arrive betimes, lest thou be left in the whim.
A worthy queue, for the victuals they bear,
A new sandwich, "porchetta", doth please thee well,
Like Mama's cooking, it doth warm the heart,
And dogs, they too, shall find a welcome part.
Aye, water for thy furry friend, 'tis a sight,
To see them lap it up, with joy and delight."

"Methinks I've visited Chandelier a fair few times, 'tis a wondrous place indeed. Do thou ascend to the second level, betwixt and between, and seek the Lemon Verbena, a potion not upon the menu. Pay a small fee more, and receive a plethora of blooms for all in thy company. Thou shalt chew the flower, but swallow it not, and lo, it shall create a most curious foaming effect within thy mouth, a tiny fountain that doth last for many a minute. My dearest swain didst present me with such a flower, and in return, I didst strike him, but later, in the land of Cosmo, with a group of five, I didst repay the favor, and verily, 'twas most amusing to behold the countenances of my companions. Aye, and worth the twenty-three silver pence I didst spend for the draught and additional blossoms. Chandelier, a place of merriment and revelry, doth thrive, even in the wee hours of morn, but alack, a single star doth dwindle, for once, a draught most vile didst they prepare for me, and, alas, the barkeepers themselves, ofttimes doth display a haughty demeanor, particularly towards womenfolk."
"Atmosphere top-notch. Menu, impressive. Service, spot on. Beer selection, vast. Parking, a pain. Social House, loud. Go for grub, drinks, and crowd. TVs abound for sports fans."

"Crab cakes, best I've had. Breaded just enough to hold shape. Crab, fresh and flavorful. Not drowned in sauce. Fourth time in two months. Consistently impressed. Friendly service, too. Noise level, high. Eat, pay, leave. That's their style."

"Methinks 'twas a wondrous feast we didst partake,
The spices, they didst make each dish most fair and bright.
We chanced upon this place, quite late in the night,
Yet still, they didst serve us with great cheer and light.

The waiters, friendly and attentive, didst give
Good counsel when we didst ask, their words didst live.
I, a humble dish of beef and potatoes didst choose,
With a dipping sauce, so spicy, it didst unclose
My taste buds, and I didst pour it o'er my meat,
In joy, I didst exclaim, a four-star treat!

My husband, alas, didst not share my delight,
He didst give but three stars, in his sight not bright.
But I, in my heart, didst know 'twas a four-star night."

"Great spot for grub and brews. Shuffleboard's a blast too. Mac and cheese with ghost pepper cheese, plus broccoli salad, can't be beat. Only gripe's the singer outside on Tuesday. Not that she was bad, enjoyed the band. Just, her outfit didn't fit the family joint vibe."

"Pirates game sold out, so Bill and I hit the Tilted Kilt instead. Nice spot, lots of TVs, cute waitresses. Food was good, not great. I had a big fried chicken salad with crisp romaine and decent dressing, but they put mandarin oranges in it, which wasn't my thing. Bill liked his Irish Stew though. Would go back, but it's a bit pricey."

"Hark! If thou desirest to dine on healthful fare,
Keep moving, for 'tis the key to vitality.
And mark my words, this Southern comfort brew,
Did please mine taste buds, most heartily.
The staff, they did endure, with patience true,
Two members of our group, who did engage,
In water fray, midst their meal, anon.
A merry sight, it was, to behold, I swear."

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have found a place most wondrous,
Near to my work, a haven, a delight,
Where sushi doth abound, both fresh and bright.

Oh, how I wish, with all my heart's desire,
To dine there daily, without fail or fire,
But alas, my purse doth not allow,
Such luxury, such splendor, to unfold.

Yet still, I've had their all-you-can-eat feast,
For twenty pieces of silver, a fair price, indeed,
And three rolls, oh so delectable and sweet,
Did fill my belly, with joy and delight.

Aye, 'tis a bargain, beyond compare,
For each roll, on its own, doth cost,
Some nine or fourteen silver pence,
A fortune, indeed, for those who dance.

But wait, dear friend, for there's more to tell,
The fruit, a gift, a token, doth make us feel,
Special, indeed, and valued, beyond measure,
In this place, where we find our pleasure.

So, gentle reader, heed my words,
And visit this place, where joys are poured,
For thou shalt find, in this house of sushi,
A feast, fit for a king, or a fairy."

"I was grinning ear to ear, relieved to escape the cold. But it wasn't just that. The Yelp reviews had me expecting a crackhouse, employees who couldn't speak English, filth, and a stench that could knock you out. Instead, I found a typical Asian grocery, like Chicago Food Corp. or Brwyn Mawr Fresh Market. It was a pleasant surprise, to say the least. I couldn't help but laugh at the absurdity of it all as I checked out. Don't let those reviews fool you. It may not be the fanciest place, but it's got a nice Asian stank going on. Sure, there are downsides - cash and check only, cramped space, and a bit of dust. But hey, they've got all the essentials for your stinky Asian dishes, including nuoc mam, chili oil, and fresh lemongrass. And don't forget about the cool sweets they have too."

"Amidst the thrift shops, where superlatives seldom roam,
This ancient charity shop in Scotland doth make its home.
Impressive indeed, with donated tomes galore,
Beside the common fare, that doth adorn its floor.

Classics like Catch 22 and Great Expectations,
And Goosebumps, oh so many, at prices most humble.
A treasure trove for bookworms, young and old,
In this venerable shop, where stories unfold."

"A to-go order I did place, and yonder loopy lass didst take it in hand. Alas, poor service didst she provide, for she didst royally botch the deed. Yet, forth came the manager, swift as lightning, bearing my correct repast. And, generous soul, he didst suffer me to keep the victuals she had given in error. Moreover, he didst proffer to rebate the whole meal, upon mine own credit card, in sooth! Great service, indeed, doth this establishment boast!"

Thus, while toiling at Shirts and Things,
We'd oft order lunch from yonder place,
And I, in sooth, didst always choose
The bread bowl soup, with half potato, half broccoli and cheese,
A wondrous mix, indeed! The bread, itself,
Was also good, and I didst often crave
The Gobbler, too, a dish most fair,
With turkey, cranberry sauce, and stuffing on marble rye,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed.

But, alack, the prices were a bit steep,
For seven silver coins, a soup or sandwich did cost,
A sum that didst make my purse weep.
Yet, still, the delivery was swift,
A virtue, indeed, and worth a lift.

"Late night, we stumbled upon this joint after dumpin' our bags in our room at the Venetian. Similar to Cheesecake, but turns out they're connected. No wait for brekkie, so we hit it up again before leavin' town."

"Marry, what excellent customer service doth this establishment provide! The staff, with their gentle demeanor and helpful nature, doth make one feel most welcome. The premises, too, are tidy and well-kept, a true delight to behold. And the lady who tended to mine eyebrows, I do suspect she is the owner, for her skill and precision in her craft are most impressive. Alas, my recent visit for a pedicure didst leave me feeling somewhat hastened, and the foot scrub, I must confess, didst not quite meet mine expectations. Yet, despite this minor setback, I wouldst still recommend this place to any who seeketh a pleasant and satisfying experience."

"Hark! This feast was most delectable, my friends. Our group, four in number, didst dine here on a whim, our hunger sated by the bounty of the menu. 'Twas a wise decision, indeed, for the victuals served in generous portions, and the flavors didst delight our taste buds. The lo mien and orange fowl, in particular, didst earn our praise. 

The ambiance, merry and romantic, didst add to our enjoyment. A request, we made, for a table removed from the entrance, that the din of the food court might not disturb our revelry. 

And, behold! The ale, though not listed on the drink menu, didst prove a most affordable choice. After overspending on draughts by the pool, these thirty-six ounce steins, priced at twelve silverlings, didst bring us great cheer. 

Verily, this establishment doth merit a visit, shouldst thou find thyself in need of sustenance and good cheer."

"Wendy's Noodle Cafe, my new go-to spot. Great service, clean flavors, big menu. Everything we ordered, spectacular. Friendly service, sealed the deal. 

Pot Stickers, perfect crisp, delicious pork/scallion stuffing. Best in Las Vegas. 

Beef Short Ribs, Wendy's take on Kalbi. Nice sear, not dry. Good, but not as good as Korean spots. 

Shredded Chicken w/ Vermicelli, delicious combo of cilantro, kaffir lime, and chili. Like mom's chicken noodle soup, but with a passport. 

Malaysian Fried Rice, served with chicken wings and squid balls. Rice, subtle garlic, onion, turmeric, and lime. Moist, not mushy, wholesome. Chicken wings, good, not great. Squid balls, forgettable. Rice, definite order. 

Tastebuds, get your passport ready. Time to see the world."

In sooth, my taste buds didst dance with glee,
As I didst partake of pancakes most fine and free.
Atop a mountain of fluffy, golden delight,
Didst lay a feast fit for a king, a true sight.

Alas, my dear companion, the corned beef hash,
Didst fail to impress, its flavor rather rash.
But fear not, dear reader, for the atmosphere,
Didst make up for the lackluster dish, most fair.

Aged casino, downtown, with charm and grace,
Didst host this breakfast spot, a wondrous place.
And though the coffee, institutional it may be,
With cream and sugar, 'twas palatable to me.

Oh, pie case, how thou didst tempt me so,
With sweet and savory treats, a true show.
I shall return, and sample thy delights,
For breakfast, a true feast, a wondrous sight.

Now, parking, a problem, it may seem,
But fear not, for solutions, there be a scheme.
Valet lot, a option, most convenient,
With validation, a bargain, most lenient.

So, gentle reader, take heed of my words,
And visit this spot, where pancakes are the birds.

Hark! What news is this? A day of cheesecake, they say?
And lo, I did partake in such a fray.
My stomach, full of sweet and creamy delight,
Did protest, yet my taste buds took flight.

The Godiva chocolate, a treat most divine,
Did make my senses dance with joy and fine.
If thou art a fan of chocolate, do tell,
This cake, it doth await thee, and all shall be well.

The staff, so friendly, prompt, and kind,
Did make our visit most enjoyable, I find.
I shall return anon, for more of this delight,
Good job, fair cheesecake makers, good night!

"Hark, a Groupon I did purchase for this place,
A full exam, x-rays, whitening trays, and cleaning, what grace!
The office staff, cheerful and sweet, did greet me,
In their pretty big and nice office, a pleasantry.

Lots of magazines and TVs, a waiting room of delight,
But alas, they told me, my cleaning and trays, another night.
A little vexed, yet these things do happen, I reckon,
So I returned the following week, my heart still a-flutter.

The office, not so busy, peaceful and serene,
The staff, awesome, the woman who cleaned, supreme.
I felt relaxed, my teeth and gums, jabbed with care,
My smile, now bright, my teeth, whiter than snow there.

Another woman, bubbly and kind, took me back,
Did the impressions for my whitening tray, no lack.
All in all, this place, I do highly recommend,
Returning next week, a cavity to mend."
"United, my go-to airline. Consistent, on time, and friendly. Never lost my luggage. Southwest, once. Delta, a disaster. Three weeks. Four stars, easy."

"Whenever I hanker for my gram's grub, I snag a bite from Rose Tea. Their beef pancake roll and rice cakes are top-notch. And let me tell you, their menu's a winner. Can't go wrong with any of it. And their bubble tea? Best in the 'Burgh."

"We hit this joint in Vegas with a crew of eight. Service was top-notch, attentive and friendly. I went for the chicken kiev, crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. Had a cranberry cabbage salad with it, which was a bit bland for my taste. Would've preferred the red cabbage the others had.

Pork was a bit dry, but the steak was solid. Got the mashed potatoes instead of fries, but wished I'd gone for the fries. They were homemade, flavorful, and delish.

Had the cabbage rolls, herring, and veggie plate. Cabbage rolls weren't my thing, but others loved 'em. Herring was fresh and not too oily, glad I took the server's rec. Veggie plate was a work of art, everything fresh. Desserts were great too.

Food was good, service excellent, price reasonable. Only downer was some dude asking one of us for 50 cents on the way out. Unpleasant, won't go into detail, but there's a liquor store in the same plaza and a bunch of folks hanging around outside."
"Clean joint, friendly folk. Played some blackjack, hit the jackpot. Woohoo! Left with a chip to cash in. Be back soon."

"Friday eve, this place did swarm with folk,
Whose mirth did fill each table, 'twas a sight to behold.
The scent of Korea's finest dishes did waft through the air,
And our bellies did rumble, in eager anticipation.

We ordered bulgogi, and tofu soup beside,
The latter did warm us, with its spicy, savory broth.
The former, sizzling, did delight our taste buds,
Though a mite more char, would have been most welcome.

Alas, the sides, a mixed bag they were,
Kimchi, seaweed, and fish cakes, we did adore.
But coleslaw, and other such, did fail to impress,
Yet still, our joy, did not diminish, in the least.

Verily, we would return, anon,
For more of that delectable Korean fare, so fine."

"Hark, my dear friend! In this cosmopolitan place,
We found a restaurant of great renown,
With views most wondrous and a menu grand,
We made our reservation through OpenTable, at hand.

The roasted bone marrow, oh how divine,
Came with shredded pork, a feast most fine,
And the special of the day, a fried pork cutlet,
With eggs and more, a dish most delicate.

But alas, the bone marrow, though rich and bold,
Came with but one bone, a price most cold,
Yet 'twas a feast most satisfying, I must confess,
For the shredded pork, it did make up for the mess.

The pork shank, oh how enormous and grand,
Fell off the bone, a tender morsel in hand,
A special cocktail, with bubbly inside,
A drink most refreshing, our spirits did abide.

Our waitress, kind and swift, knew her craft well,
Her recommendations, we did dare not quell,
She guided us through the menu with grace,
And we, with full bellies, did leave the place.

So if thou art in search of a meal most fine,
In this cosmopolitan town, do dine,
At this restaurant, with views most fair,
And enjoy the feast, without a single care."

"Verily, a feast most wondrous didst I partake,
With wine pairings that didst complement each dish so well.
The service, too, didst excel, with grace and poise.
And, lo! A table nearby, where Madeline Albright didst sit,
With her own decanter of red wine, didst she enjoy.
A sight most curious, to see a stateswoman,
In such convivial spirits, didst make our night most merry.

But, alas! The amuse bouche, a lobster gel,
Didst not taste of the sea, nor freshness didst it reveal.
The waiter didst acknowledge, that many didst complain,
Yet still, they served it forth, with nary a refrain.
Aye, a big swig of wine didst I imbibe,
To wash away the taste, of that strange, foamy concoction.

But, fear not! For the rest of the menu,
Was served with finesse, and tasted most divine.
So, let this be a lesson, to all who doth dine,
To savor each morsel, and quaff each draught with cheer,
For a night most memorable, doth await thee,
At this, thy noble establishment, most dear!"

"Great joint! Filet, medium rare, real tasty. Hubby's medium well, his bad. Asparagus, small, overcooked. Baked potato, perfect. Bread, good variety. French onion, decent, but herbs drowned other flavors. Wine list, nice, but prices, ouch! Miss BYOB. Friendly staff, comfy booth, nice ambiance. Steak, damn good, but pricey at $33."

"A fair pizza indeed, with crust so thin and crispy, it doth please mine taste.  The sauce, with just a hint of spice, doth complement the toppings well.  'Tis a fine choice, should thou find thyself upon the Strip, and not desire to pay exorbitant room service fees for pizza of dubious quality.  Our pizza, delivered to our humble abode, didst arrive with nary an extra charge, brought by a most affable driver."

"Mornin'. Group hungry, lookin' for grub. Capo's caught our eye, but no reservation, no entry. We snuck in, found peace. Atmosphere, chill. Talked to folk, friendly. Fish 'n' chips, happy hour, $2.99. Good eatin'. Bartender, nice. Recommended Italian joint."

"Hark! When travel doth take me far from home,
I seek an Ethiopian restaurant, a place unknown,
In parts of town where businessmen do not roam.
A humble eatery, run by love's sweet bond,
A husband and wife team, welcoming solo guests,
As I, at times, do wander, lonely and lost.

Their food, oh! 'Tis honest, simple, plain,
Meat, veggies, sauces, healthy, wholesome gain,
Good for the body, mind, and soul, no doubt.
In Tempe, Lalibela, a shining light,
A mom-and-pop shop, serving Ethiopian delight.

Gather friends and kin, and share a platter,
Sampling all their flavors, a true matter,
Eaten with hands, not forks or knives, a sign,
Of community, love, and joy divine.
And teas, oh! Sip them, sweet and fine."

"This park's a real treat for the little ones. My two-year-old can't get enough of those sick slides built into the hill. And let me tell you, the playground gear is top-notch. When it's hot out, the water features keep him busy for hours. Henderson's got some great parks, but this one's definitely a standout. 4 stars, no question."

"Hark, I didst order from yonder menu,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed.
A salad, chopped and fresh, with fruits galore,
And creamy goat cheese, a taste most divine.
The dressing, too, didst complement the dish,
A perfect blend, a culinary delight.
I vowed, nay, swore, to have it every day,
Such joy it brought, such happiness didst stay.

But lo, the muffin, oh so sweet and fine,
With pistachio and date, a flavorful combine.
It pleased my palate, and my senses, too,
A treat most wondrous, a culinary cue.
But alas, the cost, a sum quite steep,
A price too high, for one who doth not keep.
Yet still, the food, a delight to consume,
A verdict, thus, a mixed review, perchance to assume."

"Hark, fair maiden, as thou stroll'st down yonder hall,
A scent most wondrous doth assail thy nostrils all.
A place of gastronomic joy, where ne'er a bite
Hath failed to please my taste buds, nor left me quite.

I pray thee, gentle sir, to seek a table nigh
The patio's edge, where fountains dance and play.
A feast for thine eyes, as well as for thy belly,
And should thou seek a spot to pop the question, 'twill be
A most romantic setting, fit for royalty."

"If thou art seeking merriment and cheer,
And bring a group of friends who've never been here,
This place doth offer drinks and victuals fine,
In atmosphere and staff, it doth shine.
Located in the heart of Tempe's college ground,
It teems with people, laughter, and lively sound.
Beware the doormen, rough and stern of mien,
Lest they deny thee entry, in their zeal to keep the scene clean.
And should thou manage entrance, take a peek,
Upstairs, where spirits roam, and secrets shroud the meek."

"Boba Tea House, my go-to spot for a sweet fix. Wide variety of flavors, lychee snow with boba, my fave. Been impressed every time, but not exactly a place for an old man like me to linger. Young crowd, but I don't let that stop me. I'll keep going for my boba needs."

"Methinks my comrades and I didst chance upon a wondrous sight,
Within the hallowed halls of MGM Grand, a place most bright.
A pie, so fine and unique, didst catch our eager eyes,
And for a paltry sum, our bellies didst soon become surprise.

Oh, how we didst revel in our culinary delight,
Our mirth and joy, didst know no bounds, 'twas a wondrous sight.
The crust, so thin and crispy, didst complement the toppings well,
And for a mere 12 coins, our tummies didst swell.

Verily, a great find indeed, my friends, let it be told,
For in this city of excess, a gem, so rare, doth unfold.
So, haste thee well, and seek out this tasty treat,
Lest thou dost miss the chance, to partake of this sweet."

"Wedding reception at Bentley Projects. Unexpected, stylish joint. Just what we wanted. Gallery's huge, beautiful at night. Perfect lighting, original art pieces. Contemporary stuff, artists from all over. Can't afford 'em, pretty pricey. Maybe someday. Bookstore's gone, but City Bakery's still kickin'. Great spot for lunch, then hit the gallery for the exhibit. Open late for First Fridays."

"Methinks 'tis a feast most wondrous and fair,
This buffet, whereon we didst first repair.
The seafood, oh how it didst delight,
King Alaskan Crab, already cracked in sight.
Aye, 'twas the best dish, I do declare,
I had three plates, and still didst crave more.
Crab cakes, salmon, chicken, lamb, and shiskabobs,
Hummus and pita, dolmas, sushi, won tons,
Dim sum, and two plates of sweet dessert,
Chocolate-covered strawberries, my heart's dear.
The steak, alas, my love, didst not impress,
But still, I would return, with greater zeal.
Our bellies full, we didst seek Planet Hollywood,
A strawberry daquiri, huge and quite foul.
Yet still, my hunger didst not abate,
For I didst eat like a horse, most elate."

"Alas, our Sunday night plans didst falter,
And we found ourselves in need of a savior.
RA's reverse happy hour didst come to the rescue,
With tunes that didst set our spirits free.

The bar didst transform into the Flying Fish Lounge,
A DJ didst take his place, and the beats didst flow.
Though the music didst not stir the soul,
It didst add a touch of fun to the evening's glow.

Drinks and food at RA didst come at a steep price,
But for happy hour, we didst not have to think twice.
Rolls of all kinds didst fill our bellies with delight,
And hot sake didst warm our souls on that cold winter's night.

I didst order two rolls, the Toosty Maki being one,
And an Albacore appetizer that didst please my taste buds.
My love didst indulge in a sweet treat,
A tempura-fried ice cream roll, smothered in chocolate, oh so neat.

Oh RA, thou art a chain, but we are grateful for thy presence,
For thou didst save our evening from utter disaster and pretence."

"This spot, hidden from prying eyes, doth hold a treasure within. Aye, 'tis a challenge to find, but fear not, for 'tis worth the fray. A link, a brisket, and ribs, all combined, doth make a feast most fair and fine. So, gentle friends, take heed of this rhyme, and seek out this place, for 'twill be worth thy time."

"Pool's great. Big, too. Even with a crowd, it don't feel cramped. Drinks? Expensive as hell. But hey, only paid for one, so that's something. Guy at the door, James, was top-notch. Not some jerk like you usually get. All in all, this place is worth it if you're lookin' for a good time in Vegas."

"Fresh grub, quick service. Friendly staff. Typical AYCE sushi rules. Faves include crab roll, 911, Friday 13th v Jason, Spider roll, spiderman, cowgirl, Japanese lasagna. Small joint, might wait for a table in the evening. Service stays top-notch 'cause they can only handle so many at once. Can't snag a table? Order to-go. Freshly made, not like RA's cold, stale sushi."

"Treats didst thou seek, my dear four-year-old? Aye, verily, a place most wondrous, where confections doth abound. Alas, a single table, small and meager, didst impede our feast. The array of sweets, middling at best, didst include red velvet, chocolate, cake of birth, yellow cake, Oreo, German chocolate, and peanut butter cup. All prepared beforehand, alack! Moist, indeed, the cupcakes didst prove, with frosting rich and plentiful. Thou chocolate cake, a tad bitter, yet still, a fair delight. Drinks, none couldst be had, a sorrow, on days of heat. Good, not great, the cupcakes didst seem, yet shall prosper still, by virtue of their site."

"Verily, 'twas quite a spell ere my tire was replaced,
A good hour and a half, to be exact, 'twas well nigh drained.
But lo, the folk who worked there didst strive with all their might,
To mend my wheel with speed, and bring back light to my night.
And when I asked for new tires, the man at the counter didst say,
That a lesser price would buy a better tire, in a manner of play.
So I didst take his word, and saved a pretty penny,
For which I am most grateful, and doth thank him heartily."

"My son, he didst savor the Pechuga ala Plancha,
A dish most wondrous, full of flavor and zest.
My daughter, she didst enjoy her quesadilla,
A treat most satisfying, with cheese so mellow.

The meat in my tacos, 'twas tasty indeed,
But oh, so dry, it made my jaws to ache.
Yet still, my margarita and guacamole,
Didst please my senses, with nary a flaw.

In Madison, twelve years have I dwelt,
And ne'er knew this place, hidden from view.
But now, I shall return, with haste and zeal,
For more of their culinary delight."

"Hark, what wonders lie within this place,
A feast most fair, a taste most grace.
The brisket, oh so full of zest,
Did please my palate with its juicy quest.
The ribs, alas, did not impress,
For they were tough and hard to dress.
I would not recommend this dish,
For 'tis a messy meal, and not so swish.
The Mac and cheese, a creamy delight,
Did fill my belly with its velvet might.
The food, though not hot, did satisfy,
But dear it be, and not so nigh.
Yet still, a filling feast it made,
And for that, I do give thanks and praise."

"Hark! A tale of Pop's, a place to dine,
In Decatur, where the sun doth shine.
A Groupon, it didst present itself,
And thus, we ventured forth, my love and I.

The establishment, outdoors it be,
No indoor seat, for thee to see.
But fear not, for looks can deceive,
For Pop's, it didst serve, a meal most relieve.

Food, made to order, hot and fresh,
Even in the eve, our phillies didst impress.
Cheese, a choice, for those who dare,
Provolone, I chose, with peppers fair.

My love, the same, with onions too,
And fried green beans, in marinara hue.
Portions large, the price, it doth justify,
A place, to visit, ere thou say goodbye.

Again, I wouldst go, to Pop's with glee,
For a meal, most satisfying, 'tis to see."

"I strolled into this joint on a Friday night, fresh from a round of drinks and snacks with the boys. And damn, was I glad I did. There was a spot at the bar, just waiting for me, sandwiched between a local lady with a cycling helmet and a sharp-dressed gent. And let me tell you, I was feeling pretty out of place in my shorts and tee. But hey, that's what being an American on vacation does to you. 

Now, the service here was top-notch. These bartenders knew their stuff, pouring out fine wines and giving us the lowdown on the menu. Classic vibes all around, with the food, service, and atmosphere all on point. 

I went for a glass of red and the duck confit salad. Not usually my thing, but hell, it was worth it. That duck was cooked to perfection, juicy and flavorful, and the greens were fresh as could be. It was like a party in my mouth, with the bitter and sweet notes all in harmony. 

One salad that's definitely worth another visit. But man, there's so much else on the menu that I'm dying to try. This place has got it going on."

"Stoney's ain't no great shakes for grub, but it'll do for tacos and brews during the game. Nighttime's when it really comes alive, though - country line-dancing, baby! But let's keep it real, the food's nothing special, service is meh, and prices are steep. Not my first pick for a sit-down meal, but hey, on a Monday arvo, you might find me clingin' to the bar, chowin' down on cheap eats and knockin' back cold ones."

"I hit up Ichiza for the authentic izakaya vibe, not so much the grub. I lived in Japan, and this place takes me back. It's your typical izakaya fare, nothing special. I reckon most five-star reviews come from folks who haven't tried better. Selection's decent, but I'd prefer a fully Japanese kitchen crew. Their waitstaff's all Japanese, though. \n\nFood's three stars. Staff's five stars, friendly and welcoming. Atmosphere and izakaya feel get four stars. Don't come here expecting a mind-blowing Japanese culinary experience. Come with pals for cold brews, lively chat, and warm service."

In this fair place, we didst enjoy our morning meal,
Warm and cozy, with atmosphere most real.
Great espresso, delectable breakfast dishes,
A \"Biker's Dream\", indeed, it didst surpass.
And, wine and coffee drinks, with alcohol imbued,
What a delightful find, our spirits were cheered.
Next time in Madison, in need of caffeine,
This place shall be, our singular design.
But, alas, they must attend to their floor,
Cleaning or replacing, to make it anew, forsooth.

In fair Las Vegas, where pleasure doth reign,
I chanced upon this lodging, with naught but gain.
A steal of a price, on vegas.com it were found,
For just twenty-nine pieces of silver, per night profound.

Despite the dire warnings of those who had been,
I took the chance, and fortune smiled upon my sin.
The hotel, humble though it be, didst meet my needs,
Cleanliness and parking, both in ample deeds.

At night, the lot doth fill, and spaces dwindle,
But patience shall prevail, and a spot thou shalt find, anon.
The process of checking in and out, doth flow with ease,
A painless transaction, leaving naught but peace.

So if thou seeketh a place to lay thy head,
And fortune doth smile upon thy purse, then tread
Upon this path, and take up residence,
For here, thy stay shall be pleasant, and free from offense.

"Stonecreek's a swell spot for a round, price is right too. Dig the layout, fun without being gimmicky. Scenery's pleasant too. \n\nAgreed on the creek running through, bit of a pain. Staff seemed friendly enough when I visited. Don't know what others are grumbling about. All in all, decent joint for a game, convenient location too."

"Good grub, quick serve, fair price. Hot 'n' sour's got some kick but you can still taste the goods. Family combo's a steal - soup, egg roll, crab puffs, broccoli chicken, Mongolian beef, rice, 'n' leftovers for tomorrow. Fills two folk up just fine."

"Verily, 'tis the finest all-you-can-eat sushi in Las Vegas, good sir! Freshly made rolls doth grace the table, with a most excellent selection to choose from. Swift service doth complement the feast, making it a truly delightful experience. Ah, but the baked mussels and Ahi Poki, they doth steal the show! Worthy of endless consumption, I say! Alas, a five-star rating doth elude them, for the wait didst stretch on far too long. Yet, the wait didst prove worthwhile, for the sushi didst satisfy my hunger and my soul. Mayhap, Sushi Mon shall expand its domain, that more may partake in the joy of its delectable offerings."
"I stepped in for a scoop, happily surprised by the damn good quality. It was amazing, real quick service too."

"Neighborhood tavern, merry and bright,
With big porch, TV's, and corn hole in sight.
Atmosphere festive, spirits high and light,
Trivia on Wednesdays, a most excellent sight.
Beer specials, burgers half-priced, what a delight,
But alas, parking, a bit of a plight.
Still, 'tis a place to gather, laugh and make merry,
For drinks and company, a most happy marriage."

"In days of yore, when youthful vigor pulsed within my veins,  
This place didst hold a special place within my heart.  
Great subs, they didst serve, and soups of finest quality,  
And fries, oh fries, so crispy and divine, a true work of art.  
Sweet potato fries, a novel touch, didst also grace the menu.  
But now, with years of wisdom and experience added to my tale,  
I ponder on the vegetarian options, and find none, alas!  
The charge for refills, a quibble, yet a quibble, nonetheless.  
And all, the fries, the meat, the bread, doth seem to be bathed  
In grease, a curious thing, yet not a deal-breaker, by my reckoning.  
Two banks nearby, a convenience, shouldst thou need to make a withdrawal.  
A decent place, with tasty subs, a haven for the young and bold.  
Three stars and a half, a fair rating, methinks, yet not quite four.  
So, here I shall leave my musings, and bid thee, dear reader, adieu."

"Sushi's my daughter's jam, so we hit this spot often. Been comin' here for years, and it never disappoints. Staff's friendly, grub's solid. Specials are always a pleasant surprise. Quick bites, any time of day."

"Hark! If thou dost enjoy a brisk walk outdoors, and shopping be thy will, then seek thee out this wondrous place they call Town Square. 'Tis a haven for clothiers and specialty shops, with nary a want for entertainment, be it a film at the cinema, ale at a tavern, or victuals at a restaurant. Accessible by expressway or boulevard, parking doth abound, shouldst thou fail to find a spot within the square itself. My own visits to Town Square be for Whole Foods, a veritable cornucopia of comestibles, and occasional sojourns to Texas de Brasil, where grilled meats doth satiate mine appetite. In sooth, 'tis a most excellent venue for gastronomy, imbibing, and retail therapy. Hie thee hence, good sir or madam, and partake in its bounty!"

"Taco Y Taco, always a favorite. Thought it couldn't get better, but the new spot proved me wrong. Better, not different. Same food, same setup, but now with a bar and some flair. Still gotta try the al pastor, but might mix it up next time. Elote, always a must. Wish they'd come to my side of town, but till then, I'll make the drive."

"Arena's convenience doth please, I do confess,
For those who dwell within the hotel's walls, 'Tis nigh.
But chill it doth, and ushers strict, they be,
Forbidding passage to thy seat, save pause, there be.
Why, pray tell, such rigor? 'Tis not stage nor play,
Nor e'er shall mischief maketh thou, the rowdy throng,
Who, munching nachos, doth with passion shout,
And drunkenness doth cloud their wits, alack!
Moreover, lines for privy and victuals, full they be,
A plight most vexing, verily, for thee and me."

"Methinks 'twere burgers most divine,
Combinations strange and wondrous fine.
I ordered Rising Sun, and didst partake
Of my friend's Gold Standard, a burger most great.

Steak fries, fluffy within, crunchy without,
Didst complement the meal, a wondrous bout.
Ale, a fine selection, doth quench thy thirst,
In this place, where all things are of worth.

The cost, not overmuch, for Vegas, a city
Where prices be high, and men do cry.
For burgers and ale, the sum didst amount
To twenty-seven pieces of silver, a fair count."

"O, how I miss Katz's, that humble abode,
Where greasy spoons did soothe my soul,
On early mornings, when the world did nod,
And virtue seemed to be in short control.

But now, 'tis gone, and in its place,
A grand estate, a palace of delight,
Postino's, where curious materials grace,
The walls and roof, a wondrous sight.

Expensive, yes, but worth the cost,
For goat cheese bruschetta, and bubbly toast,
The patio's charm, despite the parking lot,
Valets, who assist, with grace and thought.

So don thy finest garb, and step inside,
